description.en: Innsbruck is the capital of the western province of Austria, Tyrol. It is known as a magnificent ancient city, surrounded by the Alps from different sides. It has long been known for the best ski resorts in Europe, which attract lovers of skis, snowboards, and skates. In turn, ancient Innsbruck has a considerable history, reminiscent of the magnificent palaces, monuments, museums, and exhibition centers. The city has become one of the most popular tourist destinations a long time ago, as it manages to combine the advantages of high-class resorts, the sophistication of imperial architecture, and the freshness of alpine nature.

long_description.en: The beautiful mountain resorts, lush gardens, parks, unique museums, magnificent palaces, and majestic churches — Innsbruck offers its guests many amazing wonders. It is better to make an itinerary of the fascinating places of the ancient capital of Tyrol to get an unforgettable experience.

description.en: Salzburg is a beautiful city as if descended from the pages of a fairy tale. It is located at the northern foot of the Alps on the banks of the Salzach River. Moreover, it is the fourth largest city in Austria. The city attracts travelers from all over the world with stunning mountain scenery, breathtaking history, and unique architecture. Here, buildings in the styles of Gothics, Baroque, and Renaissance are combined with modern architecture and buildings of post-war modernism. The city used to be widely known due to the sale of the purest salt from nearby mines. In turn, nowadays, it is famous throughout the world as the birthplace of the great Mozart — a genius who gave immortal musical masterpieces to mankind.

long_description.en: Salzburg is home to almost 150,000 people. The population can double during the tourist season. It is worth noting that this Austrian city has a large concentration of young people, as Salzburg is home to three major universities.

description.en: Graz is a city in the southeast of Austria, situated at the foot of Mount Schlossberg, washed by the clear waters of the Moore River and engaged to it with seven bridges. This administrative center of the historical land of Styria is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and in 2003, it became the European Capital of Culture. Graz is the red tile on medieval houses' roofs and the place where Arnold Schwarzenegger first began training. A trip to this city will give you the most wonderful experiences, pleasing the eye and soul with a variety of unusual historical and contemporary attractions. Graz makes you fall in love at first sight with a relaxed combination of thousands of years of tradition and modern trends in avant-garde, surrealism, and post-modern architecture. Graz is a great excuse to travel!

At the foot of the Alps, on the bank of the River Danube, stands magnificent Vienna. It is the capital of waltzes, the cultural capital of Europe, the city of inspiration and charm. There are hundreds of definitions for Vienna as it shows its unique face to every new guest. Someone shall see it in the rainbow splashes of the fountains, the other one — in the high spires of the Gothic cathedrals and odd broken lines of houses built by contemporary architects. Just as hundreds of years ago, today, Vienna will amaze you with the splendor of ball gowns and operatic vocal, will treat you to delicious coffee, and astonish with its cooking! Vienna is romantic as a young virgin and, at the same time, pragmatic as a banker. It is business-like and festive. For sure, it shall not leave any of its guests indifferent.

long_description.en: Citizens of the Austrian capital are amicable and friendly. The status of the tourist center of Europe requires lots of commitment. The ethnic composition of Vienna is quite diverse. The Slovaks, Slovenes, Hungarians, Czechs, Croats live here. However, the Germans are still in the majority. After Berlin, Vienna is the second in number city in the world where the majority of citizens speak German.

description.en: Linz is the ancient city of Austria situated on the picturesque banks of the Danube. Simultaneously, it is one of the cultural capitals of the country, where famous writers, composers, and scientists lived and worked. It also attracts tourists with architectural and historical attractions. Linz is expected to impress its visitors with perfectly preserved monuments located on the narrow streets of the Old Town, including Gothic temples, Baroque cathedrals, and the majestic walls of ancient castles. The beauty of the city's architecture is emphasized by magnificent landscapes, lush parks, and squares. In addition, Linz is a perfect place for those who want to get acquainted with real Austria, feel the atmosphere of antiquity, and just relax.

The small Austrian town of Hallstatt is situated in the beautiful Dachstein Mountains. On the one hand, it is surrounded by an emerald lake of the same name, and, on the other hand, it is protected by green mountain slopes. It seems that such a fantastic place in the world does not exist — it is just a flight of fantasy. But when you find yourself here, you realize that this is reality, and you freeze to death from pristine beauty. Hallstatt is straight from the past, where you can still go down to the salt mine, and the church keeps the skulls of local residents, buried by ancient custom. In this city, you don't want to rush anywhere. Time flies without being noticed here, and the clean air and breathtaking views make you silently enjoy the existing Elysium.

long_description.en:
Hallstatt proudly bears the title of the oldest village in Europe. As early as the eighth millennium B.C., there were prehistoric men who mined rock salt in this area. The excavations carried out in 1846 by Johann Ramsauer testify to this. The style and decoration of the items found in the ancient cemetery are very peculiar, because of which the town gave its name to the whole culture (Hallstatt). After the ancient tribes, the Romans came to these lands and continued to work in the salt mines.

Later on, little is known about the history of the city. In 1595, a pipeline was built here, and only by the end of the XIX century was the first road to Hallstatt from Salzburg. The town remained in the shadows for such a long time because of its inaccessibility and difficult location.

The houses here are constructed in 5 tiers because of the acute shortage of space. For the same reason, a special tradition operated in the city until the end of the XX century. It consisted of the fact that local cemetery were excavated every ten years, and the bones of the dead were sent to the chapel. A city artist would paint the skulls with the dates of birth and death and indicate the deceased's occupation. After a few weeks, the remains would be displayed in a special ossuary, and new ones would appear in place of the old burials. Such a custom became obsolete with the advent of cremation. But still, any city dweller could show a desire to be buried according to the old custom.

The modern city is almost no better than its ancient counterpart. It differs only in the presence of cars and crowds of tourists. The stunning architecture with many fine details and the salt mines are only a small part of what it is worth coming here for.

description.en: London is the capital of Great Britain. It’s hard to say anything new about this city: Big Ben and Tower, British Crown and red coats of the guards, telephone booths and doubledeckers, Baker Street and the London Eye, and the Union Jack flag, after all.

long_description.en:
More than 8.6 million people live in London. The thirds part of them are the representatives of the ethnic minorities. The flow of immigrants to London is so high that in such boroughs like Newham and Hillingdon people use more than 100 languages.

The majority of emigrants come from former British colonies. More than 545 thousand of Indians, 99 thousand of Nigerians, 126 thousand of Bangladeshi, 113 thousand of Pakistanis, and 113 thousand of the Irish live in the city.

description.en: York is a charming city in Northern England. According to George VI, this city is the founder of the country’s history. In York, you shall find extant Medieval streets that keep secrets of the Anglo-Saxon kings, Normans, Vikings, and even Romans. Since that ancient times up to the industrial revolution, York had been the second city in England after London. Today, it yields to other industrial cities. However, it’s still on the list of must-visit places for tourists in England. York with its small white houses, streets that are no wider than a chariot, family shops, extraordinary museums, surrounded by castles and Medieval fortresses is an extremely hospitable and safe city. Its central historical part has an unbelievable atmosphere! Since ancient times, this part of the city has been filled with plenty of tea shops, pubs, cafes, and restaurants. Daniel Defoe himself called this place “plenty of great companies and good families”.

long_description.en:
Mainly the Englishmen live in York and compile 94.3% of the population. The majority of the remaining part is the Asians. York is the best choice if you want to live among the Englishmen.

Modern local citizens honor the history of the city and treat it with love. Even nowadays you can come across companies that use the old Roman name “Eboracum” or “Ebor”.

description.en: Edinburgh is the capital and largest city of Scotland and the 7th largest in the United Kingdom. The unique architecture has been preserved here, which gave the Old and New Town the right to receive the World Heritage status and to be under the care of UNESCO. Edinburgh stretches over three hills, between the River Leith and, in addition, to historical monuments, it is impressive with its picturesque nature. Inspiring panoramas, frequent weather changes — Edinburgh's character is stubborn, and it takes a lot of effort to make it like you. However, if you succeed, you won't find a more welcoming and homely city all over Europe.

long_description.en:
According to the latest census, there has been significant growth in Edinburgh. Curiously, the percentage of Britons to visitors in the city is 95% to 5%, while in London, it is 50% to 50%.

The Scots are very friendly and kind. They are happy to help tourists. However, you should remember that English in these areas has a distorted pronunciation and a special dialect, so it is not always possible to immediately understand the local resident.

description.en: Glasgow is not just the largest city in Scotland. It is an interesting history, unique architecture, stunning nature, culture, and traditions that are fascinating and never cease to amaze. Glasgow is often called the most important center of art, as it is here that the best collections of paintings are gathered, which fine art experts from all over the world come to admire. Glasgow is a universal city for tourists, as you can find attractions and entertainment for every taste. Regardless of the preferences, all travelers agree on one thing: you should definitely come here for at least a few days, or better yet for a week!

long_description.en: If we analyze the ethnic composition of Glasgow's population, we can confidently call it the most multicultural city in Scotland. However, the vast majority of local people are Scottish (89.62%). Among national minorities, the English are the most widely represented — 4.11%, followed by Pakistanis — 2.7%. In addition, the territory of Glasgow is also inhabited by Irishmen (1.59%), representatives of continental Europe (1.07%), Indians (0.72%), Chinese (0.67%), and others.

description.en: Bournemouth is located in the southwest of England, on the English Channel coast. The famous beach resort in the county of Dorset is renowned for its long promenade and magnificent sandy beaches. The city is surrounded by tall rocks, making the coastal water the warmest in all of Great Britain. Bournemouth's beautiful gardens, fragrant pine alleys, and healing sea air attract visitors from all over England and beyond. Here you will find ideal conditions for family recreation, water fun, and recovery. Connoisseurs of sightseeing will discover many amazing and wonderful places, and lovers of nightlife will have a great time in fashionable clubs and restaurants.

long_description.en: According to data from 2011, almost 200 thousand people live in the city. Most of them are British, but Bournemouth is also home to many students worldwide.

description.en: Poole is a resort city in the South of England on the Channel coast. Also, it shares the border with Bournemouth, famous with its university and symphonic orchestra. Much of the city suffered from German bombing during World War II, and many historical buildings were destroyed. Poole has perfect facilities for yachting — not for nothiung, it attracts those who like sailing. At first, tourists go to the waterfront, where they can find a lot of historical buildings together with many cafes, restaurants overlooking the channel. In summer, you can go on a cruise along the harbor and the rivers that flow into it. Poole's beaches have been awarded the Blue Flag for cleanliness and safety.

Bristol is a wonderful place for curious tourists. In this city, you will find many architectural masterpieces of different epochs. Perhaps there is no other town that reveals the meaning of the words "old England" so fully. Not just "old", though. There are monumental cathedrals, and a museum with a fine collection of works of art, and an excellent zoo, and a lot of fashionable shops. There's also plenty of greenery and graffiti, which people in Bristol treat with indulgence. It's no wonder Bristol is the fourth most visited city in England.

long_description.en: Bristol's population is not ethnically homogenous. The British and Europeans make up just over 80% of all citizens. At least 8% come from Africa, and more than 5.5% come from Asia. The rest are of mixed race types. However, the language of communication in the city is almost always English.

description.en: Edinburgh is the capital and largest city of Scotland and the 7th largest in the United Kingdom. The unique architecture has been preserved here, which gave the Old and New Town the right to receive the World Heritage status and to be under the care of UNESCO. Edinburgh stretches over three hills, between the River Leith and, in addition, to historical monuments, it is impressive with its picturesque nature. Inspiring panoramas, frequent weather changes — Edinburgh's character is stubborn, and it takes a lot of effort to make it like you. However, if you succeed, you won't find a more welcoming and homely city all over Europe.

long_description.en:
According to the latest census, there has been significant growth in Edinburgh. Curiously, the percentage of Britons to visitors in the city is 95% to 5%, while in London, it is 50% to 50%.

The Scots are very friendly and kind. They are happy to help tourists. However, you should remember that English in these areas has a distorted pronunciation and a special dialect, so it is not always possible to immediately understand the local resident.

description.en: Brighton is England's busiest seaside resort located on the coast of the English Channel. It is a city where the provincial simplicity is harmoniously combined with the developed infrastructure of a respectable European resort. Wide pebble beaches, fresh sea breeze, lush greenery attract fans of family recreation and marine entertainment in Brighton. Here it is easy to blend beach holidays and acquaintance with local sights, nightclubs on the bank of the Channel, and quiet walks in wonderful parks. You want to come to Brighton over and over again, discovering more and more of the amazing places in this charming resort.

long_description.en: According to the 2014 census, almost 300 thousand people live in the city. Most of the inhabitants are English by nationality. Natives of Ireland, South Asia, Africa, China, and other countries also live in the town.

description.en: Birmingham is England's second-largest city and the UK's center of science. Here they have once invented a steam engine model and a bicycle bell, and now there is a tram named after the frontman of the Black Sabbath band. The uniqueness of this city is also in the fact that it was here that the writer John Tolkien was inspired to write an epic novel, "Lord of the Rings", and the events of the series "Peaky Blinders" took place. The cinematography, sophistication, and splendor of Birmingham conquer from the first minutes of arrival. It is incredibly emerald, thanks to its parks and gardens, and cut by the many channels with surgical precision where gondolas and canoes move, just like in Venice. The local "Brummie" (that's how they call the locals) is always ready to help, even with a very incomprehensible accent. Such a hospitable and friendly atmosphere makes you come to this cozy corner of England over and over again.

long_description.en:
The first mention of a settlement on the territory of modern Birmingham dates back to the Anglo-Saxon era (the VI — early VII centuries). Its transformation into a significant commercial center began in 1166. It quickly became popular for its mass fairs.

By the XVI century, they started to produce ironwork, small arms, and jewelry. Workers manufactured nails, copper goods (such as bed frames), nuts and bolts, screws, and buttons. In the XVII century, around fifteen thousand people lived here, and a century later, the figure reached seventy thousand. Birmingham became a large industrial city, where the best engineers and scientists lived and worked.

In 1856, the first city park and public baths were opened. Closer to the XX century, military and chocolate factories began to appear. During the Second World War, the city was heavily damaged by bombardments, which killed more than 2000 people.

The city was significantly rebuilt in the 1950s and 1960s. The internal ring road, shopping centers, and one of the largest regional libraries in Europe appeared.

Nowadays, Birmingham is a progressive and contemporary metropolis with glamorous shops, bustling pubs, and trendy clubs, attracting millions of tourists every year.

description.en: The capital of Wales attracts tourists with its mild climate and completely unusual castles. Cardiff is a city of rugby, delicious nature, and hearty food. Its territory is crossed by three rivers at once, including Eli and Tuff. Vacation in this part of the UK is expected to be relaxing and interesting at the same time, as this city has a variety of things to visit and admire. For example, ancient fortresses surrounded by dense gardens, as well as low hills wrapped in transparent sea air are considered the most popular local attractions. Also, shops, markets, restaurants, night clubs, and pubs with amber beer and national cuisine attract individuals from the whole world. Every year, this cozy corner of Europe is visited by approximately 1 million tourists.

The first things that come to mind, when you hear the word Manchester are football teams Manchester City and Manchester United. Rock music admirers immediately recollect the groups of the “new wave” like Oasis, Joy Division, the Smiths. If not taking into consideration cultural and sporting influence, this is a large industrial city, located in the northeastern part of Great Britain on the River Irwell by the Pennines. Manchester tears down the cliche of the classical English town. It is like a teenager who doesn’t know whether to become a football player, to gather a rock band, or to go into science.

long_description.en:
Most of the population (66.7%) are Europeans ㅡ the British and the Irish. On the second place are Asians (17.1%) ㅡ Pakistanis, Indians, Chinese, and others. In the third place are Africans (8.6%). There are also the Arabs, Bangladeshi, and the Gypsies in Manchester.

Among religions, the most popular is Christianity (48.7%), whereas 25.3% of Manchester citizens consider themselves as atheists. 15.8% of the population are Muslims.

description.en: Liverpool is a marvelous city with a thrilling history. It became the founder of technological breakthroughs and the cradle of the musical industry. It gave the great Beatles to the world. The city captivates with its progressiveness and aspiration for development. The first library in the world that gave out books home and the first school of tropical medicine were opened here.

long_description.en:
Local citizens of the cultural capital of Great Britain call themselves in a weird way: the Liverpudlians. People of Liverpool also have an informal but widespread in Britain nickname known as scousers. The rest of the world calls them either the Merseysiders (according to the title of the county) or simply the Liverpool. The population of the biggest city in the county of Merseyside became multinational owing to its past. It had been one of the largest trading centers in the world for a long period of time.
        Nowadays, the vast majority of the population are the native British (91%), and the Irish who settled here in the middle of the XIX century, trying to survive the hunger. Liverpool became the first city with the Chinatown in Europe in 1870. Chinese citizens were establishing commercial connections and migrated to other countries. They contributed their culture and originality to the city just like the representatives of other nations. The Asians and British Asians constitute almost 5% of the city’s population today. During the period of the commercial flourishing of the city, the slave trading was not less developed. After the abolition of this shameful phenomenon, many representatives of the African continent settled down in the city. There are almost 2% of the Africans and Afro-British in Liverpool today. The remaining 2% of the inhabitants represent the diversity and culture of a bright mixture of nationalities all over the world.

description.en: Oxford is the capital of the county of Oxfordshire and one of the main cities in Britain. It is called "the city of dreaming spires", and the architecture and beauty of the area are so impressive that even Hitler planned to move the capital of England here if it was conquered. Unapproachable and majestic, cold in appearance and friendly for locals — Oxford is proud not only for its famous university but also can amaze tourists of all ages. So what does this place hide? I'm sure you'll be pleasantly surprised.

long_description.en:
The majority of the local population are students. Of 151,000 people, 30,000 are students and about 5,000 are teachers. It is easy to guess that the atmosphere here is very vibrant because you can see mostly young people on the streets — the elderly and family couples prefer to live outside the city.

Unlike other cities in the UK, Oxford can boast of a high concentration of famous residents. At different times, it was home to Oscar Wilde, Lewis Carroll, Adam Smith, Margaret Thatcher, Tony Blair, Jonathan Swift, and many others.

description.en: Chester is an ancient, picturesque, and, at the same time, a small veteran city in England. It reflected the centuries-old history of Great Britain with a length of 2000 years. It is known for its Victorian and Tudor houses on the central streets with their unique covered shopping arcades from the Middle Ages. Well-preserved Roman fortifications with towers, an amphitheater, the Cathedral, the local Big Ben tell tourists about past eras. Chester remains one of the most visited cities in the Kingdom.

long_description.en:
There are 118,200 people living in densely populated Chester. Of these, 90% are native white British, about 2% are Asian, 1% are Irish, and 1.3% are of mixed race. The number of local residents is increasing every year.

More than 75% of the population is Christian. The rest of the city's residents are Muslim, Islamic, and Buddhist.

description.en: Salisbury is an incredibly beautiful cathedral city in the South of England, in Wiltshire. It was built on the river Avon and is surrounded by idyllically amazing river-meadows. The residents of Salisbury are very passionate about the native city because it is 5000 years old. They are proud of its unique architectural layout and a special atmosphere of an authentic English province. Moreover, human freedom and rights are highly respected here!

long_description.en:
According to the last census conducted in 2011, the population of the city and suburban settlements is 62216 people. Some 91% of the residents are from the titular nation (English), 5% are Irish, Scottish and Welsh, and 4% are Asian, black, and mestizo.

The ratio of the city's female to male population is 52% and 48%, respectively. Many Salisbury residents are Christian (62%), with over 27% being atheists. A religious minority practices Islam, Hinduism, and Buddhism.

description.en: A small town southwest of London - this could have been the entire description of Windsor if it was not for one crucial fact. Windsor is one of the few cities where a Queen has a residence. Moreover, that's the place where she likes spending her autumns. It's not surprising that the majority of travelers who come to Great Britain would want to see Windsor. The town prepared many pleasant surprises for its guests. A visit to the royal residence is just one of the many points on the to-do list in Windsor. A program for a weekend promises to be quite eventful!

long_description.en: Windsor is a multinational city as in its streets, and you can meet a representative of almost every nationality on the planet. If you take a look at the ethnic composition of the city, you shall see that 70% of the citizens are the native British, while the other 30% are the representatives of ethnic minorities. The Negroid race is the largest group (11%), and it includes Africans, Caribbeans, and different nationalities. Immigrants from South Asia and the Middle East compile another 10%. The Irish conclude 3%, and the remaining 6% belong to different nationalities.

description.en: Belfast is the capital and largest city of Northern Ireland, which is part of Great Britain. It is a city with a complicated history, and it has experienced many conflicts over religion. Their effects can now be seen in the residential areas of Belfast, which are surrounded by hundreds of fences and walls, and in the abundance of graffiti dedicated to the heroes of those events. But Belfast proves with all its might that it is a modern, beautiful, and interesting city, ready to show tourists its true face.

long_description.en:
In 1177, the English castle of John de Courcy was already located on the territory of modern Belfast. However, the official date of creation of the city is considered 1609, when King James began to settle English and Scottish nationals in the area. In the early XVII century, Belfast was home to about 1,000 people who were involved in the grain, wool, leather, butter, and corned beef trade. By the 1800s, the population had reached 20,000.

The first newspaper appeared here in 1737, a bank opened in 1752, and a theater established in 1768. In 1888, Queen Victoria made Belfast an official city. It continued to develop actively — hospitals, universities, and churches were built. The city's port played an important role, thanks to which trade and shipbuilding flourished (it was here that the Titanic, the Britannic, and the Olympic were built).

In 1921, Belfast became the capital of the new country of Northern Ireland. At the same time, it became the center of conflict between Catholics (Irish) and Protestants (English and Scots). There were particularly powerful confrontations in the 1960s and 1990s. They ended in 1998 (after the signing of the Belfast Agreement), but tensions between these groups remained.

During World War II, German air attacks partially destroyed the city. Thus, after another raid in 1941, several tens of thousands of residents were left without a roof over their heads.

Now Belfast does not stop its active development and attracts more and more tourists.

description.en: Leicester is a large, populous, and cosmopolitan city in the heart of England. It stands by the Sor River and is surrounded by dense forests. It's a city where bustling bars, hipster cafes, interactive museums, and modern galleries are situated in Gothic, Victorian, and Tudor buildings. Permanent migrations have made it a genuine "world in one city". Leicester became more famous among tourists when the remains of King Richard III were found here in 2012. And the famous Leicester City club attracts thousands of football fans from around the world every year. A trip to this fascinating and cozy city will certainly not leave any traveler indifferent.

The modern metropolis Nottingham lies in the center of England, and has preserved its history in ancient architectural monuments. It is the main commercial, financial, cultural, and educational center of Central England. It is well-developed retail, financial and business services, technology and science, and foreign tourism. Nottingham is located northwest of London, on the Trent River. Around the city lies Sherwood Forest. According to the legend, the famous robber Robin Hood lived and traded here. Today, his name is a symbol of romanticism and justice, as well as a hallmark of Nottingham. Streets, bars, and restaurants are named after this romantic robber, and a festival is held annually in his honor.

long_description.en:
Nottingham has a rich history. The first settlements on its territory appeared around 600. It was home to Anglo-Saxon settlers who called their town Snottingham (after the Saxon leader Snot). It was situated on a hill from where the crossing of the River Trent was clearly visible. On another hill, in 1068, the Norman ruler William the Conqueror decided to build a castle and settlement for his people. So the Saxons and Normans began to cooperate and trade at the foot of the hills. This neutral area was later called the Market Square, which has survived to this day and is now the center of the city.

Until 1300, the city consisted of separate French and English parts. Afterward, it united and received the status of a town with the rights of a county in 1449. In 1461, during the Wars of the Scarlet and White Roses, the king of England, Edward of York, was proclaimed in Nottingham. In those days, the city was a center for the production of wool and religious alabaster sculptures. Other industries soon began to develop — hosiery and lace. An entire quarter was even opened, which was called the Lace Market.

In 1667, the town's inhabitants suffered from a plague, and in 1795, there was a great flood. Another disaster came in 1833 when cholera killed a large part of the population.

The second half of the XVIII century was marked by the fact that in just 50 years, the city's population increased sharply from 10 to 50 thousand people. This led to a shortage of housing, jobs and the emergence of slums. The industrial revolution began. Many residents fought against the use of machines, calling themselves Luddites (after Ned Ludd, who first destroyed the loom). It ended with the Luddites setting fire to the Duke's palace in 1831.

However, with the development of new industries, the situation in the city began to improve. In 1839, the railroad was built in Nottingham, which connected it with Derby. The city gained independence in 1897.

At the beginning of World War II, Nottingham suffered from German bombing. This gave a new impetus to the development of the city. But many of the projects were inconsiderate and even ugly.

The modern city relied on the development of services, commerce, and industry — pharmaceutical, electrical, and electronics.

description.en: This city is like a living illustration to the tales of the Brothers Grimm — timber-framed houses, red-bricked churches, castles, cobblestones of the bridge. In some of the streets, it seems that someone has turned the pages of history back for a couple or three centuries, and there are about to be horsemen in long cloaks or a carriage with ladies in ball gowns. Take two dozen more steps, turn the corner and realize that Hannover is a modern business city with a solid reputation, annually gathering at its exhibitions millions of businessmen. It is also a very green city, with a huge number of parklands, squares, and forests, where you can easily see a squirrel or hedgehog in the streets. Hannover belongs to those cities that invade the heart and stay there for a long time.

Munich is the main city of Bavaria and an important economic center in Germany. It is German-like strict, and cozy at the same time. It will charm you with its kindness. The outer streets of the city almost touch the Alpine slopes, the bells of the majestic cathedrals beat the time, the facades of ancient houses are dazzling with flower baskets, and the grand parade squares gather crowds of beer lovers every year. With the official motto "Munich Loves You", it's hard not to fall in love back. The delicious, cheerful, intoxicating, and friendly Munich is definitely worth spending the weekend here.

long_description.en:
Munich is the largest city in the country, giving way only to Berlin and Hamburg in terms of population. Most of Munich's citizens are Germans. Scientists distinguish them into separate sub-ethnos — the Bavarians, as the inhabitants of this region, have special cultural traditions and dialects. What makes Munich no different from the rest of Germany is its high percentage of immigrants and refugees. A large Turkish diaspora with a total population of 39,400 lives here. Besides, there are many descendants from Croatia, Greece, Italy, Austria, Poland, and other European countries.

In recent years, there has been an influx of refugees from Arab countries, primarily from Syria. However, this situation is typical not only for Munich but also for Europe as a whole.

description.en: Garmisch-Partenkirchen is a resort town. It is situated, surrounded by the Bavarian Alps, in the valley of the river Loisach, at the foot of the highest mountain in Germany, Zugspitze (2962 m). Tourists visit it at any time of year. In winter, people come here for skiing and other winter sports. In summer, they prefer hiking in the mountains, swimming in mountain lakes, riding catamarans, and visiting the natural beauties, which are abundant here. In spring and autumn, they improve their health, as the local climate is considered healing. And at any time of year, they visit Olympic objects, attend museums, eat delicious food in local taverns, drink beer, and walk along ancient streets with painted houses.

Nuremberg is the most German city, a monument of medieval architecture, the birthplace of the Bavarian gingerbread. This is a city of emperors and kings, and at every step, there are amazing places and enchanting landscapes. Majestic castles, Gothic churches, beautiful fountains, unique museums, the beauty of which is emphasized by the magnificent landscape, have made Nuremberg popular with tourists from all over the world. Here you can feel the special atmosphere of old Germany, which harmoniously intertwines with the young spirit of a modern European city. Nuremberg can be explored again and again. It never disappoints, and every time opens from a new perspective.

long_description.en: According to the 2017 census, more than 500,000 people live in the city. About 83% of the city's residents are German by nationality.

description.en: Regensburg is one of several large German cities with buildings and structures from the Middle Ages that are preserved in pristine beauty. This territory was fortunate enough to avoid destruction during World War II. As a result, we have a completely unique architectural ensemble, which is especially brightly soloing in the Old District. Walking around Regensburg, you can get a variety of impressions for the soul and body. Explore the cathedrals and parks in the heart of the Ancient City and go to the oldest Sausage Kitchen in all of Germany on the banks of the Danube. This institution has been operating since the 13th century and does not change its traditions. Is it hard to believe? Check it out for yourself! In a city with a history of nearly two millennia, everything is unusual. Every tourist, being in this part of Bavaria, feels something special from the first breath of air.

Würzburg is the capital of Lower Franconia, nestled among the hills on the river Main. Its name is translated from German as "something special" ("zest"). It was here where the Nobel Laureate, Röntgen made his discovery — the very radiation we nowadays name after him. This city experienced a "witch hunt" in the XVII century and was ground to powder in 17 minutes by nine hundred thousand tons of bombs in 1945. Having survived such terrible destruction, Würzburg rose from the ashes like the proud Phoenix. In a short time, it managed to recreate the best examples of Baroque architecture and today attracts tourists with its grandeur and elegance. In such small and old German towns, you can best feel its real flavor and authentic atmosphere.

Bamberg is a large German city in the administrative district of Upper Franconia (Bavaria). It is situated on seven hills, in the valley of the Regnitz River. That is why the poetic name "Franconian Rome" was given to it. But this comparison does not limit the uniqueness of the city. Bamberg is self-sufficient and, in many ways, a dualistic city. It harmoniously combines Gothic and Baroque, modernity and traditions, religious buildings, and educational institutions. There are 11 breweries in Bamberg. The oldest of them was once housed within the walls of the Church of St. Michael, whose monks invented the famous beer "Rauchbier." Bamberg also managed to preserve the appearance of the Middle Ages, as it miraculously survived during the Second World War. To this day, the city is still full of legends, fairy tales, and even mysticism. They give this place a unique charm. The brilliant Ernst Hoffmann and the modern children's writer Paul Maar wrote their fairy tales here. Beautiful landscapes, authentic character, and some higher callings that faithfully protect the city fill Bamberg with a magical atmosphere.

This ancient Bavarian city, situated on the banks of three rivers (Lech, Wertach, and Singold), gave the world very prominent personalities in history — the richest Renaissance merchant Jakob Fugger and the German playwright Bertolt Brecht. And it was here that Rudolf Diesel built his engine, pushing the progress to a new stage. But the city is even more famous because it had never become home to Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. It was by pure chance that the greatest composer and virtuoso musician was not born in Augsburg, where his family had lived for 250 years, but in Salzburg, where his father was invited to be a Kapellmeister. Still, the city has a Mozart museum, and the kneipe serve his favorite dishes. You can discover yourself how else this greenest industrial center in Europe, which managed to become part of the most popular tourist route Romantic Road, can surprise anyone who visits it.

long_description.en:
Augsburg emerged on a Roman military camp site in 15 B.C. and owed its name to Emperor Augustus. In 121, the settlement became the center of the province and received all the rights of a Roman city. Its favorable geographical location at the crossroads of trade routes contributed to rapid economic development.

During the medieval period, it became the largest commercial center of Bavaria. A great contribution to the prosperity of his native city was made by Jakob Fugger, a merchant from a family of weavers, who, in the XVI century, became the wealthiest man on the planet thanks to his intelligence and diligence. Goods produced by local merchants and artisans were shipped all over the world with the help of his ships. Thanks to him, the concept of social housing was born when he built an entire block (Fuggerei) of 53 low-income housing units in Augsburg. Each of these was to be occupied for only one guilder (currently 80 euro cents) per year. The quarter is still operating today, and the living conditions have not changed.

The Thirty Years' War (1618-1648) was a great disaster for the city. Its population almost halved, and its political and economic importance was severely diminished. Augsburg lost its liberal imperial town status during the Napoleonic war and was annexed to the Kingdom of Bavaria on March 4, 1806.

At that time, there were facilities like the M.A.N. tank factory, Messerschmitt aircraft factory, and various repair shops. During World War II, this industrial center of Germany was mercilessly bombed by the anti-Hitler coalition aircraft. Most of the architectural treasures of the city were destroyed. It took over a decade to restore at least part of the lost.

Since the second half of the twentieth century, Augsburg has been gaining ground again as an important industrial center in Bavaria. Today it is home to the world's manufacturing giants (Siemens, KUKA, M.A.N., N.C.R., the EADS airplane manufacturer) and a number of food and light industry companies. And it does not prevent Augsburg from being an extremely beautiful old town with excellent tourist infrastructure. In 2000, it was recognized by UNESCO as the greenest city in Europe and was rewarded for its environmental commitment.

description.en: Schwangau is a cozy village in the south of Germany, located near the Austrian border in the Bavarian Alps. Here, among the mountains, there is a relaxed atmosphere, but there is also everything for the comfortable life and leisure of numerous tourists. Visitors mainly come here to visit the famous royal castles of Neuschwanstein and Hohenschwangau, as well as to visit the bridge of Mary (Marienbrücke) by the picturesque waterfall with emerald water. The Bavarian town of Schwangau looks like a fairytale place and is also called the "swan village". The mountainous area is famous for its lakes; the most popular are the Alpsee, Forggensee, and Schwansee. The latter inspired the renowned composer Pyotr Tchaikovsky to create music for the ballet Swan Lake. The infrastructure of the small town is very developed. The population of Schwangau is not large, but the flow of tourists is impressive, so there are many guest houses, hotels, and boarding houses. There are also souvenir shops, cafes, and restaurants at every step. Bicycle tourism is popular in Schwangau, and there are many cycling routes and hiking trails.

Ettal is a beautiful small village with cozy houses and stunning nature. It is located in the south of Germany in the mountainous part of Bavaria among the picturesque Ammergau Alps. Ettal Abbey draws the attention of tourists and pilgrims. It has a cheese factory and one of the best breweries in Germany. But the most visited place in the monastery is the distillery, where the liqueur is produced. Visitors have the opportunity to taste any product made in the walls of Ettal Convent. The second most popular attraction in Ettal is the Linderhof Palace, formerly owned by Bavarian King Ludwig II. The village is remarkable for its picturesque nature, so a walking tour in the surroundings will be a great pleasure.

Stuttgart lies on the banks of the River Neckar, in a picturesque valley. The automobile capital of Germany is one of the most important cultural centers in the country. This city is famous for its numerous streets that end with stairs leading to the tops of the hills. Fantastic buildings of fashionable art galleries and museums against the backdrop of Gothic towers and medieval castles, surrounded by lush parks and gardens, delight city guests. Stuttgart knows how to fascinate and impress, it is comfortable to live in and to spend a vacation. After visiting it, you would like to return here again.

long_description.en: As of 2017, the city's population was more than 600,000 people. The main part of the citizens are Germans by nationality, and they make up about 79% of the population. There are also many natives of Turkey, Italy, Greece, and Poland living in Stuttgart.

description.en: Freiburg im Breisgau is located in the southwestern part of Germany, in the federal state of Baden-Württemberg. The city was founded in the 12th century. Despite the blitz bombing during World War II, many historical and architectural monuments have been preserved here. You should definitely visit the Cathedral of the 14th century. It is decorated with a 116-meter-high spire, which has survived to this day without restructuring. Tourists should visit the Swabian gate and the Martinstor gate, the Old Town Hall with a painted facade of the 16th century, built in the same century, Historical Merchants’ Hall on Cathedral Square and the famous the Whale House. Since the mid-19th century, the city has been decorated with paving mosaics with a variety of images. You can view the panoramas of the city from the observation deck on Castle Hill or climb Schauinsland mountain, 1284 meters high, along with the longest cable car in the country 2.2 kilometers long.

The lively university town of Heidelberg is located in a cozy valley between three hills on the Neckar River banks. One of the oldest cities in Germany, which has preserved the Middle Ages' architecture, is famous for the oldest university in the country. Famous philosophers, writers, and scientists remember narrow paved streets, majestic castles, and ancient temples of Heidelberg. Goethe, Robert Bunsen, Jean Paul, and other celebrities lived and worked here. The red-tiled roofs of Heidelberg's houses are bright spots of the pastoral greenery. And the unhurried flow of the river sets the mood in a romantic manner. Ancient but always young in spirit, Heidelberg knows how to surprise, delight, and charm.

long_description.en:
Archaeologists discovered the remains of the European Homo erectus near the city in 1907. His age was 600,000 years. Scientists called him Heidelberg man. There were settlements of early Stone Age people, Celtic tribes, on the land belonging to the present city. A military fortress was located here during the Roman Empire. The earliest written mention of the city can be found in the chronicles of the monastery of Schönau, dated to the end of the XII century. The first information about the famous city fortress is found in the records of 1225.

At the end of the XIV century, a university was founded in Heidelberg, where young people from all over Europe came to study.

During the Middle Ages, the city was the seat of the rulers of the Electoral Palatinate, a territorial entity within the Holy Roman Empire.

In the XVII century, the city suffered during the Thirty Years' War. The French destroyed it in the Palatinate campaign.

With the incorporation of Heidelberg into the Electorate of Baden (early XIX century), an era of prosperity began. They built a railroad, industrial workshops, and wealthy homes.

During World War II, Heidelberg was one of the few German towns that were not destroyed. Thanks to this, it was possible to preserve the historical heritage of the city, its unique atmosphere, and its identity.

Today Heidelberg is not only a student city with many cultural centers, theaters, and clubs but also the largest scientific center in Germany.

description.en: Karlsruhe is an ancient city without protective walls. Its unusual layout in the form of a fan symbolizes the openness and acceptance of different ideas, cultures, and religions. It is an example of what the perfect city looked like in the dreams of the 18th-century margrave Karl Wilhelm. As a result, this dream successfully came true. Based on the preferences of its founder, Karlsruhe has been serving functions of the most important cultural, research, industrial, and tourist center of not only the state of Baden-Württemberg but entire Germany.

Cologne is one of the oldest cities in Europe, the cultural capital of Germany, located in the beautiful Cologne Bay. It is a real paradise for lovers of medieval architecture and historical monuments, which are found here at every turn. Majestic ancient temples and modern buildings, quiet cobbled streets and quarters with bustling nightlife, respectable restaurants and beer bars harmoniously stand side by side in Cologne. This city values life in all its manifestations but also cherishes its history and traditions.

long_description.en:
In 2017, the city was home to more than one million people of 150 nationalities. The majority of the citizens are Germans, about 83%. There are also natives of Turkey, Italy, former Yugoslavian, and CIS countries.

In the city, you can hear the West German dialect (Kölsch), which is spoken by indigenous people. It differs enough from literary German, but it is quite possible to understand its bearers.

description.en: Dusseldorf is a city that is located on the right bank of the Rhine River, in the western part of Germany. It is one of the five largest industrial, transport, and cultural centers in Germany. For example, the offices of world-famous companies, numerous educational institutions, and attractions of past centuries coexist on the territory of this city. You can be surprised, but Dusseldorf is considered German Milan. After all, it is here that the production of clothing is concentrated, and it is here that famous designers dictate fashion trends. In other words, Dusseldorf is a very diverse, friendly, and interesting city that will be liked by any tourist.

Bonn is a large German city located on the Rhine River in North Rhine-Westphalia. In terms of population, it ranks 19th in the country. In the postwar years, Bonn was the capital of the Federal Republic of Germany. Today it is a major political and economic center of the country, which has the status of a federal city. Even though travelers do not particularly visit it, the number of attractions in Bonn is on par with major tourist centers like Munich, Cologne, and Nuremberg.

long_description.en:
The first settlements on this land were as early as the XI century B.C. It was a camp for the ancient Roman army, erecting the Castra Bonnensia fortress here, which later became the first walled city. In late Antiquity, the Gauls conquered Bonn. The city got its name only in 1000. Then, thanks to the monastery's construction, Bonn began to develop actively as a city and became the spiritual center of the Frankish Empire. During the reign of Archbishop Conrad (in 1244), the city began to expand its borders. In 1288, Bonn had its first town council and court.

In 1597, the city became the cultural capital of Germany, and in 1786, the first university was founded there. For some time, Bonn was under the rule of England, France, and Canada. And only in 1933 it became a fully German city.

After World War II (from 1949 to 1990), Bonn was the capital of the Federal Republic of Germany. During this time, it expanded its borders significantly. It included Bad Godesberg, Beuel, and part of Duisdorf. After the unification of Germany into a single state, the city transferred its powers to Berlin.

description.en: The ancient city of Dortmund spreads out in a picturesque valley between the Ruhr and Emscher rivers in the west of Germany. Majestic temples and medieval buildings, beautiful parks and modern buildings in the Postmodern style, unique museums, and exhibitions — beautiful Dortmund has prepared many fascinating places for tourists. It is easy to lose track of time here, be enchanted by the lovely atmosphere of the old city, and believe in a fairy tale.

long_description.en:
People settled on the lands of the modern city back in the Bronze Age. In 880, there was a settlement of Thortmanni. At the end of the X century, it was given the right to trade. Until the middle of the XII century, it had remained a small village. And only during the reign of King Frederick I, Holy Roman Emperor, the settlement began to grow and became an imperial city. Already at that time, Dortmund was famous for its breweries far outside the city. At the end of the XIII century, it received official permission to produce beer.

In the first half of the XVII century, Dortmund was damaged in the Thirty Years' War. Houses were destroyed, and many citizens died.

In the first decade of the XIX century, the city was part of the Principality of Orange-Nassau, and then became part of the Ruhr Department Prefecture. After the Napoleonic Wars, Dortmund passed to Westphalia (Prussian province).

The middle of the XIX century brought economic prosperity to the city. Coal mines and steel factories were built, and the Cologne-Minden railway was laid. In the last years of the XIX century, a city port appeared, and a shipping Dortmund - Ems Canal was opened. The city grew rapidly, absorbing nearby settlements.

At the end of World War II, Dortmund was severely destroyed. Many even believed that the city, 98% of whose territory was in ruins, is not able to recover. But the great demand for coal and steel helped Dortmund to rise. Already in late 1945 - early 1946, all mines and blast furnaces started working here.

Ancient Dortmund quickly recovered and soon became one of Europe's most beautiful and comfortable cities for life.

description.en: Münster is one of the oldest cities in Germany with a rich history, architectural, and cultural heritage. It is located in the west of Germany, and is considered to be the cultural center of the Westphalia region. Not far from it lies the border with the Netherlands. This is a rather large city. Münster lists the 16th place in the country in terms of area. Most of it is reserved for agriculture. The residential part of the city is divided into six districts. In the west, there is the Aase Lake, which is the main resting place for both local residents and tourists. The historical part of Münster tells about many events in the life of not only the city but also the country as a whole. Among tourists, unfortunately, it is not too popular. It is more like a campus where nightlife is in full swing. But the mix of antiquity and modernity makes it special and unique.

Trier is located in the south-eastern part of Germany on the banks of the Moselle. It has a thousand years old history. A walk around this small German city will bring you wonderful emotions. Ancient Roman buildings and palaces of the Rococo period, Gothic cathedrals, and modern mansions peacefully coexist here. Trier is the only place in the world with the best-preserved monuments of antiquity. Holy relics, brought from Jerusalem by Empress Helena, are kept here. It is the birthplace of her son — the great Emperor Constantine.

As the administrative and cultural center of the federal state of Rhineland-Palatinate, the ancient city named Mainz plays a significant role in the whole country. It is located at the confluence of the Main and Rhine rivers, in the western part of Germany. It can also be called the iconic city of the country, as it offers the opportunity to get a complete picture of entire Germany. The city is filled with ancient architectural structures in the styles of Gothics, Baroque, Rococo, and Art Nouveau. Besides, Mainz gained worldwide fame thanks to Johannes Gutenberg — the inventor of the printing press and the revolutionist of book publishing. In fact, the scientist was born and worked in this city. Mainz is also classified as one of the country's main media centers. It can be explained by the fact that the main office of one of the leading television channels in the country is located here. It is a city of universities and medieval streets, theaters and museums, wineries and parks, castles and cathedrals. These elements attract tourists from all over the world to the small authentic Mainz.

If you’ve been dreaming to plunge into the swirl of West European life with its rapid development and delicate attitude to the cultural heritage, you are welcome to Frankfurt am Main. It is the most cosmopolitan city in Germany. It is also the major financial center of the continent. Here you will see the largest European airport, sharp skyscrapers, banks, banks, banks, and … the largest woodland in Germany — the City Forest. Be ready to visit atmospheric locations in the Old Town. Have a walk along Kaiserstraße, filled with smells of traditional Frankfurt cuisine and cyder, and Museum Embankment. Visit Römerberg with its fairy-tale 500-years-old half-timbering houses and go to the viewing point of St. Bartholomäus Cathedral, offering the best view of the Old Town. Pay your attention, the great Goethe walked somewhere there.

long_description.en:
The fact that Frankfurt is an international city is not an empty statement. The German population, of course, remains the ethnic majority here. But today, one out of every three residents of Frankfurt does not hold a German passport.

The city attracts migrants from all over the world as a European center of finance and commerce. So if you walk through the old city, you will hear people speaking different languages, and it doesn't necessarily have to be tourists. Communities from Turkey, Italy, Croatia, Serbia, Poland, Greece, Morocco, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Spain, Portugal, France, Japan, USA, Austria, India, Great Britain, Romania, Afghanistan, Russia, Bulgaria, Lebanon, and China coexist peacefully in Frankfurt.

description.en: Dresden is the administrative center of Saxony, which is located on the Elbe River, near the border with the Czech Republic. For centuries, the city has been serving functions of the cultural, industrial, and economic center of East Germany. World-famous artworks are collected in the local galleries of Dresden, whereas its Baroque architecture, picturesque surroundings, an abundance of historical sights attract tourists from all over the world. Moreover, Dresden is the birthplace of the filter for coffee, toothpaste, and the largest porcelain panel in the world. In fact, this city is often described as the “box with decorations,” which can be explained by the abundance of architectural monuments. At the same time, it is the only European city that has lost UNESCO status. Subsequently, the controversial and beautiful Dresden is expected to surprise travelers of all ages.

long_description.en: It is interesting that Dresden is one of the largest cities in Eastern Europe and the only German city where more people live now than before World War II. The local population is friendly and eager to help tourists. The people of Dresden speak good English and can explain how to find a particular attraction, café, or theater.

description.en: Leipzig is the German city located in the eponymous lowland, at the confluence of the three rivers, such as White Elster, Pleis, and Parte. Many artificial lakes and canals have been created in the city and its surrounding, which is why Leipzig is often described as the “Little Venice”. The main part of its territory consists of historical buildings; therefore, it has the status of the architectural capital of Germany. Gothics, Baroque, Renaissance, and Art Nouveau miraculously combine here, impressing city guests with its architectural diversity and richness. "Leipzig. Ort der Vielfalt” (“Leipzig. Place of Diversity”) is the official motto of the city, which is considered the pearl of Saxony. As an amazing city of the great composers, such as Bach and Mendelssohn, it includes one of the oldest universities in Germany, where Goethe studied. It is here that traditional fairs and festivals of contemporary art are held.

long_description.en:
The population of Leipzig in the Middle Ages was small and grew slowly because of wars, epidemics, and famine.

Rapid growth began during the industrialization of the XIX century. Reaching its peak at the beginning of the XX century, the number of residents in the city began to decrease, which was a cause of concern to the city authorities. At the beginning of the XXI century, a solution was found to improve the situation by incorporating urban districts. The population began to grow as early as the mid-2000s, and by 2011, the number of permanent residents in the city had risen to 510,000, and by the end of 2018 — to 596,500.

As of the beginning of 2018, 13.5% of the city's residents were foreigners. These were mainly from the Russian Federation, Syria, Poland, and Ukraine. Of all the cities in East Germany, Leipzig has the highest level of migrants.

The majority of the city's inhabitants (85%) do not identify themselves with any religion.

description.en: Potsdam is located near Berlin in a picturesque location on the lakes of the Havel River. It can be easily called the city of parks and palaces — just under the protection of the UNESCO World Heritage Site, there are more than 150 buildings and more than 2,000 hectares of landscape monuments. Potsdam is one big historical attraction, a city-museum with a 1000-year history, the best masterpieces of architecture created by the Prussian kings. Besides, Potsdam is the center of German cinema, education, and science. In Germany, it is one of the most popular cities among tourists.

long_description.en:
The first documented mention of Potsdam dates back to 993 when Emperor Otto III granted the land of the Slavic village Poztupimi to the Quedlinburg Abbey. In 1157 the Germans built a castle complex here. The small town stood at an important crossing of the Havel River and was granted city status in 1345. In the XVI century, two major fires almost destroyed Potsdam.

A new turn in the city's development began after 1640 when Elector Frederick William chose it as his residence. Shortly afterward, construction of the city's main palace and landscaping began. Thanks to the Prussian king Frederick William I, Potsdam became a garrison town and began to expand.

The city reached its greatest prosperity already under Frederick II the Great. Creations of his time still define the image and character of the city. In 1744, works on the enlargement of the city palace started, and the following year the construction of the Sanssouci Palace began. The New Palace, Picture Gallery, and New Chambers were erected, among other things.

Frederick William IV. went down in the city's history as an outspoken admirer of classical forms. Impressive new buildings appeared in Potsdam.

Between 1860 and 1890, the city's population increased by about a third, and the urban area continued to expand along the main roads.

Due to the November Revolution of 1918 and the emperor's abdication, Potsdam lost the title of residence, and further historical events slowed down the city's development. 

At the end of World War II, many historical buildings were damaged by bombing. Reconstruction began in 1950 and continues intermittently to this day.

description.en: Berlin is the capital of German. This city illustrates the history of the country: from its collapse to revival. Today, it’s buzzing with wild energy, sounds like loud musical festivals, throws fancy parties at nightclubs, and set trends in modern art. Berlins is the quintessence of dozens of diverse subcultures. It is more than happy to welcome both vegans and meat-eater, doesn’t censure any sexual orientation, extraordinary fashion or lifestyles. Even though Berlin is the main city in the country, it doesn’t resemble the rest of Germany. It looks poorer but attracts everyone with its genuine soul. Well, people call it poor but sexy not without a reason.

long_description.en:
Berlin is the biggest in Europe with almost 4 million citizens. Over 14% of the people living in the city are immigrants. The Turkish constitute the fourth part of emigrants. They have the largest diaspora in Germany. Plenty of immigrants from the first wave from the Soviet Union live in the districts of the former West Berlin. You can meet many Russians in the localities of “social dwelling”, Marzahn and Hellersdorf.

Women outnumber men in Berlin. More than half of the population don’t burden themselves with marriage. At the same time, they practice living together in an effort to save on accommodation. Retirees are typical habitués of cafes and bakeries.

description.en: Ancient Hamburg stands at the place where the Elbe River flows into the North Sea. The city-state, port-city, Northern Venice — the multifaceted Hamburg is a real pearl of Germany. It is known not only for one of the largest bays in Europe but also for beautiful ancient churches, unique museums, lush parks and gardens, numerous bars and nightclubs. Dozens of canals cross Hamburg with elegant bridges. Many amazingly beautiful places create a special atmosphere of an ancient but eternally young city, which attracts crowds of travelers.

long_description.en: According to the latest 2018 census, the city is home to nearly two million people. The majority of residents are Germans by nationality, and their number is about 87%. The remaining 13% are from 180 countries. Most come from other European countries, South Asia, and Africa.

description.en: At first glance, the bustling and business-like city in the north of Germany is not the most obvious choice for a holiday destination. But it's only the first and not the longest impression. Bremen, situated on both banks of the Weser River (with its swamps, beer shops, and proud merchant's past), is not a romantic knight in tragic shining armor, but rather a merchant. Besides, the merchant is wealthy, rouge, and hospitable! This place will be right for those who appreciate good food, cozy streets, and authentic buildings. There is no entertainment "just for tourists." You can see the monuments just while walking around the city. And the local citizens will gladly come to the Freimarkt, which is considered to be the oldest fair in all of Germany and is held in October. If you describe Bremen in three words, it is authenticity, energy, and comfort. And yes, you will undoubtedly find a monument to the renowned musicians here!

Malaga is a beautiful resort located in the south of the Iberian Peninsula, surrounded by sea and mountains. One of the sunniest cities in Europe is located on the Costa del Sol ("sunny coast"), which is famous for its wonderful beaches and recreation areas. Malaga is loved not only for its ideal conditions for beach holidays but also for its many unique attractions. Ancient Arabic fortresses and Roman theater, majestic cathedrals, fascinating museums, magnificent parks — you can explore the paved streets of Malaga forever. Not surprisingly, this southern city has become the birthplace of Pablo Picasso, fiery flamenco dance, and amazing Malaga wine.

long_description.en: According to the 2017 census, more than 500 thousand people live in the city. Most of them are Spanish by nationality, who make up about 90% of the total population. The city is also home to people from Morocco, Paraguay, Romania, Ukraine, Argentina, and other countries.

description.en: Marbella, often described as the Spanish Riviera, stretches along the Costa del Sol in the province of Malaga (Andalusia region). The northern part of the province is located near Sierra Blanca, where the city was built. Nowadays, it is a fashionable and expensive resort that attracts many wealthy tourists, such as Arab sheiks, European kings, aristocrats, and celebrities. For instance, Antonio Banderas and Bruce Willis bought their own villas here. In turn, in 2010, Michelle Obama, the wife of the former president of the United States, was relaxing at the resort. In Marbella, you can find all the appropriate attributes of luxurious life, including private jets and yachts, expensive restaurants and spas, luxury tennis courts, and golf clubs.

long_description.en:
The coast where Marbella is located has been inhabited since the Paleolithic period. But the beginning of the city's history is considered to be from 1600 BC. Ruins on the site of Roman baths, the original mosaic Villa Romana de Rio Verde, and the San Pedro Basilica, where the remains of the first Christians are buried, remind one of the Roman period.

In the VI century, the south of Spain was invaded by Arabs, and Marbella became Muslim for about 900 years. During this period, the city grew in size. Arab engineers built many houses and strong fortifications — a fort, protective moats, and walls. And now, walking around the city, you can see the houses with characteristic Moorish architecture.

In 1485, Marbella was conquered by the troops of the Spanish King Fernando. The city was badly damaged during the storm, and after the victory, the Spaniards destroyed the mosque in its center. Their place is now occupied by Orange Square (Plaza de los Naranjos). A few centuries later, the fortification of the walls and construction of another fort was required as the coast had become unsafe due to the growing number of pirates. Today all that remains of these structures is the tower, which rises in the gardens of the Hotel Fuerte.

Until 1954, Marbella had been a small agricultural town. That all changed when Prince Alfonso, impressed by the beautiful panoramas of the region, bought the land here and built the first-class Marbella Club Hotel. The resort attracted members of the European royal families, which gave impetus to the construction of comfortable hotels, villas, expensive restaurants, and other attributes of luxury living.

description.en: Seville is a city of graceful towers and magnificent palaces, cobblestone streets and lush gardens, breathtaking bullfights, and passionate flamenco. Here the spirit of true Spain is brightly manifested — temperamental, burning, and fiery. It is impossible not to fall in love with this city, which amazes with the beauty of the palaces in the ancient Roman style, Moorish strongholds, majestic temples, and many fountains. The city is full of orange trees, whose heady scent envelops its streets every spring. The charming capital of Andalusia is fascinating, intoxicating with beauty and splendor.

long_description.en: In 2017, the population of Seville was almost 700 thousand people. About 95% of them are Spaniards. The natives of other European countries account for about 1.5% of Sevilleans. The rest of the city's inhabitants are from various nationalities in Africa, Asia, and the Americas.

description.en: One of the most beautiful cities on the planet, Granada, is located in the south of Spain. The ancient town, situated on three hills in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada, is famous for its historical and architectural heritage of Moorish, Gothic, and Renaissance periods. The maze of narrow medieval streets, the huge Alhambra palace complex, fancy cathedrals and churches, fiery dance shows in the caves of Sacromonte — Granada can amaze and delight. A native city of ancient architecture, passionate music, and bustling nightlife attracts tourists from all over the world.

Ancient Cadiz is a godsend for aesthetes of all generations. With more than three millennia of existence, the city has incorporated the tragedy and splendor of many historical eras. Each of its streets breathes the air of different centuries, thereby creating a very special atmosphere. In the city, Christian and Moorish temples, buildings, and palaces, which represent different styles and directions in architecture, peacefully coexist with each other. Here you can dance until the morning in numerous clubs and endlessly admire the beauty of the Cathedral and hundreds of local towers. People also have the opportunity to spend hours and days on the beaches stretching off the Atlantic's shores. At the same time, you can enjoy the local cuisine based on seafood and olives. Enjoy an unforgettable shopping experience, and take many unique photos when climbing to one of several viewing platforms. Cadiz is history and modernity, which complement each other in every building and object, making the city a truly unique resort.

long_description.en:
Cadiz is an ancient city, the oldest in Europe, as it existed a thousand years before Christ. It was founded by Phoenician navigators around 1100 BC and was called Gadir. Over the next few centuries, the city was repeatedly conquered. It took turns owned by the Carthaginians and the Romans. Under the Romans, it was already called Gades. It was granted municipal rights by the young Gaius Julius Caesar. The city has seen the Vandals, Visigoths, Arabs, Greeks, and Byzantines. In the 1280s, Cadiz (then already had a modern name) appeared in the first Spanish chronicle of King Alfonso X.

During the Age of Discovery, the city and the ports nearby were strategically important to Europeans discovering new routes and lands. Spanish expeditions to the Americas departed from here, and Columbus' ships sailed in search of the lands of the New World.

In 1810-1812, Cadiz was unsuccessfully besieged by the French. At the same time, the city's population grew considerably at the expense of Spanish refugees who saw this vacant place as a safe haven. Members of the Cortes came here to debate the nuances of Europe's first constitution. On March 19, 1812, it was adopted and became the first constitution of Spain. It established a constitutional monarchy: the legislative power was vested in the Cortes and the king, and the executive power was in the king alone.

Eight years later, the city was dragged into a revolution provoked by the lack of promised reforms. King Ferdinand VII was imprisoned in the castle of Cadiz. Three years later, he was released and made new promises, which he again broke. As a result, the constitution was abolished. The "black decade" began with repression and terror. Naturally, this attitude towards the people caused a new wave of discontent and a new revolution, which ended with the formation of a new government headed by Jose Concha.

Up to the beginning of the twentieth century, Cadiz survived mainly as a port through shipbuilding and trading activities. But the well-being of the citizens, alas, did not grow until the development of tourism. Tourism was the impetus for constructing a streetcar line and hotels and expanding the port quays to accommodate cruise ships.

On August 18, 1947, an explosion in the armories of Cadiz took the lives of 5 thousand citizens and severely damaged some of the city's buildings. The Cathedral and the Falla Theater were among those destroyed. Within a few years, the major damage was repaired.

Today, the province of Cadiz, with its rich history and many historical monuments, is a popular tourist destination. Millions of travelers come here every year.

description.en: In the south of Spain, in Andalusia, you can find an incredibly beautiful city named Cordoba. Its rich history is expressed through the amazing interweaving of Roman, Arab, and European cultures. Famous bridges, watchtowers, magnificent palaces, and ancient temples demonstrate specific features of the period of the Middle Ages. At the same time, the picturesque snow-white buildings entwined with flowers and tiny parks with lemon trees captivate with the charm of the southern province. It is impossible to ignore the charm of the ancient, but a young spirit of the Andalusian city. Usually, people aim to come back here in order to plunge into the atmosphere of bliss and pleasure again.

long_description.en:
The first settlement on the site of the modern city dates back to the VIII century BC. At that time, it was called Corduba. In the time of ancient Rome, the city was a military base of the Romans, who conquered Spain. In the II century BC, Cordoba was granted the status of a self-governing Roman colony. The city then became the capital of the province of Baetica and one of the largest settlements of the Roman Empire. The city had cobbled streets, aqueducts, temples, theaters, and rich mansions.

The end of the III century brought the decline of the city, which lost its status as the capital of the province. Then it was often attacked by the ancient Germanic tribes of the Vandals and Visigoths.

At the beginning of the VIII century, the Arabs conquered the town. During this period, it was named Cordoba and became the capital of the province of Andalusia, which later became an independent emirate. Over time, persecution of Christians began in Cordoba — temples were destroyed, and Christians who resisted were brutally executed.

The status of the capital of the emirate made Cordoba a famous city. Trade, crafts, and science flourished here.

In the IX-X centuries, there were 70 libraries, which kept the rarest manuscripts. Magnificent residences of caliphs and mansions of noblemen were built there.

The XI century marked the beginning of the decline of Cordoba. Berbers destroyed it, and then it passed into the possession of Spain.

The XV century is remembered for the cruelest Inquisition in the city when many Jews and Muslims were exterminated.

Cordoba's economic heyday was between the XVI and XIX centuries. They built new factories, developed industry and trade, and opened the railroad.

Despite many tragic periods in history, Cordoba has managed to preserve its cultural heritage and the incredible charm of an ancient southern city.

description.en: Time on the streets of Barcelona is either frozen or compressed. Here, the fragments of the Antiquity, Medieval masterpieces, and the contemporaneity exist in absolute harmony with each other. Narrow bricked streets naturally intertwine with broad highways. The horns of liner coming into harbor call to the tolling of the church and cathedral bells. Barcelona is constantly changing its mood depending on the season and time of a day. However, it is always hospitable and is ready to amaze you on every corner. The city is “armed” with Gothic temples and Gaudi’s masterpieces, monasteries and stadiums, parks and museums. Barcelona managed to keep the spirit of antiquity and combine it with being a comfortable modern city, the capital of Spanish Catalonia.

long_description.en: More than 1.5 million people live in Barcelona today. According to the municipal register, the fairer sex predominate. However, in the age groups from 35 to 44 and up to 19 years old, there are more men than women. Barcelona is multinational. This city has immigrants, foreign students, and expats who work in numerous international companies that have chosen the capital of Catalonia for their headquarters. The largest diasporas include the Italians, French, Venezuelans, Chinese, and Colombians.

description.en: Nowadays, the magnificent Girona is located on a high hill above the river. The city, founded by the Romans, attracts tourists with its well-preserved medieval buildings and numerous architectural masterpieces. When you walk along the narrow streets of the historical center, you can easily travel back several centuries and experience the atmosphere of the ancient city. Traditional colorful buildings along the river, a huge cathedral towering above the city, the Jewish quarter, Arab baths, monumental Roman stone walls are the examples of the attractions that you can find wandering through the old city. In Girona, the antiquity of the Middle Ages is harmoniously combined with the spirit of youth, which is especially felt on the streets of the modern city. There are many shops and boutiques, cafes and restaurants. Girona captivates with beauty; it also promises unforgettable surprises and fabulous miracles.

Tarragona is a small town on the Mediterranean coast in an autonomous community of Catalonia (Spain). It belongs to the famous resort area of the Costa Daurada, which is known for its magnificent sandy beaches. But Tarragona attracts tourists not only with beach recreation.
