There are many unique architectural landmarks, including ancient buildings, in the city. Here you can perfectly combine an excellent beach holiday with the exploration of the greatest works of the Roman Empire.

A lovely Figueras is located in the east of Spain, not far from a border with France. The city is a popular travel destination. Those who like works by Salvador Dalí visit his homeland to learn more about his life and creative work, and also to visit the Teatre-Museu Gala Salvador Dalí, which has a unique shape. But Figueras is proud not only with the heritage of the great painter. Magnificent churches, splendid castle, unique museums — all this can impress the most experienced travelers. Simple walks around this picturesque city will bring pleasant emotions and bright impressions.

Benidorm is a luxury resort in one of Spain's most famous tourist areas on the Costa Blanca shore. Life is buzzing here all year round, day and night, and the comfortable sandy beaches of Poniente and Levante, marked with the Blue Flag, hospitably welcome holidaymakers who came here to swim and sunbathe. Benidorm offers its guests many exciting and vibrant impressions from exploring the city and traveling along its hospitable and picturesque coastline.

long_description.en:
The first information about this area dates back to the III century BC when the ancient Phoenicians inhabited the coast. A little later, they were replaced by the Romans and Greeks, later displaced by the Moors. Benidorm received the City Charter in 1325, becoming part of the possessions of the King of Aragon - James II the Just.

In the 16th century, pirate raids on the coast became more frequent. The city built a fortress and several towers on the cliffs, allowing time to notice the enemy fleet and prepare for defense. Nevertheless, Benidorm often suffered from the attacks of sea robbers. This greatly hampered trade and prevented the locals from fishing.

This state of affairs continued until the 19th century. In the period from 1802 to 1812, the coast was occupied by Napoleon's troops, but the city did not suffer much, in contrast to the population robbed by the soldiers. After the defeat of the French, smugglers and pirates began to return to Benidorm, but King Fernando VII of Spain sent a separate fleet to fight them and restore order there.

At the end of the XIX century, the first vacationers from Madrid appeared in the town, but the further tourist development of the city was stopped first by the Civil and then the Second World War. The real resort of Benidorm became only in the 70s of the XX century when its beaches attracted tourists from all over the world, attracted by the uniquely mild climate of the region. 

Legend has it that an extravagant publicity campaign, organized at his own expense by Pedro Zaragoza, then mayor of the city, contributed greatly to this. He paid a family of reindeer herders - they rode together through the major airports of Spain with a sign that read, "This northern family is coming to rest on the coast of Benidorm." Word of this quickly spread throughout Europe, and the influx of tourists gradually increased. Whether this is true or not is unknown, but Pedro Zaragoza really did a lot for the prosperity of his city. For example, he created a master plan for the town, changing the previous concept in favor of vertical buildings and creating wide avenues. It was also through his efforts that he created the water system and ensured its uninterrupted operation.

description.en: A small town on the eastern coast of Spain, the province of Alicante, resort area of Costa Blanca, Mediterranean Sea — a magnificent Torrevieja hides behind all these geographical references. This resort is called the “Russian capital” of Spain but citizens of other countries also really enjoy coming here. No wonder, because Torrevieja is not only white beaches and soft sea. It is also picturesque nature, different entertainments, delicious cuisine, and sunny weather throughout the year.

The greenest Spanish megalopolis; a dynamic city; a picturesque resort on the coast of the Mediterranean Sea – there are various options to describe Valencia. However, there is hardly one title that can give a full picture of this incredible city. It combines humans with nature, ancient architecture and contemporary buildings, calm holidays to never-ending parties. You can come to Valencia for one or two weeks or even a month! You won’t get bored here. Hundreds of interesting places are located not only in the city but also in its suburbs.

long_description.en:
Valencia is the third-largest populated city in Spain. Around 800 thousand people live here. The Spaniards compile the majority of the citizens. Yet, the capital of the region is pretty multinational. According to the information gathered in 2017, there are 140 nationalities registered in Valencia.

Around 12% of the population in Valencia (almost 100 thousand people) have a foreign nationality. The third part of these people (31.4%) are the citizens of various countries of the European Union. As far as the diasporas are concerned, the Romanians (11%), Italians (6.9%), and Chinese (6.6%) are the largest ones.

description.en: The port city of Alicante is located in the south-eastern part of Spain, occupying the best picturesque shores of the Mediterranean Sea. The warm climate and rich history of this place have turned it into a popular tourist resort. The lazy beach vacation in this city blends perfectly with trips to cultural centers, museums, and historical sites. And the buzzing bars, sparkling sangria, and temperamental bullfighters immerse any traveler in the hot Spanish atmosphere.

long_description.en: Coastal Alicante is home to 366,449 people. A total of 128 nationalities inhabit the city. Of these, 82% are Spanish, and 18% are foreigners. Most of them are Algerians, Moroccans, and Romanians. Residents of the Costa Blanca coast speak two languages — Spanish and Valencian.

description.en: The capital of the largest Balearic Island — Majorca — relaxed like the siesta, playful and joyful like sangria. There is a legend that this city appeared because the rugged Roman consul Caecilius Metellus, wearing a palm crown, got off the ship and fell in love with the land by the Mediterranean Sea from the first sight. The past of Majorca is filled with tragic and happy events, so the city got a fascinating architectural layout — a unique combination of Arabic and European cultures. And Spanish nature became a great frame for this exceptional city.

long_description.en: Palma de Mallorca ranks 8th in Spain in terms of population. According to 2019 statistics, 461,196 people live here. The 2017 census showed that 26.6% of citizens were born outside of Spain: 9.6% were born in European Union countries and 17% in other countries. Citizens of more than 25 states represent the national diversity of the city. The largest ethnic groups are Spanish (Castilians), Catalans, Germans, Bulgarians, English, Moroccans, Chinese, and Argentines.

description.en: Without any exaggerations, this place can be called one of the most beautiful spots on the planet. The city is safely surrounded by the Sierra de Guadarrama mountain range. Madrid will impress you with its natural landscapes and contemporary architectural solutions of a huge megalopolis.

long_description.en: Madrid is a multi-million-strong city, the most populated one in the country. Though the Spaniards compile the majority of the population, the immigrants form the rest of the population. This is a native city for Catalans, Castilians, Basques, Romani, Galicians. That’s why the languages of these ethnic groups are used on the same level as Spanish. There are also plenty of Arabs, the Japanese, Jews, and other national minorities. No wonder, Madrid is frequently called the shake of nationalities, languages, and cultures.

description.en: Santiago de Compostela is the capital of the Galicia community, which sprang up around one of the most significant world pilgrimage centers — the Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela. Most of the city sights belong to the Christian religion, although there are interesting museums and examples of unusual Spanish architecture. According to its religious significance, Santiago de Compostela is in third place among Catholics — right after Rome and Jerusalem. For more than 10 centuries, pilgrims have come here who follow the Way of Saint James the Great to bow to the relics of one of the apostles of Jesus Christ.

long_description.en:
The exact date of the founding of Santiago de Compostela is unknown. It is said that from 711 to 739, it belonged to the Arabs but was conquered from them by the King of Asturias, Alfonso I. After the Galician hermit, Pelayo found the relics of Saint James in 814; they built a temporary chapel at their resting place. According to legend, he followed a guiding star, which gave the city the second part of the name - in Latin, Campus Stellae means "place marked by a star." It received the first part in honor of Santiago, one of the disciples of Jesus Christ, whom Galicians consider their patron.

In the IX century, the chapel was successively replaced by two cathedrals. The illustrious warlord, Hajib al-Mansur, destroyed the latter. The present cathedral began construction in 1075 by King Alfonso VI of Castile, taking the basilica of St. Sernin in Toulouse as his model. Historians have quite detailed information about the building thanks to the Calixtinus Codex. This manuscript was accidentally discovered in 1895 on the temple's territory and contained a lot of interesting information about the stages of its construction. The cathedral was completed and consecrated in 1128. Today it is recognized as the most spacious in Europe.

The discovery of the relics of St. James transformed the small town into one of the major pilgrimage centers of Catholicism and brought it worldwide fame.

In 2000 Santiago de Compostela was designated the cultural capital of Europe, and in 2004 it hosted its first Orthodox liturgy.

description.en: Zaragoza is the capital of the province of the same name and autonomous region of Aragon in Spain. The city with a rich history has retained in its appearance the features of the cultures of all the people that previously lived here. You can see the echoes of the Roman, Christian, Arab and Jewish periods of the history of Zaragoza here. Ancient walls, Moorish palaces, baroque temples give a special charm to this ancient city. And modern buildings, wide streets, and magnificent parks add the elusive charm of youth and freshness. Zaragoza is a cozy provincial city where a pleasant vacation is accompanied by incredible discoveries.

long_description.en:
The Iberians have inhabited the land of the present city since ancient times. In the first century B.C., the Roman army conquered this territory. By order of Emperor Octavian Augustus, Colonia Caesaraugusta was founded. It grew rapidly with the construction of a forum, theater, and public baths. According to tradition, in the first century A.D., the Christian apostle James preached in the city.

After the Romans were the Visigoths who ruled the city. In the VIII century, the Arab period of Zaragoza's history began. The city became an outpost of the Moors in the struggle against Christian Northern Spain.

King Alfonso I of Aragon and Navarre conquered Zaragoza in the early twelfth century. Gradually it turned into the prosperous capital of the kingdom.

Jewish riots in Spain marked the end of the XIV century. But the Jews of Zaragoza did not suffer from them. However, a hundred years later, the Jews and Arabs were still expelled from the city, which greatly reduced the number of its inhabitants.

Zaragoza's history's tragic but glorious period falls at the beginning of the nineteenth century. The city withstood two sieges of Napoleon's French army, which lasted for a year. All the inhabitants, including women and children, rose to the defense. The losses of the townspeople were very high - up to 50 thousand people. But they did not surrender Zaragoza.

In 1936, during the Spanish Civil War, General Franco's rebels seized the city. Then more than 3.5 thousand republicans were executed.

The second half of the XX century was the city's economic development period. Zaragoza became a prosperous city, comfortable to live in and attractive to tourists.

description.en: Cartagena is an ancient city in southeastern Spain, which is part of the autonomous community of Murcia. It is located on a plain between mountain ranges, on the shores of the azure Mediterranean Sea. In this city, people do not pay attention to the time, which is why they are in no hurry. Once you arrive here, it is recommended to spend the day exploring ancient ruins and buildings; enjoying delicious national food; sunbathing on local beaches. Subsequently, Cartagena is a small Spanish town with elements of antiquity, which is simply created for hiking. No wonder more than a hundred cruise ships land here annually.

On the shore of the Bay of Biscay in the Basque Country lies one of the most beautiful cities in Spain — San Sebastian (Donostia). The city is often called the cultural capital of Europe. And its beaches and developed infrastructure attract tourists from many countries of the world. People come here for the sake of the ocean, amazing architecture reminiscent of Paris, magnificent views, Michelin restaurants, and amazing local cuisine. San Sebastian is famous for its many festivals, pinchos bars, and memorable holidays.

long_description.en:
The history of the city begins with the appearance on these lands of the monastery of San Sebastian in the early XI century. After 180 years, the monks were gifted the surrounding land, and the village grew up near it. The fortunate location on the shores of the bay and at the crossroads of trade routes to France led to the city's flourishing, which became a major port.

In the XIII century, the town was conquered by the Castile armies, and its port became the base of the military fleet of this state. A little later, the Castilian authorities allowed the port to be used as a base for the Spanish navy as well.

The second half of the XIII century brought decay and frequent fires to the city. At the end of the XV century, the most terrible was a fire, which almost completely destroyed San Sebastian. However, the city quickly revived, and new buildings were built of stone.

At the beginning of the XIX century, San Sebastian was attacked by French and then Portuguese troops. But within ten years, it was rebuilt and became the country's financial center.

Gradually, summer residences of aristocratic families from Spain and France sprang up on the city's coast. At the end of the XIX century, there was a residence of the Spanish Queen Maria Christina of Austria. The city became a fashionable European resort.

The first decades of the XX century were called the beautiful era of San Sebastian. Spain maintained neutrality during the First World War. High society from many European countries came to the resort.

The city did not suffer during the Civil War in 1936 nor during World War II. This made San Sebastian a true gem of Spain, a favorite vacation spot for surfers and connoisseurs of ancient architecture.

description.en: Bilbao is a city in the north of Spain, the largest port and industrial center of the country. It does not feel like the Spain that travelers are used to: you will not hear the sound of wooden castanets, and you will not be treated to paella. Bilbao is impressive in size. It is not a small and cozy town in Europe, but a large industrial center, not without its charm. The place is surrounded by mountains and thick greenery, which attracts tourists from all corners of the world. Here you will not see old architectural buildings, but it is in Bilbao where you can learn the charm of modern art.

long_description.en: The people of Bilbao love to party, as evidenced by the duration of their festivals and celebrations. In this, they are very similar to Spaniards, but they have significant differences in other respects. Firstly, the locals strongly reject talking about national identity because they do not consider themselves Spaniards and refer specifically to the Basque. Secondly, it is customary to speak the Basque language, which is not similar to any European. Thirdly, the locals are very fond of sports, especially soccer.

description.en: As an expert tourist would say: He who never been to Toledo, had never been to Spain. And he would be absolutely right. The ancient city, which at different times was an integral part of the Roman, Visigothic, Arabic, and Spanish cultures, was poetized in Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra’s and Lope de Vega’s works. It gently keeps the spirit of historical events, and attracts with its magical architecture of the old churches, synagogues, and former mosques. Even today, the city serves as a background for significant historical films and serials. Brave Don Quixote la Mancha, who fought with white windmills, became a lucking symbol of Spain a long time ago. And which you can view in the vicinity of Toledo.

long_description.en:
The history of Toledo began with the small settlement, where Celtic and Iberian tribes (back in the pre-Roman period) were building their fortresses. Further, the territory was conquered many times. In 192 BC, Roman general Marcus Fulvius Nobilior founded here his outpost and named it Toletum. In 411, the nomadic tribe (the Alans) settled in this small village. Seven years later, an early Germanic tribe of the Visigoths located on the territory and made Toletum their capital. In this status, it lasted till 711.

In 712, the Moors conquered the territory. After the Visigoths’ banishment, the Moors renamed Toletum into Ṭulayṭulah. But in 1085, Alfonso VI of Castile oppressed these lands and located the residence of the Castilian kings. Once, the Muslim city Ṭulayṭulah became the Christian Toledo. The residence occupied the place for 5 centuries, until 1561, when Philip II of Spain removed his possessions to Madrid. 

During the wars on the Iberian peninsula (the Reconquista epoch), Toledo was the capital of Spain and carried a name of the City of the Three Cultures. Jewish, Christian, and Muslim movements were deeply intertwined in all the fields, that Toledo wore the name of the Reconquista symbol. 

Since the 16th century, under the reign of Charles I of Spain, Toledo became the capital of the Holy Roman Empire. However, Toledo lost its position as a capital to Valladolid, and then — to Madrid. 

The Spanish Civil War overtook Toledo, along with Spain, from 1936 to 1939. About a thousand of general Franco’s supporters, led by general Moscardó, captured the ancient fortification Alcázar in 1936 and held the building 70 days against overwhelming Spanish Republican forces. Then, the Francoist forces, who came to help, deblocked the Alcázar and brutally avenged the citizens.

Fortunately, the event of the wars of the 20th century didn’t cardinally affect the town image, and most parts of its ancient architecture remained up to now.

Today, Toledo is the capital of the similar province and the autonomous community of Castile-La Mancha. It has preserved the features of the Medieval town and now gratifies tourists with unique narrow streets, ancient temples, castles, and fortresses against the background of rich nature. Toledo has been declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO since 1986.

description.en: Florence sounds like music and fills with inspiration. This beautiful Italian city hides among green hills on the banks of the Arno River in the heart of Tuscany. Bright sun, blue sky, the whole palette of colors reflected in the flowers of parks and gardens, street musicians — all this makes the city charming and so attractive to tourists. It's breathtaking when you think about the names associated with Florence, the great people who wandered these streets, inspired by this magical nature. This is where Leonardo da Vinci, Petrarch, Sandro Botticelli, Michelangelo, Dante worked and created their masterpieces. Florence is the very embodiment of the spirit of the Renaissance. It was here that the first advanced ideas in art, culture, science appeared. In Florence, everything is imbued with love for art and luxury, harmoniously combining the lush splendor of architecture and its refinement. Come and enjoy the unique masterpieces and recharge yourself with the powerful energy of this fantastic city.

long_description.en:
The distant ancestors of the modern inhabitants of Florence were representatives of the ancient culture of Villanova, who settled in these places in the X century BC. They were replaced by Etruscans, who were attracted by the fertile blooming land of the future Tuscany. With the coming of Julius Caesar, there were many descendants of the Roman Empire in this area. The majority of modern Florence's population is not indigenous, but many of them are Italians. A minority of the population are immigrants from Eastern Europe and Arabs.

The Florentines are temperamental, sociable, expansive, and have graceful manners and impeccable taste. They adore their city and are always ready to help tourists and to admire Florence together with them.

description.en: In the north of Italian Tuscany, at the mouth of the Arno River, lies one of the most visited city museums in Europe — Pisa. The Leaning Tower of Pisa brought worldwide fame — a “falling” landmark of the Middle Ages. But the city has prepared many more wonders for travelers: paved streets with colorful houses, small picturesque squares, magnificent temples, beautiful palaces, unique museums, and magnificent parks. You can wander around Pisa indefinitely, discovering incredibly interesting places in the old town.

long_description.en: According to the 2008 data, more than 80 thousand people live in the city. Most of the townspeople are Italians by nationality. The city also has natives of Germany, Slovenia, Albania, Greece, and France.

description.en: Having lost independence in the 16th century, the Siena Republic has sunk into oblivion, and its capital has remained behind the board of political and cultural life. But it was this annoying event that allowed Siena to turn into a photographically accurate reproduction of the Italian Middle Ages over the centuries. The city seemed to forever fall asleep on top of a hill under the rays of the subtropical sun in the guise created by palaces and cathedrals of brick. Their walls keep the buzz of bazaars, the secrets of merchant deals and political intrigues, and also remember the horrors of the black death (epidemic of plague), which destroyed almost the entire population in the middle of the 14th century. However, despite its ancient appearance, youth is in full swing in the city, because almost half of its population is students of the local university. And twice a year, residents give Siena its former metropolitan grandeur by staging the Palio festival in the main square of Piazza del Campo — spectacular horse races in which the Siena contractions compete.

long_description.en: Siena is now home to more than 50,000 people, almost half of whom are students at the local university. You'll find cultural and national diversity among them, while the natives are Italians who are used to an unhurried life within the ancient city's walls.

description.en: In vino veritas — in wine lies the truth. This famous Latin expression is best suited for a brief description of Montepulciano. The ancient Italian city lies on a high Tuscan hill, 120 kilometers from Florence, and 180 kilometers from Rome. Arriving here, tourists know that you can try the original Italian red wine Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, which has been produced since the 17th century. It is clear that for a wine, you need a great snack, and here it is in abundance. Fine Pecorino cheese (Pecorino Romano) is another Montepulciano trademark. You should definitely order this cheese at the local restaurants. The best kinds are produced in medieval mansions, and there are a lot of them. No coincidence, director Chris Weitz chose the views of this city as the scenery for the adaptation of New Moon, the second book of The Twilight Saga by Stephenie Meyer. Beautiful palaces and cathedrals of the Renaissance period, built during the Medici time, as if inviting to plunge into the sea of the architectural charm of southern Tuscany. Against the backdrop of the picturesque hills and narrow streets of the Italian chamber town, they look even stricter and more beautiful.

long_description.en:
Ancient legends say that Montepulciano was founded by the Etruscan king Lars Porsena. And this is about the V century B.C. Many city residents are happy to identify themselves as descendants of the Etruscans. However, archaeological research has disproved the connection between this branch of civilization and the Italians. However, already in those early days, there were vineyards and thermal springs.

In 568, together with other Italian lands, it was conquered by the Lombards. The ancient Germanic tribe founded the Lombard state, whose center was located on the territory of modern Lombardy. Montepulciano served as a defensive fortress against barbarian raids for a long time. For this purpose, defensive structures were built there.

Since the twelfth century, Montepulciano had been conquered by the Republic of Siena, which had established itself in the southern part of Tuscany. To seriously oppose these attempts, 200 years later, the city joined Florence in an alliance with it. In 1511, at the behest of the Medici dukes, the disputed territory on the hill was surrounded by high and thick walls. Together, Siena's claims were repulsed.

The main temples and sumptuous palaces from the XVI century were built in Montepulciano. Many of the buildings belonged to the famous Florentine architect Giuliano da Sangallo and his relatives, who worked on behalf of Lorenzo de' Medici. Most of these medieval architectural gems are still preserved in Montepulciano today. It is worth coming here just to see them.

By the end of the XVI century, Siena was annexed to the Duchy of Florence. The former importance of Montepulciano as a defensive point was lost. Since then, the city has led a measured existence based on wine production and the development of the food industry. It has become, in fact, a resort where wealthy nobles go to rest or settle permanently.

Today, tens of thousands of tourists visit Montepulciano every year. They are attracted by the unique atmosphere created by the ancient monuments, surrounded by picturesque hills, and maintained by the hospitable people of the town.

description.en: Livorno is an extraordinary Italian city located in the west of Toscana, 25 km from Pisa, on the coast of the Ligurian Sea. In fact, it is one of the youngest cities in Toscana, so do not expect to see old medieval attractions here. As the city that has always attracted merchants from around the world, Livorno is included in the list of the most important ports of the country. In turn, this group of people brought new customs, habits, exotic cuisine, and various religions to this place. Accordingly, diversity and multiculturalism are the main attractions of Livorno.

Palermo is the sunny capital of Sicily. This is an amazing ancient city in which the epochs peacefully passed one into another: throughout its long history, the city did not know the persecution of religious, cultural, and ethnic beliefs. There are preserved architectural monuments that keep traces of different periods of rule — Byzantine mosaics, Baroque churches, palazzos, and ancient catacombs. Palermo is a temperamental, noisy, and vibrant city. Historical sights here are generously diluted with aromas of Sicilian cuisine, bright sun, pebble beaches, and the gentle Tyrrhenian Sea, which is part of the Mediterranean Sea. There is still a mafia here. The authorities do not deny this, but claim that the mafia does not touch tourists.

long_description.en:
According to statistics in 2018, Palermo is home to 663,770 people. The population growth occurred in the postwar years, as people from other regions of Sicily came here in search of work.

The official religion in the city is Catholicism.

description.en: The sunniest and one of Italy's largest cities, Catania, is comfortably located at the foot of Etna, the largest active volcano in Europe, on one of the eastern shores of Sicily. The hot climate, the beautiful seacoast of the Ionian Sea, and the breathtaking views attract tourists from all over the world. In other words, Catania can be considered a prosperous city. Long streets are lined with shops, boutiques, restaurants, and cafes. Besides, the local hotels provide the highest quality services to their guests. In turn, the nightlife of Catania is noisy and varied. Tourists and locals can visit numerous discos, luxury nightclubs, atmospheric pubs, and round-the-clock restaurants that familiarize the city guests with the elements of Sicilian cuisine. At the same time, Catania is famous for its unusual history. Based on historical information, the city was populated by different people who left their imprint on its culture and traditions. In the city, you can visit the architectural monuments of the Roman Empire, ancient Greece, the Renaissance, and the Middle Ages.

long_description.en:
The history of Catania began as early as 729 B.C. when the Greeks came to this land. In 476 B.C., the settlement was conquered by the cruel tyrant from Syracuse, Hieron I. He expelled all the locals and named the town Etna. After his death, the inhabitants returned, renaming the city back to Catania. But they did not live here in peace for long. The next ruler of Syracuse once again seized the land for the next 150 years, and the inhabitants were sold into slavery.

From 263 B.C. until the V century A.D. Catania was part of the Roman Empire. The city developed its economy, culture, and infrastructure during this time. A forum (its ruins can still be seen today), a theater, an amphitheater, a circus, and an odeon were built there. There was also a water supply system.

After the fall of the Roman Empire, the city was ruled by the Byzantine Empire. In 827, the Arabs arrived on the island, and in 1071 they were forced out by the Normans.

In 1169 there was a great earthquake that significantly destroyed the city. 30 years later, the dynasty, which the city's inhabitants supported, captured and partially burned it. Catania was freed from feudal dependence only in 1240.

In 1347, a plague came to the city that killed almost the entire local population.

In 1669 and 1693, two strong eruptions of Etna almost wiped the city off the face of the earth. But residents did not give up and restored Catania from the ruins. The materials used for the construction were black lava and light limestone.

In 1837 and 1848, Catania rebelled against the Bourbons. A little later, it became part of United Italy and began its rapid development, slowing down only during World War II.

description.en: Azure sea, magnificent mountains, splendid palaces, gothic cathedrals, and medieval streets. Taormina is a city that makes you choose between meditative doing nothing on the beach and an unharried guided tour around the ancient quarters. Between shopping for exclusive items and a guided tour to the most famous active volcano Etna. Between amazing almond wine and wonderful coffee from a small cozy café, the owner of which knows a magic way to make it. When in Taormina, you start to plan your next trip here.

long_description.en:
Taormina owes its appearance to several ancient Greek sailors who were thrown ashore by a shipwreck at the foot of Monte Tauro. Later they told their fellow villagers about this picturesque place, and in 735 B.C., the first Greek settlers settled down there. The city was named Tauromenion. The ancient period was not a quiet one - the city passed from one ruler to another, and in 210 B.C., it was surrendered to the Romans. It was even part of the short-lived slave state of Sicily.

At the end of the I century, Taormina became Christian and fought long and painfully for its faith. But in 902, it was conquered by the Arabs, rebuilt, and renamed, but still, it was not conquered completely. Already in 1078, the Normans returned the city to the bosom of Christianity.

In the XIX century, it gained fame as a popular European resort. And all thanks to the great Goethe, who traveled here and was struck by the beauty of the city and the unique climate. It was visited by the members of the noble families and even royal families, as well as bohemians. Hugo and Nabokov, Maupassant and Dumas, and Dali and Wagner all praised Taormina. Today, a small town with thousands of years of history and carefully preserved past monuments still attracts tourists.

description.en: Shopping is the first thing which comes to our minds when somebody mentions Milan. And it’s not surprising! Sales here happen twice a year and the number of fashionable boutiques per one square meter is the highest in Europe. Fashion weeks, stylish Italian ladies and gentlemen, noisy streets, a fast pace of life – Milan is fundamentally different from other cities in Italy. Even the coffee here is weak and served with milk in the evening - that’s an inexcusable frivolity for the true Italians. But you can excuse everything to Milan as it combines everything we love in Italy: its history, architecture, art, cuisine, and of course, its impeccable style.

long_description.en:
Despite its rich and vivid history, the representatives of two nationalities live in Milan: the Italians and Lombards. But the city doesn’t have a problem with people. Annually, tourists from all corners of the world come to explore it.

Unlike the majority of the Italians, local citizens are extremely punctual and have an excellent knowledge of English. Moreover, the Milaneses are gallant and tactful. They mention by name just their friends and relatives. Colleagues and acquaintances are called by the last name only.

description.en: When it comes to Italy, the imagination immediately draws high castles of the Middle Ages, the ancient narrow cobblestone pavements, streets filled with flowers, espresso, parmesan, sculptures, operetta, small cozy cafes with wicker furniture. And also cities like Rome, Venice, Milan, Verona, even Palermo immediately come to mind. But for some reason, Bergamo is not associated with such an Italian idyll. And in vain! This small cozy town absolutely coincides with the idea of the traditional image of Italy. Moreover, it makes it more expressive and distinct. Without a provincial town as vintage as Bergamo, Italy's character would be imperfect. It is like the missing piece in the puzzle that connects all the other parts together: once it takes its place, a beautiful picture emerges. It is composed of many puzzles in unique and slightly motley integrity! And at the same time, you can confidently say that such an Italy, with the taste of bergamot and the majesty of the mountains, you have not yet seen! The picturesque Lake Como and the foothill valley of the Alps give a special beauty to the city. Bergamo breathes freshness with retrospectives into the past, as UNESCO fully protects the town. For so many centuries, the paradox of Bergamo is that with so many authentic sights, it remains a little-known city. Today, however, it is possible to break stereotypes and take a trip on the intricately intertwined trails of Bergamo. It will be a great investment in your impressions!

Bari, nestled on the heel of an Italian "boot," is unlike any other city in Italy. It is remembered for its measured, calm rhythm of life and cozy courtyards. Time slows down here, and the stunning atmosphere gives a sense of real Italian flavors: pizza, coffee, and laundry, hanging on a narrow old street from the balcony. Almost at every step, there is a church, and walking through the old atmospheric courtyards, you hear emotional Italian speech everywhere. In this city, you want to devote yourself to the atmosphere of complete tranquility and feel the real life of a small port city in Italy.

long_description.en:
A total of 622,287,000 people live in the city. Most residents (97%) are Italian, 2% are Albanian, and 1% are Greeks and migrants from Africa.

The number of children under the age of 18 in Bari is equal to the number of pensioners living there.

description.en: Among all the cities in Italy, Alberobello can be called one of the most amazing and interesting. It is a highlight of the Bari region, part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site, an important tourist center. You can hardly find a variety of entertainment in Alberobello, but this city gives its guests something more. The magical atmosphere, the spirit of antiquity in every building, the stories and legends that have been passed down through generations — it is very easy to fall in love with such an Italy!

long_description.en:
The first mention of a settlement in the Itria valley dates back to the XVI century. Around this time, Duke Andrea Matteo III of the Acquaviva dynasty brought his peasants here. They began cultivating the land and settling in a new place, but the local areas were subject to special laws. The feudal lord had to pay a tax to settle on the land belonging to the King of Naples, but Andrea Matteo III did not want to do that.

To solve the tax problem, the duke ordered the peasants to build special stone houses called trulli. Their main feature was the presence of stone, which was laid in the base. It was enough to remove this stone that the house crumbled in a moment. Thus, when the duke learned that the royal tax collectors were approaching, the houses in the settlement were quickly destroyed. In this case, it was not necessary to pay taxes, but the peasants had to rebuild their homes anew each time.

In 1797, King Ferdinand of the Bourbon dynasty tried to change the situation and granted Alberobello freedom. However, frightened peasants continued to build trulli; only a few people ventured to build new houses with entrenchment. Classic trulli with a domed roof appeared in Alberobello until 1925, until the Italian authorities issued a law according to which it was forbidden to erect such structures. In this case, it was possible to repair old houses, but it was not possible to build new ones.

The official abolition of the trulli tax dates back to 1979. Since then, all such houses have been privately owned, and the city has gained fame as one of the most unusual in Italy, which attracts many tourists. Since 1996, Alberobello has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

description.en: The olive groves and vineyards are carefully embracing the golden beaches of Brindisi, washed by the Adriatic Sea and warmed by the sun. It can be hasty and bustling as well as lazy and meditative. This rather small town is ideal for a secluded family holiday and for active pastime. Brindisi has managed to preserve the historical monuments, which are thousands of years old, and built near them a new, modern infrastructure of the contemporary metropolis, achieving absolute harmony. Even a few days spent in Brindisi will bring unforgettable impressions and inexpressible emotions.

Every stone of the pavement had been brilliantly polished through 2000 years of the city’s existence. This is a living history book that everyone should read. This is Rome. When somebody mentions the Eternal City, it’s impossible not to recall Caesar, gladiators, Colosseum, Pope, and the tiniest country in the world, Vatican City. You can’t keep thinking of grandiose ruins, ancient Pantheon, the powerful Roman Empire that gave us almost all domestic items we use nowadays, philosophy, art, and literature. Rome is not just an average city and the capital of Italy. It became a sacred place where you can trip 2000 years back in history and see how everything had begun.

long_description.en:
Modern Romans have many similarities with their ancient ancestors. They are still unmindful of time and don’t take being late seriously. By the way, in defense of local citizens, it’s important to mention that they had a weird system of time reading. The length of the hour depended on the seasons. Thus, in summer, one hour could last 75 minutes, while in winter it equals 44 minutes.

Modern Romans don’t hurry anywhere, enjoy their lives, and are considered to be European long-livers. The average longevity of men is 74 years and of women is 82. Mind, that people here treat siesta seriously. Therefore, all banks, shops, and restaurants are closed from 1 PM to 3 PM.

description.en: Venice is an extraordinary city in terms of its architecture, history, and lifestyle. The whole world knows it as a city on water, the center of masquerades, and the motherland of Marco Polo and Antonio Vivaldi. It has the most expensive housing, products, and even transport. Despite everything, over 18 million tourists visit it annually and fall in love with Venice at first sight. What is this place? And why does it attract tourists all over the world like a magnet?

long_description.en: The number of the population in Venice is decreasing thick and fast. There are various reasons for this. However, the main cause is the incredibly high prices on housing and life in general. The Venetians are never in a hurry. They prefer a slow flow of time to the rapid lifestyle. They resemble the quiet waters of the Venetian canals. These people live a regular life and revere traditions.

description.en: Verona is a city pierced with rays of the bright Italian Sun and love. It is located in the northern part of Italy, not far from Lake Garda, on the river of Adige. Due to William Shakespeare, Verona became the symbol of eternal love. Couples from all over the world come here to dive into the marvelous story of the great playwright, stand under the balcony of Juliet’s House, make a wish, and feel the incredibly romantic atmosphere of this place. Who knows, maybe your eternal love story shall also start here.

long_description.en:
The Italians compile the majority of Verona’s population. However, one can easily call this city multinational. Representatives of various cultures and nations live here: the Chinese, Arabs, Indians, emigrants from the countries of Eastern Europe. Throughout the centuries, wars, epidemics, natural cataclysms influenced the population size. Nowadays, it has increased considerably due to a high flow of emigrants.

The Veroneses are extremely kind-hearted and open people. They will definitely help and support you. You can easily find a common language and see eye to eye with a local despite the language barrier. The characteristic feature of native citizens is that they are the biggest romantics in Italy. There’s no other way once you are in the city of love!

description.en: Located just 37 kilometers from Venice, Padua does not hide in the shadow of the famous city. On the contrary, it occupies an important place on the map of Italy and annually meets hundreds of thousands of tourists. In the city, you can see the country's oldest university, stroll through the unique Botanical Garden, and learn more about the life of St. Anthony. This is a territory with a unique atmosphere that no photograph conveys. Here you can spend a busy day or stay for the weekend — Padua will definitely not let you get bored!

As a considerable center for winter sports, Cortina d'Ampezzo serves the functions of a famous alpine resort. For example, the 1956 Winter Olympics were held here. Nowadays, this area is considered a significant destination for championships and the World Cups related to bobsleigh, skeleton, and skiing. Besides, the picturesque town located in the Dolomites has a long history. In the second half of the 19th century, the city became a popular center of mountaineering. In the 30s of the last century, it was widely known as one of the best ski resorts of Cortina d'Ampezzo. Here you can also visit the gallery of modern art and the Basilica of the Holy Apostles Philip and James.

An ancient city of Treviso is located nearly 40 minutes’ drive from Venice and is very similar to its neighbor. Here you will also find ancient castles, canals (that were made to protect from enemies), and small tile-roofed houses. But by contrast with Venice, you won’t see crowds of tourists here who prevent from admiring attractions and feeling the atmosphere of Northern Italy. You should walk slowly along cobbled Treviso streets, contemplate the architecture peering into hidden backyards, and of course, enjoy delicious food. Dessert Tiramisù worth special attention. It was invented here, in Treviso.

Bolzano is the administrative center of the Italian Autonomous Province of the same name. The city is located on a picturesque plateau surrounded by majestic Alpine peaks. Since ancient times, the Italians, Germans, and the Ladin people have lived here. Thanks to the close fusion of the three cultures, Bolzano stands out for its charming identity. Its historical center seems to have descended from a pastoral picture by a German artist. And the influence of Italian culture gives the city its vividness and brightness. The mountain air, incredibly beautiful landscapes, amazing architecture — Bolzano pleases guests with its unique beauty.

Cagliari is not only the capital of Sardinia but also one of the largest cities in southern Italy. Numerous tourists of the whole world tend to come here in order to enjoy the picturesque panorama of the Bay of Angels and relax on the pristine beaches of Poetto and Kalamaska. Moreover, Cagliari has preserved a variety of historical monuments and architectural attractions. For example, the necropolises of the Tuvikseddu hills have been famous since the time of Punic wars. The city has a lot of museums, churches, and cathedrals, although ordinary walks through the picturesque quarters of the city offer the opportunity to get positive impressions as well. It can be explained by the fact that Cagliari has preserved the bright and unusual architecture of the era of Spanish kings.

Olbia is the first in Sardinia to meet tourists with well-maintained beaches, water activities, lovely restaurants, and cozy cafes. For a reason it is called the gates of the island — there is a large port and an international airport. In addition to a beach holiday, the city can offer the curious guests the well-preserved legacy of the Roman Empire, medieval architectural masterpieces, religious shrines, and a huge park, spread right in the middle of the city. Olbia has a typical Italian character — funny, noisy, and a little mysterious. It has something to attract tourists, rather than to surprise, and often, even amaze their imagination.

Naples is one of the most famous Italian cities, third-largest after Rome and Milan, the largest in the south of Italy, the capital of the Campania region. It is located in the picturesque bay of the Gulf of Naples. As a rule, Naples is associated with two completely incompatible things — Mount Vesuvius and pizza. The first one has made the city famous for its eruptions that had killed many people. But the second has made thousands of people around the world happy with its existence. Every year, hundreds of tourists come here for top-class pizza, and nothing can stop them.

long_description.en:
The people of Naples are the ancestors of the ancient Greeks and Romans who survived many wars. Most of the city's inhabitants are Italians, indigenous Neapolitans. In addition to them, Filipinos and Africans live here. According to the latest data, the city's population is over a million people.

Neapolitans are people who are very attached to their homes, patriots of their city. They have a strong character and an explosive temper. They love holidays, know how to eat and enjoy life, no matter what is in their hearts.

description.en: The main advantage of Sorrento is the absence of crowds, hustle, and bustle. Here you can spend hours wandering through quiet olive and lemon groves, or sitting on the coastal rocks, admiring the sunrises and sunsets. Beach holidays are not very common in the resort, and the coast is too rocky. But there are plenty of historical monuments to walk around and learn more about the city's history and traditions.

long_description.en:
The first Phoenician colony was founded on the site of Sorrento during the reign of ancient Rome. Later, the village grew and became a port, thanks to the lively trade of the Greeks with Naples and other cities of southern Italy. The Greek sailors called it Sireon (land of the sirens). During the war with the Phoenicians, the Romans captured the city and were so impressed by its beauty that many patricians began to build their villas there.

In the 90s B.C., civil disturbances broke out in Rome, provoked by Sulla. During the same period, the village was given the status of a municipality. It was mainly inhabited by war veterans who received their land plots as rent.

Sorrento received its autonomy in the VII century. It became a duchy under the protectorate of Naples. The Middle Ages was a very turbulent period for the city. It was ruled by Byzantines, Goths, Saracens, and even one of the Germanic tribes (Lombards).

In the X century, the Maritime Republic existed here for a while, but the Normans defeated it in the end. Then the Aragonese ruled the city, and in the XVI century, the Turks came, who were eventually expelled by the troops of Naples.

In 1860, during the Risorgimento (unification of the country), Sorrento became part of Italy. That was the end of Sorrento's troubles.

In modern times, the town became very popular as a resort. Such celebrities as Goethe, Nietzsche, Wagner, Byron, Dickens, Stendhal, and Gorky loved to stay here. In the late XX and early XXI centuries, Sorrento became a favorite holiday destination for tourists worldwide.

description.en: This beautiful port city on the Tyrrhenian Sea does not look too glazed and smoothed. It is bright and pulsating with energy. Here you would want to tirelessly roam the streets built thousands of years ago. Page by page, study the history of these lands. And relaxation on its beaches is a great way to rest and learn what Italian dolce vita is.

Positano is a charming resort town on the coast of the Tyrrhenian Sea in the Province of Salerno. A cascade of picturesque houses is located in three small valleys clutched between the sea and mountains. Convenient bay, a mild climate, sandy beaches surrounded by pine groves and lemon gardens — real heaven on Earth. Positano makes you fall in love with it. You cannot get enough of its air. The holidays in Positano will be the most peaceful and memorable.

long_description.en:
A mythic explanation of the town foundation is described in the local legend. Poseidon, the God of the seas, was captivated by the beauty of the nymph Pasitea. To make an impression on the beauty, he decided to give her a present — he founded a small but incredibly fascinating town and presented it to the nymph. The town was named after her. A great Ancient Greek poet Homer didn’t leave Positano behind. He described sweet-voiced Sirens, who lured ships on reefs, in his famous Odyssey. And according to Homer, they lived on the islands not far from Positano.

The town became a vacation spot for wealthy people back in the days of the Roman Empire in the 1 century. Merchants and patricians built stone mansions and villas here.

The heyday of the town came after the decline of the Roman Empire when Positano was included in the Amalfi Republic. Mansions were constructed, craft guilds and trading houses were opened, and coins were minted. 

In the 11th — 12th centuries, the town suffered from Saracens raids. During this period, watchtowers were brought up. You can see some of them nowadays.

In the 13th century, new houses of rich vacationers, luxury villas were built. 

But the golden age of the town came in the early 20th century. After the end of World War I, representatives of the European upper class began visiting the resort.

description.en: Amalfi is love at first sight. Nature has blessed this tiny Italian town with extraordinary landscapes that will follow you everywhere. The paradise of the Amalfi Coast is surrounded by the Lattari Mountains. Its winding roads overhang the cobalt blue waters of the Tyrrhenian Sea and its picturesque houses seem to be glued to the steep mountain slopes. The appearance of Amalfi was shaped back in the Middle Ages and has not changed much since then. Secluded coves, lemon gardens, olive groves, ancient buildings and elegant narrow streets still reflect the true Italian flavor. Life here flows in a measured and leisurely fashion. A journey to Amalfi is an opportunity to find inspiration, relax your mind, and believe in a fairy tale.

long_description.en:
According to a legend, Amalfi was the name of the beautiful nymph with whom Heracles was in love. It is believed that his beloved was buried here as well. Turning to the more prosaic chronicles, there were four powerful maritime republics in the IX-XIII centuries in Italy — Pisa, Genoa, Venice, and Amalfi. Their role was to create trade routes between Europe and the Orient, new ways and rules of commerce, and the foundations of maritime law. The Republic of Amalfi was chronologically the first. It was initially a Byzantine dominion and became independent in the middle of the IX century, after the famous sea battle of Ostia (849) and the complete defeat of the Saracen fleet.

The citizens of Amalfi established transshipment and trading bases in Constantinople, Syria, and Egypt. In 1135, the Amalfi fleet was defeated, and the city was looted. By the middle of the XII century, only memories of the Republic's former glory remained. Seafaring and fishing and the production of paper, limoncello liqueur, and traditional pasta were the main activities of the locals. However, history is unpredictable. Amalfi regained its fame and got a second chance thanks to its natural beauty.

Today, the city is the most famous center of tourism in Italy, and the Amalfi coast is among the 55 sites included in the UNESCO World Heritage List.

description.en: Capri is the main city of the Italian island of the same name. The municipality is often associated with a variety of terraces that are located above the sea. You can go upstairs on foot, by taxi, bus, or funicular. Simultaneously, it is recommended to choose the last option. People usually wait nearly 5 minutes for the funicular that arrives at a height of 650 m. As a result, tourists can admire a wonderful panorama of the Marina Grande and the Tyrrhenian Sea. Nearby, people can also visit the square named Piazza Umberto I, where the cafe tables are crowded. As the main city cathedral, the Cathedral of Santo Stefano was built in the 17th century. In addition, a walk across the pedestrian streets of the town is expected to bring positive emotions as well, because you will be offered the opportunity to enjoy the gorgeous scenery in the shade of orange trees.

Genoa is a picturesque city in the north of Italy, surrounded by two seas and the Apennine Mountains. Since ancient times, this area has been the center of trade, which brought good income for the entire region. It was here that Columbus and Paganini were born. This area is so impressive in its beauty and fabulous atmosphere that it is in great demand by filmmakers. It was in Genoa, the Lumiere brothers and Alfred Hitchcock filmed their movies. The Italians themselves are very fond of this resort city, but foreign tourists are just beginning to discover it.

long_description.en: Genoa is considered the most English city in Italy. The fact is that the inhabitants of England have long fancied this place. They not only regularly come here for holidays, but also buy property here. That is why, unlike other cities in Italy, in Genoa, locals speak excellent English, and all signs and menus are duplicated.

description.en: Portofino is a tiny northern Italian city located in the bay of San Fruttuoso near the Ligurian Sea. All beaches of this area are marked with the Blue Flag for their crystal clearness. For about two hundred years, Portofino has been considered a prestigious resort city, chosen by celebrities. At different times, Sigmund Freud, Ernest Hemingway, Guy de Maupassant, Madonna, George Clooney, Sharon Stone, and Demi Moore rested in this bay. Portofino is a picturesque symbiosis of Mediterranean nature, bright houses, and azure water, which looks like a painting by an Italian artist.

long_description.en: Portofino can be considered home to about 400 people who are actively engaged in tourism. In the holiday season, the population of the city increases several times due to visitors.

description.en: A beautiful city of Bologna lies in the north of Italy at the foot of the Apennine Mountains. The city is famous for its medieval architecture, red-tiled rooftops, and the oldest university in Western Europe, so it is often called the cultural capital of the country. The streets of Bologna are always filled with loud students who add a modern touch to the age-old look of the city. The elegance of Italian architecture, unique museums, and youthful charm of Bologna are fascinating and easily have you smitten with the city.

long_description.en: According to the 2016 census, almost 400,000 people live in the city. Most citizens are Italians. The city is also home to people who come from different EU and Asian countries.

description.en: Rimini spreads on the Italian coast of the Adriatic Sea and is primarily known as a budget resort, where for relatively modest money, you will be offered quality service. This is a great place to relax with children, because the sea off the coast is shallow. On the other hand, there are a lot of clubs, bars, restaurants, and all kinds of entertainment, so adults will not be bored here either. Besides, Rimini is one of the few places where it is possible to combine a beach holiday with sightseeing. Monuments of ancient Rome and the Middle Ages are preserved in the town. This city still remembers how Julius Caesar wondered whether it was worth crossing the Rubicon. And, among other things, having settled in Rimini, you have the opportunity, after spending very little time, to get acquainted with another country — the miniature Republic of San Marino, located about 30 kilometers from Rimini.

Ravenna is a beautiful ancient city in eastern Italy near the Adriatic Sea (Emilia-Romagna region). Nature has awarded this place with extraordinary beauty. Picturesque landscapes around the Po River delta, sandy beaches and green valleys surround the city with lush vegetation. But first of all, Ravenna is famous for its mosaics. This type of art decorates many buildings throughout the city. A huge number of early Christian monuments, samples of medieval architecture and baroque are concentrated here. The oldest and most beautiful compositions of Ravenna are protected by UNESCO World Heritage Sites. This city was admired by talented poets and writers, its panoramas inspired George Byron, Dante Alighieri, Alexander Blok, Oscar Wilde, and Hermann Hesse. Ravenna is filled with art and tradition for centuries. “For a thousand years, unchanged,” once wrote Blok about Ravenna. His words remain relevant to this day.

long_description.en:
Researchers do not give the exact date of the foundation of Ravenna. It is only known that the Roman Empire established its colonies throughout the Padan Plain, including Ravenna, in the II century BC. The Romans built here the port of Classe, a powerful trading and military point for the entire Mediterranean. However, over the years, the coastline of the Adriatic Sea moved away. The process of silting contributed to the flow of the river Po (today, the city is 10 km from the Adriatic, and the sea is connected only by an artificial canal).

During the millennial history of its existence, Ravenna has been the capital of the different states three times. The ruler of the Western Roman Empire, Honorius, gave the city that status in 402. Together with his sister Galla Placidia, he established the imperial residence here. During this period, the whole of Italy suffered from the Great Migration of Peoples, while Ravenna was rapidly developing economically and culturally.

A new page in the history of the city began on September 2, 476. Then Odoacer dethroned the last emperor of the Roman Empire, Romulus. The leader of the Germanic tribes took these lands under his rule. Odoacer declared himself the leader of the Kingdom of Italy, in which Ravenna became the capital.

Ravenna remained the main city during the rule of the King of the Ostrogoths, Theodoric the Great. After a long siege in 493, the power was in his hands. Ravenna experienced another round of development during the reign of Theodoric.

After half a century, Ravenna was part of Byzantium for the next 200 years. During this period, Christianity flourished here; the city experienced its third wave of prosperity.

Ravenna was subjected to the Lombard Kingdom, the Venetian Empire, and the Papal States in the following years.

At the beginning of the XVII century, the sea flooded the city. Irrigation methods were used to restore Ravenna to its former state.

Since the XIX century, it has been a richly developed city in united Italy.

description.en: The charming city Modena lies in the Italian Emilia-Romagna region, between the Panaro and Secchia rivers. The homeland of the famous Parmesan cheese and balsamic vinegar “Aceto balsamico” is considered one of the gastronomic capitals of Italy. But Modena is known not only to gourmets. Many tourists come to the ancient city to see its magnificent temples and palaces, unique museums, and splendid parks. Picturesque Modena has given the world many famous people. Here were born the tenor Luciano Pavarotti, the famous racer Enzo Ferrari, the thinker Pico della Mirandola. Modena is an unusually colorful city in Italy, capable to surprise and inspire.

Turin is the capital of Piedmont at the foot of the snowy Alps. At first sight, you arrive in an unimpressive city, and it seems that it won’t surprise you. But Turin has incorporated all the charming things for which people like Italy. It will feed you delicious risotto, treat you with chocolate and a cup of flavored coffee, and give you a ride in a luxury car. This city gave gorgeous historical buildings by Filippo Juvarra, FIAT cars, hazelnut cocoa spread Nutella, Lavazza coffee, vermouth Martini, and a hot drink Bicerin to the world. Turin honors its centuries-old history and continues to keep pace with the times.

long_description.en: A total of 886,837 people live in the city. About 90% are Italians, and 10% are foreigners from Romania, Morocco, Albania, China, and Moldova.

description.en: Ancona is a major port in Central Italy and a well-known resort on the Adriatic coast. Beach recreation is not very popular here, in its classical sense. Although, there are shallow waters for families with children, and deep areas right at the coast for lovers to dive. The landscape of the area where the city is located in a succession of hills and picturesque valleys. This is why many tourists come here for active recreation: cycling, horse riding, and skiing. There are also suitable places for climbing and mountain climbing lovers. There are many hiking trails in the vicinity, and there are even several speleological routes.

long_description.en:
Ancona was founded by the Greeks around 390 BC. The population was engaged in trade. This was facilitated by the convenient harbor, which allowed trade with many cities on the Adriatic coast. A few centuries later, the city was conquered by Roman troops under the command of Gaius Julius Caesar. This happened just after his famous crossing of the Rubicon. Later, Emperor Trajan recognized the importance of the port in Ancona. It was very convenient for the Empire to trade with Dalmatia. Therefore the port was enlarged and fortified. And the city itself, thanks to the lively trade, began to grow rapidly.

In 774, Ancona joined the Papal States and remained part of them until 1100. Later it was declared an independent republic. This event provoked the aggression of the neighbors - no one wanted to miss the opportunity to take possession of such a large trading port. The city had to repel the attacks of the Venetian Republic, the Holy See, and the German emperors one by one. The last siege of 1173-1174 was especially bloody. During this period, the Archbishop of Mainz, a legate of Emperor Barbarossa, tried to conquer Ancona.

In 1532, power over the city again passed into the hands of the Vatican. A year later, with Pope Julius III's permission, fleeing from the Inquisition, Marranos arrived in Ancona. They settled in one of the quarters and built the first synagogue, which was later destroyed.

During the French Revolution, a republic was once again proclaimed in Ancona. But after the overthrow of Napoleon, the Pope regained power over the region, but not for long. In 1861 the city became part of the Italian Kingdom.

Ancona is now the administrative center of the Marche region and province of the same name. Various kinds of industries are developed in the city: shipbuilding and carriage construction, oil refining, glassware, and majolica production. At the same time, a lot of tourists come here every year for vacation.

description.en: Assisi is a real museum city, protected by UNESCO. The city is located on the high southern slope of Mount Subasio. First of all, Assisi is famous for the Basilica of Saint Francis situated in the monastery of the Sacred Convent. This 13th-century temple with famous frescoes includes the relics of St. Francis of Assisi. This person was born, lived, and died in the city, which is why and the temple was created in his honor. Today, it is one of the six great basilicas of the Catholic Church. Also, once you visit this city, take appropriate measures in order to find the grave of St. Clare of Assisi. In the middle of the 13th century, the Santa Chiara church was erected in her honor. In Arezzo, you also have the opportunity to find the ruins of the Etruscan and Roman eras, as well as other monuments of the medieval period.

Perugia is the administrative center of the Italian province of the same name and the capital of the Umbria region. This amazingly beautiful medieval town lies in the Tiber Valley in the very center of Italy, on a high hill and its five spurs, which form the main areas of Perugia. The image of the city is formed by ancient buildings, narrow winding streets, numerous steps, magnificent squares, and unique historical monuments. All this beauty is filled with a specific Italian flavor and an unforgettable atmosphere.

A small, cozy town named Lamezia Terme is located in the south of sunny Italy. Furthermore, the resort is situated in the administrative region of Calabria, in the province of Catanzaro, between the Ionian and Tyrrhenian (Mediterranean) seas. If Italy is represented in the shape of a boot, then Lamezia Terme is its front part. In turn, the Amato River and the Apennine Range form a heterogeneous landscape of the city. Nowadays, Lamezia Terme is widely known due to picturesque corners of nature with sand dunes and rocky landscapes; hills and plains; clean sea air with the aroma of oranges and rosemary; magnificent churches and museums; the ruins of ancient medieval castles and fortresses. At the same time, hot mineral springs are considered an essential part of this town. The thermal procedures are more effective when they are carried out in a beautiful historical place with the modern benefits of civilization. In other words, people have the opportunity to escape from the noisy bustle of megalopolises, get health benefits, and enjoy peace in the traditional Italian atmosphere in Lamezia Terme. This is a corner of Italy, which has not become tremendously popular yet.

Trieste is a territory embraced by mountains and washed by the sea. A little bit pompous, too decorated, and at the same time of the classically symmetrical and monumental city. It is its monumentality and lightness peculiar to all sea cities, creates unusual, unique contrast. A well-structured city center, with a clear street system, simply knocks down with a sudden seaside view. And the city paving stone on the horizon transforms into the sea. Trieste is charming, unique, diverse, and, without a doubt, is worth visiting.

Matera is an amazing rocky town, situated in southeastern Italy. This is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and its unique old part known as “the underground city”. Tourists from all over the world come to Matera to see evidence of people's incredible ability to adapt to any environmental conditions. Fantastic grottoes, rock churches with stalactites instead of columns, covered with ancient frescoes, tunnels, and streets that run one above the other — there are little places in the world where you can still see such landscapes. Matera is a distinctive corner of Italy, carefully preserving its history and attracting tourists with unusual architectural monuments.

Various stereotypes draw in our imagination an absolutely vicious and weird city of Amsterdam. However, you understand they are false after the first time you get acquainted with it. Amsterdam miraculously manages to become your city no matter who you are. Van Gogh’s creations are already waiting for all the fans of art; the floating flower market “Bloemenmarkt” and the renowned Keukenhof park will delight all the fanciers of flowers; Museum Quarter gives a cordial welcome to all the inquisitive tourists; Gassan Diamonds factory and museum can’t wait to meet the connoisseurs of diamonds. There, you shall learn and see the secrets of jewellery. No wonder, Amsterdam is called the city of diamonds. Needless to say that Amsterdam is a genuine paradise for cyclists. It’s bright, modern, and free – you should definitely meet it!

long_description.en: The population of the capital is extremely diverse! According to information received in 2009, 177 nationalities live here. It’s not surprising that Amsterdam is considered to be the most multinational city in the world. The majority of citizens of the capital have Dutch citizenship. At the same time, immigrants from non-European countries compile around 33 %.

description.en: Rotterdam is fairly called the architectural capital of Europe, and even the city of the future. Its image differs sharply from other major cities in the Netherlands, and is a showcase of modern design and urban planning. Its futuristic buildings and sculptures, which wonderfully combine with ancient monuments, numerous canals, ponds and islands of wildlife, will not leave anyone indifferent.

long_description.en:
The city's population is very international. The native Dutch constitute only a little more than half of its inhabitants. The largest minority groups are Surinamese, Turks, Moroccans, and natives of the Netherlands Antilles.

In 2009, Ahmed Abutaleb, a Dutchman with Moroccan roots, became Mayor of Rotterdam. This is the first time in Europe that a Muslim has become the head of a major city.

The people of Rotterdam are tolerant and friendly, and it's widespread to say hello to strangers here. Don't be surprised, and don't forget to respond to greetings.

description.en: The locals call Eindhoven “the city of light”. Also, it bears proud names of the most intellectual city in the world, a center of high technologies, modern art, and design. All these titles it got because of the Philips Company. Its work had a great influence on the development and layout of Eindhoven. Here you can find a monument to one of the founders of the corporation. The Philips Museum is one of the tourist attractions of the city. This city is aimed at the future. People here value art, are proud of sports achievements, and remember past success.

Utrecht is an administrative center of the eponymous province in the Netherlands. One of the oldest cities in the country is famous for its unique two-level canals. Once, it was a part of different Kingdoms and Empires and remembers many important historical events. It impacted its layout — narrow winding cobbled streets, lovely houses built in different styles, cathedrals of different centuries. The diversity of ancient architecture harmoniously neighbors with modern buildings of the ever young city where you will find the largest university in the Netherlands.

long_description.en:
At the end of the I century BC, there were settlements of the ancient Germanic tribes of the Batavi on the land of what is now Utrecht. On the site of one of them, the village of Traiectum, a Roman fortress of earth and wood, arose. It housed a garrison of soldiers numbering about 500 men. Because of the constant attacks of the Germanic tribes, the Roman legionaries left the fortress in the III century.

In the first half of the VII century, by order of the Frankish king Dagobert I, a church was built in Traiectum. Gradually, the settlement was revived. In the last years of the VII century, the bishop's chair appeared here and became the center of spreading Christianity in the surrounding areas.

At the beginning of the XII century, Traiectum received the status of a city and its new name, Utrecht. It is translated from Old Dutch as "the crossing of the lowland river". The river referred to the Rhine.

In the middle of the XVI century, the city came into the possession of Charles V of Habsburg, the Roman emperor. Then the lands of the Netherlands and Utrecht itself passed to his son, the Spanish King Philip II. This led to the establishment of Spanish rule.

The population was dissatisfied with Spanish rule, and the struggle for independence at the end of the XVI century resulted in the proclamation of the sovereignty of the Netherlands. But Spain did not officially give liberty to the state until the middle of the XVII century.

During World War II, Utrecht was occupied by German troops for five years. After the war, the city quickly recovered and gradually became one of the largest in the country.

description.en: Groningen is a major university city in the north of the Netherlands. It is ancient and, at the same time, very young — fervent, cheerful, student, scientific. It's also very cozy and homely, chamber-like. Groningen knows how to rest and work. It has his own traditions and his own vision of life. It's a city that will never be boring. Life here is booming day and night. But at the same time, Groningen can be absolutely serious, respecting traditions and carefully protecting them. It knows how to surprise and amaze — ancient architecture, parks, and squares, tours of numerous canals, museums with rare exhibitions. It is necessary to see Groningen because here, you can best feel the unique Dutch flavor.

This gingerbread town seems to have descended to the shores of the Baltic Sea from the tales of Andersen and the Brothers Grimm. It has a long, extraordinary, tragic, heroic history. It seems to have arisen from the ashes of war, becoming even more beautiful than it was before. They call it the capital of amber, the architectural pearl of Poland, and its tourist capital. This city has changed its name many times — Gdansk, Danzig, and Gdansk again.

long_description.en:
The name of Gdansk, referring to the city on the Motlawa River, was first mentioned in documents of 997. In the X-XI centuries, the Pomeranian princes ruled the city, and it became a prominent trading center. In 1308, the Teutonic Knights conquered Gdansk and built a fortress here. They renamed the city Danzig. In 1466, after the defeat of the Teutonic Order, the city returned to the Polish lands and regained its former name, Gdansk. At the same time, it received great privileges from the Polish king. The city minted its own coins and elected its own officials.

Its belonging to the merchant union of Hansa towns (1361-1669) was of great importance for the city's development, both under the Teutonic domination and during its being a part of Poland. Gdańsk played one of the leading roles in the Hanseatic League. In the XVI century, it became the biggest city in Poland and one of the biggest centers of European trade.

At the end of the XIX century, after the partition of Poland, Gdansk is part of Prussia. However, in 1807, Napoleon revived Poland and declared Gdansk a free city. But in 1815, Bonaparte suffered a final defeat, and Prussia got the city again.

After World War I, under the Treaty of Versailles, Danzig once again received the status of a free city, but under the general patronage of the League of Nations and Poland. But the majority of the city's population was German.

On September 1, 1939, German troops invaded Poland. And the war began here. A small Polish garrison heroically resisted the superior enemy forces for almost 150 hours near Gdansk (Danzig), on the Westerplatte Peninsula. The city was cleared of the Nazis in March 1945 by Soviet troops, but up to 80% of the buildings in the center of Gdansk were destroyed during the war.

Reconstruction of the city began as early as the late 1940s. Buildings of historical value were reconstructed. New buildings were erected instead of the ruins in the city center, in the style of Dutch mannerism, typical for the XVIII-century Gdansk. The imitation of the old times concerned only the facades, while the interiors contained entirely modern apartments.

Many famous people have lived and worked in Gdańsk, such as Johannes Hevelius (an astronomer and creator of astronomical instruments), Martin Opitz (a theorist of German poetics), Daniel Fahrenheit (a physicist who developed the temperature scale later named after him). The famous philosopher Arthur Schopenhauer was born in Gdańsk.

description.en: Krakow is the old capital of the Polish kingdom, nestled on the Vistula River's picturesque banks, a city with a thousand years of history, where monarchs were crowned, and the dragon was defeated. It preserves both the memory of the good and the scars of the tragic events in the history of Poland and humankind. Its architecture harmoniously combines the splendor of the Middle Ages, Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance, and Baroque styles with modern Art Nouveau and a student atmosphere that reigns today. Krakow and its Wawel Hill is the heart of Poland. For centuries, artisans and artists have created its unique image. Fortress-like buildings, valuable monuments, original sculptures, music festivals, street performances, lots of unusual cafes, beer bars, atmospheric cellars, jazz clubs, and theme restaurants for every taste and purse attract thousands of tourists from all over the world.

long_description.en:
In 1815, 95,000 people were living in the autonomous territory of Krakow. By 1843, the population had grown to 145,000. Most of the inhabitants (about 80%) professed Judaism. During World War II, most of Krakow's Jewish population was exterminated.

Today, the city is home to many foreigners who come here to work. Most of them come from the post-Soviet countries of Belarus, Ukraine, and Moldova. Students from all over the world come to Krakow's universities to study. That is why during the academic terms, most of the population is young, and Krakow proudly bears the title of an academic city, a center of high-level students.
