Krakow citizens have great respect for the memory of their ancestors, and they are cheerful and good-natured people. They will always be happy to tell you how to find this or that sight, seasoning the explanation with humorous expressions.

description.en: Wroclaw is a city located at the crossroads of five rivers, the "cultural capital of Europe" and home to the Krasnoludek (famous dwarves who have become a symbol of this place). In 1997, John Paul II, who was then Pope, called Wroclaw a "meeting city," and this characteristic reflects the essence of the place. The city harmoniously combines German architecture with Soviet panel buildings, the historical heritage of the former capital of the independent Lower Silesia Province, and close ties with Ukrainian Lviv. When experienced travelers visit Wroclaw, they will have the feeling that they have seen it all before. This common and even, to some extent, homelike atmosphere makes it very attractive for tourists to stay here for a few days and explore the city over and over again.

long_description.en: Wroclaw is home to people from various European countries, mostly Czechs and Germans. The locals are very reserved. Before doing anything, they think several times, which many tourists mistake for slow and phlegmatic. A calm attitude to life, in general, has become a hallmark of the local population.

description.en: People used to call Warsaw "Eastern Paris" at the beginning of the last century for its beauty, charm, and romanticism. It is multi-faceted and diverse. Like the legendary Phoenix bird, it rose from the ashes, reborn from the ruins, and, as a result, became even more beautiful. The status of the capital does not burden Warsaw in any way. It is equally friendly to its guests and locals. Although the first ones may be a little confused by the light chaotics of the buildings and the sudden mix-up of styles. But people willingly forgive it all this, like any beautiful and capricious woman. This is a city that has character. Perhaps, it was the character that allowed the Polish capital to go through the tough challenges and survive.

long_description.en: Warsaw, like the whole of Poland in general, is a mono-ethnic city. The vast majority of the city's inhabitants are Polish (over 95%). The representatives of other nationalities are very few here, mostly Germans, Belarusians, and Ukrainians. As in many modern cities, the proportion of women living in Warsaw is slightly higher than that of men, 54% and 46% respectively.

description.en: Poznan is the administrative center of the Greater Poland Voivodeship in western Poland. A city with a rich historical past, the first capital of the Polish state, one of the most important scientific and cultural centers of the country. Connoisseurs of ancient architecture will find Poznan with amazingly beautiful buildings in the Renaissance, Baroque, and neoclassical style. Fans of a comfortable and interesting holiday will enjoy spending time in local museums, cozy cafes, and lush parks. Even just walking along the streets of Poznan, you can discover many charming places that will make your holiday bright and unforgettable.

Lodz is the industrial center of Poland. Its name translates as "boat," as rivers have played an essential role in the past of the city. At the same time, there are no rivers in the city today. However, the former textile factories, palaces, villas of magnates, and memorial places of the ghetto have survived. Lodz attracts tourists with its architectural imperfection and roughness, which can be explained by the fact that life in this city is much more interesting than in other more popular cities in Western Europe. Taking advantage of modern technologies, the city continues to improve. For instance, old buildings are turned into new, modern, and creative spaces. Lodz, which combines features of four cultures, finds its own style with the masterpieces of Baroque.

Adler is a microdistrict and the administrative center of Sochi. It’s also one of the most renowned and popular resorts of Krasnodar Krai. This place frequently hosts various forums, cultural, economic, and other events of the international level. The 2014 Winter Olympic Games also took place in Adler. Even though Adler is just a microdistrict, it can’t stop it from being the largest sea and recreation resort in Sochi. The word “adler” has the Abkhazian origin and translates as a “wharf”. What made an average coastal district a large and full-scale administrative unit? What year became the crucial point in its history? This place deserves to be noticed.

long_description.en:
Adler is the most populated district of Sochi. Over 130 thousand of the local population live here. During the high season of vacations, this number can reach 800-900 thousand. The majority of the population are representatives of eastern nations and Slavonic people. Local citizens and other people who live by the sea try to earn as much as possible during the high season. Therefore, they frequently drive up the prices for products, services, and accommodation. Don’t be afraid to bargain at the market or while using the services of a taxi.
        As a rule, the prices are apriori 3-4 times higher.

description.en: Sochi is a gem on the northeast coast of the Black Sea, surrounded by emerald mountains. The city of high cypresses, sweet-smelling magnolias, and sunlit beaches became the favorite holiday destination of the Russians and guests of the country. Sochi is considered one of the most popular resorts in Russia thanks to its unique climate, fresh sea air, lush southern flora, and clear sea. Here you can improve your health and spend a great time in numerous entertainment centers, parks, and stadiums.

Anapa, the sunniest city in Russia stands on the coast of the Black Sea. Wide beaches, a blue-sky sea, a wonderful climate, and lush vegetation made this city one of the most popular resorts in the country. In the suburbs of Anapa, you can see the unique active mud volcanoes, relic juniper forests, vibrant valleys, and fabulous lakes. The city offers a variety of attractions and amusements for tourists including museums, exhibition halls, an aquapark, and a dolphinarium. There is no place for boredom here neither for adults not for children.

long_description.en: According to the information of 2019, around 80 thousand people live in the city. Approximately 80% of them are Russian. Besides, the Ukrainians, Armenians, Tatars, Greeks, and representatives of other nationalities live in Anapa.

description.en: Novorossiysk is located in the south of Russia, in the Tsemes Bay. It is a large trading port, a city of naval glory, with a rich, carefully preserved history, and wonderful natural attractions. Beautiful promenades, sandy and pebble beaches, wonderful parks, unique nature reserves, interesting museums, magnificent temples attract tourists not only from Russia, but also from all over the world. Acquaintance with the city turns into a fascinating tour that will remain in your memory for a long time.

A city that never sleeps, doesn’t believe in tears and leave anyone indifferent. Just like any other capital, Moscow lives at a rapid pace. Not everyone can bear its rhythm. However, everyone can find something peculiar, familiar, and inimitable in it. The city enlaces with the circles of boulevards, turn your head with skyscrapers, blinds you with the lights of the shop-fronts, lure with the mysteries of the streets, incredible houses of the XIX century. Moscow is variable and sudden. It is romantic and quite practical at the same time. It is impossible to fully explore it as the city changes imminently every day. But these transformations make it only better. Moscow will linger in your memory for a long time. Almost always, you can’t wait to return and see it again.

long_description.en:
All handbooks write that Moscow is the largest city in Russia and Europe. According to the official data, over 12.5 million people live here. The unofficial data states that these figures have almost reached 20 million. First of all, there are plenty of immigrants from former-Soviet countries and other regions of Russia. According to the statistics, the average age of the capital’s citizen is 41. There are more women than men in Moscow. However, due to the flow of labor migrants, men have a strong lead. Most likely, Moscow can upend the common assumption that “it is not made of rubber”.
        The number of citizens multiplies each year.

description.en: Kaliningrad is a Russian city with centuries-old German history. Its uniqueness is based on the fact that it is the westernmost city, which is located hundreds of kilometers from Russia. Today, it is also called the "cut off city". The Kaliningrad region borders with Poland and Lithuania, which are situated 35 km and 70 km away, respectively. Königsberg (the old name of Kaliningrad) is the birthplace of the great German philosopher Kant and the gloomy storyteller Hoffmann, who is the author of the world-famous Nutcracker. Nowadays, it is a modern Russian city where nine-story panel buildings perfectly coexist with magnificent German villas. Furthermore, streets lined with handmade paving stones and Victory Square are situated near the new Sunday School of the Cathedral of Christ the Savior.

long_description.en: About half a million people are living in Kaliningrad, mostly ethnic Russians. After the war, the city was actively settled by residents of many Soviet republics, and today you can find Belarusians, Ukrainians, Lithuanians, and Armenians there. In total, about 30 nationalities live here, but no more than 1% of each.

description.en: Kazan is a city with an amazing history that is based on a thousand years-long experience. At the beginning of its existence, it was a part of the Volga Bulgaria, although it was subjugated by the Golden Horde later. Throughout its history, the city served the functions of the capital of the Kazan Khanate and part of the Russian Empire. Moreover, it was the pearl of the Soviet Union. Finally, today, Kazan is the capital of Tatarstan. One of the main advantages of the city was its beneficial geographical position. In fact, it is the place where the paths of merchants of West, East, Kievan Rus, and India crossed. In turn, caravans from Byzantium and China met there as well. Nowadays, Kazan is described as the "third" capital of Russia, as it is one of the three most visited cities in the country by tourists. This beautiful and modern metropolis of the European level impresses everyone who visits it.

“The ancient city, the glorious city, the name of Catherine” — lyrics of this song and a variety of other songs are dedicated to Yekaterinburg. The industrial city of miners and artisans has become widely known due to the fact that the family of Nicholas II, the last emperor of Russia, and his retinue were shot here. Later, it was decided to erect Church on the Blood. In turn, the remains of the royal family were transported to Peter and Paul Cathedral, St. Petersburg. It is clear that there is nothing to be proud of, which is why the city residents are not very fond of talking about this fact. However, memorial places are very popular among tourists. Simultaneously, it is here that the most advanced factories and plants of Tsarist Russia were based.

Nizhny Novgorod is an 800-year-old Russian city located on the spit of two majestic rivers, the Volga and the Oka. The city of patriots who liberated Moscow from Polish captivity, for which a monument at the Red Square was erected to the heroes, Minin and Pozharsky. A city that has repeatedly experienced the raids of the Mongol Yoke, but has always risen from the ashes. Today, it is a modern metropolis that surprises with the interweaving of eras, old Russian churches and Italian cuisine, street art, and new modern theaters, the IT Russian center and the city of European quality of life.

As the capital of Eastern Siberia, Irkutsk is situated on the banks of the Angara River. This ancient Siberian city has turned into one of the main industrial, scientific, and cultural centers of the country. It has a variety of interesting things to visit and admire: wooden houses with "lace" trim, colorful churches, beautiful estates of past centuries, and museums. In other words, Irkutsk and its environs are rich in wonderful attractions, which encourage tourists of the whole world to get acquainted with the city and the entire country.

Samara is an eternal dialogue between the city and nature, history and modernity, where the Volga bends and borders the Zhiguli Mountains, and the Samara Embankment peers into it with a pearl swan — the longest in Russia. Ilya Repin painted his famous Barge Haulers on the Volga, Alexander Pushkin and Ivan Bunin wrote poems here. This is an old merchant city, which has become a huge metropolis that stretches along the elevated left bank of the Volga River and is considered a large industrial, commercial, and transport center of Russia.

On the eastern coast of the Kola Bay lies one of the largest ports of Russia — Murmansk. This is the city beyond the Arctic Circle, the base of the icebreaker fleet, a warm-water seaport. It hasn’t got ancient historical monuments, but this distinctive and harsh city attracts with natural sights and war memorials. Only Murmansk has such a bottomless sky, transparent, ringing air, and a burning salty wind. Arctic lights, harsh pristine landscapes, the architecture that harmoniously fit into the surrounding panorama — Murmansk is gradually, but confidently, winning the hearts of those who come here.

Odessa is one of the largest seaports of the Black Sea, the capital of the South of Ukraine, an amazing resort city. Sandy beaches, lush parks, luxury palaces, interesting museums made it favorite holiday destination among the Ukrainians and tourists from many countries of the world. Odessa is famous not only for picturesque streets, fascinating architecture, and beach recreation but also for a unique spirit of welcome and sparkling sense of humor. All this gives charm to the resort city, and every tourist, who comes to South Palmyra, senses it.

long_description.en: According to the 2019 census, more than 1 million people live in Odessa. Ukrainians make up a majority (approximately 62%) of the inhabitants. Also, Russians, Bulgarians, Jews, Moldovans, Belarusians, Armenians, and representatives of other nationalities live here.

description.en: Kyiv is situated in eastern Europe, on both sides of the Dnipro River. As a former capital of Kyivan Rus, this dynamic and noisy metropolis is a city with a centuries-old glorious history. The cobbled streets of St. Andrew's Descent, the majestic domes of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, the unique Golden Gate, and the many-voiced Khreshchatyk are considered the main symbols of handsome Kyiv. The city on the hills, which offers an incredibly beautiful view of the picturesque Dnipro River, attracts tourists with its historical monuments, numerous museums, magnificent parks, and gardens.

long_description.en: In 2019, almost three million people were living in the city. Most of the citizens, more than 80%, are Ukrainians by nationality. There are also Russians, Belarusians, Poles, Jews, Armenians, and natives of other countries.

description.en: Bukovel is a young resort in the Ivano-Frankivsk region in Ukraine, not far from the village of Polianitsa, which is surrounded by the Carpathian Mountains. The River Prutiets with several branches flow across Bukovel. In 2014, Bukovel opened the artificial lake Molodost. Its area is almost the same as the lake Synevyr (in summer, it is the center of the resort life). Bukovel is the best winter sports destination in the country with the Carpathian atmosphere and incredible nature. Its infrastructure is of a European level. Here you can learn to ski and snowboard. And experienced sportsmen will enjoy black slopes of a difficult level.

Lviv is the western tourist capital of Ukraine, a city of legends and myths, a land of nobles and kings. It is often described by tourists as a city with a special European charm and an atmosphere of majestic tranquility. Cobbled streets with old buildings, magnificent temples, unusual museums, and numerous architectural monuments attract crowds of tourists not only from Ukraine but also from around the world. Everyone can find their favorite places in Lviv: an architectural masterpiece on a paved square, a magnificent view from the observation deck of the High Castle, or a cozy cafe with an unrivaled aroma of an invigorating drink.

Bukovel is a young resort in the Ivano-Frankivsk region in Ukraine, not far from the village of Polianitsa, which is surrounded by the Carpathian Mountains. The River Prutiets with several branches flow across Bukovel. In 2014, Bukovel opened the artificial lake Molodost. Its area is almost the same as the lake Synevyr (in summer, it is the center of the resort life). Bukovel is the best winter sports destination in the country with the Carpathian atmosphere and incredible nature. Its infrastructure is of a European level. Here you can learn to ski and snowboard. And experienced sportsmen will enjoy black slopes of a difficult level.

A city on the banks of the Dnepr River, the deepest river of the country, bears the same name. One of the largest industrial centers of the state, its space capital. The most daring inventions and global achievements of engineering were made here. Once, Dnepr was a closed area, entrance and exit were forbidden. You could do it only if you had a special visa because it was a strategically important and security-restricted city. It was a center of rocket science. Important scientific and engineering evaluation tests were conducted in the city. But now, except for powerful metallurgic objects, the city has wonderful tourist and cultural landmarks. It has a well-developed infrastructure. An industrial layout is balanced by magnificent modern architecture, lush greenery in the parks, and a powerful river. Modern Dnepr became one of the most attractive and visited cities in Ukraine.

On the right bank of the Kremenchuk Reservoir, Cherkasy City is located. It is the administrative center of central Ukraine, a city with an ancient history; land hymned by the great Ukrainian poet Taras Shevchenko. Cozy streets, covered in lush greenery, magnificent temples, interesting museums — it is all about Cherkasy.

Lyon is one of the most significant cities in France. It is its business and industrial center which takes third place in the population size. The town is situated in the east-central part of the country on the banks of two picturesque rivers — the Rhône and Saône. This city was the birthplace of such Roman rulers as Tiberius, Claudius, and Caracalla, the fathers of cinematography Auguste and Louis Lumière, the author of “The Little Prince” Antoine de Saint-Exupéry. Every street and every house have a history it keeps. Not without a reason, the old part of Lyon was proclaimed to be the UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1998. The city is also famous for haute cuisine and many people consider it to be the culinary capital of France.

long_description.en: Initially, the Romans and Gauls inhabited this territory. After the formation of the Kingdom of the Burgundians, Lyon became the center of the German occupation army and the French Resistance in the south. All the citizens of France can be divided into such groups: south-European, north-European, and central-European. The majority of the ethnic composition includes the French, Italians, Arabs, and Armenians.

description.en: The small town of Annecy is nestled in the eastern part of France, on the shores of a beautiful lake surrounded by the majestic Alps. "Savoy Venice," "Alpine Rome," "The city of flowers" — Annecy is considered one of the most beautiful cities in France. Narrow streets, pastoral houses studded with flowers, and many canals, with their lace wrapped around ancient buildings, attract tens of thousands of tourists. Sitting here with a cup of coffee and admiring the view of snow-covered alpine peaks is so pleasant. Or take a boat trip through one of the many channels. Lovers of the beautiful will be fascinated by Annecy's magnificent castles and churches, and the dishes of the restaurants will not leave the gourmets indifferent. The small but incredibly charming Annecy is the perfect place for those who dream of a quiet holiday surrounded by pastoral landscapes.

long_description.en:
The first human settlements on the shores of Lake Annecy appeared in 4000 BC. The Celtic Allobroges tribes lived here. In the middle of the I century BC, the Roman city of Boutae emerged on the territory of modern Annecy. After the collapse of the Roman Empire, it was looted and destroyed by barbarian tribes. In the X century, Annecy became the residence of the Geneva Counts. A castle appeared on the island of the Thiou Canal. Under their protection, a craftsmen's settlement near the canal began to sprout.

In the XIII century, the Counts of Geneva finally moved to Annecy after losing the battle for power to the bishops of Geneva. But 200 years later, the city fell under the ownership of the Dukes of Savoy.

The first half of the XVI century marked the re-settlement of the Geneva bishops in Annecy, who were escaping the Reformation in Switzerland. Annecy had become a stronghold of Catholicism in the region by the beginning of the XVII century.

At the end of the XVIII century, the city was first annexed to France. Then, it became the property of the Dukes of Savoy but finally became a part of France in 1860.

Industry developed in Annecy, and the infrastructure improved. The city gradually became one of the most popular tourist destinations in Upper Savoy.

description.en: They call this city the capital of the Alps for a reason, as Grenoble is the geographical, cultural, historical, and economic center of the entire region. It is a place where people study at university and work in modern technology companies. Here you can visit museums and admire the natural beauties. Here you can taste the local cuisine and enjoy shopping. People here are friendly and welcome travelers who come to the city all year round with a smile. Grenoble is a place to fall in love with, even if you've only spent a few days here.

long_description.en:
The first settlement on the site of modern Grenoble appeared in the III century and was called Cularo. In those days, the Allobroges lived here. In 380, when the Roman Emperor Gratian came to power, the town was renamed Grazianopolis. After the collapse of the Roman Empire, the city became part of the Burgundian kingdoms, and in 1032, it was part of the Holy Roman Empire.

As early as 1349, Grenoble was sold to France, making the city the center of the Dauphiné province. During the French wars with the Dukes of Savoy, the city served as a border fortress, and during the Italian Wars (1494-1559), the French army was stationed here.

The history of Grenoble as a whole is quite closely connected with military operations. It was from here in 1788 that the French Revolution began after the first local rebellion.

Since the beginning of the XIX century, Grenoble began to develop manufacturing actively. Glove making, cement and paper production, hydroelectric power plant, mining, and metallurgical industry made Grenoble an important economic center of France.

The city announced itself on the international scene in 1968 when the Winter Olympics were held.

description.en: As a city of festivals, snow-white villas, and architectural monuments, Cannes is a world-famous resort on the Cote d'Azur. This magnificent city, which has been visited by the majority of movie stars and world celebrities, is a real decoration of the Riviera. Perfect beaches, luxury hotels, impeccable promenades are the reasons why Cannes is considered as one of the best resorts in the world. However, the city is famous not only for its cultural events and beach vacation. In Cannes, tourists can find various examples of magnificent architecture, interesting art galleries, and museums. The beautiful city is simply fascinating with its sophistication and luxury.

long_description.en: In 2012, the city had more than 73 thousand people. Most of the citizens are French by nationality. They make up about 94% of the total population.

description.en: This is a real pearl of the French Riviera and the most popular sea resort in the world. The elegant and beautiful Nice spreads on the coast of the Bay of Angels. The sky-blue sea, marvelous gravel beaches, a mild climate, and a beautiful landscape have been attracting tourists from all over the world for more than 200 years! Nice was the favorite holiday destination for the renowned noble European families at the beginning of the XIX century. However, the city has so much more to offer than beautiful beaches. Nice occupies the second position in the number of museums and galleries in Europe. Numerous parks, charming embankments, picturesque palaces, and villas - the exquisite Nice has prepared a lot of interesting places for its guests.

long_description.en:
According to the population census of 2014, more than 300 thousand people live in Nice. The city in multinational and you meet immigrants from various countries all over the world here.

Around 65% of the citizens are French. Nice also has large diasporas of the Greeks, Spaniards, Italians, Tunisians, Moroccans, Algerians, and Portuguese.

description.en: Marseille is a real bad boy from the South of France. It’s the largest port in the country situated on the coast of the Mediterranean Sea. It gained the unsavory reputation of a dangerous, dirty city with dozens of cultures and nationalities. But don’t you even think of canceling your flight! The slightly unbrushed Marseille will take the fancy of everyone fond of maritime romance. He will drive you crazy with the mind-blowing odors of the freshly-cooked seafood dishes and salty breeze. Its narrow streets of the historical center and the wide avenues of the Second Empire; the snow-white yachts and magnificent cathedrals; the roaring tribunes of the “Orange Vélodrome” stadium and the Medieval castles — this diverse Marseille will become the front gate to your lavender adventures in Provence.

long_description.en:
Marseille is perhaps the most multicultural city in France. In the past century, the Italians came here in search of a better life, the Russians and Armenians hid here from wars and revolutions. At the same time, Marseille became a real mecca for the immigrants from the former African colonies of France.

Today, the population of Marseille is almost 1 million people. The main phenomenon of the city is that there are not more than 50% of the native Frenchmen here. Immigrants from countries of North Africa form around 30% of the population. Besides, around 80 000 Armenians and the same number of Jews live here. Don’t forget to add a considerable diaspora of Greeks, Poles, Italians, and you will get a real cocktail of cultures and nationalities called Marseille.

description.en: Antibes is a charming city on the French Riviera. Claude Monet himself painted its sunsets and sunrises. Picasso was so happy here that he created his brightest painting, "La Joie de vivre." George Sand and Francis Scott Fitzgerald talked about the beauty of Antibes in their works. And English writer and British intelligence officer Graham Greene called Antibes "the only city on the Côte d'Azur, which managed to save his soul."

long_description.en:
Greeks founded the city in the V century B.C. and called it Antipolis. After 300 years, it became the property of Rome and rapidly developed because of its favorable location. After the fall of the Western Roman Empire, the town was renamed Antibulus. In 442, a bishopric was founded there. But the constant raids of the Saracens, Visigoths, and barbarians gradually ruined it. Even the formidable castle and the fortress walls erected around Antibulus did not save it. This forced Pope Innocent IV in 1243 to transfer the bishop's throne to Grasse.

From 1385 to 1608, the Grimaldi family ruled the city. They rebuilt and enlarged the castle to its present size. In 1482, Provence became part of the Kingdom of France and Antibes became a border town.

In the XVII century, on the orders of Louis XIV, its fortifications were modernized. This enabled it to withstand a 58-day siege by Austrian, Sardinian, and English troops in the winter of 1747.

In 1815, Napoleon was not favored here. For his loyalty, King Louis XVIII returned to the city the title "Bon Ville," which had previously been revoked by the Emperor. Antibes also received a new coat of arms depicting the Fleur-de-Lis.

In the mid-XIX century, the beauty of nature attracted the wealthy nobility here. Luxury villas and residences began to appear in the city. In 1870 the first luxurious hotel was built. And in 1887, Stephen Liegeard made the French Riviera famous in his novel "The Cote d'Azur ."Over the next six years, two more luxury hotels opened in the new resort area of Juan-les-Pins. After that, wealthy people from all over the world began to flock to Antibes. It took its place between Nice and Cannes in a series of magnificent seaside resorts. By 1895 the town had grown so big that the protective walls had become "too small" for it, and the authorities began to tear them down. Tourism took an important place in the priorities of the city's economy.

The late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries are a special era for Antibes. During this period, the most fashionable and popular artists of the day come here - artists, musicians, actors, poets, and writers. Here is where Francis Scott Fitzgerald created the novel "A Gentle Night ."The prototype of the hotel described in it still exists today under the name "Hotel du Cap-Eden-Rock ."And the stars of the XXI century are still happy to stay there.

World War II briefly interrupted the idyllic development of events. But as soon as it ended, Antibes once again became a place of attraction for the American and European creative elite. Pablo Picasso lived here for six months. A part of the Grimaldi castle was allocated for his studio. In gratitude, the artist left an impressive collection of works as a gift to the city.

In 1960, the first jazz festival in Europe was held in Juan-les-Pins. And ten years later, Marineland was opened. It is a very large entertainment marine park and research center. In 1970-1984, a project was implemented to create a technology park, Sophia Antipolis, northwest of the resort. It is the French version of Silicon Valley.

Today Antibes is the largest yacht port and a trendy tourist center of the Cote d'Azur. It is also called the most popular youth resort on the Riviera.

description.en: Not many cities in the world can win the heart of any tourist, regardless of their interests and preferences. French Avignon is undoubtedly one of these cities. With historical sites that are on UNESCO's World Heritage List, picturesque nature, a theatrical festival, a jazz music festival, the best wineries, and stunning local cuisine — it seems that Avignon has everything for an unforgettable holiday. Let's add the magical atmosphere of Provence and the hospitality of the city's residents. Sounds very tempting, doesn't it?

long_description.en: The ethnic composition of Avignon is quite diverse. The vast majority of local residents are French by nationality. The percentage of this group is about 75%. The second largest is the group of natives of North Africa - just over 10%. The national composition also represents Italians, Portuguese, Turks, and Asians.

description.en: Aix-en-Provence is one of the most beautiful cities in the south-east of France. It is located in the province of Provence among the mountains. The main features of the town are its narrow cobbled streets, Baroque houses from the XVII and XVIII centuries, lovely squares, ancient fountains, and numerous markets. Various festivals are organized in the town. One of the most famous is the Aix-en-Provence Festival, an international music festival where you can listen to opera and other classical styles. Aix-en-Provence is the cultural pearl of France and also a city of art. The post-impressionist painter Paul Cézanne was born and created here. Many artists came here for inspiration. You can start your acquaintance with Aix-en-Provence with Cours Mirabeau; there are many restaurants and cafes here. The traditional local dish is a basil soup. Fish and stewed meat by special recipes are also popular.

On the shores of the Mediterranean Sea, in the French Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region, lies the luxury resort of Saint-Tropez. It has long been a favorite holiday destination of the European Bohemia. A harbor full of luxury yachts and sailing boats, sandy beaches surrounded by pine groves, pastel houses on the coastal slopes — it's hard to resist the beauty of Saint-Tropez. History and art lovers won't be bored here either. Medieval architecture, mysterious streets of the Old Town, rich art galleries, and museums await curious tourists. Saint-Tropez is particularly popular with the youth. Nightclubs, discos, and bars, as well as social parties and daily promenades along the waterfront, are waiting for them. Saint-Tropez is a SPA fairy tale that cannot be forgotten and to which one wants to return over and over again.

long_description.en:
The first settlement on the place of modern Saint-Tropez appeared in the II century BC. The city received its name after the Holy Great Martyr Saint Torpes of Pisa (Torpetius). According to a description of his life, in the I century, during the persecution of Christians, he was beheaded near Pisa. His body, together with a dog and rooster, was placed in an old boat and sent to the sea. The boat was washed on the bank where the settlement, later named after the apostle, was located.

At the beginning of the X century, Saint-Tropez was one of the settlements where Muslim pirates were based. Then it became part of the Counts of Provence. The citizens built a small fortress to protect the coast from attacks from the sea.

In the first half of the XVII century, a Japanese expedition led by Samurai Tsunenaga landed on the coast of Saint-Tropez. It is believed that this was the first contact between the French and Japanese.

In the middle of the XVII century, the city was attacked by the Spaniards. But the inhabitants managed to fight off the attacks of 22 enemy galleons.

Saint-Tropez as a resort was first mentioned at the very end of the XIX century. At that time, the famous artist Paul Signac settled here in the villa. He was so fascinated by this place that he told his friends and acquaintances about it with delight. Famous Bohemians and aristocrats of that time, including Henri Matisse, Pierre Bonnard, Coco Chanel, and Elsa Schiaparelli, followed him here.

During the Second World War, German troops landed on the city's coast. From here, they began to invade southern France.

After the war, the popularity of the resort decreased. The next revival of the city began in the 1950s, after the filming of the famous movies with Brigitte Bardot and Louis de Funes, starring "And God Created Woman" and "The Troops of St. Tropez".

description.en: Toulon is a French city on the Mediterranean coast located in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region, which is called the far southeastern point of the French Riviera. It combines the good old-fashioned French charm, the eternal beauty of Provence, and its unique layout. Toulon is gifted with great natural beauty; and the turquoise sea is a must-have. It starts with a very beautiful harbor of the Mediterranean Sea, and Mont Faron, surrounded by picturesque greenery, rises above it. This lovely sea city in the south of France has a rich history, picturesque wild landscapes, and well-developed infrastructure. It is s dream come true of every traveler.

Montpellier is a southern French city, comfortably situated in the valley of the River Lez. It is located only 10 kilometers from the Mediterranean coast and is considered a favorite summer destination for the French. Montpellier offers guests everything that the south of France is famous for: the magnificent city center, shady streets with charming cafes, and huge vineyards in the suburbs. And here you can enjoy fashionable shopping and delicious cuisine. A small but very beautiful provincial town impresses with its sophisticated delicacy, the atmosphere of comfort and blissful tranquility.

Bordeaux is home to the best French wines, the fifth-largest city in France, and the second most important port, which was even called "little Rome." Here you will find interesting locations for both experienced travelers and beginners. The city will delight with the beauty of its architectural ensemble, original museums, active nightlife, and, of course, the most exquisite French wines. The French themselves love to come to Bordeaux with their children because there is a magnificent zoo, many park areas where you can feed the ducks, and the largest amusement park in France "Let's Jump Bordeaux." If you want to see real France, don't hesitate to travel here with your family.

long_description.en: Although it is a port city, the majority of people living here until the 2010s were French. After France opened its borders to migrants and refugees, an influx of people from Africa and the Middle East, and Asia poured in. Today Bordeaux is considered the fifth city in France in terms of the number of inhabitants. Up to half a million people live in the city itself and one million in the agglomeration.

description.en: Biarritz is a famous resort of celebrities. It is not for nothing that it is called the "beach of kings" (plage de rois). It is much easier to enumerate politicians and celebrities who have never been here than those who have spent their holidays here many times. Biarritz is a warm sea and refreshing breeze, picturesque cliffs, delightful sunsets, bright impressions. Since the century before last, this city has been the capital of French golf, and in recent decades, it has also become the Mecca of European surfing. Biarritz is a symbol of high style, elegance, and prestige. The city is located in the southwest of France, in the department of the Atlantic Pyrenees on the Bay of Biscay, 22 km from the Spanish border.

long_description.en:
The climate is one of the main advantages of this resort. Winters are very mild, and fresh sea breezes compensate for the summer heat. The average temperature in winter is +8°C, and in summer, it is about 20°C. The Gulf Stream warms up the coastal waters in Biarritz to acceptable temperatures, so the bathing season starts early. While the water temperature on most of the Atlantic coast of France in the summer does not exceed +18°C, at times, it heats up to +25°C in Biarritz. The tourist season here opens in late May and lasts until October. By the way, in late May and early June, the local beaches are not as crowded as in mid- and late-summer.

In mid-July, Biarritz hosts the Roxy Pro Biarritz, the biggest surf festival in Europe. A vibrant music program accompanies the competitions.

In late May and June, the city often hosts fashion exhibitions, and in mid-July and mid-August, there are traditional fireworks displays.

Travelers should keep in mind that Biarritz is a city of holidays, shows, concerts, all kinds of exhibitions, decorated with illumination. A variety of entertainment events are held here almost continuously from April to October.

description.en: When someone mentions romance, many people imagine Paris. Its streets which smell like roasted chestnuts, magnificent architecture and splendid gardens enrapture not only tourists but local citizens as well. Over 45 million people come to the city of love annually. They want to see Montmartre, Notre-Dame de Paris, and the statue of the Venus de Milo in the Louvre Museum with their own eyes. Some people come here to return home in a new status of a fiancé and a bride. The Eiffel Tower is one of the most popular locations where people say “yes” in all languages of the world.

long_description.en:
Just like any other capital, Paris is an important economic and cultural center of the country. Many people say that Parisians are arrogant. However, at the same time, the French capital is renowned for its cosmopolitanism. Such contrasts are typical for many French megalopolises. But it is a true lifestyle and a part of the culture for Paris. The French honor their language a lot. Therefore, if you want to ask something, start your communication in French and ask if a person knows English. You are most likely to be ignored if you start your conversation in English.
        Make sure you pack a French phrase-book to your luggage.

description.en: Versailles may seem artificial, too perfect, too clean, and too royal compared to other cities in France. But this is where your idea of what French cities should look like coincides with reality. Every house, street, and square in Versailles is soaked in the atmosphere of a festive and vacuous life. The city, built around the summer residence of French monarchs, captivates with its aristocratic atmosphere and makes you fall in love at first sight.

long_description.en: The population of Versailles is mainly involved in tourism, culture, and education. There are five universities, a theatre, libraries, museums, markets, and churches located in a small area. The citizens of Versailles are very settled and do not leave their hometown. According to statistics, 88% of local residents were born here and do not plan to move anywhere. These are open and friendly people. They will gladly help tourists find their way to their main attraction and explain things until you understand them. They indeed speak English very rarely, although they understand it well.

description.en: Nantes is a large, bustling city in the west of France, which stretches along the banks of the Loire and Erdre Rivers. Once it was the capital of the Duchy of Brittany, which played an important role in its development. Today, it is the third-largest industrial city in France. It is located just a couple of hours drive from Paris. Not too long ago, most travelers could not even imagine Nantes as a tourist city. But local authorities are doing everything possible to change this situation. In recent years, Nantes has become one of the fastest-growing and most progressive cities. Its rich history is expressed in local attractions. This allows it to gain more and more popularity among tourists lately.

Toulouse is the city of contrasts. Ancient winding streets that remember the soles of his sandals of Roman legionaries and the European largest the National Centre for Space Studies are found side by side. When walking along the waterfront of the Garonne river, you never know who you meet at the corner — a trouvere or a hero in a spacesuit. The French call Toulouse “La Ville Rose” and consider it the most stylish city in the country. All because of red brick from which buildings of the City Center were made. Those who like The Little Prince by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry visit Toulouse as the Mecca. A courageous aviator started his first flights over Africa and the Atlantic from exactly this place. A mixture of ancient and modern, Spanish, Basque, and Lengadocian traditions, a charm of Provence and fiery energy of Gascony — it’s all about Toulouse. You are the lucky one, is you had an opportunity to try this crazy cocktail!

long_description.en:
One in five residents of Toulouse is a student. Universities are open to foreigners. This fact alone guarantees the ethnic diversity of the population. In addition, the city's history is rich in events that have contributed to the settlement of people of different nationalities. After World War I, Italians fled to Toulouse to escape the repression of Mussolini. In the 1930s, the dictatorial policies of Franco caused a wave of emigration of Spaniards. Now there are more than 25 thousand of them living in the city.

The Jewish community has existed in Toulouse since the VIII century. It is the fourth-largest Jewish community in France and has about 30 thousand people. Twelve percent of Toulouse's residents come from Arab countries. This proximity contributes to frequent conflicts between members of national communities. But these events, more often than not, take place in residential areas and do not affect the city's tourist areas.

description.en: Ajaccio is the picturesque capital of Corsica, lying at the foot of the wooded hills. Napoleon Bonaparte was born in this city. His pedestal, street name, museum, or souvenir will remind you about it literally at every step. The townspeople are very proud of their famous countryman. But tourists come here not only to visit the house where the great military leader was born. Here you can also enjoy leisurely walks along the streets of the Old Town and its luxurious squares with fountains. Ajaccio has incredibly beautiful nature, and in its bays, there are beautiful beaches and the emerald waters of the tender Mediterranean Sea.
Cognac is a small town in France, which is located along the Charente River. It is home to the divine drink and of King Francis I.

long_description.en: The first statistical data, dating back to 1793, show that about 3000 people were living in the city at that time. According to the French National Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies, as of 2015, the town of Cognac had 18,654 inhabitants. The city's current population is growing, including due to migrants.

description.en: The city of Blois is located on the banks of the Loire River in Central France and is a starting point for traveling through historic castles. In the XV century, it was the residence of the greatest kings of France — the Dukes of Orleans. The town itself is small but very cozy, and the ancient castles in its surroundings attract thousands of tourists. The Royal Château de Blois is one of the main attractions of the Central region and the cultural heritage of France in general. Cycling is popular in the city; tourists can rent a bike and go to see the magnificent castles while enjoying the beautiful nature. Some of the most popular castles in the Loire Valley are Château de Cheverny and Château de Chambord. About 5 km from Blois, tourists visit the iron mineral springs of Saint-Denis and upstream the Loire River, the Boulogne Forest, and the Chambord Park. The Forest of Blois is to the west of the city. The banks of the Loire River in the town of Blois are connected by the stone bridge of Jacques Gabriel, constructed in the early XVIII century. From the left bank, there are the most beautiful views of the city. Here you will also find the historic center of Blois, the Old Town, where tourists will find many restaurants and cozy cafes. The menu offers traditional French Mediterranean cuisine, while local delicacies include cheese, honey, and other sweets.

As one of the country's cultural capitals, Lille is located in northern France. In this city, a variety of architectural styles and trends have been wonderfully intertwined. Monuments of history are adjacent to modern quarters, whereas real masterpieces of architecture perfectly coexist with fashionable shops and boutiques. It is tremendously nice to walk around the old quarters of the city, admire the magnificent mansions and temples, as well as relax in the magnificent gardens and parks. Lille is a city that impresses with its beauty, captivates with incredible charm, and becomes an unforgettable memory.

Strasbourg is a city in the center of Europe on the right bank of the Rhine river. It combines German preciseness and French charm. The motherland of the first Christmas tree and the first printed book in Europe keeps many legends and tales. Gothic cathedrals and castles, universities and parks, restaurants, and cafes of Strasbourg are crowded with tourists all year round. A unique architectural layout of the central part of the city, Grande Ile, was classified a World Heritage Site by UNESCO. The parliament capital of Europe offers interesting places and incredible emotions to every guest. And people keep coming back here because the city fascinates and makes you fall in love with it.

long_description.en:
According to official data from 2013, Strasbourg is home to almost 300,000 people, and the population is constantly increasing.

Most of the city's residents are French and Germans. Their number is about 80% of the total population. Representatives of other European nationalities make up 7%. The remaining 13% come from Africa, Turkey, Asia, and South America.

description.en: Colmar is the most beautiful city in Alsace, which is often described as the "open-air museum." It is large enough but very cozy and unusually beautiful. The close proximity to the German border gave the city's architecture its own special style. Near the Gothic pathos buildings, people have the opportunity to find small multi-colored half-timbered buildings twined with a vine. In Colmar, there are many canals and bridges that open up extraordinarily beautiful mesmerizing landscapes. Colmar is said to be an example of the entire Alsace. Everyone, who has visited it at least once, will remember this city forever. Once you arrive, it is recommended to walk across its cobbled streets with bright flower beds, taste local delicacies, enjoy wines and works of art. Visitors of this city frequently describe it as a place transported beyond reality. Usually, Colmar is associated with a fairy tale where real dragons, gnomes, knights, and princesses live. In fact, the atmosphere of this city is based on the combination of magnificent nature and cheerfulness.

Dijon is an incredibly colorful and refined French town. It has become a vivid example of the careful treatment of history and traditions that are in harmony with modernity. The answer to the question of what to do in Dijon is short: "Eat, drink, and walk." The city is rightfully called a gastronomic paradise, and culinary festivals here are a common part of life. Burgundy's capital will acquaint the tourist with the best wines, famous mustard, and leisurely lifestyle. A trip to Dijon is an opportunity to move to another era, get acquainted with art, and feel like a real Frenchman. Every walk here is a real date with the city. Cozy streets, numerous architectural monuments, and authentic restaurants will be the main attributes of its unique atmosphere.

Rouen is the capital of the French region of Normandy, spread out on both sides of the River Seine. This city is the embodiment of French enchantment and charm. In the Middle Ages, it was got all the misfortunes inherent in those difficult times — illness, war, and destruction. Here, in 1431, young Joan of Arc was executed. Having managed to preserve and increase the heritage of the past, the modern city demonstrates its best masterpieces. Among them is the diamond of Gothic architecture Notre Dame de Rouen (Rouen Cathedral). Claude Monet was fascinated by its beauty, who created a series of thirty paintings, known in the world as the Rouen Cathedral. French artists Paul Gauguin and Camille Pissarro found inspiration in it. Gustave Flaubert was born and wrote his famous novel Madame Bovary. And Victor Hugo gave it his name — the city of a hundred bell towers. In 2002, Rouen was given the status of the city of history and art.

The name of the city speaks for itself because Le Havre translates from French as "the harbor." A visit to this ancient port city will be fascinating — there are many beautiful churches and ancient houses with a peculiar architecture. And of course, as in any big city in France, there are many art exhibitions and museums in Le Havre, which will help anyone to get a complete picture of the history and culture of these places.

Amiens is located in the north of France, 150 km from Paris. The capital of historical Picardy beckons with its medieval mystery, enchants with its cozy streets, lost in the river canals, and attracts with numerous museums, towers, and temples. Genuine adventure seekers come here — it is no coincidence that the famous writer, Jules Verne, wrote his best works in Amiens. Not only has the city preserved the house where he had lived for almost 30 years, but also the atmosphere that inspired the master. So if your plans include a trip "around the world in 80 days", be sure to leave room in your busy schedule for Amiens. It is worth it!

long_description.en:
In ancient times the territory of Amiens was inhabited by the Gaulish tribe of Ambiani. The settlement was called Samarobriva (from the name of the river Samara, now the Somme). Then the Romans came here - they called the place Samarobriva Ambianorum.

In the second half of the IX century, the Normans looted and burned the settlement. From the XII to the XV century, Amiens was the first part of the counties of Vermandois and Amienois, then became part of the land of Burgundy Netherlands. Its advantageous geographical position (between Paris and Lille) led to the fact that the city was fought for as a strategic object and a launching pad for capturing the capital's territories. Thus, the Spaniards occupied it at the end of the XVI century. Subsequently, Henry IV returned it to French possession.

During the First and Second World Wars, the city was badly damaged. More than 10,000 houses and buildings were damaged.

The new history of Amiens is also not cloudless. In 2012 riots involving immigrants and police took place in the city streets, during which houses and government offices were burned down.

Today the city is a major center of the textile industry. Amiens is home to Picardy State University, named after Jules Verne. It includes eight institutes and two doctoral schools.

Amiens is popular with tourists as a place with historical monuments and all opportunities for good, eventful recreation.

description.en: On the shore of the Istria island, washed by the turquoise waters of the Adriatic Sea, lies the ancient resort town of Pula — a beautiful creation of nature, polished to perfection by humans. Elite beaches, ancient architectural structures, olive groves, pine trees, fountains, sculptures, a varied menu of the Mediterranean diet, recognized by UNESCO as the intangible heritage of mankind — all this is about the Croatian city of Pula. The best combination for a vivid and memorable trip than the ancient Roman monuments, clear seawater and air with the scent of lavender and pine needles simply cannot be found! Pula attracts tourists from all over the world. Here you can relax and significantly expand the horizons of your own worldview! After all, even the brilliant Dante mentioned Pula in his work “Divine Comedy”. This small town of great opportunities, always hospitably welcomes travelers!

Split is a Croatian port and resort city that keeps many secrets. Annually it attracts thousands of tourists. Different epochs and cultures meet there: modern concrete and glass constructions are found side by side with the survived houses of the 15th – 19th centuries. The locals draw an analogy with clotheslines, which connect different houses as if epochs. A cozy Split is located in the center on the Adriatic coast. Nowadays, it is considered the second-largest city of Croatia after Zagreb. The food industry, including fish processing and wine production, is also well-developed here. Azure sea, the imperial castle, cozy cafes, and noisy markets create a unique mood for everyone who has been to this incredible city.

Zagreb is located on the bank of the Sava (Danube tributary), near the Medvednica mountain. Today, it serves functions of the cultural capital of Eastern Europe, a major tourist center of Croatia, and a green city with clear lakes. Here, majestic Gothic temples create a picturesque backdrop for modern skyscrapers. Magnificent empire-style buildings, interesting museums, lush parks, and gardens attract millions of tourists to Zagreb. The charm of ancient Europe impresses everyone who makes the decision to come here. Usually, people tend to come back here again and again in order to feel the amazing combinations of antiquity and youth.

long_description.en: More than 800 thousand people live in the city. The number of inhabitants of the urban agglomeration with the surrounding areas is more than one million. About 92% of the citizens are Croats by nationality. Also, natives of Serbia, Bosnia, Albania, Slovenia, Montenegro, and Macedonia live here.

description.en: Like a scattering of emeralds, the Adriatic Sea embraces this ancient gem called Dubrovnik, a UNESCO-protected heritage of the world. The city's streets, like the eye of a needle, sharp because of the numerous extraordinary steps leading upwards, are very cozy and hospitable. The terracotta roofs of ancient buildings come to life under the gentle Croatian sun. Sometimes it seems that now, as in a fairy tale, a knight on his warhorse will ride by, and in the opposite house, the window will open, and a pretty girl will appear, his Lady of the Heart. Every day or hour spent in Dubrovnik will be unforgettable and exceptional for you.

long_description.en:
Dubrovnik, like the rest of Croatia, becomes the love of a lifetime after the first visit. The city is very diverse, and almost 42 thousand people live there. Everywhere there is an extraordinary harmony of human unity with nature, the world, and the people who visit these places. The careful attitude of Croats to their land, history, and ecology is admirable.

The locals lead a leisurely and measured life, chatting in small cafes in the evenings, with children running around the streets and laughing joyfully. They are always hospitable to you, ask about life, and almost always offer you a small glass of raki. The people of Dubrovnik know the value of peace and life.

description.en: Zadar is a picturesque Croatian resort that is very popular among tourists. This popularity can be explained by the fact that it not only offers the opportunity to relax on the clean pebble and sandy beaches but also to visit a lot of interesting attractions. Ancient monuments of architecture, museums, and magnificent parks belong to the list of the must-see sights in the city. When it comes to temples, there are nearly a dozen and a half of these buildings. In Zadar, there are many shops, nightclubs, and restaurants. Here you can have fun and go shopping from morning until late evening. At the same time, you will not get tired! If you still want to take a break, follow the advice of Alfred Hitchcock. Go to the promenade and admire the scenery and the sound of the sea. After visiting this part of the city, the famous director noticed that Zadar has the most beautiful sunsets in the world. It is essential to come here in order to check whether it is the truth.

Korčula — is the capital of the island of the same name in the Croatian region Southern Dalmatian. Its central part is well-preserved by the medieval fort walls. Five our of six defensive towers of the 15th century survived till nowadays. Powerful fortification is a distinctive symbol of the city, but St. Mark's Cathedral of the 14th century is even more famous. It is located in the heart of the Old City. The majority of buildings in this district were built in the 15th - 16th century in the style of the Venetian Renaissance and are considered the architectural treasures. A collection of rare icons is kept in Bishop's palace. Also, an exposition of valuable paintings, including those created by Leonardo da Vinci, is set there. Marco Polo Birth House serves as a museum of the great traveler. The historical heritage doesn't prevent the city from developing as a modern resort. A tourist will find here more than a dozen different beaches, a lot of excellent cafes, restaurants, and bars.

Zermatt is one of the best ski resorts in the world. An upscale city is located at the foot of the famous peak Matterhorn in Switzerland near the border with Italy. Magnificent Alpine landscapes, top trails, great infrastructure, and fresh mountain air made it one of the most popular resorts. Throughout the year, Zermatt is crowded with fans of active holidays, natural wonders, and delicious Alpine cuisine.

long_description.en:
The first mention of the town dates back to the XIII century. At that time, it was a small village of shepherds, which had the Italian name Praborno. The history of the spa town began in the middle of the XIX century. The doctor J. Lauber opened the first hotel here. At the same time, the town was named Zermatt, which means "in the meadow" in German.

In 1884, the first big hotel appeared in Zermatt. It was built by the founder of the famous dynasty of hoteliers Alexander Seiler. The hotel was built at an altitude of 2222 m, giving rise to its name, Riffelalp Resort 2222m.

Gradually, the town developed and became a fashionable resort. Now every other house in Zermatt is a hotel or restaurant.

description.en: Grindelwald is a small village at the foot of the Jungfrau, Eiger, and Mönch mountains. Thousands of tourists come here every year to relax, go skiing, climb the Alps' peaks, and just hike. After all, the air here is stunningly clean, not to mention the unique and vivid beauty of the scenery.

long_description.en:
The accurate date of the origin of the Grindelwald is unknown. This settlement was first mentioned in a document of one of the monasteries of Interlaken, dated 1146.

The first tourists who came to relax among the Grindelwald mountains were the British. Soon, rumors spread about this small village's charms, and at the end of the XVIII century, residents of many European countries began to flow into the village.

In the XIX century, when the great passion for mountaineering began, the resort became even more popular. And in 1858, the first ascent to the most challenging mountain in the Alps — the Eiger — was made here. After that, Grindelwald became one of the favorite gathering points for masters of climbing from all over the world. This gave the necessary boost for infrastructure development. At the end of the XIX century, a railway appeared in the village, and in 1908, the region's first cable car was built. Thanks to the initiative of local residents, in 1912, trains began to go to Mount Jungfrau too. The settlement became a full-fledged resort, which is very easy to reach.

Now Grindelwald offers its guests everything necessary for good rest, including ultramodern infrastructure:

  • comfortable hotels;
  • perfectly equipped slopes for popular winter sports;
  • comfortable elevators;
  • many carefully designed, safe routes for mountain hiking.

And if you add to this local hospitality and famous Swiss accuracy and commitment, you get a real dream-resort, where you will remember the rest for a lifetime.

description.en: Bern is an amazing and unique city located on the Aare River banks in the southern part of the Swiss Plateau. Its special status makes it unique. We have known it from school that the capital of Switzerland is Bern, but de jure, this country has no capital at all. Yes, Parliament and the Federal Council are indeed situated, but officially, all the major cities in the cantons are equal. If you forget about the bureaucratic issues and look at the city through the eyes of a tourist, you will be absolutely delighted: old cobbled streets, neat "gingerbread" houses with tiled roofs, majestic churches, and, of course, the Alps, which fascinate with their beauty. Bern welcomes its guests with a measured rhythm of life and serenity, distinguishing it from other European capitals.

long_description.en: Over the past couple of years, Bern's population has grown rapidly, from 131,550 people in 2015 to more than 1 million in 2018. This rapid growth is due to a large number of immigrants from the Middle East. However, it is still safe to stay and live in Bern. Very few real locals are left, but you can recognize them even in a crowd by their slower reactions and movements. They do everything leisurely and enjoy every minute of life in their beloved city.

description.en: Lugano is a small Swiss town in the canton of Ticino. Surrounded by the Alps and a mountain lake, the town is located in the south of the country. It is a cozy place with small colored buildings, magnificent parks, ancient churches, and incredible restaurants, which are marked by the Michelin Red Guide. Here you can relax from the bustle of megacities, as well as enjoy the views of snow-capped peaks and perfectly calm water surface.

long_description.en:
One of the first mentions of Lugano dates back to the X century. It is described as a trading town. In the XIV-XV centuries, battles between the Guelphs and the Ghibellines occurred here. In 1416, the region of Lugano became the feudal possession of the Duke of Milan. And a year later, the city became fully independent.

In 1499, the French invaded, and Lugano became an object of dispute between the Dukes of Como and Milan. In 1513, it became a Swiss possession. This lasted until 1798 when Napoleon created the Helvetic Republic. In 1802, the canton of Lugano became independent of the republic. After merging with the city of Bellinzona, the canton of Ticino was formed.

In the 1830s, the city began to expand. Governmental, residential, and religious buildings were built there. The promenade, new roads, steamship, and railroad connections all came into being in Lugano in the middle of the XIX century. The latter became an important transport link between Northern Italy and the rest of Europe, allowing tourism to develop.

In the XX century, the city's population continued to grow rapidly. In 1956, Lugano became the first city organizer of the international song contest Eurovision. It also became the third financial center of Switzerland, with more than a hundred banks. In 1980, the local airport began receiving regular regional flights.

At the beginning of the XXI century, eighteen municipalities joined Lugano. The city continues to develop its tourist potential and attracts many travelers.

description.en: Lausanne is the fourth largest city in Switzerland. Due to its hilly terrain, it is often compared to American California. The city has the headquarters of the International Olympic Committee and several world sports federations. At first sight, it seems that Lausanne is an unremarkable and modest destination, although it is a place where every tourist can find interesting entertainment options. Many museums, cathedrals, and unique architectural structures are well-suited for leisurely walking and exploring the city's culture. In order to connect with nature, it is recommended to find incredible panoramic views on the shores of Lake Geneva.

long_description.en:
The first settlements on the territory of modern Lausanne appeared as early as 1000 BC. But they quickly lost their value and disappeared even before the onset of Roman rule in 15 BC. With the advent of the Romans, the settlement of Lausanne was founded on hilly Swiss land. Rather quickly, its population grew to 1500. A theater was built in the outlying areas, and wealthier homeowners settled on the hillsides opposite the lake. After two centuries of prosperity, the Roman world collapsed, and most of the population left the area.

At the end of the VI century, the town became an Episcopal center and gradually expanded. The newcomers began to populate the foothills of Cité hill, thus creating new neighborhoods.

By the XIII century, the city had reached its maximum size with a population of 9,000. In 1481 municipal autonomy was introduced, and an alliance with Fribourg and Bern was soon signed. Lausanne lost its political importance, becoming a provincial town.

At the end of the XVI-mid XVII centuries, the city was plagued by witch hunts. By the early XVIII century, there was a rebellion to free it from the Bern authorities. But it was quickly suppressed.

At the end of the Napoleonic wars, the Republic of Lehman was proclaimed. In 1816 the city was plagued by a smallpox epidemic and a famine caused by the cooling of the continent.

By 1860, Lausanne had gradually changed its appearance as its population grew to 20,000. During this time, a municipal theater, a cantonal hospice, and a Federal court building were built.

With the advent of the XX century, Lausanne received the prestigious title of "Olympic Capital," hosting the headquarters of the International Olympic Committee. The city breathed a breath of new life and flourished, thanks to the offices of large companies and the globalization of commercial activity.

description.en: Zurich is Switzerland's largest city, its financial and scientific center, ranked second in the world for quality of life in 2019. It is very diverse and atmospheric. Narrow streets with an air of deep antiquity and wide boulevards; spires of ancient churches propping up the sky; painted medieval houses, so neat and tidy, as if they were all built a month ago; the scent of blooming lime trees and festive evening illumination; dazzling luxury stores and a democratic "flea market"; mulled wine, roasted chestnuts, and deliciously delicate cakes with a variety of fillings; a huge picturesque lake, shared by dozens of swans and hundreds of seagulls; stained glass windows by Marc Chagall, paintings by Claude Monet and Salvador Dali — all this combines in Zurich! And this magic rests in the setting of majestic mountains.

long_description.en: Zurich and the entire canton, of which it is the center, are German-speaking. German is the native language for 77% of the population, and Italian is preferred by about 5% of the population. About 30% of the city's population are foreigners, primarily citizens of Germany and Italy. There are quite a lot of Serbs and Montenegrins. There are also a few natives of African and Asian countries. But in any case, German dominates in communication, so a knowledge of a few common phrases in German will come in handy for any tourist.

description.en: Try to imagine both a cold and surprisingly warm city, where the beauty of nature perfectly combines with the strict facades of local buildings. Does it not work? Then you definitely need to come to Lucerne! This tourist destination is widely known as one of the most popular cities in Switzerland. Locals tend to describe Lucerne as a thoughtful, exemplary, cozy, welcoming, interesting, and very atmospheric place. It is certainly worth visiting this city at least once, which can be proved by 9 million tourists who visit magnificent Lucerne annually!

long_description.en: The vast majority of Lucerne residents have Swiss citizenship - about 75.8%. In addition, a large number of German citizens live in the city - 20.4% of the total number of residents. Other European countries also have representatives: Italians - 11.4%, Serbs - 10.9%, Portuguese - 9%, and Spanish - 3.9%.

description.en: Geneva is beautiful, elegant, well-kept, and fashionable. The city beckons with its glitz, glamor, prosperity, its architecture, picturesque parks, luxurious hotels and boutiques on the Rue du Rhone, its art galleries, museums, restaurants, and bars, which creative people usually attend. Many people think of this city as the capital of Switzerland, but it is not. Geneva is the second-largest city in the country. It is cosmopolitan and rich. It is the location of many global organizations, various conventions, and conferences of the world scale are held here. The city lies in a hollow between two mountain ranges, the Alps and the Jura mountains, on Lake Geneva banks (the largest in Switzerland), and the Rhone river. You can admire the beautiful Mont Blanc from any part of the city. Geneva is a center of human thought, visited by many great men, including Julius Caesar, Albert Einstein, Gustav Jung. Jean-Jacques Rousseau was born here. The city encourages contemplation, reflection, and dreaming — everything in it is made thoroughly and soundly. It stands firmly on its feet, unaware of crises, enjoying Swiss chocolate and fondue.

long_description.en:
Until the end of the XIX century, Geneva was the most densely populated city in Switzerland. Later, this status passed to Zurich. It has a very high population density per square meter, as so many people aspire to live in this prosperous and well-kept city. Almost 50% of the population is not Swiss, as there are many international organizations, which employ newcomers. The proximity to the French border explains a large number of French people in Geneva. English is second only to French, and there are also speakers of Spanish, Italian, and German.
        The locals are calm, pedantic, well-bred; they value high quality, adore parties, are sympathetic and easygoing. Maybe that's why there are so many concerts, festivals, auctions, and exhibitions for all tastes in Geneva.

description.en: Basel is located on the Swiss border with France and Germany. It is a quiet, modest city on the Rhine River that cannot boast of its history, success, and importance, but it has something to offer. Along with the Australian city of Sydney, Swiss Basel ranks tenth in the list of cities with the highest standards and quality of life. It is famous for its international tram route, has the largest area of green roofs per person in the world, builds energy-efficient skyscrapers, and former underground crossings of the city are equipped with modern bicycle parking. Hans Holbein the Younger, an outstanding artist, used to create his works in Basel, Nietzsche and Bernoulli taught at the local university (the oldest in Switzerland). It is also the birthplace of Roger Federer, an award-winning tennis player of our time.

long_description.en:
The ancient Roman colony of Augusta Raurica (now an open-air museum) was built in the bend of the Upper Rhine in the II century BC. A century later, the inhabitants abandoned the settlement and moved 20 km away, where the fortification of Basilea was built. In 83 AD, Basel became part of the Roman province of Upper Germany. In 406 AD, the Alemanni crossed the Rhine and inhabited the local territories, which became part of their principality. In the VII century, Basel became the seat of the bishop. And in 1032, it became part of the Holy Roman Empire.

At the beginning of the XIII century, it turned into a trading city thanks to the bridge's construction over the Rhine.

An epidemic of plague raged here in the next century, followed by earthquakes and fires.

In the XV century, Basel hosted the Ecumenical Council, the purpose of which was the reformation and reunification of the Eastern and Western Catholic churches. This century was also marked by the opening of a university, the appearance of the first printing house, and obtaining permission to hold fairs.

In 1501, Basel joined the confederation of Swiss cantons. The next hundred years brought a flowering of culture and science to the city, and silk production brought wealth. That same century also saw printing of the first book on human anatomy and the foundation of the first public art museum.

In the XVII century, the University Library was founded in Basel, which became the largest library in the country. The same period saw the birth of Bernoulli, a dynasty of famous mathematicians. Their scientific achievements were continued by another famous scientist — Leonhard Euler (a student of one of Bernoulli), a native of Basel.

At the end of the XIX century, the first zoo in Switzerland was opened in Basel.

During the Second World War, the city barely suffered thanks to the state's position of neutrality.

Basel was the first city in the world in which residents decided to purchase artwork for a public institution. In 1967, they voted to buy three paintings by Pablo Picasso, which could have been sold and removed from the local Museum of Art because of the financial crisis of the owner's family.

Modern Basel is now firmly established as a commercial, financial, and cultural center. The city hosts the headquarters of major international organizations — the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and the Bank for International Settlements. The city hosts the Baselworld, an annual exhibition of watches and jewelry. The city is also the capital of the pharmaceutical and chemical industries.

description.en: Gothenburg is a city on the shore of the Kattegat Strait in the south-western part of Sweden. The second-largest city in the country is called the cultural capital of Scandinavia. It is famous for its old center with canals, majestic fortresses, incredibly beautiful harsh landscapes, and exciting museums. Rock music fans know Gothenburg as the home of the Swedish style Melodic Death Metal (MDM). The combination of ancient and modern architecture gives the ancient city a captivating charm of youth. And the variety of parks and amazingly clean air made it one of the most popular holiday destinations of Europeans.

long_description.en:
A small Swedish settlement of Lödöse existed in the XI century in the area adjacent to the modern city. It gradually fell into decay. After some time, the Swedes decided to restore it. But the Danes, who encroached on the land overlooking the Kattegat strait, prevented them.

The city of Gothenburg was founded on the island of Hisingen in the very early XVII century by order of Swedish King Charles IX. Its name comes from the ancient German tribe Goths, who previously lived in this area. The tribe also gave its name to the river Göta älv, at the mouth of which the city was founded. The Danes quickly destroyed a settlement of Swedes.

In 1619, King Gustav II Adolf of Sweden moved the city to its present location. Gothenburg was exempted from duties on trade and other taxes for 16 years. Thanks to the erected fortifications, the citizens were able to repel all the attacks of the Danes during the Danish-Swedish war in the middle of the XVII century.

In the XVIII century, the town was in a period of prosperity. Its location at the crossroads of important trade routes from China to Europe contributed to this. The residence of the Swedish East India Company worked here, and open trade auctions were held.

In the XIX century, the city lost its military significance, and its fortifications were demolished. Gothenburg became Sweden's largest commercial port and factory center. Since then, it has developed steadily. Its borders have expanded, and its standard of living has risen.

description.en: As one of the largest cities in Sweden, Malmö is located in the south of the country. Furthermore, globally known as a city with a glorious Hanseatic past, cultural cosmopolitan, and the largest port, Malmö captivates with its atmosphere, Danish mood, and Swedish character. In this city, history and traditions are honored, whereas modern technologies are taken into consideration as well. Subsequently, Malmö has become an ecological city of the future.

Taipei used to its title of the capital. It has been bearing it for two hundred years. Since 1949 there has been a dispute, whether it is the capital of Taiwan Province of the Republic of China or the independent Republic of China. But the political controversy doesn’t prevent this charming city, surrounded by green hills with tea plantations, grow and develop as a popular cultural and tourism center.

Stockholm — the capital of Sweden, is located in the east of the country, on the banks of the Norström canal, which connects Lake Mälaren with the Baltic Sea.
