When it comes to Stockholm, many people immediately imagine small multi-colored houses with original color and a phenomenon originated from psychology called the Stockholm Syndrome. Also, the city is known for its methods of cooking fish, the variety of which will surprise any gourmet. Moreover, nightlife lovers come to Stockholm — a variety of nightclubs, where popular DJs play their DJ sets, make Stockholm one of the most desirable cities for hanging out.

long_description.en:
In the Middle Ages, the Swedish, unfortunately, did not have a habit of conducting a population census, which is why the statistics were not preserved. Therefore, the number of urban residents at that time remained unknown. At the same time, the books that contain detailed information of the city give reason to believe that in 1290 there were about three thousand inhabitants in the city — a considerable number for those times. The population rates declined during wars and epidemics and then increased again.

Modern Stockholm is a huge metropolis, which in combination with the communes, totals 962,154 residents of the city as of January 1, 2019.

description.en: Tirana is the capital and the largest city in Albania, which is surrounded by mountains. Tiranë river flows through the city, as does the Lanë river. It hasn’t become the most popular travel destination yet. But it doesn’t make Tirana less interesting for travelers. The city combines the uncombinable — the bunkers of the former dictator, ancient mosques, the Soviet-style and modern buildings.

long_description.en:
The city has a population of about 500,000 people. The agglomeration's population is more than one million people (one-third of the total population of Albania). Between 1820 and 1955, the population of Tirana grew tenfold. Since 1989, the number of residents has increased annually by 2.7%.

Albanians are the largest ethnic group (84%), followed by Greeks, Aromanians, Macedonians, and Italians. Most of the population is Muslim (56%), 29% are atheists, 7% are Orthodox Christians, 5% are Catholics, and 3% are Bektashis.

description.en: Minsk is the European capital without fuss and noise, a metropolis with a bizarre interweaving of medieval baroque and Soviet monumental buildings. The ancient city, which always remains young, attracts tourists with its ancient architecture and impressive buildings of modern construction, classical theaters, and creative art hubs. Amazing discoveries here await not only connoisseurs of antiquity, but also lovers of modern architectural trends.

long_description.en: The latest census of 2017 showed that almost two million people live in the capital of Belarus. Most of the city's residents are Belarusians; they are about 80% of the total population. The next largest ethnic group is Russians, about 10% of the population. Ukrainians, Poles, Jews, and representatives of many other nationalities also live in the city.

description.en: The hero town of Brest is amazing and unique. Romantics are attracted here by its narrow medieval streets, the amazing architecture of castles and monasteries, and the magical ritual of lighting street lamps. Tourists with children are interested in the heroical Brest Fortress, as a symbol of courage and fortitude of the people who defended it. One of the best nature reserves in Europe, “Belovezhskaya Pushcha”, lies north of the city. The residence of the brother of the Slavic Santa Claus named Zyuzya is located there. Brest is a perfect place to relax, spend time away from the hustle and bustle. You will enjoy walks around the city. The sights will leave a trail in your heart. It is ready to welcome guests in the best and most beautiful time of the year: late spring, early autumn, or summer. Old willows, a smooth bend of the river, ancient churches and cathedrals, blooming cherries — all this is so opposing to the events that happened in terrible years of the last wars of the 20th century.

Imagine a quiet idyll of nature on the background of the Medieval stone houses, swans swimming elegantly in the same canal with cruise ships, beautiful picturesque docks and the most delicious waffles with chocolate in the world! All of this inspires wonder and causes an irresistible desire to visit the described place. That’s a small but quite authentic Belgian town called Bruges.

long_description.en:
Nowadays, the population of Bruges is a little more than one hundred thousand people. Though, it used to be a populated city once with over two hundred thousand citizens. According to other sources, the number even reached five hundred thousand people. For historical reasons, the national composition of the citizens is divided into three almost equal groups: the Belgians, Dutch, French. You can also meet here representatives of many other ethnical groups. Dutch is considered to be the most popular language here. It has a strong Flemish dialect.
        Annually, over 2 million tourists all over the world come to explore Bruges. Locals will be more than happy to greet every newcomer.

description.en: Liege is one of the largest cities in the Kingdom of Belgium and the capital of the province of the same name in the south of the country. At the same time, it has been considered the world center of firearms designers for several centuries. In fact, these groups of people come here in order to study and work. In addition, Liege is widely known as a major port that is located on the Meuse River. Nowadays, it is connected to Antwerp through the Albert Canal.

Brussels is the heart of Europe and the non-official capital of the European Union. It’s worth visiting its place at least once in a lifetime to see the gorgeous palaces, ancient architecture, extraordinary fountains, and sculptures. Thousands of tourists come here to attend unique museums and galleries, and afterward, relax in a cozy cafe or bar. It has a truly inimitable atmosphere that every person who likes traveling and discovering something new should experience. Brussels is located in the center of Belgium. The city stands on the river Senne. However, you won’t be able to see it. Due to the urbanization in the XIX century, the Belgian engineers covered it. Start your acquaintance with the city with the central square Grand Place (Grote Markt). There you can find the City Hall, King’s House, and other historical buildings that were built in the XVII century. The architectural complex of the square is included in the UNESCO World Heritage Sites List.

long_description.en:
The population of Brussels compiles almost 180 thousand people. In fact, Brussels embraces nowadays a considerable part of the Brussels-Capital Region. Thus, the total number of citizens is more than one million people.

Brussels is mostly inhabited by the Francophones. The main red line of the population is not in nationality but the language. It’s connected with a big number of immigrants, and employees of the European Quarter (an area with the establishments of the EU, NATO, and other organizations). Moreover, one-third of the population are foreigners.

description.en: The largest city in Flanders is located on the banks of the River Scheldt. Antwerp is the city of Gothic cathedrals, marvelous castles, the center of fashion, and diamond industry. Antwerp is the European capital of luxury, the motherland of Peter Paul Rubens and many other great artists. Streets with ancient mansions neighbor on districts with nightclubs. After you spend the whole day attending galleries and museums, you can drop by boutiques of famous designers. This city of royal chocolate, diamond masterpieces, and fashionable shops has gained great popularity among tourists all over the world a long time ago.

long_description.en: According to the population census in 2017, more than 500 thousand people live in the city. The majority of citizens are Flemings. The city also has immigrants from Eastern Europe, Africa, and Asia.

description.en: Ghent is a musical symphony, frozen in stone. This charming city is situated in the north of Belgium in the region of East Flanders, where the Scheldt and Leie rivers meet. It combines a magnificent and harmonious blend of scenic nature, architectural masterpieces, and modern buildings. It is cozy and spacious at the same time. Lanes, many canals, and the most beautiful buildings on their banks are cozily and whimsically intertwined here. Many sights of this city are included in the UNESCO World Heritage List. In the streets of Ghent, you seem to be immersed in a medieval fairy tale, as the city has not yielded to the influence of time, has preserved its identity and magic to this day. Its warm atmosphere and friendly people make it unique and especially attractive for tourist trips. Ghent is particularly stunning when it is buried in green parks, gardens, and squares decorated with flowers.

long_description.en:
Ghent is incredibly cosmopolitan and welcoming to its visitors. Its inhabitants have a very pleasant and easygoing disposition; they are cheerful and upbeat. Ghent people love nature and take care of it. Perhaps that is why the streets are full of flowerbeds, which delight with the riot and variety of colors.

The ancestors of modern citizens have experienced hard times more than once. They have survived, kept their face and color, love of life, kindness, and passed all these qualities to their offspring. They honor their ancestors in Ghent, honor the past, and are proud of it. This is a city of hard workers, not accustomed to bowing before hardships. Many students from all over the world come here every year. You are sure to be won over by the hospitality and incredibly warm aura of this wonderful city.

description.en: Sofia, as a real woman, prefers to keep her real age in secret. There is a saying on its coat of arms: “Grows but never gets old”. Indeed, you won’t tell the exact age of the capital of Bulgaria. But if to look closer, it becomes evident. The previous millenniums peer out of church windows, wink with survived mosaics on the floor, call over with a thud of stones on a narrow street. Sofia is versatile and multifaceted; it can fascinate and impress. While walking along its streets, time slows and it seems that you also stop to grow old. Sofia has seen a lot and is always ready to share its knowledge.

long_description.en:
The majority of the capital's population (over 96%) are ethnic Bulgarians. Turks are in second place. Another significant nation in Sofia is the Roma. Some areas, because of the abundance of their settlements, are even called Roma ghettos.

The gender component here is not different from other modern major cities. There are slightly fewer men than women. So, in Sofia, there are 1,106 women for every 1,000 representatives of the stronger sex. The most numerous age group is people aged 18 to 64 years.

description.en: Varna is a beautiful resort-city, located on the Black Sea shore of Bulgaria. The picturesque coast, sandy beaches, and balneological centers have made the city a favorite place for recreation and treatment of Europeans. Ancient Varna has prepared for tourists not only a beach holiday but also many amazing historical monuments. Ancient architecture, the royal manor, majestic cathedrals, interesting museums, magnificent parks — there are many unique places worth admiring.

Bansko is a popular ski resort 160 km from the capital of Bulgaria, Sofia. People come here to have a bright and vibrant rest and, at the same time, not to spend too much money. Recently, this place has been recognized as the most cost-effective ski resort in the world. For those who do not know how to ski, there are professional schools — experienced instructors will teach you how to ski and snowboard within a few days. Apart from active recreation, there is also something to see in terms of architecture. Ancient temples and a uniquely-beautiful park will not leave anyone indifferent. Bansko has many night clubs, restaurants, and cafes with delicious and nourishing Bulgarian food. Therefore, you will not be bored in this cozy city with narrow streets and cute houses — either you are 20 or 70 years old.

Like the ancient capital of the Roman Empire, the primarily Bulgarian Plovdiv was built on Seven Hills. However, one of them (Markov) was destroyed by the inhabitants a little more than a century ago, when they dismantled it in stone for the construction of an expanding policy. But it is worth paying tribute to the citizens — they carefully preserved all the other attractions of Plovdiv. And over a history of several millennia, many of these sights have accumulated — Thracian, Roman, Byzantine, Ottoman, and Soviet. And this is not counting their beautiful and original Bulgarian sites! To get around this entire splendor, you will need more than one day and really sturdy shoes.

Sarajevo is an extravaganza city in which the ancient Ottoman culture merges with modern Europe into an incredible cocktail. The world-famous Serbian writer and artist Momo Kapor, called the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina —the center of all wars. Surely, there are many dark days in the history of Sarajevo, but they are already past. And nothing prevents its residents from enjoying life and sharing with the guests the incredible beauty of the city streets and the mountains surrounding them, the stunning atmosphere of old coffee houses, and the inherently Balkan ability not to rush anywhere and relish every moment.

long_description.en: According to the results of the last census, 275524 people live in the capital. The largest ethnic group is Bosnians (81%). Serbs make up 4% of Sarajevo's population, Croats — 5%. The remaining 10% are Jews, Roma, descendants of mixed marriages, and foreign workers who have settled in the city.

description.en: Budapest is the capital of Hungary and one of the most beautiful cities in Europe. It stretches on both sides of the wide Danube river and attracts tourists with its magnificent architecture, comfortable climate, and thermal springs. Only when you walk around Budapest and admire its extraordinary beauty, you do understand why it is called the "pearl of the Danube". The majestic Citadella, the pompous Parliament building, Margaret Island, beautiful bridges are only a small part of what is waiting for tourists here. Moreover, the city has a rich history, which is told by every street, every square, and every building.

long_description.en:
The population of the city is as diverse as its history. Budapest is home to almost 20% of Hungary's population. Still, recent statistics show that the city's residents are increasingly choosing to live in its quiet suburbs rather than in a bustling metropolis. The city is home to 91% of Hungarians, while the remaining 9% are divided between Germans, Slovaks, Russians, and Ukrainians.

As far as the religious affiliation of Budapest residents is concerned, the majority of the population are the followers of Protestantism and Catholicism. But globalization has also intruded into the religious sphere. Lately, more and more representatives of Islam have been living in Budapest.

description.en: Debrecen is a cozy European city in the east of Hungary, which attracts tourists with its variety of architecture, fantastic atmosphere, and, of course, its famous thermal baths. It has everything for a comfortable and leisurely holiday — cozy restaurants, green parks, SPA centers, colorful markets, and shops. Debrecen will meet every guest with warmth, tell its centuries-old history, and demonstrate itself in all its glory. The Nagyerdei Park, colorful trams, old houses, and delicious pastries will undoubtedly remain in the memory of the traveler. The city does not promise you extreme emotions but guarantees a warm welcome and the most enjoyable holiday experience.

This island is famous for a variety of mystical legends associated with this tourist destination. It was mentioned by Homer in the Odyssey. In turn, the locals consider Feakes, the son of Poseidon and the nymph Kerkyra, as the first person in their global family. Simultaneously, Corfu is a beautiful island in its own way. The architecture of its cities and towns amazes with a unique mixture of many styles. In turn, nature captivates with its beauty and generosity of solar heat, whereas the coast of the island is washed by two seas. The residents of this island are surprisingly open-minded and friendly. These people love music, which is why they often sing cantadedes (funny songs created by locals). By the way, it was on this island that the oldest philharmonic society in Greece was founded. For quite a long time, the vacation on Corfu has been considered a privilege of aristocrats and representatives of Bohemia. However, today, the cleanest sandy beaches, cozy bays, and green cliffs are accessible to everyone. Corfu is always waiting for guests who want to enjoy this unique corner of nature.

Chania is located on the northwest coast of the Greek island of Crete. This picturesque place is a real paradise for dreamers and those who prefer a peaceful holiday. For centuries, the city has been reverently preserving its unique atmosphere and combines the outlines of different cultures in its layout. A trip here is an opportunity to get a boost of inspiration, spiritually enrich yourself and relax from the hustle. Amazing long beaches, picturesque nature, a sea of ​​traditional delicacies, and the enchanting energy of historical places make your vacation unforgettable. A trip to Chania will bring vivid emotions, beautiful photos, and the desire to come here again.

On the Mediterranean coast of Crete, you can find the legendary city named Heraklion. It is the abode of the ancient Greek hero Hercules and the mythical Labyrinth of the Minotaur. This unique corner of Greece offers tourists a lot of entertainment options. The beauty of the colorful narrow streets with charming buildings and ancient temples is emphasized by the natural splendor of this place, such as turquoise sea waters, sunny beaches, and green vineyards. Heraklion guests have the opportunity to find stunning historical attractions, souvenir shops, boutiques, picturesque cafes, and restaurants with amazing local cuisine.

On the coast of the Thermaic Gulf lies the cultural capital of Greece — Thessaloniki. The home of the country's national culture is called the city of three civilizations — Roman, Hellenistic, and Byzantine. Roman columns, early Christian and Byzantine cathedrals, Turkish mosques can impress the most demanding tourist. Medicinal thermal springs, pristine lakes, and a wonderful climate brought Thessaloniki the glory of an open-air resort. Developed infrastructure, many nightclubs, and marine entertainment attract outdoor enthusiasts to the city. It is impossible to get bored in Thessaloniki, here everyone will find a lot of interesting and exciting things.

long_description.en: The city has more than 300 thousand people, and the number of inhabitants together with the suburban area is more than 1 million. Most of the citizens are Greeks by nationality. Also in the city live Bulgarians, Jews, Romanians, Pakistanis, Indians, Georgians, Russians, Ukrainians, and representatives of other nations.

description.en: When you feel the urge to touch the antiquities and visit places of strength and relax at sea at the same time, Athens is the best option. In the capital of Greece, you will discover not only the diverse ancient world, but also enjoy the beautiful nature and breathe clean sea air with the admixture of light, pine, and citrus scent. This is a museum city, consisting of unique monuments and architectural masterpieces. Everything here is imbued with the spirit of history: from the narrow medieval streets of Plaka to the majestic Acropolis and Parthenon. And if you try to solve all the mysteries of the city, it will take a long time.

long_description.en: More than three million people officially live in Athens. But in fact, some sources indicate a very different figure of five million. The city is home to many foreigners who are not officially registered. The absolute majority of the population is Greek. There are communities of Turks, Albanians, Armenians, some Balkan peoples. Most of the communication in the city is in Greek and English, but one can also hear Russian.

description.en: Rhodes is the main city on the island of the same name with many thousands history, a place where the Mediterranean Sea merges with the Aegean. It will surprise everyone who loves a varied vacation with the atmosphere of Antiquity and the Middle Ages, combined with modern solutions. The capital of the island is perhaps the most interesting and beautiful corner of Greece, where the peculiar “traces” of all the conquerors (and there were many of them) will tell a lot about the greatness of ancient civilizations. Once, right here, in the Mandraki port, all travelers were greeted by the giant Colossus of Rhodes (one of the 7 Wonders of the World), showing in advance the greatness and power of the entire policy. A bronze sun-god statue was destroyed long ago by an earthquake, but some special piece of a miracle still lives here, and there is still something unusual in the city. But what exactly — you will decide to yourself as soon as you personally visit Rhodes!

Kalamata is a resort town on the northwest coast of the Messiniakos Gulf of the Greek Peninsula named Peloponnese (the capital of Messenia County). Mount Kalata‌ (part of the Taiget ridge) and the Pamisos River surround the city from different sides. However, the main part of Kalamata is facing the Ionian Sea gulf. Quiet, idyllic seascapes, centuries-old history, and key attributes of the modern megapolis come together in this place. As a result, tourists often describe this city as a paradise. Simultaneously, Kalamata is famous for its olive groves, which are usually perceived as one of the best in the world. Oil, soap, and olives are exported from this city to various places on our planet. Once you visit this city, it is recommended to consider different kinds of attractions, including nightclubs, picturesque landscapes, and educational museums. Besides, pay attention to figs, olives, raisins, and clean pebble beaches with blue waters.

long_description.en:
The history of Kalamata begins with the ancient city of Pharae. This name, referring to this area, was mentioned even by the ancient Greek poet Homer. It is known that from the VIII century B.C., the place was ruled by the valiant Spartans. During the Peloponnesian War between Athens and Sparta, Kalamata was not economically developed and was of little strategic interest to the city-states.

The changes in the life of the city began in the 13th century and were associated with the Fourth Crusade. From this period, Kalamata belonged to the Franks. The construction of the fortifications also led to the city's economic development.

The rich and generous land of Kalamata now beckoned more and more conquerors. In 1459, the city fell under the rule of the Serene Republic of Venice. And three centuries later, the conquerors appeared here again - Kalamata became part of the Ottoman Empire.

The year 1821 was marked as the year of the city's liberation from the Turks. In Kalamata, rebellions against Ottoman domination broke out. Soon the wave of liberation swept across Greece. And in 1829, Turkey had to recognize the independence of this country. Kalamata was at the origin of the Greek Revolution for Freedom.

At the end of the XIX century, the town began to build a port. This contributed to the rapid development of Kalamata. Although it is not strategically important for the country, it is the second most important polis in the Peloponnese Peninsula today. The export of olives has already become a trademark of the city. And the fame of a quiet tourist spot with top-notch beaches gradually attracts more and more travelers worldwide.

description.en: Tbilisi is a dream city. When you think of it, a smile appears on your face and heart fills up with warmth. Stories about Georgian hospitality are true. And you can see it for yourself when coming to the capital of Georgia. The past and present meet in this city, creating a unique painting. Tbilisi has a special, full of kindness, atmosphere, the air is filled with love and sentimentality, and the smiles of the people you meet make you smile in return. Georgian hospitality, together with gorgeous local cuisine, will grant you an amazing trip. Tbilisi is a city where you feel right at home. You are always welcomed here. The capital of Georgia is lying on the banks of the Kura River. On the one bank, you will find the Old Town with its legendary baths, the Narikala fortress, Kartlis Deda, and narrow cozy streets with wine shops, churchkhela stalls, and gift shops. On A glass Presidential Palace and Rike Park are situated on the other bank.

long_description.en:
Because Tbilisi was invaded more than 20 times in antiquity, the city's population has developed a very colorful character. The vibrant mixture of the best features of such nationalities as Georgians, Armenians, Russians, Jews, Azerbaijanis, Kurds, Ossetians, Ukrainians, and Greeks has yielded a magnificent result — the people of Tbilisi. They are cheerful, positive, creative, talented, and very enterprising people. Where else will you find such a rich and colorful variety of cultures, customs, and religions coexisting at the hospitable Georgian table under the roof of the blue Tbilisi sky?

The residents of the capital of Georgia are very friendly and helpful. Neighbors in the streets of the old districts know each other not just by sight but also by name. The doors of the houses here are not locked. Family holidays, birthdays, and weddings are celebrated across the street, and guests are always welcome as the dearest people. They are musical and poetic people who cherish the history of their ancestors and their culture with devotion.

description.en: Sunny Batumi is located in a comfortable bay, on the Black Sea coast. It is a city where ancient monuments of history and architecture of the third millennium are harmoniously combined with national flavor. Batumi attracts tourists not only with its sights, but also with its unique microclimate, exotic flora of subtropics, and national cuisine. Sea recreation, exciting places, and incredible discoveries - hospitable Batumi offers it all.

Even if you don't like the fairy tales of Hans Christian Andersen and have never been a fan of The Little Mermaid, you will surely like Copenhagen. Denmark won the status of the most visited city in Scandinavia for a reason. It's a city of history, coziness, and strolls. There are almost no modern skyscrapers here, but there are unique streets, parks, and buildings that tourists from all over the world come to admire. Copenhagen warmly welcomes its guests, offers bicycles for rent, attracts with festivals, and even beaches with snow-white sand. It sounds a bit fantastic, not to mention a face to face meeting with this magical city!

long_description.en:
Copenhagen ranks first in Denmark and one of the leading Scandinavian countries by the number of local residents. The capital has experienced two waves of mass immigration to Denmark that took place in 1990 and the first decade of the XXI century.

Nowadays, the vast majority of Copenhagen's locals are Danish — 96%. They are followed by Germans, Swedes, Norwegians, Icelanders, Dutch, and other nationalities.

description.en: Dublin — is the capital of freedom-loving Ireland, the city of ancient Vikings, dynamic and cheerful metropolis. Its luxury districts with wealthy residences and Georgian architecture are close to numerous pubs and nightclubs, whereas wide streets and broad squares are near beautiful parks and gardens. Diverse Dublin knows how to fascinate a tourist with millennial historical monuments, unique museums, and galleries, the unbelievably wonderful atmosphere of independent and proud-spirited Ireland.

long_description.en: According to information in 2016, almost 1 million 200 thousand people live in the city. About 79% have Irish nationality. Also, immigrants from other countries like Europe, Asia, and Africa live here.

description.en: Kenmare is located in County Kerry in southern Ireland. The name of the city can be translated as "the little nest." And it reflects the appearance of the settlement — everything around looks very cozy and neat. Kenmare has original buildings with unusual architectural elements. And even the local Holy Cross Church, looks more festively than strictly. Kenmare produces good wool products, as well as handmade laces. At the uptown of the city you can find a ritual circle of stones dating back to the Bronze Age, and not far from it — an unusual small bridge. In the south, near the bay, there is a city park. What is more, it is easy to get from Kenmare to two natural pearls of Ireland — Gleninchaquin Park (in the south) and Killarney National Park (in the north).

Waterford is a city in the south of Ireland. It is located on the banks of the River Suir, near its firth, and is the largest seaport in the region. Also, the city is famous for its crystal products which have been produced here since the end of the 18th century. Waterford is the oldest city in the country, which was founded by the Vikings back in 914. And today it attracts tourists with its historical monuments, museums and parks. Firstly, a tourist should visit the Viking Triangle — the old part of the city, enclosed by a wall of the 10th century. The inherent Viking settlement was situated on its borders. At one of the Triangle Sites stands the Reginald’s Tower, constructed with the wall. Now there is one of the three city historical museums. You should also visit the Medieval Museum and the Bishop's Palace Museum. Other places of interest include Christ Church Cathedral, Municipal Art Gallery, The Theatre Royal, and John Roberts Square. You can also take a tour of Waterford Crystal. And about 14 kilometers from Waterford, in Kilmeadan, there is a beautiful Mount Congreve botanical garden.

Reykjavik, the northernmost capital of the planet, is located on the Seltjarnarnes peninsula in the northern Atlantic. A city with surprisingly clean air, situated in a bay and surrounded by mountains, is considered one of the most comfortable for living in the world. White nights, proximity to nature, buildings in the early Scandinavian style, and vibrant nightlife attract tourists here at any time of the year. The city of harsh Vikings has prepared many wonderful discoveries, magnificent places, and exciting entertainments.

long_description.en: According to the 2010 data, Reykjavik is home to slightly more than 100 thousand people. The national composition of the city's inhabitants is quite homogeneous: about 94% are Icelanders. There are also natives of Poland, Lithuania, the Philippines, and Germany.

description.en: Famagusta is located on the east coast of Cyprus. Once, it was a popular fashionable resort which was known for noisy beach parties and a luxury holiday. Modern Famagusta looks like a ghost-city. A trip here allows you to explore the history, which gives shivers up your spine. Lonely ancient buildings and the ruins under security transfer you to the far 1974. And it seems that the city is still there. Famagusta is surrounded by the atmosphere of the past but still remembers the future. In addition to the interesting sights, tourists are offered clean beaches, lovely restaurants, and a full range of emotions.

Pristina is a city on the Balkan Peninsula, the capital of the partially recognized Republic of Kosovo. It is located in the North-Eastern part, near the Goljak mountains. Despite the fact that the military conflict in the Balkans has long ended, Pristina has not yet gained popularity among the tourist community. Nevertheless, the tourism business is actively developing in the city, and the infrastructure is expanding. So if you have a desire and opportunity to visit this city, then there is sure to be something to see and where to go.

Riga is a tempting word for connoisseurs of new experiences, vivid emotions, and a relaxed atmosphere. On the coast of the Baltic Sea is a city that embodied the dream of every tourist. The chaste plains lie on the banks of the Daugava River (Zapadnaya Dvina), where it flows into the Gulf of Riga. The city will please nature-lovers, and urban connoisseurs will be satisfied while enjoying the view of amazing architectural buildings in the Art Nouveau style, the sophistication of monuments, and the relaxed interweaving of streets, avenues, and boulevards. If someone at least once takes a walk in the evening-night Riga, one will fall in love with this city for life!

long_description.en: Riga is the most populous city not only in Latvia but also in the whole Baltics. The lion's share of all nationalities living here belongs to Latvians (46.3%). There are also Russians (also quite a few — 40.2%), Belarusians (about 3.9%), Ukrainians (about 3.4%), Poles (very few - 1.9%), and other nationalities (such as native residents of neighboring Lithuania and Estonia, as well as Germans and Jews).

description.en: Palanga is a wonderful Baltic Sea resort, celebrated by the poet Adam Mickiewicz in the 19th century. It attracts tourists throughout the year. In summer, life is in full swing here. The city hosts many festivals and fests. There is a wide range of ways to spend time with children. Those who like sport can find a lot of venues for their favorite activities (tennis courts, swimming pools, bicycle paths, horseback riding locations). Sounds of bicycles and taxis passing by are constantly heard. It is quiet and peaceful here in winter. The beaches are not crowded. Those who like winter sea romantics and who want to improve health in the local balneological health centers and SPAs, drink calcium and sodium chloride waters, and take bog baths come to the city. Tourists from all over the world come to Palanga for magical nature, idyllic long sandy beaches surrounded by velvet dunes and fragrant emerald pines. In addition to wonderful nature, there you can find many interesting locations — castles, old mansions, churches, and cathedrals. Palanga has an atmosphere that is good for a holiday. Here you can recharge your energy.

Klaipeda is the northern port of Lithuania, washed by the waters of the Baltic Sea and the Curonian Spit; it is also known as the birthplace of the legendary Balts. The rich history of the city is reflected in its architecture, creating a unique charm and atmosphere. Narrow cobbled streets, half-timbered buildings, and the majestic Teutonic castle are ancient witnesses to the glorious past of the city, which attract history connoisseurs. At the same time, Klaipeda is known not only for its architectural attractions, but also for its unique museums, art galleries, white beaches, and charming parks. As a city where you can fall in love from the first minutes, Klaipeda is also a place that encourages people to return and enjoy local attractions again and again.

Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania, can safely be called one of the most beautiful cities in Europe. Its historic center (the Old City) is rightfully included in the UNESCO World Heritage List. Many tourists, having once visited this cozy and green city, want to return here again and again to plunge into the atmosphere of its ancient, cobblestone streets, to admire the abundance of architectural styles of buildings and numerous churches, to feel the magical aura of the city, described by Max Fry in "Tales of Old Vilnius." Here you will find a harmonious combination of old buildings with new structures of modern architecture. In some places, you can see the houses left from the Soviet times. By the way, they, as well as other buildings of the capital at that time, became the "heroes" of the famous series "Chernobyl." Most of the filming took place in Vilnius, and it has added to its popularity. Every year, more than a million tourists visit this clean, quiet, friendly, and multinational city. Old Vilnius has many mysteries, which can hardly be discovered in one trip. It's worth coming here at any time of year.

long_description.en:
Vilnius is the home of all nations. It has always been and remains open and friendly to people of all nationalities. Until the middle of the 20th century, the Lithuanians were even in the minority here. The main population at that time was Poles, Jews, Russians, and Belarusians. Today Lithuanians make up a large part of the population; the rest (according to data from 2011) are representatives of 128 nationalities, comprising more than 30 percent of the capital's inhabitants. They are mostly Poles, Russians, Belarusians, Ukrainians, and Jews.
        Since 2013, Lithuania has celebrated the Day of National Communities annually.

description.en: As a miniature and unique city, Kaunas is situated in the heart of Lithuania, among picturesque nature, not far from the Baltic Sea, at the mouth of the Neris and Nemunas rivers. This city is often associated with an animated illustration of a children's fairy tale, which tells the story about beautiful princesses, treacherous dragons, and brave knights. The interweaving of different architectural directions and eras makes its appearance completely unique. Kaunas has its own beautiful image, its own style, exquisite charm, grace, and a certain chic. When people arrive here, they tend to slowly roam the streets, as well as enjoy the beautiful nature, the atmosphere of comfort, and peace. Once you get into the Old City, you imperceptibly immerse in the period of chivalry. Kaunas has leisure and relaxation options for every taste. Numerous local theaters can delight with their repertoire, whereas museums can offer a wide variety of exhibitions and excursions. If you wish to spend time alongside nature, you can visit wonderful alleys, parks, and squares. Moreover, the majority of tourists are fond of donuts from cozy cafes on Laisves Alley. It is a very atmospheric city, which is why your trip will definitely be unforgettable.

The capital of North Macedonia, surrounded by mountains on the Vardar River, is the largest city in the country. The city is an economic and tourist center. After a visit to Skopje, you may have mixed feelings. On the one hand, it has a rich historical heritage, and the locals try hard to highlight it by erecting monuments to their former governors. On the other hand, when you start to dig deeper into history, you start to understand that many of them are pedestals to kings, who ruled in Bulgaria. And a military commander Alexander the Great, whose monument stands on Central Square, has nothing to do with Skopje and Macedonia. The name of the country was also adopted. There is a region of Macedonia in Greece. For the first time in history, a state had to change its official name and add “Northern”. But despite such contortion of facts, Skopje remains a homeland of mother Theresa, a cosmopolitan capital, and a city where you can find the Millennium Cross, one of the world’s largest.

long_description.en:
Because of the long Turkish influence in these lands, Arab culture is firmly entrenched in the local customs. Many women wear closed clothing and hats, and wearing open clothes in public or mosques is considered disrespectful to their culture.

In general, the local population is very positive towards tourists. They do not speak English well but will do their best to help you. However, there is something you should not do - avoid talking to the locals about political topics. The issues of independence and the identity of the entire state are very acute here and are going through a bad time.

description.en: Valletta is a beautiful, cozy, and ancient city. It is not only the capital of the island state of Malta but also the major city of excursions — a solid open-air museum. Valletta is located in the north-east of Malta. The heart of the town lies on small Mount Sciberras, while the rest of the polis goes smoothly down to the Mediterranean Sea. Valletta is so tiny that it can be walked through the length and breadth. And in this context, the main feature of the Maltese capital emerges — despite its miniature size, it has never been captured by anyone! And, as a consequence, since the founding of the city in the XVI century, its appearance has remained in its pristine form. Architectural creations in the Baroque style continue to delight guests in Valletta today. And this is not a stylization for an era; this is the era itself! Millions of tourists come to Valletta to unravel the big secret of the small capital and enjoy a bright holiday in a knightly town.

Would you like to be invited on a date with King Stefan cel Mare? Have you received an invitation to Cathedral Park? Would you like to taste nectar from juicy bunches of grapes or drink a glass of traditional wine? What about taking a romantic walk to the Valea Morilor Lake, which means “valley of the mills”, feeding the swans, and making a wish? If these statements make you excited, you should definitely come to Chisinau!

Bergen is the largest city in Norway, cozily settled on the North Sea coast. It embraces everyone who crosses the fylke line, lulls with the rustling waves in the picturesque fjords, charms with the green mountain slopes covered with clouds. Traveling around Bergen feels like you're in a toy world with bright wooden houses and boats waving their masts' spires at the port marina. There's no room for fuss, and you can breathe easily and freely. Bergen will be the perfect final point on a cruise through the Norwegian fjords, so make sure you stay here for a day or two.

long_description.en: There are only 250,000 people living in Bergen. They are mostly native Norwegians and descendants of European merchants. All of them are very proud of the beauty of their city, its cultural and commercial traditions. The locals are friendly and are always happy with tourists. Everyone will help you find your way or tell you how to have a good time. About 10% of the population are students, thanks to whom Bergen is always young, lively, and vibrant.

description.en: The most beautiful city in the country, located between the Geiranger and Huron fjords, has not a self-proclaimed title at all. Almost unanimously, the inhabitants of Norway decided by popular vote. And who can object to them, looking at the fabulous Ålesund, above which the snowy peaks of the Sunnmøre Alps rise. But the city on seven islands, connected by bridges and underground tunnels, is famous not only for its majestic nature. Rebuilt after a grand fire in 1904 in a single Art Nouveau style, it became a real monument of the architectural era. Ålesund is part of the international Art Nouveau network, created to study, protect and spread the Art Nouveau style.

Stavanger is an interesting and versatile city. It bears the title of the richest city in Norway and was nicknamed “White”. Major oil companies have their offices here. Also, here you will find the most beautiful fjord in the country. All the buildings of the Old City are made of wood. They are painted yellow and white. Only one street differs from the palette — Colorful. It was made because Norway rarely has sunny days. This stroke creates a unique, festive atmosphere and makes Stavanger even more recognizable. Of course, here you can find modern buildings; among them are the fish market, hotels, cafes, and restaurants. But still, the narrow streets of centuries-long history in the city center are something special. The majority of tourists come here to see them. Not to mention, the incredible beauty of bays and cliffs. They have no competition.

Oslo is a city with a complicated Nordic character. In the capital of Norway, you can feel the noble restraint, refined simplicity, comfort, and coziness. This is one of the oldest cities in the Scandinavian Peninsula, the largest town in Europe. It is located in the northern part of the picturesque bay of the same name. The unique and elegant style of Oslo architecture is fascinating and impressive. The calm rhythm of life, the atmosphere of well-being, and the absence of deliberate chic create a special aura that is inclined to dreams and creation. Art lovers in all its manifestations will find here interesting museums, art galleries, and theaters. For those who prefer outdoor activities, we recommend upscale ski slopes. On the shores of the North Sea, you can relax on the magnificent rocky beaches. The magical nature of fabulous fjords is an ideal place to relax and seek inspiration. Here people with great awe relate to the environment. The reward is pure air and water. Oslo is not at first sight, but confidently, step by step, will open its heart for you. A piece of your soul will forever remain among the bays and rocks where the melodies of Edvard Grieg hover in the narrow streets of the city, warmed by the rays of the gentle Norwegian sun, and preserving the memory of Henryk Ibsen.

long_description.en:
The ancestors of the modern quiet and happy inhabitants of the Norwegian capital were the mighty, legendary Vikings. Since the XIX century, mostly ethnic Norwegians and visitors from Western Europe live in the western part of Oslo. First and second-generation migrants mostly populate the eastern part of the city.

The descendants of the Vikings do not rush anywhere. They enjoy the harmony of life and love music. Their passion is the sea and skiing. Residents of Oslo have a special mentality. They are true patriots of the country and love their city. The love of nature and all-natural things here is elevated to the cult. And in general, typical Scandinavians are practical, reserved, and adore sports and picnics.

description.en: Appear in the Arctic Circle and open a new Norway, this is what you get after exploring Tromsø. The city is located on several islands connected by bridges and attracts those who like unusual nature. Famous fjords, mountains, sea — Tromsø won’t let anyone indifferent. You would like to walk along the streets of this city even in winter, visit museums and learn its history, meet the locals and remember to look in the sky because you may see real wonder there.

The south of Portugal, a popular tourist Algarve region, the Ria Formosa lagoon, and the Atlantic ocean. This is Faro from the geographical point of view. However, travelers get a lot more than just standard geographical names. Cozy streets and old houses, ancient temples on the background of beautiful nature, preserved area, the most delicious cuisine, friendly people — Faro is perfect for an unforgettable vacation and as a starting point to travel around Portugal.

long_description.en:
The first settlement on the territory of today's Faro was founded in the pre-Roman period. It was inhabited by the Cynetes, who supported the Romans during the Lusitanian War. After the Romans' conquest of the Iberian Peninsula, the settlement turned into a city called Ossonoba. It became one of the largest ports and an important administrative center in a short time.

From the VII to the XIII century, the territory of the Iberian Peninsula, including Ossonoba, was ruled by Arab and Moorish invaders. In 1249 King Afonso III liberated the land, renamed Ossonoba in Faro, and gave it the official status of city (September 7, 1540). Later he made it the capital of the Algarve.

The period from the XVIII to the XIX century is considered the most difficult in the city's history. The first challenges were the earthquakes that happened in 1722 and 1755. Serious devastation was also brought to the city by British soldiers, who often ravaged the territory of Portugal.

But even such events did not prevent Faro from becoming one of the central cities not only in its region but also in the country as a whole. It continues to develop and attracts more and more tourists every year.

description.en: Lisbon is a city that smells like salt, fish, fresh pastries, and pine needles. A considerable historical past of the capital of Portugal is closely intertwined with progressive, modernist trends. Lisbon is inspiring. Situated on the banks of the Tagus River, it lurks its own ocean — waves of red roofs and foam of snow-white facades of houses from the height of viewing platforms (mirador) excite consciousness. Here you can wander around the streets paved with white cobblestone all day, drink coffee, observe azulejos — and you won’t find any similar details. Lisbon is revealed to every traveler in different ways. Go there to meet your personal capital of conquistadors.

long_description.en: A quarter of the country’s population lives in the metropolitan area of Lisbon. In turn, 87% of them are Portuguese, whereas the rest comes from former Portuguese colonies. When it comes to the capital of Lisbon, numerous friendly people live there. They value comfort and traditions, highlighting the importance of family and football in their lives. Considering that Lisbon sometimes lacks drive, you can often experience the desire to pull local populations out of the state of calmness.

description.en: Cascais is a small resort town in Portugal, which is located on the shores of the Atlantic Ocean. As a city situated near the mouth of the Tagus River, it is surrounded by the Sintra mountains. From the lighthouse to the church, Cascais is completely painted, whereas its colorful balconies are often associated with linens that hang there. Such an atmospheric small town offers people the opportunity to feel the charm of Portugal — with its ancient palaces and castles of the Renaissance, as well as delicious seafood delicacies. Locals prefer to slowly walk along the cobbled streets, while young people go on picnics on the golden beach of the ocean. In this city, you can relax from the bustle of modern megapolises and enjoy the natural wonder — the Boca do Inferno cliff, nicknamed the "Devil's Mouth".

Fabulous! It is the definition that suits Sintra best. Here, standing on the wall of one of the many castles, you can easily imagine that a horn will blow out now and a brave knight will challenge a fire-breathing dragon to a mortal battle. Sintra castles, palaces, mansions, and villas are really great. They are scattered on the rocks and immersed in greenery. Each of these beautiful buildings has a legend or even several. From one of the buildings - the evil lizard abducted the beautiful princess, and on the other - the restless spirit of the former owner still roams. Also, Sintra is about magnificent parks and gardens, as well as narrow streets, as if frozen in the Middle Ages. Here you are fascinated at every step. And this is not an exaggeration at all. It has been inspiring poets and artists. It attracts couples in love and those who still believe in fairy tales.

long_description.en:
In terms of ethnic composition, most Sintra residents are Portuguese, followed by Spaniards. In addition, quite a large percentage of the city's population today are of Maghreb origin — Arabs and Africans. About 20% of the current residents of Sintra were born far beyond its borders.

The age structure of Sintra is quite young compared to other European cities. The predominant age group here is between 30 and 39 years old. The most common religions are Catholicism, Islam, and Judaism. Almost all residents of Sintra are quite sociable, eager to help tourists, and ready to tell many amazing stories about the local attractions.

description.en: On the hills of the Atlantic coast lies one of the most ancient cities in Europe — Porto. The stunningly beautiful old capital of Portugal seems to be floating out of the water. Ancient houses built into the rocks, colorful medieval buildings, narrow cobblestone streets, and stone stairs — all this creates a fabulous atmosphere of the Middle Ages. Amazingly, the spirit of antiquity in the city is combined with modern buildings, numerous nightclubs, and entertainment venues. Such a variety of historical monuments and lots of entertainment made Porto incredibly attractive for travelers.

long_description.en: According to the 2011 census, more than 200 thousand people live in the city. About 90% of them are Portuguese by nationality. Spaniards, Africans, Brazilians, and Eastern Europeans also live here.

description.en: Coimbra is one of the most beautiful Portuguese cities located in the central part of the country. It was founded on the place of a Roman settlement and was the first capital of Portugal. The city gained wide fame because of the university, listed by UNESCO. The educational institution was established in 1290, and is considered the oldest in the country and one of the oldest in Europe. Tourists take a great interest in the Ancient University Square, Tower of the University, General Library, as well as museums, including an Academic Prison. A third of the city’s population is students, teachers, and university staff. Among the architectural monuments of Coimbra, one can distinguish the main temple of the city — the Old Cathedral of Coimbra of the 12-13th centuries, as well as the Canons Regular of the Holy Cross of the 12th century, where the first Portuguese kings were buried, and the Monastery of Santa Clara-a-Nova of the 14th and 17th centuries.

There are moments when you want to see something beautiful, but not carnival, change the setting, but not very far from home, to see the unseen, but not very exotic, to learn a lot of exciting things, but not from the encyclopedias, expand horizons and breathe something new, but without the intrusion and pomposity. After all, you just want to have a good rest in a beautiful city! If such a need arises, Bucharest is an ideal place that combines all these desires in one! It is located on seven hills, in the heart of the Lower Danube lowland on the Dâmbovița River. The city is decorated with picturesque lakes, like pearls, and is filled with an abundance of emerald parks. The main city of Romania, shrouded in many mystical legends, is truly magnificent and magical! And its expressive architecture, unique natural background, and friendly people make the capital unique and cheerful. It is worth visiting Bucharest at least once in your life!

long_description.en: Romania's capital is the most populous metropolitan city in the country, with a population of over one million people. It is home to about one-sixth of the population of the entire state. The numerical figure for the inhabitants of the metropolis reaches 2,000,000 people. The ethnic core of the population is Romanian, with the second-largest number of people being Roma. It also includes such nationalities as Hungarians, Jews, Chinese, but in small percentages. The inhabitants of Bucharest are optimistic, friendly, and hospitable.

description.en: Constantza is a hospitable Romanian resort located on the Black Sea coast. Most people tend to come here for the beach vacation and recreation. The city includes a variety of sanatoriums, whereas its vicinity includes several healing mineral springs. For example, the resorts of Mamaia and Eforie are very popular among tourists. Its visitors are treated with sapropelic mud, which is considered as effective as the healing effects of the Dead Sea. In turn, walking across Constanta will bring you a lot of pleasure as well. The city is tremendously green; it has many numerous boulevards with fountains and places for relaxation. There is even a freshwater lake filled with underground sources — Tabacaria. According to one of the legends, the grave of the poet Ovid is located somewhere nearby.

Braşov is located in the central part of Romania, in the historical area of Țara Bârsei, in the south-east of Transylvania. The Teutonic Knights founded the fortress on the site of the future city in 1211. The town has preserved many architectural monuments of the Middle Ages, including Gothic quarters and ancient temples. It is not without reason that Braşov is called Salzburg of Romania. There is also a ski resort Poiana Brașov. It is worth visiting the Black Church of the XIV century — the largest Gothic church in the country, the Saint Nicholas Church dating back to the end of the XV century, dominating the city, St. Bartholomew Church of the XIII century — the oldest surviving building. After walking through the ancient streets and visiting fascinating museums, one cannot do without a trip to the Dracula Bran Castle, which is located 32 km from Braşov.

The main city of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca, in the north-west of Romania, has a long history. At the beginning of the II century AD, the Romans built a fort to house their legion, named Napoca, on the site of the future city. After its destruction, the new town was founded in 1213, and Transylvania fell under Hungarian rule. They renamed the Kolozsvár town, and after Hungary became part of the Habsburg Empire, it was renamed Klausenburg. In Cluj-Napoca, it is worth seeing the architectural ensemble of the main town square of Unification, with the famous Gothic St. Michael's Church of the XIV-XV centuries, a monument to the Hungarian King Matthias Corvinus, the Museum of Pharmacy in the building of the oldest pharmacy in the city, founded in 1573. It is interesting to visit the National Museum of Art, also known as Banffy Palace in the Baroque style, and see the panorama of the city from Castle Hill.

Belgrade is the city on two rivers and the capital of Serbia. It is considered one of the oldest cities in Europe and the largest in the Balkans. Here, the past and the future have no borders, they merge into a single stream, surprising their guests and the world with their uniqueness and originality. The challenging history, national traditions, and incredible energy of this city will not leave any tourist indifferent. Despite the fact that ancient monuments cannot be found here (Belgrade was destroyed many times by wars), the atmosphere and local flavor of this city will surprise even the most spoilt tourist.

long_description.en:
Despite the fact that most of Belgrade's population is pure-blooded Serbs, the city has become home to people of many nationalities from the former Yugoslavia. The city is home to former residents of Montenegro, Croatia, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Macedonia. There is also a large Chinese diaspora, which accounts for about 10-20 thousand people. Settlers from the Middle East also reside in the city. These are mostly students from Syria, Jordan, Iran, and Iraq. You can also see a lot of Roma in Belgrade.

The multiplicity of nationalities in Belgrade is a reason for the poly-religiousness of the city. In addition to the main religion, Orthodox Christianity, which counts 90% of all the parishioners, there are Muslim, Catholic, Protestant, Jewish, and Hindu churches in Belgrade.

description.en: Bratislava is a small, cozy, and modestly sophisticated city, spread on the banks of the Danube. It is genuinely homely, inviting to quiet meetings with friends, leisurely walks with children and dogs. By the way, both are loved here very much. Just 10 minutes drive from the center begins a huge forest park area, which smoothly passes into the mountain system of the Carpathians. Locals joke that the main attraction of Bratislava is Vienna, located just an hour away. Slovakia's capital is the only one in the world that has borders with two states at once — Austria and Hungary. And Bratislava's Kopčianska Street is unique as it flows smoothly into the Austrian Preßburger Straße.

long_description.en:
Slovak is the official language, but Czech, Hungarian, German, English, and Russian are also widely spoken. The population mainly goes to Roman Catholic churches, but there are parishioners of Greek Catholicism, Protestantism, Lutheranism, and Orthodoxy.

It's hard to find more friendly people than the citizens of Bratislava in all of Europe. They are not interested in your nationality, skin color, religion. The city is very multicultural.

description.en: When you look at the map, you can’t immediately notice that the small country named Slovenia resembles a chicken in shape. Designed in the form of a star, Ljubljana is located in the center of this “bird”. In addition to the unusual shape on the map, the main highlight of the city is the dragon that can be found everywhere. According to legends, a huge green dragon lived in the local caves and burned castles, thereby scaring people. In turn, the hero named Jason defeated him and founded the city in this area. Enveloped in secrets, the mysterious Ljubljana considerably differs from other cities in Europe. On the one hand, it is the administrative center of the country; on the other hand, it is a small town of a tremendously little size with a quiet and calm atmosphere. Today, a weekend in the capital of Slovenia can be considered the best solution for people who aim to explore mesmerizing caves and medieval castles.

long_description.en:
The number of inhabitants of the capital is 279,631. It is not only the most populous but also one of the leading cities of Slovenia in culture and business.

The most common religion in Ljubljana is Roman Catholicism, which 39% of the inhabitants practice. The main language is Slovene. It is spoken by more than 90% of the population.

description.en: The heart of Turkey. A city where you can breathe freely. A place of power, inspiration, and romance. You fall in love with this city at first sight. It's not hard to guess that we are talking about Istanbul — incredibly beautiful, atmospheric, cozy, harmonic, flavored, and hospitable. Here, you want to wander idly to and fro along its streets or rush from one excursion to another. You want to pay attention to every detail and take millions of colorful photos. Here, you can feast your eyes upon the picturesque strait of the Bosporus, see the Sea of Marmara, and even be in Europe and Asia simultaneously. Istanbul is lovely, and it's impossible to disagree with this.

long_description.en:
Istanbul is the largest city in Europe, and its population consists of many nationalities. The Turks compile the majority of the citizens, although it used to be the Armenians and Greeks before.

The Kurdish community is considered to be the most significant ethnic minority. According to the different estimates, around two-three million of citizens in Istanbul are Kurds. The Bosnian and Jewish communities are less significant. As Turkey continues to develop its partnership with African countries, the number of students from Nigeria, the Kingdom of Kongo, and Somalia in Istanbul is growing.

description.en: Fethiye is a resort city in the south-west of Turkey in the Mediterranean shores. It is located in the harbor at the foot of Lycian mountains covered with pines and cedar trees. It is not the most popular travel destinations in Turkey, that is why, in Fethiye, you can enjoy your vacation without crowds of tourists. Here you will find everything for your unforgettable vacation — azure sea, ancient landmarks, extreme entertainments, and marvelous nature.

One of Turkey's most popular resorts, Bodrum, is located on the picturesque Aegean Sea coast. Pebble and sandy beaches, the blue water of the Aegean Sea, lush vegetation, ideal climate, and comfortable infrastructure attract tourists from all over the world. Ancient mansions, majestic churches, and remains of medieval fortresses are waiting for the lovers of fascinating tours here. In this city, the centuries-old Turkish traditions and heritage of Ancient Greece are blended. Bodrum is a unique beach holiday and a bustling nightlife. It mesmerizes, makes you fall in love with itself, and lingers in your memory for a long time to come.

long_description.en: The city has about 40 thousand people. The main part of the citizens is Turks. There are also Kurds, Arabs, Greeks, Armenians, Jews, Circassians, and other nationalities.

description.en: Coming to Izmir for a dream... It is recommended to go to this amazing city if you want to not only get to the seashore but also to see something important and valuable to all mankind. In addition, a visit to Izmir offers the opportunity to find something historically significant; it is often described as “relax with meaning.” Located near the gulf of the Aegean sea under the Pagos Mountain in Turkey, Izmir is filled with everything you need for a quality vacation. Cultural and historical heritage, picturesque landscapes, and crystal clear sea — these three components can turn any trip into a fairy tale! Izmir is not only a major center of economy and business but also a popular resort that attracts the attention of tourists from all over the world. A lot of people go here annually in order to sunbathe and have a good rest in the local resorts, as well as to admire the remains of the ancient Roman Akropolis and Agora Square. Entire sections of the city are located on the mountain terraces, whereas the sea, with perfectly clear water, takes the place of areas that cross the boundaries of the surf line. This city is what your soul needs on vacation!

The incredible combination of sea, mountains, and forest makes the beautiful Marmaris a perfect place for a comfortable stay. Located on the shores of the Aegean and Mediterranean Seas, its spacious beaches are visited by tourists from all over Europe. Here you can increase the level of awareness of the culture of the Ottoman Empire, visit the Cleopatra island, go diving, or explore the sea on a yacht. Sometimes, this fashionable coast is compared with the Ibiza, as both these resorts are considered the best tourist destinations in Europe. Marmaris can be translated as “brilliant,” “shining,” and “sea pearl”. Any of these definitions ​​is perfectly suited to the modern resort, which never sleeps. Locals and tourists of this resort are usually accompanied by music, dancing, and fun at every step. In the city, you can also find a sculpture that depicts a pearl in an ajar globe. It can be considered as one of the main symbols of the city.

Kusadasi is a Turkish resort. Its name translates as “Bird Island,” whereas pigeons have been the main symbol of the city for several centuries. You can find these birds everywhere in spite of the fact where you are located. Tourists of the whole world tend to come here in order to enjoy a beach vacation, diving, beautiful nature, and ancient monuments of antiquity. In addition, the visitors of Kusadasi plunge into an authentic environment. Usually, they walk across the streets of the old city and observe the process of buying fruits by locals who do not leave their homes. In fact, there is an opportunity to buy food without leaving home, as locals can lower the basket with money through the window when merchants appear under the balcony. Simultaneously, they pick them up once the baskets are filled with goods. Kusadasi is also an old port, where snow-white yachts are moored. Besides, it is here that huge cruise ships can be found.

“The Eighth Wonder of the World”, “Cotton Castle”, and the third most popular Turkish resort is Pamukkale. It attracts tourists with snow-white travertines with blue water and cosmic landscapes, which you can enjoy for hours and not completely believe that you saw it in reality. Tourists come here not only to relax, but also to rejuvenate at the healing springs of the Turkish resort. Pamukkale and its surroundings will take you to the world of amazing nature and ancient stories.

long_description.en:
Thousands of years ago, earthquakes raged in Asia Minor, creating many springs underground. For a very long time, springs of mineralized water came out, evaporated under the scorching sun, and at the same time settled on a small hill. Over thousands of years, the travertines of Pamukkale, a white polycrystalline rock with a high level of fragility, were formed. Unusual depressions formed in it, filled with sky-blue water.

In the second century B.C., near Pamukkale, the kings of the Attalid dynasty founded the small town of Hierapolis. Here they built traditional Roman baths, an amphitheater, and several temples. The Roman spa developed very rapidly. Thermal mineral water was used for many therapeutic purposes.

In the seventh century B.C., an earthquake caused a lake with spring water to appear in the ground. Now everyone knows it as the ancient basin of Hierapolis. The ancient city of Hierapolis and the travertines of Pamukkale are the two main components of the archaeological complex of Hierapolis, which was inscribed in 1988 on the list of natural and cultural heritage under the auspices of UNESCO.

Since the 1930s, archeological excavations in Pamukkale have been constantly underway. Eight years ago, scientists excavated a basilica built in honor of St. Philip. Martyrium, the entrance to the underworld mentioned in historical and mythological tales, was also found.

description.en: Antalya is the Mediterranean pearl of Turkey. The beach season here lasts almost six months. Turkish Riviera fascinates travelers from all over the world with its picturesque scenery, warm sea, and developed infrastructure. In Antalya, stunning monuments of ancient architecture stretched against a background of palm trees and rocks, and chic beaches with golden sand and cozy coves with fishing boats beckon people like a magnet. Travelers come back here again and again for a combination of oriental flavor and European service. Here you can stay in magnificent hotels and enjoy the beach rest, occasionally changing it with exciting excursions to the ancient city and other local attractions.

long_description.en:
Despite the region's rich history, most of the inhabitants are Turks (83.1%). Greeks remain only 7.9%, and representatives of other nationalities - 9%.

Foreigners love Antalya, so they buy resort real estate here. This, in their opinion, is a good investment in the holiday. The British, the Germans, the Russians, the Ukrainians, and the Belarusians have their own apartments here.

description.en: The sun, sea, beach is the ideal formula for recreation for the majority of tourists. Alanya has much more to offer. It is a city with a history of 20 centuries, each of which left its indelible traces. Nature here is also beautiful: the Taurus Mountains with its fast rivers and beautiful canyons, fruit plantations, and the gentle Mediterranean Sea. No matter what kind of entertainment you are looking for in Alanya, you will always find something to suit your taste. Explore the most important monuments in history or take an adventurous voyage through pirate caves. Fish on the rushing mountain river or immerse yourself in the bustling nightlife.

long_description.en:
The Turkish Institute of Statistics announced that at the end of 2018, there were 312 thousand of people living in Alanya County. Of these, foreigners accounted for 78 thousand. The most densely populated district is Mahmutlar. Today it has about 40 thousand people.

In the last 15 years, population growth has gained great momentum. Residents of the colder regions of Turkey and citizens of other countries move to the city for permanent residence. Most often, real estate in Alanya is bought by Germans, the English, Ukrainians, Russians, and Scandinavians.

description.en: Side is a Turkish resort town on the Mediterranean coast. The tourist potential of Side was discovered only in the 90s of the last century, when luxury hotels and beaches were equipped. Families with young children are especially fond of the resort — here are ideal sandy beaches with a shallow entrance to the shallow sea, a large number of entertainments and excursions for every taste, and the restaurants have a special children's menu.

long_description.en: The city has about 14 thousand inhabitants. During the tourist season (from April to November), many tourists come to Side and nearby areas, increasing the population several times over.

description.en: Belek is the best example of the modern tourist industry in Turkey. It is also the most expensive and elite resort. The unique zone of preserving the reserved species of birds, plants, and sea animals — this is all about a young and respectable resort of the Antalya coast. Delightfully-romantic landscapes, golden beaches, and comfortable hotels with golf courses are waiting for their guests.

On the picturesque Anatolian Plateau, at the confluence of the two rivers, stands beautiful Ankara. The ancient eastern city cherishes its history: Roman baths, majestic mosques, grandiose mausoleums, and unique museums fascinate the lovers of ancient times. The spirit of youth harmoniously complements the eastern atmosphere of the town. The minarets of mosques rise against the background of modern buildings, fashionable restaurants adjoin traditional coffee shops, and shopping in boutiques can be combined with shopping at colorful markets. Ankara is a vibrant and diverse city that will stay in your memory for a long time to come.

long_description.en: In 2017, more than five million people lived in the city. Most of the population of the capital are Turks by nationality. Kurds, Greeks, Armenians, Arabs, and other ethnic groups also live in the city.

description.en: In the early days, this city gave an indelible impression on travelers with its luxury and magnificent temples and palaces. Nowadays, at first sight, it is just a large commercial port. But when strolling along the streets of modern Trabzon, a traveler will constantly encounter evidences of the past grandeur of the Byzantine era. The city is located at the foot of naturally beautiful, woody Karadağ mountains in the eastern part of the Black Sea coast of Turkey. Trabzon may not be the best place for beach holiday but it offers numerous historical landmarks, special atmosphere, and good shopping possibilities.

Erzurum is a versatile, interesting resort. Its charm was noticed by the poet Alexander Pushkin in his travel essays in 1829. Here, you can find ancient mosques and wild nature with mountains and waterfalls, and night clubs, and Turkish baths. There are ski trails of Palandöken in several kilometers from the city. Both the beginners and the experienced skiers will enjoy it here. The trails meet international standards and are the place where the national team of Turkey has its practice. After walking and skiing, it’s time to visit one of the numerous restaurants where you can try famous Turkish dishes: kebab, manti, meze, dolma, and many more. Don’t forget about shopping, you will enjoy it in Erzurum. There are a lot of stores and gift shops. You should bargain everywhere, and it is quite an engaging process because lets you learn a lot about the locals. People come here for emotions, and they get enough of them.

Rovaniemi is the northernmost of Finland's major cities. It is located 8 kilometers from the Arctic Circle, 800 kilometers from Helsinki, and is the administrative center of the Lapland province. Despite being close to the Arctic Circle, winters are not very cold here. And since nature in these places is surprisingly good, the city attracts lovers of winter sports, as well as those who wish to ride a deer or dog sled. Furthermore, as everyone knows, Lapland is the birthplace of Santa Claus (aka Joulupukki, aka Santa Claus). His official residence is situated near Rovaniemi, so in the winter, on Christmas and New Year's Day, hundreds of thousands of tourists come here with children.

Do you dream of visiting the top five cities in the world? Start with Helsinki, the youngest capital among all Scandinavian countries! It is here that you can "taste" all the spice of a real Finnish character, admire the scenery of amazingly beautiful nature on the shore of the Gulf of Finland and, at the same time, enjoy all the infrastructure and urban benefits of the city.

long_description.en: Residents of Helsinki are very friendly and peaceful people, always welcome every tourist. It must be said that this is the most not densely populated capital of Europe. The nationality of people living here is quite diverse. Most of them are Finns, but there are also a lot of Swedes, Russians, a little fewer Estonians, while the rest of the ethnic groups are represented in the city in very small numbers (Germans, Jews, Belarusians, Poles, Ukrainians, Latvians, and others).

description.en: Budva organically complements the transparent water, clear blue skies and magnificent bustling beaches of the Adriatic coast with mysterious medieval streets, squares, and churches that hide behind the stone walls of the Old Town. It seems to be living in parallel in two dimensions or moving from one time to another. There is always a place for fun lovers and those who need a leisurely, contemplative reflection. Atmospheric pubs, night clubs, amusement parks — Budva will please anyone, even the most demanding guest. And it will fill everyone with the warmth of the sun and pleasant memories, which will last until the next meeting.

Green and floral Kotor is one of the most popular resorts in Montenegro. It is located on the limestone cliffs of Lovcen Mountain, on the Adriatic coast. Once people arrive in Montenegro, they choose this particular town for vacation, despite the fact that it can be bypassed in a day. It seems that the resort is protected from the bustle of the big world by huge mountains and rocks. In turn, residents are tremendously sensitive to historical heritage. When you walk across the narrow streets with ancient stone buildings, you feel as if you were in a different era. Numerous tourists return to Kotor in order to have a picnic near the St John Fortress, take a boat ride to the Gospa od Skrpela island, enjoy local dishes in authentic street cafes, and simply enjoy the natural beauties. When it comes to the water, it is azure and clear, and the locals are extremely hospitable and welcoming. Kotor is a place where you can relax with your soul and body, stop the moment, and not worry about anything.

long_description.en:
Illyrian tribes founded the city in ancient times, and in 168 BC, it became part of the Roman Empire. From the late 400s BC until 1185, it was under Byzantine rule and was called Dekaderon. Then the city surrendered without a fight to the founder of the Serbian royal dynasty of the Nemanjić dynasty, the Grand Duke Stefan Nemanjić. During the Serbian period, Kotor was the center of the state. It was a rather favorable time for the city, and its cultural and economic development was gaining momentum.

From the end of the XIV century to the beginning of the XV century, Kotor was an independent city-republic, and in 1420, it voluntarily became part of Venice because of the threat of Ottoman invasion. Even today, this is reminded by the city's architecture, which is sometimes called Little Italy. Kotor has changed its "owners" for a long time, which included the French, the Austrians, the Croats, the Slovenes, and the Germans.

Only after the collapse of socialist Yugoslavia it became part of current Montenegro.

In 1979, Kotor became a UNESCO World Heritage Site because every corner of it is imbued with the spirit of rich history.

description.en: Podgorica is the capital of Montenegro and the city, which involuntarily is ignored by all tourists going to rest in the Balkans. Podgorica is not the most remarkable capital of Europe, there is no sea or Sagrada Familia, and instead of Big Ben there is a modest Clock Tower. But this cute town, nestled in a valley of five rivers, attracts with unusual natural landscapes, comfort and hospitality of local residents.

If you want to abstract yourself from the fuss and just relax with enthusiasm, then Prague is a perfect fit for you. Here you can enrich both your body and mind.
