A charming ancient city allows you to admire historical monuments, gardens and parks, museums, galleries, and theatres. The capital of the Czech Republic is also known for its delicious beer, filling shin, and marvelous fried cheese.

long_description.en: In the last couple of years, the community has been growing driven by a significant flow of immigrants and the high living standards of the seniors. Even though the majority of the population are the Czechs, there are still many immigrants from the ex-USSR countries (especially Ukrainians and Russians), many Slovaks, and Vietnamese. Most people skep Czech; however, everybody understands Slovak. German, English, and Russian are also quite widespread.

description.en: Český Krumlov, with fairy-tale, brick-red roofs houses, stands on the Vltava River. Its winding streets with lovely buildings, ancient brickwork, and even pavement keep the memory of centuries-old history, aristocratic families that owned the castle in the City Center, and amazing city dwellers. Walls of the castles under the emblem of pentapetalous rose, conceal legends about ghosts of the White Lady and the palace alchemist, and about the princess of vampires, who drank wolf’s milk. Real Siberian bears live in a ditch around the castle. The city has a lot more to offer! Český Krumlov is not only a cozy fairy-tale. It is an ancient city that has seen wars and peace, and hundreds of generations with their happiness and grieves.

The Czech Republic starts with Prague — everyone thinks so, but not the people of Brno. The history of this ancient Czech settlement dates far back to the Middle Ages. At that time, it was a fortress, which played an important defensive role in Moravia. Later, due to its successful location at the crossroads of trade routes, Brno grew and developed, becoming a center of trade, culture, and science. Today, modern and ancient motifs are very harmoniously intertwined in the city. At the same time, Brno and its surroundings are completely unfairly left without the attention of travelers. And in vain, because there is much to see here. On the other hand, such disregard makes it possible to enjoy the city without any fuss or tourist bustle.

Pilsen lies in the west of the Czech Republic, in the picturesque confluence of four rivers. It is the beer capital, a city with medieval flavor, a modern industrial and cultural center. Majestic Gothic temples, mysterious multi-kilometer dungeons, old houses decorated with paintings and frescoes, amazing fountains, and numerous statues — Pilsen has incredible architectural surprises at every turn. The famous Plzeňský Prazdroj brewery, many museums, as well as the most interesting Techmania Science Center, will not leave indifferent both adults and children. In Pilsen, you will fall in love with old streets, beautiful buildings, and the distinctive atmosphere of Western Bohemia.

Tallinn is the capital of Estonia and a port city located on the shores of the Baltic Sea. The city where different styles, architectural trends, and traditions meet together. It attracts tourists from all over the world. Cobblestone streets, elegant buildings, and medieval churches create a unique atmosphere of fabulousness and magic. One of the smallest European capitals became the favorite holiday destination of travelers. Tallinn is full of surprises and knows how to amaze and fascinate.

long_description.en: According to the 2019 census, more than 400 thousand people live in Tallinn. Most of the residents are Estonians - up to 53%. Many Russians are in the city (about 38% of the population). Also, Ukrainians, Finns, Belarusians, Jews, Tatars, and representatives of other nationalities are among the capital's residents.

description.en: Pärnu is a magnificent resort located in the southwestern part of Estonia. It is also called Estonia’s Summer Capital. During the holiday season, the population of Pärnu is tripled. The resort was famous for its white sandy beaches with numerous shallows, sea air with a pine aroma, a large number of SPA centers and mud-baths, beautiful architecture of temples and old houses. The city has long been chosen by couples in love, noisy youth companies, and families with small children. Amazing places, exciting entertainments, and unforgettable impressions await everyone here.

As for the city that soon will celebrate its 1000th anniversary, Tartu has too much young energy. And all because it is the student capital of Estonia. People come here to study from all over the country. There are also many foreign students. It's not an exaggeration to say that all the historically important trends for science and culture originated in the University of Tartu. Besides, highly intelligent vibes, it is also a beautiful ancient city, where people like long walks, fun, and simple nutritious food.

Hong Kong is a special administrative region of China, located in the southeast of the country. The incredible combination of Eastern and Western cultures makes this metropolis unlike any other. Contemporary skyscrapers, where business people cut multimillion deals, luxurious restaurants with exotic dishes, large amusement centers for children, exciting attractions, picturesque parts, and cozy beaches - it's impossible to explore Hong Kong in just a couple of days. Still, you can easily fall in love at first sight.

long_description.en:
In terms of population, Hong Kong ranks #103 in the world. However, it continues to grow. The overwhelming majority of the local citizens (95%) consider themselves to be Chinese. The remaining 5% are immigrants from Asian countries, Europe, and even North America. As a rule, representatives of different nationalities form ethnic communities and live within the boundaries of one district.

A trip to new countries and cities is not only about bright emotions, but also a little stressful because you have to learn to navigate in a completely different world. We prepared a list of useful recommendation to help the people who head to Hong Kong:

  • Since 2009, there is a strict law in Hong Kong that forbids smoking in public places: restaurants and cafes, public transport stops, and even in lavatories. Public appearance with a cigarette makes yourself liable to a serious fine. There are specially equipped zones for smokers.
  • You can and even should bargain in shops and markets in Hong Kong unless these are big shopping centers. When you buy some goods, and the price is set for weight, you should pay attention to the units used. The thing is that they often use zin and catty in China instead of a kilogram. They stand for 0.5 and 0.6 kg, respectively.
  • The majority of cafes in Hong Kong offer their menus in Chinese only. It's hard to gain an understanding, so one should start their acquaintance with local cuisine with fast food. Almost all establishments have long lines. You can grab a quick snack only in some restaurants. If you want to save money, you should order sets and not every dish separately. Another piece of advice concerns flatware. As a rule, guests are given only chopsticks with their order. So, if you are not sure about your skills, you should bring a plastic fork with you.
  • The best way to save your budget during a trip to Hong Kong is to purchase a special adVenture Card. You can buy it on the official website. This card allows you to visit 15 sights for free or with up to 50% discount. The venture program also includes rides on a cableway, a tour bus, and a trip to Macau.
  • Hong Kong has left-hand traffic. This rule concerns drivers, pedestrians in the streets, metro, underground passages. So, before you cross a street, first look right, and only then — left.

description.en: Emerald greenery with a bright touch of exotic flowers, luxury villas, and bamboo houses, rivers winding between the cliffs, ancient temples, and statues of extraordinary gods — it all about Ubud. Any photo taken here turns into a bright postcard with unique landscape and central streets at some point pass into narrow paths winding among rice fields. The city is surrounded by jungles, which seem to protect it from the hustle of the modern world. Ubud managed to preserve its unity with nature, and even rigorous flight of time of the 21st century cannot tear it apart. A tired, nervous, and harassed traveler can find inner harmony and peace of mind.

Nusa Dua is a private resort in the south of the exotic island of Bali. Here, tourists feel like exclusive guests surrounded by tropical nature, pure white beaches, perfect lawns, and premium services. A three-kilometer wide coastline is able to accommodate everyone at the same time, without violating anyone's personal space. It is an ideal place for family and romantic getaways. Nusa Dua is a great way to look behind the curtain of luxury relaxation, which was previously available only to the rich.

Jakarta is the capital of the largest (in terms of the population, which professes Islam) Muslim country, a picturesque city with exotic culture, stretched on the coast of the Java Sea. It is a large metropolis, where modern skyscrapers are next to the streets where the poorest people live, and outright poverty is next to expensive boutiques and restaurants. A city of extremes, a place where different peoples and cultures mix, it is famous for its brightest nightlife and bustling language diversity. Beautiful beaches, tropical plants, entertainment complexes, unique monuments — Jakarta offers something to see and do.

long_description.en:
According to the statistics of 2012, almost 10 million people live in the city. In the urban agglomeration of Jakarta, the population, back in 2010, exceeded 28 million and is growing steadily every year. The majority of Jakarta residents (about 65%) are from Java. The next largest ethnic groups in the city are the peoples of Sumatra, Sulawesi, the Moluccas, Kalimantan, and the Chinese.

Indonesia, unlike other countries of the world, is home to the largest number of Muslims. In Jakarta, they make up about 86% of all believers. The rest are the representatives of other religions: Protestants, Catholics, Buddhists, Hindus.

description.en: Yogyakarta is the administrative center of the province of the same name in Indonesia, located on the island of Java. It is one of the oldest cities in the region where the Javanese civilization was born. Tourists here will find majestic castles and palaces, picturesque corners of pristine nature, exciting museums. Yogyakarta fascinates with its Indonesian flavor, fascinates with the atmosphere of ancient times, and inspires with the eternally young spirit of bustling streets.

Guangzhou bears five different Chinese titles, and all of them mean “The City of Five Goats”. It is the third-largest city in China. It’s also considered to be not only the world trading and industrial center but also the cultural and historical center of China. According to the legends, a small village, located on the spot of the modern megalopolis, was on the verge of extinction from hunger. But rescue came from Heaven. Five gods came down on Earth on five goats (“Yangcheng” stands for the city of goats). Every animal held rice pieces in the mouths (“Jiangcheng” stands for “The City of Rice”). The citizens did not only satisfy their hunger but also scattered the fields and gathered an abundant harvest. Modern Guangzhou is an extraordinarily contemporary and fast-evolving city. Trading and industrial corporations attract business people from all over the world. Fascinating attractions and incredible atmosphere are a genuine magnet for tourists.

long_description.en: The Han Chinese constitute the highest percentage of the local citizens in Guangzhou. The persons belonging to national minorities compile not more than 1.5% of the total population. At the same time, over 40 representatives of national minorities live in the city. The Hui people are considered to be the largest ethnic community due to the active trading contacts with the Persian Empire, India, and countries of Southeast Asia. Guangzhou also has small communities of such ethnic groups and national minorities as the Manchun, Yao, Li, She, Zhuang people.

description.en: Shenzhen is located in Guangdong province in southeast China. From a poor fishing village, this city has turned into the largest prosperous metropolis. Today it is easy to get lost in a shopping center, make up a brand new smartphone at the market, and even release a batch of tablets of your brand. Shenzhen may be the way you want to see it because there is entertainment for every taste. This is a place where skyscrapers and factories stand side by side with green parks and flowering gardens. It has many theme museums, markets, authentic establishments, and natural areas. This city is ahead of time but never forgets about old traditions.

long_description.en:
The first settlements on the territory of Shengzhen appeared as early as the III century BC. For a long time, this place was home to the Baiyue tribe, skilled in fishing. Over time, the land began to attract Chinese colonists. They later discovered rich salt deposits on the banks of the Zhujiang River. During the Yuan dynasty, pearl mining was added to the traditional salt and spice trade. The earliest mention of the city's name dates back to 1410 (the time of the Ming Empire).

In 1979, Deng Xiaoping (Chinese politician and statesman) chose Shenzhen as a place to create a new economic zone as part of his large-scale reforms. Each year, industrial districts appeared in the city, and its population grew rapidly. As early as 1999, Shenzhen hosted the most important event — the China High-Tech Fair. Since then, it's been held here regularly. The modern city boasts many large industrial facilities, cultural complexes of world significance, as well as huge shopping and entertainment centers.

description.en: Nanjing is an ancient city, the former capital of China, which has lots of attractions. Moreover, some of them are included in the UNESCO World Heritage List. There is everything that may be of interest to tourists who come to China for the first time — huge skyscrapers, bright and colorful street bustle, beautiful parks, pavilions, and sculptures. And, of course, incomparable Chinese cuisine, unusual for Europeans, but amazingly tasty. Through the Nanjing flows the Yangtze River called, the "Blue River", which is considered the first in Eurasia (and the third on the planet) in terms of length and fullness.

long_description.en:
The legend says that the history of Nanjing began in 495 BC when the ruler of the Wu kingdom founded Ye Chen Fort. But what is known is that it is a very ancient city, which was the capital of several kingdoms since the III century AD. In 1386 it was proclaimed the capital of the Chinese Empire of the Ming dynasty until, in 1421, it was moved to Beijing. During this period, Nanjing changed its name several times, being named first Jian Kang and then Jingshi.

In 1645 the Mancus took Nanking city, and the ruler Li Zicheng fled. The town renamed Jianying suffered minor damage, but the invaders destroyed the imperial palace and took many women prisoners.

In 1842, the First Opium War ended, and the British invaded the city. A few years after the signing of the Treaty of Nanjing (in 1853), it became the center of the Taiping Rebellion. The turmoil and infighting lasted for about nine years. As a result, the Porcelain Tower and some other priceless historical monuments were destroyed. From 1853 to 1864, the government of the Republic of China settled in the city, sitting in the Nanjing presidential palace.

In 1937, the Japanese army entered Nanjing and exterminated about 300,000 citizens. This tragedy was later called the Nanjing Massacre. On April 23, 1946, the Japanese were defeated, and China's People's Liberation Army entered the city.

Now Nanjing is one of the most important industrial zones in China. Mechanical engineering, pharmaceuticals, electronics, and telecommunications equipment are developed here. In addition, the city offers numerous joint ventures involving leading international high-tech companies.

description.en: Qingdao is translated as “Green Island”. The city is located on the eastern coast if Chine, between Beijing and Shanghai, in Shandong province. It is among 15 top Chinese metropolitan cities. Once, unremarkable fishing village has become the developed port city and resort for less than 150 years. A modern metropolis is known for its incredible skyscrapers, green parks, and golden beaches along the Yellow Sea coastline. Moreover, Qingdao is the largest center of Chinese filmmaking, where famous directors shoot their box-office films. You can learn more in the Movie Museum. In a short time, this wonderful city managed to win the title of the economic, cultural, and travel center of China.

Shanghai is a city that holds a special place both in China and in the world. It is diverse and controversial, attractive, and mysterious, just like the East itself. Its name, which has not changed since its foundation, means "a city over the sea". Located south of the Yangtze River, near the East China Sea, it is the center of financial and commercial life. Stylish and modern boutiques in Shanghai showcase fashionable novelties from around the world. It strikes with its scale, diversity, and splendor. Outstanding buildings and masterpieces of contemporary architecture impress with their grandeur. The combination of coziness and Asian flavor with the magnitude of a modern, highly developed metropolis amazes the imagination. You feel a special atmosphere from the first minutes of your stay in Shanghai — it captivates and does not let go. A visit here can be the biggest adventure in life.

long_description.en:
The descendants of the inhabitants of the old "city over the sea" now constitute a small percentage of Shanghai's population. The ancestors of most of the residents are immigrants from neighboring Jiangsu and Zhejiang provinces.

In the XIX century, these places were flooded with emigrants from all over Europe. Shanghai is the most populous city in China. It can be compared to an anthill. There is a belief that the Shanghainese despise the people from the province. However, people living here astonish with their thoroughness, pedantry, and attentiveness to details.

description.en: The largest city in China is located on the hills of three mountains (the Daba, the Wu, and the Dalou) in the place where Yangtze and Jialing rivers meet. It is around the size of Austria, and it has 4 times more citizens than this country. Its dormitory districts are full of high buildings, in the back yards of which people grow vegetables and keep hens. No one is surprised to find a playground on the rooftops and monorails going through the apartment complex. The locals managed to use each piece of land, they rebuilt old neighborhoods but preserve historical buildings and ancient temples. Chongqing often suffers from smog, but people here care about nature and eco-balance. This city of contrasts is often compared with Foggy Albion, but it cannot be named European. It is an authentic Chinese metropolis.

long_description.en:
Chongqing is an ancient city. In 2070-1600 BC, it was already the capital of the Ba Kingdom, which later became part of the Chinese Empire. At that time, this settlement was called Jianzhou. And it got its modern name in 1189. In translation, it means "double celebration." The name was chosen to commemorate two important events. First, the third son of Emperor Xiaozong of Song was granted the status of the prince of the Guangzhou region here, and then the title of emperor.

Since 1368, Chongqing has been a major crossroads of trade routes. In 1891, it became an open port linking southwest China and the outside world with an equipped customs office.

In 1929, the rapidly developing Chongqing was granted the status of a municipality of the republic. And in the years of the Sino-Japanese war (1937-1945), it became a provisional capital. In the same period, the anti-fascist headquarters was located here, which led the allied forces of China, Thailand, Burma, Vietnam, and Malaysia.

On March 14, 1997, following a government decision to merge Chongqing with neighboring prefectures, a single municipality was formed with a population of 30,020,000 and direct central subordination.

Today, Chongqing is one of the most important industrial and commercial centers in China. Tourism is an important part of its economic success. The city is visited by up to 390 million travelers per year.

description.en: Throughout its history, Hangzhou was the capital of several states and one of the major centers of Chinese culture. Nowadays, it keeps Chinese traditions and is the capital of e-commerce. An ancient and super-modern Hangzhou is among the richest cities in the People's Republic of China, taking the highest positions according to the index of human well-being. The Chinese preserved ancient pagodas, built the longest bridge in the Pacific region, and created a business incubator, "the city of a dream," with a total area of 3km². Tourists are attracted by natural beauty, ancient monuments, modern architecture, and good possibilities for shopping. One Chinese saying goes that you need to be born in Suzhou and live in Hangzhou. This amazing city is located in the eastern part of the People's Republic of China, at the mouth of the Qiantang River, 180 km away from Shanghai, and is an administrative center of Zhejiang province.

long_description.en:
The climate in Hangzhou is temperate, subtropical, and quite humid. Summers here are hot, with daytime temperatures of +30°C in July and August being the norm. And at times, it does not feel embarrassed to break through the +35°C mark. In the fall (September, October), the temperature drops to a tolerable +27°C — +25°C. June and August are the rainiest months. On average, it is about 200 mm of rainfall per month. However, July and September can't be called "dry" either.

Winter in Hangzhou is cool, but not cold. In December and February, the daytime temperature is +11°C — +15°C; at night, it's +5°C —+7°C. However, there are light frosts and, sometimes, even snow.

The best seasons to visit this city are spring (April, May) and fall (September, October). The temperature during this time is pleasant, and the rains don't bother you too much.

September and the beginning of October are also attractive because at that time, the devilwood, which is considered a symbol of Hangzhou, is in bloom. And in spring, as you know, cherry blossoms bloom.

In late September or early October (on the eighteenth day of the eighth lunar month), it is possible to observe a rare natural phenomenon on the river — a powerful tide coming from the river's mouth. This is due to the special location of the planets — the Sun, the Earth, and the Moon. Similar can be observed in different parts of the planet, but it is on Qiantang because the river from the mouth narrows sharply, and the waves are incredibly powerful.

And around the same time, during the full moon, Hangzhou hosts the Mid-Autumn Festival.

The Dragon Boat Festival greets the beginning of summer in China. In Hangzhou, it is traditionally one of the most colorful.

description.en: Loud and densely populated, multifaced, and fascinating, modern and atmospheric - there is a reason why Beijing is called one of the most legendary cities on the planet. Words "freakish" and "odd" perfectly fit into the description of the town. However, such original characteristics only deepen tourists' interest in Beijing. Life doesn't stop even for a couple of seconds in the streets of the Chinese capital. It's one of the largest megapolises not only in China but in the whole world. You should come here for the sake of ancient temples and parks, cheap shopping opportunities, delicious food, and various entertainments. People visit Beijing for the unforgettable emotions they can get only here.

long_description.en:
The number of citizens in Beijing growth annually. Only 50% of the population have official local residence. The rest of the people live in the city with a temporary permit. In addition to that, around ten million people compile a group of so-called labor immigrants.

As far as the ethnic composition is concerned, the Han Chinese or the Han People constitute the overwhelming majority of the population (95%). The ethnic minorities are thinly represented in the capital of China:

  • the Manchu people – 1,8%;
  • the Hui people – 1,7%;
  • the Mongols – 0,3%.

It is also worth mentioning that, in general, representatives of 56 nationalities live on the territory of Beijing.

description.en: Chengdu is the capital of Sichuan province in China. This metropolis is located in the valley of the Ming River. It has more than three-thousand-tear-old history. It was called “the city of brocade” and “paradise”, and now the capital of Chinese traditional medicine. Chengdu preserves its rich past and it is sure about its future.

long_description.en:
Chengdu emerged in the IV century BC during the founding of the Shu Kingdom. The name of the city is translated from Chinese as "to become the capital," which may have determined its fate. For thousands of years, it has been the main city of different kingdoms and states — Shu and Shu Han, Cheng and Western Shu, Early Shu and Late Shu, as well as the rebel one — Li Shu. In the Middle Ages, Chengdu was the capital of the Great Western State.

After the internecine wars, it suffered considerably and was abandoned by a large part of the population. When the Qing Empire came to power, the issue of settling Sichuan province, which included Chengdu, was resolved. As a result, the city was revived and became the seat of the governor of Sichuan.

In 1911, there was a hotbed of the Sichuan Rebellion.

In 1928, Chengdu formed its own government. And in 1949, it became part of China.

In 1952, the Sichuan province was restored, and Chengdu was the seat of its government.

Modern Chengdu is a major science, technology, industry, trade, and finance center. It has the largest aerospace industry in the country. It is a megalopolis that produces automobiles, equipment, food, and medicine. Chengdu has a reputation as a city with a favorable investment climate.

description.en: Wǔhàn is an administrative center of Hubei Province in China. One of the most populous cities in the country is located at the confluence of the Yangtze and Hànshǔi Rivers. A modern noisy metropolitan city managed to preserve the magnificent architectural and historical landmarks, picturesque locations of unique nature, authentic atmosphere of Northeast Asia. Wǔhàn is a city where the ancient tradition of the Chinese and the newest technologies of the modern world meet together.

Dalian is the second-largest city in Liaoning Province. It is located in the Yellow Sea Bay, in the south of the Liaodong Peninsula, and it is the western part of the Bohai Economic Rim. The city is washed by the waters of the Yellow Sea on three sides. In different historical times, the town was owned by Japan and Russia, which had left their marks on its culture and architecture. Dalian is a major tourist, financial, and transport center of China with well-developed infrastructure and many health and medical facilities. This modern metropolis has numerous squares, parks, hotels, shopping malls, restaurants, nightclubs, beaches, and health resorts. It is called the most favorable city for living in all China, not only for locals but also for tourists.

Tianjin is the largest modern metropolitan city along the Hai River in the northeast of China, 96 km from Bejing. Several waterways come across the city, including the Grand Canal. From the east, Tianjin is washed by the waters of the Gulf of Bohai. This city combines modern skyscrapers and old monasteries, innovative restaurants with robots instead of waiters, and street stalls with traditional snacks. It is a futuristic and, at the same time, ancient corner of Chine where the link between generations is kept.

long_description.en:
The area of modern Tianjin was first settled in the XII century when food warehouses and saltworks were located there. After the Chinese capital was moved to Beijing, the neighboring settlement began to grow. Tianjin became the gateway to the capital for residents from the south and east of the country. During the Qing dynasty, Tianjin continued to develop rapidly, thanks to its location on the banks of the Grand Canal. Here the goods arrived were loaded on carts and transported to Beijing.

In the XIX century, the canal became clogged due to changes in the course of the Haihe, and the city's economy suffered greatly. A Qing dynasty viceroy, Zhili, settled here and signed the Treaty of Tianjin and the Russo-Chinese Treaty. During the Second Opium War, the British and the French bombed the city.

In the late XIX and early XX centuries, foreign concessions formed in the city. The emergence of new European neighborhoods provoked nationalist sentiments, which turned into armed attacks and the Yihetuan movement. Enemy troops re-entered the city, destroyed the old city wall, and new concessions sprang up. Eventually, there were eight: Austro-Hungarian, Italian, Russian, Belgian, Japanese, French, British, and German.

In 1937, the Second Sino-Japanese War began, during which the enemy side occupied the city. This lasted until the capture of Tianjin by Chinese troops in January 1949.

For 20 years, the city changed its status, size, and composition. Eventually, it became one of the four cities of central subordination to the PRC.

In the XXI century, Tianjin is a major industrial and economic center with rich tourist potential.

description.en: Harbin is the major city of Heilongjiang, its administrative and cultural center. In a short time, it managed to grow from a small railway station to a modern metropolis. Unique museums, original temples, areas of wild nature in the city center — Harbin surprises and fascinates its guests. In winter, it becomes the major city in China, inviting everyone to the ice sculpture festival. In summer, it attracts by a pleasant freshness and green parks. This city is amazing in any season!

Changchun is not just the capital of the Chinese province of Jilin. This is one of the largest cities in China, a cultural and educational center with many features that attract travelers. The largest woodland was planted, and an artificial reservoir was created here. In this city, cars are manufactured and then they are taken to all the corners of the country. 27 universities work here. And even foreigners dream to study in them. Changchun is a large and interesting city that you will discover again and again.

Ürümqi or Urumchi is an administrative center of the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region of China. One of the largest cities in Asia is located on the northern slopes of the Tianshan Mountains. A modern metropolitan city, surrounded by snowy peaks, thick pinewood, and magnificent salty lake, has its unique atmosphere. Ürümqi is a border between modern China and the ancient settlements period of the Great Silk Road.

Lhasa is in the west of China in the Tibet Autonomous Region. This city is where the Dalai Lama's residence is located. The name Lhasa means the "place of the gods" in Tibetan. It used to be the capital of independent Tibet, and nowadays, the government of the autonomous region works here. The city is home to many outstanding historical and architectural monuments, sacral structures, and secular sites. All of them are of great value to the world culture. It is worth starting sightseeing from the majestic Potala Palace, visit the central temple of Jokhang, see the monasteries of Drepung, Sera, Ganden, Ramoche, the summer palace of the Dalai Lama Norbulingka. You should also get acquainted with the unique architecture of the mosque, made in Tibetan style. It is interesting to walk along historical Barkhor Street and the old city.

As the gateway between Asia and Oceania, Kuala Lumpur is the city that is often compared with an exotic flower that managed to turn from a mining village into a powerful metropolis in approximately a century and a half. Situated in a lowland valley surrounded by mountains with equatorial forests, Kuala Lumpur, like an Asian tiger, observes everything that happens around. Here, the Klang and Gombak rivers merge and flow into the Strait of Malacca. The Petronas Twin Towers are regarded as the main symbols of the city, as they rise above the urban landscape. This is a city of contrasts, where different people, languages, ​​and religions intertwine together. Additionally, it is here that the economic and cultural life is concentrated. At the same time, evergreen forests, hilly terrain, and equatorial beaches with white and golden sand, washed by the warm waters of the Strait of Malacca, will surprise the most sophisticated connoisseur of exotic relaxation.

long_description.en: The modern inhabitants of Kuala Lumpur are the descendants of immigrants who have worked in the mines and constructed buildings since the founding of Kuala Lumpur. The current population is approximately 1.8 million. Most of it is represented by three ethnic groups: Malays, Chinese, and Indians. The city's inhabitants are predominantly Muslim and Buddhist, but thanks to the mix of many nations, there is religious and cultural freedom in the city.

description.en: Sandakan is a city in eastern Malaysia on the shores of the Sulu Sea. It is located on the island of Borneo — the third-largest in the world and the largest in Asia. The territory of the city is mostly flat, with small hills, and the coastline is full of bays and gulfs. Sandakan is a magnet for lovers of wild and exotic nature. Here rare animals live in protected nature reserves in a natural environment. You can walk through the wild jungle without leaving the city limits. And in the local market, there is always the opportunity to taste the freshest seafood at very affordable prices.

Dubai is the largest city in the UAE that lies on the bank of the Persian Gulf. It strikes the imagination from at first sight. It seems that you are in the movie about the high-technology future where everything is possible. People here create wildlife sanctuaries, build canals, erect skyscrapers made of glass, build shopping centers that look like small towns. They even have their Little Venice of Dubai! The splendor and luxury became the lifestyle of this largest trading, finance, and tourist megalopolis in the Middle East. Local emirs try to demonstrate the beauty and magnificence of the city to the whole world. They also aim to create new, incredible, and inimitable constructions that will attract even more tourists.

long_description.en: The population of Dubai is actively growing. High living standards, economic stability, a high number of job opportunities with excellent salaries attract immigrants from all corners of the world. They already surpass half of the Dubai population. These are mainly the Chinese, Indians, Filipinos, Pakistanis, citizens of countries in Central and Eastern Africa, and also people from Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, and Kazakhstan. Only 15% of the population are the local Arabic people.

description.en: Snow-white sand of the beaches, emerald greenery conquering even the everlasting sultriness, smooth and even streets like there were made with a ruler, and mind-blowing skyscrapers. Abu Dhabi is so respectable, solid, and accurate. This city emerged in the middle of a harsh desert within just a couple of decades, challenging nature. It's an Arabian fairy-tale where the rapid rhythm of modern life intertwists with ancient traditions and futuristic technologies. Abu Dhabi reasonably justifies its status of capital. It knows how to steal a way into a guest's heart and how to amaze him. It can show you such wonders that no other city in the world is aware of.

long_description.en: Local citizens, the Arabs, constitute a small part of the population of Abu Dhabi. According to some statistics, there are only around 20% of them. The rest of the residents are immigrants. The Indians, Pakistanis, and Filipinos compile the majority of the international communities. That's why hearing Arabic language here is quite a rare occasion, unlike Hindi, for example. But even an elementary level of English can considerably simplify your life. The local Arabs or Emirates, as they call them here, are incredibly kindhearted, hospitable, and smiling.

description.en: Sharjah is a lovely green city overlooking the coastline on the warm Persian Gulf. Antique and modern architecture, progress, and centuries-old traditions of the ancient East are mixed up here. It is a wonderful place for peaceful, relaxed, and family vacation, exploration of the luxurious oriental atmosphere at the numerous markets of the city. Sharjah markets impress with their beauty, brightness of the interiors, and a wide choice of items. The city located not far from Dubai, so you for a change you can visit a noisy metropolis and then go back to clean beaches and quiet lagoons. There are many museums in the city: ethnographic, art, archeological, historical, armor, and even the Museum of Police. The city also offers magnificent parks, bridges, fountains, and waterfront promenades to its guests. Sharjah is called the cultural and architectural capital of the United Arab Emirates. This resort boasts of a wide range of top hotels with great cuisine, service, different entertainments, and luxury interiors, even Shahrazad would be jealous.

In the hot desert of the UAE, on the shores of the Persian Gulf lies a blossoming oasis Ras Al Khaimah. The capital of the emirate of the same name in the north of the country is located on both sides of the bay. Ras Al Khaimah is famous for its pristine beaches with white sand and turquoise waters, excellent conditions for outdoor activities, many tourist attractions and natural wonders. Even at night, it is impossible to get bored in the city. There are restaurants with live music and performances by Arabian dancers that attract guests with the magical atmosphere of an oriental tale.

Fujairah (El- Fujairah) is the capital of the eponymous Emirate in the United Arab Emirates. Located on the cozy Gulf of Oman, part of the Indian Ocean, a small town is considered one of the most popular resorts in the country. Wide gold-sand beaches, coral reefs, green valleys, picturesque ravines attract those who like peaceful vacations full of bright impressions. Those who are interested in historical landmarks won’t be bored here. Tourists will see ancients forts, grandeur mosques, the ruins of the ancient settlements.

In the capital of the resort island, there is not a single good beach. But are they really needed if the routes to all the best resorts of the island diverge from Phuket Town? This city has a completely different mission to show how bright, colorful, and different Thailand can be. Here, even in the middle of a bustling market, you can find a quiet Taoist temple; theatrical performances are more reminiscent of fabulous actions, stunning the imagination; and the architecture of the oldest quarters embodied the seemingly impossible merger of the cultures of East and West.

Bangkok is the capital of Thailand. People often call it Venice of the East as it also has plenty of canals just like in real Venice. The city is situated at the mouth of the river Chao Phraya, in the place where it flows into the Gulf of Siam. As Bangkok is located in the area of humid tropics, this factor predetermined the formation of the subequatorial climate on its territory. The weather here is hot all year round with insignificant seasonal shifts. Tourists come here to get acquainted with the bright Southeastern culture, try the renowned street food, attend extraordinary shows, and enjoy shopping.

Pattaya is the most vibrant, bustling, and rave city in Thailand. People who can’t imagine their vacation without noisy parties, extravagant show programs, and real adventures come here. However, besides endless parties, the resort has many other trump cards. During the day, Pattaya will offer tourists a lot of interesting entertainments, a warm sea, picturesque places, excursions, and authentic places, and at night it will put on bright neon lights and break into dance. The resort is an hour's drive from Bangkok and pleases with very affordable prices. Pattaya has collected everything that is needed for an active and lively holiday. Here you can delve into the local culture, explore the jungle, meet monkeys, try exotic food, and dance for years to come.

long_description.en:
Pattaya was an unknown fishing village until the late 1950s. Its original name (Pad Thai Ya) translates as "the wind moves from the southwest at the beginning of the rainy season. Later it was shortened to Pattaya. Around 1959, several transport trucks with U.S. military personnel came to Pattaya for vacation. The local beauty and pristine beaches attracted them. The soldiers stayed there for about a week, returned to base, and then told their fellow soldiers about their vacation. It is believed that this was the beginning of the development of Pattaya as a resort.

Enterprising Thais (mostly businessmen from Bangkok) saw this as a good source of income and began to develop the village's infrastructure. In 1960, the first hotel Nautical Inn, which continues to operate today, along with new restaurants, bars, nightclubs, and cafes.

In 1975, the popularity of Pattaya, with the end of the Vietnam War, went into decline, and part of the institutions closed. However, the decline did not last long. November 29, 1978, Pattaya was officially designated a city. This date in history is considered the birthday of the resort and is celebrated every year.

Today Pattaya is a favorite tourist city, which is famous for its entertainment, nightlife, and developed infrastructure.

description.en: Chiang Mai is located in the northern part of Thailand, 700 km away from Bangkok. It is the largest city in the region and the second-largest after the capital. Chiang Mai looks like a big blooming garden for tourists, where buildings were built by mistake. There are about three hundred Buddhist temples in the city, which were constructed in different historical periods. This is why there is an environment of peace, positive spirit, and tranquility. It is worth mentioning Wat Chiang Man — the oldest religious building in the city. It was erected in the XIII century. It contains important relics such as the Jade Buddha and the Crystal Buddha. Wat Phra That Doi Suthep is located in the vicinity of the city on the top of Mount Doi Suthep at an altitude of one thousand six hundred meters. Tourists also visit the nearby national parks and enjoy night shopping in the largest market in the north of the country.

Hua Hin is a resort city in Thailand, which is located on the west coast of the Gulf of Thailand. A peaceful, cozy, and charming — this is how a vacation in this city may be described. The city isn’t a destination for those who like noisy clubs, show-programs, and tourist routes. But those who cherish authenticity, elegance, and love of traditions will like it. Originally, Hua Hin was a royal resort and it hasn’t lost its charm. Here you can communicate with nature, enjoy a beach holiday, and explore the local culture. Hua Hin is a great choice for a romantic trip or a peaceful family vacation.

One of the greenest and most secluded resorts in Thailand is successfully located on the west coast of the Andaman Sea. Khao Lak is a city that manages to combine modern hotels, restaurants, nightclubs, and national parks with wildlife. There are not as many tourists as neighboring Phuket has, which contributes to a more relaxed and measured rest. At the same time, Khao Lak knows exactly how to surprise its guests and make sure that they will love this town forever.

On the banks of the Kok River in northern Thailand, it is located Chiang Rai, one of the cities of the Golden Triangle of Thailand. In the city, you can find the most famous religious buildings of the country. For example, the White Temple is a widely known destination, as it provides the opportunity to admire the mirror mosaics and carved sculptures from alabaster. The Buddhist Blue Temple with bright turquoise walls and high gilded ceilings is considered as a very atmospheric place of the capital. Another famous attraction of Chiang Rai is the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. It is a huge temple complex that includes an ancient statue of the emerald Buddha, which is regarded as the real “pearl.” Adults and children are expected to appreciate Singha Park that has gardens, tea plantations, a swan lake, and a zoo. Furthermore, it is essential to take into account the Hilltribe Museum, Oub Kham Museum with collections related to royal families, and the Ho Watthanatham Nithat museum.

At the confluence of the Kwai Yai and Kwai Noi rivers, surrounded by limestone hills, it is located Kanchanaburi. It is the administrative center of the province of the same name in Thailand. The city has become a tremendously popular tourist destination due to the bridge over the Kwai River — a military monument that is the central theme of an Oscar-winning movie that was produced in 1957. Most of Kanchanaburi’s attractions are related to the war period. For instance, the World War II Museum, JEATH War Museum, and several military cemeteries are visited by the tourists in the first place. It is better to start a tour related to military monuments from the Thailand-Burma Railway Center, as it includes information about all historical destinations. Travelers also pay attention to the Floating Nun Temple. It is known for a nun who, dressed in white, swims in the pond and meditates at the same time. Besides, you can find limestone caves, including the ones that are consecrated as temples, as well as a national park with a seven-tiered waterfall near the city.

Hikkaduwa is a resort town on the coast of the Indian Ocean in Sri Lanka. people come here to spend a great beach vacation, go diving, surfing, and snorkeling. Life here is slow-paced. Sea turtles come to the beach, iguanas crawl along the beach, and coral reefs grow in azure clear water.

Galle is a beautiful port city in the southern part of the island of Sri Lanka. The provincial town is known first of all as a place of excursion acquaintance with the centuries-old history and color of the tea island country. Three waves of colonization by different European countries left a bright imprint in the city's architectural appearance. The beach area on the Indian Ocean's shores is as attractive to the city's guests as its cultural facilities. Galle is a popular corner among tourists of the exotic and authentic flavor. The proximity to the ocean, leisurely pace of life and beautiful landscapes will be a real delight for experienced tourists seeking for new unique atmospheric places. The subtle nature of South Asia, its picturesque nature, and its cultural and historical sites attract more and more travelers to Galle each year.

Colombo is the cultural, economic, industrial, and business capital of Sri Lanka. The city is located in the southwestern part of the island of the same name, on the shores of the Indian Ocean. Representatives of four world religions (Buddhism, Hinduism, Christianity, and Islam) live under the azure sky of Colombo. This city is full of contrasts and contradictions. All areas of life (culture, architecture, and even the rhythm of life) are affected by the influence of numerous conquerors, which makes this place tremendously unique and interesting. In fact, an amazing combination of eras and styles is fascinating. For instance, the original architecture of Buddhist temples perfectly coexists with the modern buildings of the metropolis. Colombo impresses, shimmers with different colors, and excites the imagination of its guests. At the same time, it is a peaceful place that fills the soul and heart with light and warmth, respectively. Saturated with the ocean breeze and warmed by the rays of the equatorial sun, the city is expected to give you a lot of energy and fill you with optimism and faith in the best.

long_description.en: Colombo has managed to preserve the ancient indigenous flavor that blends well with the buildings of a modern Asian metropolis. Colombo has many attractions: natural parks, monuments, and temples of four religions, which harmoniously coexist in the streets of this extraordinary city. Colombo is an incredibly atmospheric place, where it is impossible to remain indifferent and not be imbued with its energy and spirit.

description.en: Jeju City is an administrative center of the eponymous province in the Republic of Korea. It is located on the northern coast of Jeju Island. The island is 60 km away from the southern coastline of the Korean peninsula, where three seas meet — the Yellow Sea, the Sea of Japan, and the East China Sea. Jeju City is divided into two parts: the northern one is of Jeju, and the southern one is of Seogwipo. In other words, Jeju is only one-half of Jeju. There are a lot of natural landmarks on the island. In the city, tourists adore luxury parks, amazing beaches, different museums, temples, comfortable hotels, restaurants, and theme parks that fit every taste. Warm and equable climate add to the popularity of Jeju. You won’t suffer from too much heat. Nowadays, the resort is very popular among Korean, Chinese, and Japanese. And there is no doubt that in the near future, Jeju will be among the most visited resorts in the world.

long_description.en:
The history of Jeju City is inextricably linked with the history of Jeju Island. There is no data on when people settled here and when they established their first state. All that is known is that the island, then called Thamna, had its own state entity in the VII century. In 662, it became a protectorate of the Korean state of Silla. In 1105, it actually became part of another state, Goryeo, and was renamed Jeju ("far district") or Jeju-do ("far district island"). Subsequently, Jeju remained part of the Korean state for centuries.

Until the early 1960s, the islanders lived in poverty, subsisting mainly on the gifts of the sea. But Jeju-do is an amazingly beautiful island. And when its natural wonders were appreciated, the tourism industry began to boom here. The first "big" group of tourists, 100 people, visited Jeju-do in 1958. And 13 years later, Newsweek magazine already wrote about it as "the island of the Gods. Accordingly, the island's main city, Jeju, was rapidly turning into a tourist center. Today, about 80% of the island's population is engaged in tourism, and more than 4 million (!) tourists visit the main resort of Korea every year.

description.en: Tokyo is one of the largest cities in the world, a modern megalopolis, a true hive of activities where life doesn’t stop even at night. It’s one of the most incredible towns on the planet! Only in Tokyo, the concrete “jungles” stand side by side with ancient temples, the latest hi-tech releases strike the imagination, and even the local citizens can mix up the local metro lines. A complicated layout of the streets and districts is another particular feature of the megalopolis. You can easily get lost here, so you should build a route carefully but always be ready to take the wrong turn. Tokyo is a city with an attitude, and it depends only on you if you manage to make friends with it or not.

long_description.en:
Even though Tokyo is considered to be an international city, the majority of its citizens are the Japanese. The number of permanent foreign residents in the capital is only around 3%. According to the data gathered in 2008, this number includes:

  • Indians (almost 190 thousand people);
  • Chinese (approximately 145 thousand);
  • Koreans (about 117 thousand);
  • Filipinos (over 31 thousand);
  • Americans (nearly 20 thousand).

It should be noted that the fast aging of the nation is the main problems of the population in Tokyo. The birth rates are decreasing, while the expectancy of life is, vice versa, increasing. According to the statistics, more than 20% of the citizens in Tokyo are seniors.

description.en: Osaka is called the "Venice of Japan" because the city is pierced by many river arms and human-made canals with more than 100 bridges across them. It is referred to as the "culinary capital of Japan" because its cuisine is exceptionally diverse, and local chefs stand out for their skills. Osaka is the busiest and most cheerful city in Japan, the most striking and vibrant. It amazes with its original architecture and the kindness of the locals. Osaka is mesmerizing!

long_description.en: Most of the people in Osaka are Japanese. But the city is home to one of the largest Korean communities in Japan. The townspeople mostly speak the Kansai dialect of Japanese (Kansai-ben). It should be noted that they are more sociable and open than residents of other regions of Japan.

description.en: You can't go to Japan without seeing Kyoto, because Kyoto is Japan. No other city boasts so many ancient palaces, temples, and beautiful parks. No other city reflects the Japanese spirit to such an extent. A walk through Kyoto is a fascinating journey through the corners of the history of the Land of the Rising Sun.

long_description.en: Kyoto's ethnic composition is homogeneous, with an overwhelming majority of its inhabitants being Japanese. Interestingly, the city's population has barely increased in recent years, slowly approaching one and a half million.

description.en: The world-famous winter resort of Sapporo is located in the southwestern part of the second largest island in Japan — Hokkaido. It comfortably lies on a plain in the valley of the Ishikari and Toyohira Rivers, protected from the winds by low mountain ranges. Despite its youth, in terms of population, Sapporo ranks fifth in the country. The city has a lot of greenery, parks, and mountains, surrounding it that are amazingly good at any time of the year. But the main thing is the unique natural conditions of this part of Hokkaido. They create the richest opportunities for winter sports. For this reason, a huge number of skiers and snowboarders come here every year — professionals and amateurs. Besides, thermal springs are located near Sapporo, which turns it into a health resort.

long_description.en:
The climate in this part of Hokkaido is not quite usual. Despite its proximity to the sea, it has continental features. Summers here are usually hot, and the average temperature ranges from +21°C to +26°C, but sometimes gets above +30°C. August is the hottest month. At the same time, precipitation is rare from April to June. But August and September are the rainy months.

Winters are usually mild. The average December temperature is -0.9°C, and in January, it gets around -3.6°C. However, sometimes the winters are very frosty, and the temperature reaches -20°C. A distinctive feature of the local climate is the abundance of snow in winter. In this regard, Sapporo is the second city in the world. The average annual thickness of the snow cover here is almost 600 mm. The mild but snowy winters are what made Sapporo so popular as a ski resort.

Winter is the best time to visit Sapporo. The city is also beautiful at other times as well because the nature around it is quite picturesque.

Each year, in early February, more than two million tourists come here for the Snow Festival. It lasts for a week. During this time, hundreds of snow and ice sculptures appear in the city, built by teams of sculptors worldwide. They have erected copies of Buckingham Palace, St. Basil's Cathedral, the White House, etc. were erected here. The height of some buildings was up to 12 meters.

In Sapporo, from mid-May to June 1, a lilac festival is held, which is one of the city's symbols. Sapporo is home to many varieties of this wonderful shrub. The gardens and parks take on a magical appearance in the spring and early summer.

description.en: Yokohama is the administrative center of Kanagawa Prefecture, the second-largest city in Japan (more than 3.7 million people live there), and one of the pillars of its economic power. As a modern and tremendously beautiful city, it is located on the southeast coast of Honshu Island, 30 km from Tokyo. The annual Japanese ranking of the most popular cities often places Yokohama in the first position. This metropolis has a special atmosphere, as it is very comfortable for living. In fact, the green and comfortable city has everything for a pleasant stay.

long_description.en:
Since the city is located on the ocean shore, the climate here is mild, coastal. In winter, the temperature rarely drops below 0°C. The warmest month is August when the average temperature is about +27°C. Speaking about the weather, the best time to visit Yokohama is spring and autumn. It can be too hot and stuffy in summer. In addition, the cherry blossoms in spring, at the end of March and beginning of April, and in autumn, the city is colored in gold and purple. Summer, on the other hand, is the fireworks season. In mid-July in Yokohama, lovers of this spectacle enjoy a two-day festival called Sparkling Twilight. It is followed (in August) by the Kanagawa Shimbun Fireworks Festival. It's even more colorful — 15,000 fireworks explode into the sky, with the main one, the Nishakudama, literally covering the entire sky.

In October, several cities in Japan traditionally hold the Oktoberfest beer festival, but Yokohama hosts the largest one. They bring here foamy drink not only from all over Japan but also from almost all over the world. Among other things, you can taste beers brewed especially for this festival. The festival lasts for two weeks and is accompanied by numerous entertainment events.

description.en: Kamakura is a cozy green city that is located 50 km away from Tokyo and a 20-minute drive from Yokohama. Taking into consideration that it is over 800 years old, every detail of this city breathes antiquity that is filled with majestic beauty. For instance, Shintoist and Buddhist temples are surrounded by azaleas, lotuses, and hydrangeas. In turn, trees with domed crowns effectively complement the picture, whereas huge statues of saints (in stone, wood, and gilding) seem to compete in luxury. This ancient city has all appropriate conditions for measured rest, as it saturates with energy from the inside. Buildings constructed according to the style of old Europe and modern Japan create an indescribable atmosphere. Each street and every courtyard of the city is regarded as a mini work of art.

long_description.en:
There was once a fisherman's village where the city stands today. The rapid transformation of Kamakura into the informal capital of Japan was facilitated by the usual for that time feuds. In the XII century, the greatest power in the country belonged to the Taira clan. At one point, its leader even managed to make his three-year-old grandson an emperor. Eventually, however, the Taira lost the power contest to the Minamoto clan, who put their candidate on the throne. The head of the clan, Yoritomo Minamoto, received the title of shogun ("barbarian-quelling generalissimo," a military ruler) from the new emperor. He decided it was wiser to place his administration away from the imperial palace in Kyoto. He created a bakufu (or shogunate, literally, "tent government"), a field headquarters, on his land (in Kamakura). Thus, in 1192, the small village became the center of political life in Japan, and the "Kamakura period" appeared in history.

In its heyday, the town was the largest in the country, with about 10,000 houses. One by one, Buddhist temples were built. Trade was booming, and blacksmithing was developing. The properties and quality of samurai tools of the XII-XIII centuries are still valued today. Masamune, from the province of Sagami, was the most famous blacksmith of this period.

The city's decline was as rapid as its rise. In 1274 and 1281, Japan survived invasions by the Mongol-Chinese forces of Kublai Khan. The country survived, but its economy was badly damaged. At the same time, the influence of the bakufu military administration was shaken - it simply lacked money.

In 1333 the Kamakura shogunate fell to the Ashikaga clan. Following this, Kamakura lost its status as a political center forever and once again became a small village. At the same time, the city's religious significance, thanks to its numerous temples, diminished only slightly.

After the Meiji restoration in 1868, life in Kamakura revived as the country began to show interest in ancient Japan's history and spiritual heritage.

In 1923, Kamakura, like many other cities on the east coast of Honshu, was thoroughly destroyed in a monstrous earthquake. But it was quickly rebuilt.

American air raids during World War II, fortunately, bypassed it. During the entire subsequent period, the city actively developed, and thanks to the surviving historical monuments, it became a popular tourist center.

description.en: Hiroshima is the sadly remembered Japanese city that suffered from nuclear bombardment. It was the first case in the history of humanity when the atomic weapon was used. It claimed the lives of hundreds of thousands of people. The tragic story of a small girl named Sadako Sasaki went round of the globe. This girl died from radiation poisoning but had desperately believed in the legend about a thousand paper cranes that could save her life...

long_description.en:
According to the statistics of 2015, around 1,194 million people live in Hiroshima, and 98.5% of them are Japanese.

The absolute majority of people (84%) are adherents of Shintoism (the national religion in Japan). However, only 30% of people identify themselves as religious. The rest of the people treat religion as a part of traditions.

description.en: Kobe is located in Japan on Honshu Island. The city is a major industrial and commercial center of the Land of the Rising Sun, one of the main ports of the country. For the first time, the area where the city is located today was mentioned in written sources in 201 BC. You can visit museums, temples, parks, an old aquarium, see the port tower, Akashi Kaikyō Bridge — the longest suspension bridge in the world, wander through the European quarters of Yamamoto Street, climb to see the panorama of the city and port to the Hyperboloid Tower. Every December, Kobe hosts the Festival of Light in memory of the victims of the earthquake that killed nearly six and a half thousand city residents. Approximately four million Japanese people and guests attend the festival.

Nagasaki is located in the west of Kyushu island (Japan), in a picturesque bay, surrounded by mountains on all sides. For a long time it was the only port city for communication with Europe, that is why you can notice some characteristic accents in architecture. Nevertheless, people here with special awe keep their traditions. It is famous for fascinating Buddhist temples, modern green parks, untouched scenic nature, and the smiles of local residents. Nagasaki automatically evokes the memories of the famous tragedy. But this does not mean at all that the amazing Japanese city has nothing more to present. Today, Nagasaki is a prosperous, modern city with an extraordinary love of life. It is characterized by immense cordiality, rich culture and unique beauty, and a trip here is an opportunity to get into a special, unlike anything world.

long_description.en:
The samurai feudal leader Omura Sumitada ruled the territory of the modern city of Nagasaki from the second half of the XVI century. In order to develop trade relations with Europe, he converted to Christianity and founded port settlements, including Nagasaki. In 1570, it was equipped with a port, and in 1571 a settlement grew there. Thanks to active trade, the city quickly developed and became one of the richest in Japan.

In 1715, the growth of economy of Nagasaki went into decline. The reason was the establishment of government limits on the importation of goods. But despite this, the city remained the center of education in Japan. They studied foreign languages, science, and European medicine here.

At the beginning of the XIX century, the local port was declared open for ships of foreign states such as Russia, Great Britain, the United States, and others. This contributed to the modernization of Nagasaki. Later, the first Japanese railroad, an English-language newspaper, and a telegraph appeared here. Thanks to the activities of Western embassies, the country was able to lift the ban on Christianity, which had lasted about two hundred years. Most of the people of Nagasaki were able to return to the Church openly.

The most famous tragedy in the city's history was the atomic bombing on August 9, 1945. Most of Nagasaki was destroyed, and the terrible explosion took the lives of about 70 thousand people. The city was located in a hilly area, so there was less destruction than in Hiroshima. Over time, numerous museums and memorials were built in its territory to commemorate the victims of the atomic bombing — the Peace Statue, the Atomic Bomb Museum, and the Peace Park were created.

description.en: Baku is one of the oldest cities in the world, keeping secrets and mysteries worthy of special attention of a traveler. Many centuries ago, its first inhabitants admired this truly fertile shore of the Caspian Sea on the border of Asia and Europe. During its existence, Baku has welcomed and sheltered thousands of tired travelers. Its caravanserais accommodated countless merchants, who increased the prosperity of the city. Over the centuries, despite conquests and strife, the city became even more majestic. With every ruler, it acquired something new and turned into a cultural center of Transcaucasia, where theatres, libraries, and temples were opened, and architectural heritage multiplied. Baku reached even greater heyday after oil was found here, and money flowed into the city like a river. All events experienced by Baku residents are depicted in different city sights. And if you like narrow labyrinths of ancient streets, if you like romantic walks along the evening seafront, if warm, clean beaches attract you — you should definitely go to Baku. Tourists will have a vibrant adventure here, colored with bright and unforgettable impressions.

long_description.en:
Bakililar is a succinct word. After all, the city is very international. However, mostly Azerbaijanis live on the territory of modern Baku. According to recent data, they account for more than 90%. Other nationalities include Russians, Ukrainians, Georgians, and Turks. But, regardless of ethnicity or religion, all Baku citizens have a soul of boundless breadth. They love their city and know almost everything about it, which they are willing to share with visitors.
        Although Baku is constantly moving with the times and actively developing, the citizens cherish the traditions and customs of their ancestors. Therefore, travelers, both men, and women are also advised to study the existing rules, for example, avoid very bright and open clothing so as not to offend anyone. The Baku people are very hospitable. Regardless of the class of the host, they always serve a splendid table for their guests. In no case can you refuse a treat so as not to offend the hosts. Those who have ever been to Baku say that the main asset of the city are its people, who are hospitable and generous.

description.en: It is no coincidence that Yerevan is associated with a city for an eternal vacation. This is a place where it is impossible to work, as you only want to rest endlessly and enjoy the beauty. The relaxing life flows on the streets, and the magical aroma of roses is floating in the air. At the same time, the walls of the buildings are decorated in pink colors, whereas the restaurants serve delicious kebabs and the famous Ararat. One-third of the country's population lives in Yerevan, although this fact does not interfere with the opportunity of getting a good rest, which you will probably want to repeat.

Manama is the most sparsely populated capital of the Arab world, which is located on the shores of the Persian Gulf. The main city of the exotic Kingdom of Bahrain impresses with a bizarre mix of Arab and European cultures. For example, the narrow streets of ancient Arab quarters with ancient mosques turn into modern streets with high skyscrapers. In turn, snow-white beaches with date palms and coral reefs attract admirers of sea vacation. Simultaneously, connoisseurs of ancient Arabian culture can find amazing historical and architectural monuments here. Manama is a stylish modern city, where tourists can experience the feeling of being a part of a fascinating Arabian fairy tale.

Southern capital, Paris of the East that never sleeps — Ho Chi Minh City as many different names, and each of them is justified. It is one of the largest metropolises in Vietnam, the center of industry and trade. Ho Chi Minh City is about picturesque landscapes and rich architecture, exotic cuisine and noisy nightlife, interesting guided tours, and a unique atmosphere. Tourists from all over the world come to Ho Chi Minh City for shopping and bright emotions and there are enough of them in the city!

long_description.en: The majority of Ho Chi Minh City's local population is made up of Viets, about 93.5%. The Chinese are represented in the city in rather large numbers — almost 5.8%. It is worth noting that Ho Chi Minh City (the district of Cholon) is the center of the largest Chinese community in Vietnam. The number of other nationalities in the city is noticeably smaller. Among them are the Khmer (0.34%) and the Chams (0.1%).

description.en: Cultures, styles, and even past and present are so mixed in a modern Hanoi that it became a unique city. Deliberateness and tranquility of ancient Buddhism keep in step with fuss and hustle of business modernity. Pagodas and temples, the charm of colonial architecture, and a touch of Soviet buildings, and also numerous magnificent lakes — Hanoi is changeable and many-sided. It has something to offer for everyone. You will remember it and will look forward to your next meeting. Each time, Hanoi will surprise with something special.

long_description.en:
The peculiarity of the capital of Vietnam is that the total number of visitors to the city annually exceeds the number of its residents. There is a worldwide trend of the predominance of women over men. The average age of the capital's residents is 35 years. The most numerous age group are people from 16 to 65 years, and the most common surname is Nguyen. Most Hanoi residents are adherents of the so-called folk beliefs, which are based on the rituals of the cult of ancestors. The second-largest group is atheists, the third — the Buddhists.

Despite practically 100% literacy of the capital, there are few English-speaking people in Hanoi.

description.en: Da Nang is a dynamic, fast-growing city that has staked on tourism and has not missed out. It is located on the shore of the South China Sea, on the Khan River, in the heart of Vietnam. Both Europeans and Asians come here to have a rest. Giant areas of city beaches can give comfort and seclusion even in high season, and the developed infrastructure will not allow feeling cut off from civilization. Lovers of water sports and passive beach recreation go to Da Nang. Fans of night clubs and gourmets who discover cuisines of new countries will find here something to do. For shopping lovers, Da Nang offers cute souvenirs and useful things, and for curious visitors wishing to learn something interesting about the country of stay — exciting excursions.

long_description.en:
The history of Da Nang dates back to the tiny fishing villages that existed on the seashore 2,000 years ago. In 192, natives of Indonesia founded their city here. It was called Indrapura, and it was the capital of the Union of Champa Princedoms, which occupied the territory of central and southern Vietnam from 875 to 1000 years. In the middle of the XVI century, Europeans appeared in Da Nang. One of the first to land in 1535 was the Portuguese navigator Antonio de Faria. He was the first to make a detailed description of the area.

In the second half of the XVIII century, the Portuguese, who were the first to discover the area, began to be pressed by the French, who wanted to take over the whole of Indochina.

Thus, by the end of the XIX century, Da Nang had really become one of the French outposts in Indochina, a major trading post and port.

During the Second World War, the Japanese reigned in Da Nang, and during the Vietnam War, the Americans stationed here the largest naval base and airbase, through which, later, Da Nang had its own airport.

After the war, in 1975, Danang became the administrative center of the province of Quang Nam-Da Nang, and in 1997, it was the city of the central government, an independent administrative unit.

description.en: Nha Trang is the main resort city of Vietnam on the shores of the South China Sea, separated by the Yachang River. The beaches with white sand and clear water, a beautiful bay, brought the city great popularity. It is considered one of the most picturesque resorts in the world. Emerald hills, an 8-kilometer long beach, tropical islands in the middle of the bay, and a modern city all mix with ancient temples and Asian markets.

The name of the island stands for the "rich land." And it really is! But this is not about oil, diamonds, or gold, but about the stunning beauty and almost wild nature. Tourists go to this fast-growing resort to enjoy a fantastic beach holiday, to get acquainted with Vietnamese culture, to taste the best seafood in the country, and see with their own eyes the paradisiacal tropics.

The sea, sun, magnificent beaches, night clubs, luxury hotels; and also ancient monuments of architecture, narrow streets, which paving stone keeps the history of centuries; even usual rocks, covered with lots of legends and fables — cheerful Tel Aviv managed to unite all this together, and quite harmoniously. This city will show tourists the breathtaking sunsets of the Mediterranean Sea, will imbue with the salty breeze of the quays, mesmerize with the worship song of the old neighborhoods and make you fall in love with itself. Forever! The rhythms of Tel Aviv are ragged, alluring, promising all earthly pleasures at once, stirring up the blood, and not letting you forget about your trip here for a long time to come.

long_description.en: Tel Aviv is the second-largest city in Israel. The vast majority of its residents (just over 90%) are Jews, 3.0% are Muslim Arabs, about 1% are Christian Arabs, and the rest are of other nationalities. Almost half of the residents of Tel Aviv have an excellent knowledge of Russian, being either from the former Soviet Union or their descendants.

description.en: Haifa is the largest city in northern Israel. It flows into the Mediterranean Sea along the slopes of Mount Carmel, where the biblical prophet Ilya once lived. The picturesque coastline, beautiful beaches, and great views made Haifa the famous modern resort. But this city is not so simple. In addition, it is the center of important industrial hubs in the country and the center of several world religions. The laws of Judaism are honored here, but the Sabbath isn’t kept up to. Ancient buildings stand side by side with skyscrapers, and high technology does not interfere with the spiritual growth of numerous pilgrims. Haifa is a unique city. And it’s worth coming here to unravel its secret.

long_description.en:
The first information about Haifa as a small settlement dates to the second half of the III century. In the VII century, the Arabs settled in this area and turned the city into a fairly important Mediterranean port in 200 years. In the XII century, the Christian conquerors came to the Holy Land. Haifa fell in 1100 after a month-long siege. Almost all of its inhabitants were mercilessly killed, and their property was looted. In 1156, Berthold of Calabria and his loyal crusaders founded the Monastery of Our Lady of Mount Carmel on the hillside.

The city passed from Christians to Muslims and vice versa for more than a century, and the Mamelukes destroyed it in the XIII century. Up to the XVIII century, Haifa was a small fishing village until a new ruler, Bedouin Zahir al-Umar al-Zaydani, revived it. In 1799, not to be destroyed a second time, Haifa surrendered without a fight to the forces of Napoleon Bonaparte. And after him, the Turks seized the city.

The XIX century was marked by the city's rapid development of steam shipping. It became an important port again. The population grew dramatically. People began to settle behind its walls on the slopes of Mount Carmel.

The rule of the Turks ended after World War I. Haifa passed to the British. They have erected a strong military base, a new port, railroad, airport, oil pipeline, and power plant and started massive buildings, giving Haifa a European appearance. In 20-30 years of the last century, the Jewish refugees began to arrive here en masse.

After establishing the State of Israel in 1948, the Haifa municipality began to govern the city. The second half of the XX century was a period of active development of industrial, cultural, and tourist potential.

Haifa entered the new century as a popular resort, a major seaport, and the most important municipality in the north of Israel.

description.en: Mountains, sea, and the sun — can there be a more perfect combination for an unforgettable vacation? All this you will find in Eilat, a pride of Israel and one of the most popular resorts on the Red Sea. Diving or snorkeling, jeep safari or mountain climbing, a yacht trip or bicycle touring, surfing, or lazy days on the beach — Eilat cannot boast of historical and architectural landmarks but it offers a great choice of entertainment. Another feature of the city is the possibility to spend days by the sea all year-round. Isn’t it a paradise?

The wide well-groomed beaches of Ashdod with snow-white sand stretch for 8 kilometers and go straight down to the azure waters of the Mediterranean Sea. They attract tourists like a magnet. But travelers are even more interested in the ruins of ancient structures, which confirm that the first settlements in this city were already in the XIX-XX centuries BC. There is much to see and recall. Ashdod has seen many people and many things. It is probably because of such a rich history that today we face Israel's modern, highly-developed industrial center. This is where the country's largest port is located — 60% of all imported goods pass through it. Ashdod offers all opportunities to relax with taste and comfort, which is made possible by hotels with excellent service and restaurants with exotic food. But there is also everything here to be enriched spiritually, literally breathing in the air of the three-thousand-year history and realizing every minute of belonging to those ancient centuries.

long_description.en:
Ashdod was founded around the XX century B.C. by the Canaanite tribes. They built a village at the foot of the mound of Tel Mor and a port at the mouth of the Lakhish River. For several centuries, the purple cloth trade - with Egypt, the Mediterranean countries, and Greece - was their main activity.
