In terms of ethnic composition, about 72.6% of the population is white, 6.9% is African-American, 2.4% comes from Asia, and 0.9% is indigenous peoples of the United States and Alaska. Another study shows that approximately 63.2% of the San Antonio population is of Latin American descent. Analysis of religious beliefs shows that 80% of the city's residents consider themselves Christians, 32% of whom are Catholic.

description.en: Aspen is a picturesque city in Colorado, United States. First of all, it is known as one of the most prestigious ski resorts. Hundreds of tourists come here to conquer snowy arduous hills and feel real winter magic. A cozy and romantic atmosphere is everywhere — in lovely wooden houses, yellow lights, and amazing landscapes. Aspen is the happy mean for both active and lazy tourists. You can try an extreme or peaceful vacation here. Everyone will find time for long walks and breathtaking entertainment. Clear air, green pines, and fluffy snow won’t leave you indifferent.

long_description.en:
The city originally was founded as Ute City by miners in 1879. It was renamed Aspen in 1880. The city experienced economic growth during the period of silver mining. Here in the mine, a silver nugget, weighing 6060 pounds, was found. It assayed at 93 percent pure silver. New schools, banks, churches, and an opera theatre were built in the city. Its population grew to 15 thousand people. But steadily declined, reaching 700 people by 1930. In the 1930s, winter sports enthusiasts conceived Aspen as a potential ski resort.

But their plans were interrupted by World War II. After the war, in 1950, the city hosted the FIS World Championships. Aspen was then on the path to becoming one of the leading ski resorts. The area would continue to develop with the foundation of three additional ski areas, Aspen Mountain (1958), Aspen Highlands (1958) и Snowmass (1967).

At the end of the 20th century, the city became a popular holiday destination among celebrities.

Nowadays, Aspen is the most popular tourist destination. Moreover, it is the area with the most expensive real estate property in the USA.

Colorado Springs rarely has bad weather. The city can boast of at least 300 sunny days a year. The peak of the tourist season comes in summer when the average temperature reaches +27-30°C. At this time, the main natural attractions, as a rule, have no time to rest from the streams of tourists. Lovers of long walks will enjoy the autumn Colorado Springs. Temperatures in September and October range from +17-23°C. Stunning natural landscapes are an additional bonus. Precipitation is rare, and the weather pleases tourists with the mild sun.

Winter landscapes of Colorado Springs are no less attractive, but from November to February, the number of tourists in the city is declining rapidly. At this time, the average minimum temperature is about -8°C, and the maximum is +9°C.

If you plan to visit Colorado Springs in spring, it is best to do it in late April or early May. At this time, the thermometer column rises to about +16-21°C.

There are often interesting art festivals and events in the city. One of them is the Balloon Festival, which takes place in September. In autumn (most often in October), here is also held the Month of Art. At this time, you can see the works of talented contemporary creators on the city's streets. People in Colorado Springs also throw bright celebrations of Halloween, Thanksgiving, Valentine's Day, St. Patrick's Day, Easter, and Christmas holidays.

Before the first settlers from Europe, the Waccamaw tribe lived on this territory. In 1526, the Spaniards founded a small settlement here. It was located 50 miles north of the modern city. A year later, they returned home, having realized that the sandy soil of the region was not suitable for agriculture. In the XVIII century, a small colony Long Bay was formed in this place. Its inhabitants were engaged in the cultivation of indigo and tobacco plantations.

In 1900, the settlement got its present name, Myrtle Beach. It was chosen because of the thick thickets of wax myrtle, which grew everywhere. Around the same time, the first tourists were attracted by the magnificent sandy beaches of the coast.

In 1957, Myrtle Beach received the status of a city. At that time, it was home to over 5000 inhabitants. Until 1993, the U.S. Air Force military base was located here, and after its shutdown, all its property — land and real estate — passed to the city.

A few years later, Myrtle Beach began rapidly gaining popularity as a comfortable resort. Nowadays, not only the residents of the United States and Canada but also guests from many countries around the world like to rest on its beaches.

The settlement appeared in the XVIII century at the crossroads of historical routes connecting the North of the country with the South and the Center with the Atlantic coast. The Indians used these trade routes even before the arrival of European settlers. The city was named after Queen Charlotte, wife of King George III of England.

Charlotte received the city statute in 1768 and later became the residence of the county. This was mainly due to the efforts of local residents, who built a courthouse with columns and other public facilities. In May 1775, Charlotte made its declaration of disobedience to Britain. The Mecklenburg Orders of May 31, 1775, declared "the power of the king or parliament invalid."

The second half of the XVIII century is famous for the prosperity of the inner parts of North Carolina. The discovery of gold nearby led to an increase in settlements in the Charlotte area. Mining activities contributed to the city's development, and the proximity to the mines led to the appearance here in 1837, a branch of the national mint. At the same time, several banks were opened in the city. Before the California Gold Rush of 1849, Charlotte was the center of gold production in the country.

In the 1850s, Charlotte became the southern end station of the North Carolina railroad. During the Civil War of 1861-1865, thanks to access to the railroad, the city increased the number of important military facilities.

Charlotte survived the war with dignity. African Americans, who made up 40% of the population of Mecklenburg County, were now free. The population of the city has doubled during the 1860s. A new era began with the civil rights movement in the middle of the XX century.

At the same time, the first racing tracks began to appear in Charlotte. In 1949, here was held the first-ever race of professional serial cars NASCAR. And ten years later, the famous Charlotte Motor Speedway racing track was built.

In 1993, a soccer team, Carolina Panthers, was created in Charlotte. In the early 2000s, the city continued its educational and cultural development. In addition, it became a center of professional sports, in particular, car racing. The city has preserved this fame up to the present day.

Scientists believe that the modern territory of Chattanooga was inhabited back in the Paleolithic period. But the history of Chattanooga itself began in 1816. At that time, John Ross, who later became the Cherokee Nation chief, founded Ross's Landing trading post on the river.

In 1838, the U.S. government forced the indigenous peoples to leave the territory, and a year later, Ross's Landing became the city of Chattanooga. The settlement grew rapidly and developed as an important river port on the banks of the Tennessee River. Its prosperity further stimulated the construction of the railroad in the middle of the XIX century.

During the U.S. Civil War, the city was an important strategic center for the Confederate army. In 1863, one of the most significant battles of that period took place here. In memory of it, the veterans founded the oldest and largest in the country, the Chickamauga & Chattanooga National Military Park.

After the war, iron and steel plants were constructed in the city, leading to a disastrous environmental situation at the end of the 1960s. However, in the 1980s, the Vision 2000 program for air and water purification was launched in Chattanooga. It was also aimed at creating beautiful green areas, attractions, and infrastructure to attract visitors to the city. The program produced excellent results.

In the XXI century, Chattanooga has become a popular tourist center and one of the best places in the country for life, work, and entertainment.

description.en: Atlanta is the capital of the southern American state of Georgia and one of the largest cities in the USA. This city is not so popular among tourists like Los Angeles, New York, and Chicago. However, it has a couple of aces in its sleeve. That’s the city where Margaret Mitchell wrote “Gone with the Wind”, doctor Martin Luther King started his public activities, and John Stith Pemberton invented Coca-Cola. The city is located at the foot of the Appalachian Mountains that spread along the whole East Coast of the United States and a part of Canada.

long_description.en:
Around 498,044 people live in Atlanta. With the agglomeration, this number reaches five million people. The metropolitan area consists of 140 towns. It’s the fastest-growing agglomeration in the United States.

For historical reasons, the majority of the population (52.29%) is Afro-Americans, 40.08% are white Americans, 4.03% are Latin Americans, 2.27% are the representatives of two and more nationalities. The other nations compile 1.05%, while the native Americans constitute only 0.26%. The 0.03% are native citizens of Hawaii and islanders. The sex ratio is approximately equal. The average age is 33.5 years. Half of the population has higher educational attainment.

Protestantism is the main religion in the city. Over 75% of Atlantans are protestants. Approximately 15% of people consider themselves to be Catholics. Nearly 5% of citizens are Jews.

description.en: There's America where there's no fuss, crazy pace of running crowds and incredibly high buildings. The cozy little town of Savannah in the south of the States is a striking example. It's nestled among gloomy forests and impassable swamps. In this city, American rural Gothic small houses stand next to ancient oaks with legendary Spanish moss hanging from its branches. People here do not tend to rush having a snack as the run, but to sit and enjoy their breakfasts in local cafes until midday. And many of the houses and streets are left in their untouched original state. Savannah is a quiet whirlpool where tourists have crazy adventures.

long_description.en:
Savannah has a population of 146,000 people. Over the past ten years, the city's population has increased significantly and reached its peak since 1960. The black population in Savannah is 56%, the white population compiles 39%, the Asian population is 2%, and almost 3% are representatives of different races.

The city is home to many students, as there are two state universities and the College of Art and Design. Almost 22% of the city's residents live below the federal poverty level.

description.en: Salt Lake City is the capital of Utah (USA), surrounded by the waters of the Great Salt Lake. The city is located in a picturesque place where rocky cliffs and mighty mountain ranges peacefully neighbor with deserted lowlands and forests. Mormons make up the majority of Salt Lake City's population. This explains the huge number of their churches, temples, and themed museums within the city. Its neighborhoods attract fans of skiing and climbing. It's only a half-hour drive away, and you can already admire the beauty of one of the famous slopes. In Salt Lake, every tourist can count on a warm welcome, where the locals will be happy to share their traditions and make you feel part of one big family.

long_description.en:
The official date for the first permanent settlements in the Salt Lake Valley is July 24, 1847. On that day, a group of Mormons led by Brigham Young arrived here. They traveled around the United States in search of a secluded place to live in their faith in peace — without the violence to which they had been subjected in other states. The famous phrase Young said after his visit to the valley, "This is the place!" imprinted on the history of the town. In eastern Salt Lake City, where the leader said the historical words, there is now "This Is the Place Heritage Park" with a monument dedicated to the Pioneer-Mormons.

Four days after his relocation, Brigham Young identified a place to build the Salt Lake Temple. It later became one of Salt Lake's most famous landmarks and a "hallmark" for the Mormons. 

In 1849, the Mormons decided to call their lands Deseret and filed an official petition formally. The U.S. Congress rejected the petition and named them the Territory of Utah, making Fillmore the capital. 

In 1858, the title of state capital passed to Salt Lake City. The city's population continued to grow with new converts of Mormons and gold diggers from the Gold Rush period. Eventually, the town became one of the most populated places in the Wild West. 

From the middle of the XIX century, Mormons were under strict government control. The reason for this was the polygamy they practiced. The federal authorities established two military bases on their territory, and in 1890, a manifesto was issued ordering church members to obey the government and abandon polygamy. Eventually, the Mormons gave up. 

In 1896, Utah became a state. In 2002, Salt Lake City hosted the Winter Olympics. Preparations for it had a positive impact on the entire infrastructure of the city.

description.en: If you want to be in a real paradise, visit the tropical jungle, climb the mountains under the roar of a waterfall, lie on golden beaches and see bright coral reefs with your own eyes — you need to go to Honolulu. And, of course, the surfboard is as typical as a bike in the Netherlands. And in the heart of the capital of Hawaii, tourists are met by a classic American metropolis, with its majestic skyscrapers, noisy and colorful bustle of national quarters. Honolulu is a fantastic set of contrasts, where nature and concrete, languages, and cultural traditions of almost the whole world have mixed together.

long_description.en:
Honolulu is located on Oahu, the third-largest and most populous island in the Hawaiian Archipelago. It is a relatively young city, with a history that began in the XI century with a small Polynesian settlement called Waikiki. It had existed quietly and inconspicuously until 1804 when the island was conquered by King Kamehameha I and his court was transferred here. In 1809, the ruler moved to Kailua Kona, then to Lahaina, and did not return until 1845. With the efforts of the king and his descendants, the city became a real capital and was renamed to Honolulu, after the title of the harbor. And the name of Waikiki is anchored to the most famous beach in Hawaii and its surrounding area.

In 1893, the Hawaiian Archipelago came under US jurisdiction. The beginning of the XX century was marked by a massive fire, which destroyed the entire Chinatown and significantly damaged the neighboring quarters. The reason was the careless handling of the fire — there were cases of bubonic plague, and the attempt to burn down the infected houses led to tragic results.

The next major incident occurred in 1941 — the Japanese aviation attacked Pearl Harbor, a U.S. naval base built near Honolulu. After this tragedy, the war did not return to Hawaii, and Honolulu eventually only won and became a major supply center for U.S. troops in the Pacific Ocean. A lot of money was invested in developing its infrastructure at the time.

After the end of World War II, the Hawaiian Islands began to develop its tourism industry rapidly. Gradually, Honolulu has turned into one of the most comfortable resorts of the archipelago.

description.en: This city, with its complex history, looks very modern and businesslike. But if you walk through its clean streets, you will find many carefully-preserved architectural sights, ancient buildings, museums, parks, and gardens. Residents affectionately call their worky-town "Jax". They are proud of the fact that as a major industrial center, it always remains attractive to tourists. And they take care of the beaches, on the shores of which the Atlantic Ocean splashes in its pristine form.

long_description.en:
The lands of modern Jacksonville were inhabited as early as 4,000 years BC by the Timucua Indians. In 1513, Spanish settlers landed here. But the area had remained rather deserted for a long time until the French built Fort Caroline here in 1564. However, it was soon destroyed when the Spaniards regained power over this land.

In 1821, Florida came under US jurisdiction. After that, the settlement became known as Jacksonville. Thus, the inhabitants paid tribute to the first military governor of Florida (and later, the seventh president of America) Andrew Jackson. Jacksonville received the status of the city in 1859. Already at that time, it was a major supplier of cotton and wood, thanks to the most important port in Florida.

Since the beginning of the Civil War in 1861, the city became a major supplier of meat products to the Confederate troops. During the war, it moved from the south to the north several times and vice versa. In 1864, a major fight took place near it — a battle near the railway station of Olustee.

At the end of the confrontation, the city was quite ragged but quickly recovered. From 1867 to 1898, it even was a fashionable winter resort for American families who had enriched themselves during the war. They came here by steamboats and by rail. By the end of the century, the yellow fever epidemic had reduced the influx of tourists. And the railway, which stretched deep into the peninsula, led travelers to new cities.

In the first year of the XX century, a major fire broke out in Jacksonville. It destroyed the wooden buildings in the center and left 10,000 inhabitants homeless. The restoration of the city lasted 11 years under the direction of Henry Klutho, a famous architect from New York.

In the second decade of the past century, movie producers became interested in the city. Thirty studios were built here. However, the film boom for Jacksonville passed (as well as tourist boom had) when Hollywood was built.

Simultaneously with the development of cinematography, Jacksonville was established as a major banking and insurance center. Many companies of national importance thrived here.

During the Second World War, three large US Navy bases were built in the urban area. They are still prominent employers and a driving force in the development of the city's economy to this day.

In the XXI century, Jacksonville is a major manufacturing center of America. The economic areas of financing, insurance, biomedicine, information services, ship repair, and loading-unloading are developed here. Tourism is another important source of the city's development. More than 10% of the working residents of the Jacksonville agglomeration are engaged in this sphere. And it's not surprising, because more than three million tourists come here every year.

description.en: New York is the city where people talk in 800 languages. It’s the city that determines the economic fate of the whole world and which every tourist without exception dreams to visit. “Big Apple” allures with its freedom, the sound of sirens, yellow taxis, Manhattan, Times Square, and the Statue of Liberty. You can experience a déjà vu every time you come to New York as you have already seen all these parks, square gardens, and streets in movies and series. New York impresses, amazes, and even startles. You can adore it and hate it, but you definitely can’t stay indifferent to this “capital of the world”.

long_description.en:
New York is considered to be the most populated city in the USA with the largest agglomeration (over 19 million people!). According to the last data, one in thirty-eight Americans lives here. Here you can hear all the languages of the world and get acquainted with every nationality. The Chinese and Jew ex-pat communities are the largest in New York. There are somewhat less Polish people here than there are in Poland. Due to the abundance of various nationalities, the local citizens are incredibly tolerant of different cultures.
        They are always ready to help and assist in finding the way if you get lost.

description.en: Few cities in America can boast of having so many informal names like Seattle has. It is known as the Emerald City, Queen’s City, Gate to Alaska, City of Rains, and Jet City. Moreover, it’s the largest megalopolis in the Northwestern United States. One can even call it American Rome as it also stands on seven hills. But these are only a few natural wonders of Seattle. In the east, beautiful Lake Washington outlines the boundary of the city while Puget Sound defines it in the west. The primary port of Seattle was built on the banks of Elliot Bay in 1911. It’s the eighth largest port by size and cargo capacity among other American ports. It’s the most important center for maintaining trading relations with Asia. The snowcaps of the Olympic and Cascade Mountains can be seen from every spot in the city. Mount Rainier rises above the town like a conic grey giant. City landscapes and the nature of Seattle inspired Hollywood directors more than once. That’s where you can find the headquarters of such business giants as Boeing, Microsoft, and Amazon. What’s the secret of Seattle’s glamour?

long_description.en:
According to the last statistics, the population of Seattle compiles 744 955. The metropolitan area includes communities with a population of over 3.7 million people. This index takes the 14th position in the USA.

From its foundation till 1960, Seattle had been the city of the white people. The posterity of the colonizers compiled 91.6% of citizens. However, the statistics changed in the succeeding 60 years due to the high flow of population. The number of white citizens in Seattle decreased by one third in percentage correlation. The development of the technology corporation attracted over 50 thousand residents of new nationalities only in the last decade of the XX century. From the beginning of the 2000s, this figure reached 150 thousand people.

According to the latest data from ACS, the racial composition of Seattle is the following:

  • white citizens — 68,63%;
  • Asians — 14,49%;
  • Afro-Americans and black-skinned — 7,10%;
  • ladinos and quadroons — 6,63%;
  • native Americans — 0,55%;
  • Hawaiian and citizens of the Pacific islands — 0,39%;
  • representatives of other races — 2,20%.

The demographic situation in the city flavors the continual population growth. Its average annual rate between 2010 and 2018 is 2.3%.

description.en: Industrial, port Baltimore is a city with a manly character. It's determined, independent, and ambitious. It's passionate about ventures and loves adventures. Sometimes it even shows its cool temper and stubbornness. But at the same time, it is sincere, friendly, and always ready to come to the rescue. Baltimore can charm any guest with perfectly preserved sights, feed with seafood delicacies, mesmerize with the sounds of good old jazz, and surprise with thousands of exciting stories related to the time when the United States had gained independence.

long_description.en:
Several villages laid the foundation for the present metropolis, and in 1729, they united to form a town named after Lord Baltimore, the first governor of the province of Maryland. 

Located on the Patapsco River, it was initially built as a port city and later played a key role in the struggle for U.S. independence. Fort McHenry, located at the mouth of Inner Harbor, during the war of 1812-1814, became a landmark place for Americans — a symbol of strength and bravery. The British had been firing cannons at it for 24 hours, but the fort, and with it, Baltimore, stood firm. A few days later, there was a general battle between the Americans and the British, in which the latter were defeated. Just during the siege of Baltimore, the captured lawyer Francis Scott Key wrote poems that became the American anthem. 

During the U.S. Civil War, the city took the side of the northerners, thus opposing slavery. But Baltimore had always been famous for its cool temper — there were often riots in Baltimore that required the use of the army to subdue. For example, the streets of the city "blazed up" in 1968, after the murder of African-American rights defender Martin Luther King. The intervention of the National Guard was also needed in 2015 — because of protests that began in Baltimore after the arrest and death of African-American Freddie Gray.

description.en: The city of Pittsburgh is located at the picturesque junction of the tributary streams that form the Ohio River. One of the largest settlements in Pennsylvania (USA) is at the top of the list of the most suitable cities for living. Due to its unique landscape, it consists of many separate districts, each of which has its own architecture and culture. The city center, famous for its high skyscrapers, is surrounded by residential areas with narrow streets. The landscape is enhanced by numerous bridges connecting all parts of the city.

long_description.en:
Before the appearance of the European settlers, there were settlements of Indian tribes of Iroquois, and later — the Delaware tribes.

At the beginning of the XVIII century, the French arrived here, who wanted to add these lands to their properties in Louisiana and Canada. But the British asserted their rights to these territories and demanded from the French to leave them. For several decades, the lands had belonged to either the French or the English. Until the British built Fort Pitt here in 1758. The settlement of Pittsborough was established nearby. Eleven years later, it was called Pittsburgh. For another ten years, there was a dispute between Pennsylvania and Virginia for it. As a result, in 1780, Pittsburgh moved to Pennsylvania.

The XIX century became a period of active city development. Large enterprises producing bronze, steel, tin, and glass were opened. New districts appeared, houses were built, infrastructure was developing.

At the beginning of the XX century, Pittsburgh produced 35 - 50% of all steel in the USA. In the second half of the XX century, the authorities began to implement projects to improve the quality of life of citizens. As part of the struggle for the protection of the environment, steel mills and other production facilities were closed. This led to a sharp decline in the number of residents. 

At the beginning of the XXI century, Pittsburgh began to develop tourism, medicine and high-tech sciences actively.

Charlottesville is located in a subtropical climate and has four distinct seasons. Precipitation falls here throughout the year, and the largest amount of precipitation falls from May to October. The hottest month is July. At this time, the average air temperature is +24°С. The coldest month is January. Thermometer's column is kept at +1.8°С. Snow falls rarely, and it melts before reaching the ground. There are occasional frosts (down to -7°C), and only a few days during the whole winter.

A visit to the city can be timed to coincide with cultural events and holidays. For example, there is a major Virginia Film Festival in Charlottesville in late October and early November.

At the end of April, there is another spectacular event — horse racing.

description.en: Cincinnati is an American city in Ohio, in the northeast of the country. Geographically, it is located on the border of three states — Kentucky, Ohio, and Indiana. The southern boundary of the city is the large Ohio River. Winston Churchill called Cincinnati the most continental beautiful town in the United States. The town received its unofficial name courtesy of the poet Henry Longfellow, who called the city "Queen of the West". Cincinnati is one of the oldest cities in the United States, where they honor the history and are not afraid of innovation.

The city of winds grew on the bank of the Chicago River. That’s the only river on the planet that flows backward. The city inherited the capricious character from it. Chicago uprushes to the sky with its skyscrapers, indefatigable develops and gives new wonderful inventions to the world. The Ferris wheel, the zipper and vacuum cleaner were invented here. The first franchise of McDonald’s was also opened in this city. Walt Disney was born and Al Capone became famous in Chicago. The irrepressible energy of the city on the coast of Lake Michigan attracts travelers from all over the world. Museums and galleries wait for tourists during the day. And when the nightfall comes, thousands of bars and nightclubs open their doors to the siren notes of jazz.

Boston is the capital and the largest city in the state of Massachusetts. It is in the top-10 oldest and wealthiest cities in America. The city is also known as New England. It has its own Cambridge and Harvard. The look of its streets and architecture resemble typical European cities rather than any traditional American style. Boston can boast of having a lot of parks and buildings in the European style, Chinatown, and a diversity of museums. Among them, you will find the worldwide known Museum of Fine Arts and Museum of Science. Once, Charles Dickens wrote about Boston: “The rest of America should take it for a model”.

long_description.en: The white people of Irish and Italian origin compile the majority of the city’s population. Moreover, one of the biggest Asian expat communities in the USA lives here. The local population embraces of different cultures and religious confessions. Thanks to a large number of students, the nightlife doesn’t stop till the sun goes up.

description.en: Albuquerque is the largest city in New Mexico, a state in the south of the United States. Despite its status, it is very cozy and colorful. There are very few high-rise buildings, while there are preserved buildings of the Spanish colonial era in the center and a desert and rocky mountains around the city. The sun shines almost all year round in Albuquerque as well as hot-air balloons fly, which mainly attracted tourists here. Everything changed with the release of the popular series "Breaking Bad", which won the love of critics and viewers. Nowadays, travelers come here not only to fly in a balloon but also to visit the places where their favorite characters lived and found themselves in incredible situations — Walter White, Jesse Pinkman, Saul Goodman, and Gus Fring.

This city has many names — "the musical capital", "Athens of the South", "Protestant Vatican"... And each name has its own meaning. Nashville is the capital of the state of Tennessee, which is a multi-faceted city in the southeast of the United States. Its not very long history is closely intertwined with American history — with civil conflicts, with racial segregation, and ... with music. Well, that's what has happened. It's believed to be the homeland of country music. Perhaps, that's an exaggeration. But it's an actual fact that this music, while retaining its inherent originality, has become part of the US music industry in Nashville. Nashville today is a Mecca of country.

long_description.en:
In 1779, American immigrants founded a settlement on lands taken from the Cherokee tribe. Hunting and fur trade were their main activities at that time. Five years later, the authorities of the state of North Carolina, which then belonged to these lands, gave the village the name of Nashville — in honor of American General Francis Nash, who died in the war for independence of the North American states. In 1796, a new state was formed in the territory that had separated from North Carolina — Tennessee and Nashville became part of it. The settlement grew rapidly and became a city in 1806.

In 1826, the University of Nashville was established, and in 1833 the city's water supply system started functioning. In 1843, Nashville became the capital of Tennessee.

By the outbreak of the 1861-1865 Civil War, Nashville was already an important river port and railroad junction. In 1861, Tennessee joined the Confederation of Southern States. Defeat in the war was devastating for the southerners, but Nashville recovered quicker than others and developed successfully at the end of the XIX century. Then, the period of stagnation followed, but at the end of the XX century, the city experienced an economic boom again.

Nashville is considered to be the capital of country music. Back in the 20s of the last century, the city radio station was broadcasting country music, and the first recording studio appeared here in 1945. The city ranks second in the U.S. after New York in terms of recordings of musical programs, but first in terms of studios and concert venues. In addition, the city has a well-developed health industry (250 companies associated with medicine are located here), publishing, and the financial sector.

description.en: Tourists buy tickets to Atlantic City — a famous resort city on the Atlantic coast in the state of New Jersey (USA) to get the most out of their holidays. During the day, you can relax here on the magnificent sandy beaches, surf, or treat yourself to shopping in giant shopping malls. In the evening, try your luck at one of the many local casinos and dive into the glittering neon lights. Life in this city doesn't stop for a moment, because there's just no time to rest. There are various shows and entertainment programs every night, and sometimes, there are festivals and concerts of world stars. Atlantic City is a combination of hot sun, luxurious views, and entertainment for every taste. It has trendy restaurants, museums, and picturesque promenades. But the main feature is the fireworks of unforgettable emotions that the city gives to millions of its guests.

long_description.en:
Atlantic City was founded in 1854 on the island of Absecon and literally immediately became a resort town. This status was finally established after the railway companies built a branch between Absecon and Philadelphia. The scenic nature and location of the area played a significant role in attracting new visitors. New Jersey and Pennsylvania were among the first to enjoy the wide beaches of the Atlantic Ocean, followed by a huge influx of tourists from Philadelphia.

Each year, the popularity of Atlantic City was gaining momentum and reached its peak in the first half of the twentieth century. Affordable prices, high-quality services, and a wide variety of entertainment made the resort popular and accessible for many people. 

However, in the middle of the twentieth century, recreation in Atlantic City began to go out of fashion. The city was able to regain its former glory only after a referendum in 1976 when the gambling business was legalized. New casinos started to appear along the waterfront quickly, attracting new crowds of tourists. 

Today's Atlantic City is called the second Las Vegas, although it has many advantages over the famous Sin City.

description.en: Jazz and festive New Orleans stands out against the same-type American cities with sky-high skyscrapers and boring single-store suburbia. The largest city in the state of Louisiana and one of the largest port cities in the USA is located on both banks of the Mississippi River. New Orleans is one large, loud bar that gathers all street Jazz musicians, rainforests, and French provinces. Every year, it calls together crowds of tourists with its hasty tunes to its grandiose carnivals. This city amazes and creates an atmosphere of a real holiday.

long_description.en:
The history easily explains the population heterogeneity and diversity of New Orleans. Around 391 thousand people live in the city. The majority of the people are Afro-Americans (60%). White Americans compile 34%, while the Asians and Latin Americans have 3% each.

A rare combination of such a diversity of nations caused the appearance of new ethnic groups such as Creole and Cajuns. These are the descendants of immigrants from France and Spain with their language. When 200 years ago, black-skinned slaves were brought to America from Africa and Haiti, they also brought their faith with them. It was the Voodoo cult. This mystical theme is trendy among tourists. However, New Orleans can’t boast of having too many followers of this religion. The French and Spaniards brought Catholicism with them. It is still the predominant religion in New Orleans.

description.en: Indianapolis is not only the capital of the state of Indiana in the United States but also the largest center of the automobile industry. This city is home to the most renowned racetracks, where crowds of tourists from all over the world come for a new thrill. This is what the city is famous for, despite the fact that there are many other attractions. And the unusual architecture of the town, which harmoniously combines ancient buildings and modern skyscrapers, huge parks, and cozy cafes, gives the city a special flavor. Indianapolis is located on the White River, in the center of Indiana, as if on the crossroads of America. The roads leading from south to north and from west to east meet here. The main trade routes of the country pass through them.

long_description.en:
The city name itself translates as "Indiana City". Initially, the lands of Indianapolis were inhabited by Miami and Delaware Indian tribes. But in the 1820s, Europeans came to this territory and forced them to the southwest, turning the city into the state capital. The Scottish architect Alexander Ralston was entrusted to build it up. On October 1, 1847, a railway connection was opened in Indianapolis, which led to the rapid development of the city.

At the beginning of the XX century, Indianapolis became a major automobile manufacturer and the center of the transport network. In the middle of the XX century, the city saw a rapid increase not only in the white but also in the African-American population. This led to the formation of a ghetto for black minorities with unsanitary conditions and high crime rates. White citizens were prohibited from entering such neighborhoods. This situation led to an economic downturn in the country. Racial conflicts have now been eased, but criminal "black" neighborhoods still exist.

Until the middle of the XVII century, the Dakota Indians had lived in the modern city. And in 1680, French researchers began to study the land. Gradually, settlers from the Old World displaced the indigenous inhabitants. The United States acquired the territory of the future Minneapolis in the early XIX century. In 1819, at the confluence of the Minnesota and Mississippi rivers, Fort Snelling was founded. Next to it, on the Mississippi's west bank, a small village of Minneapolis grew up in 1854. In 1867, it received the status of a city.

In the second half of the XIX century, Minneapolis, located at Saint Anthony Falls and surrounded by dense forests, became the forestry and flour industry's center. This contributed to the development of a wide network of railroads. In the same period, the University of Minnesota was founded in Minneapolis; beautiful park zones were opened, cultural institutions and temples were built.

After 1930, the industrial decline started in the city. Flour mills began to close gradually. Minneapolis went through the Great Depression and World War II with tremendous pressure.

In the period from 1963 to 1975, several new major highways passed through its territory. This allowed a significant re-profiling of the city's economy.

Today Minneapolis is an important transport hub and a popular tourist destination. It produces metal and plastic products, electronics, medical devices, computer equipment, chemicals, cars, spare parts, and has a well-developed retail trade.

description.en: Philadelphia is an ancient city in the east of the United States. It is located between the Delaware and Schuylkill Rivers. In this city, people made history that influenced the vector of the country's development. Creative people from all over the world used to come here and bring their culture. That's how Philadelphia became an incredible mixture of history and art of various nationalities. It can be seen in the external architectural character of the city where glass skyscrapers stand side by side with bricked Colonial buildings.

long_description.en:
Approximately 1.5 million people live in Philadelphia. It's the second-largest city on the East Coast of the US and the fifth in America in general. The population of Philadelphia's agglomeration is more than six million people. 

The majority of people living in the city are Afro-Americans (43%). The white community compiles 42%. The Asians conclude 7%, and the remaining 8% are the representatives of other nationalities. Among them, there are 68% of the Christian (including 41% of the Protestants); 24% of the population is religiously unaffiliated. The remaining 8% are Buddhists, Jews, Muslims, and Hindus. 

The median age of the citizens of Philadelphia is 34 years. Even though there is a university in the city that is included in the Ivy League, only 27% of the adult population have higher education.

description.en: Houston is the largest city with more than 1 million inhabitants in the American state of Texas. It became known worldwide after the release of the film "Apollo 13", with Tom Hanks playing the leading role. The famous phrase "Houston, we have a problem!" became a slogan for an Oscar-winning film. By modern standards, it's a young city. But in its short history, it has managed to become the center of aerospace, energy, gas, and oil industries. And that's all thanks to the energetic persistence of the ancestors of Texas cowboys. Houston keeps up with its brothers in culture and tourism. It ranks second in the U.S. by the number of theaters, known for its magnificent parks (there are 337 of them in the city), and beautiful museums (there is even a whole block of them).

Anchorage is not only the largest city in Alaska but also the most significant tourist center in this region. At the same time, there are almost no attractions in the region, except for the majestic and harsh nature that is so realistically described in the novels of Jack London. At first sight, it seems that there is absolutely nothing interesting — just eternal cold, snow, and ice. However, the very first trip to the surroundings, for example, to the Denali National Park, can help you to see the indescribably bright, wild, and colorful nature of Alaska in all its glory.

long_description.en:
Officially, Alaska became part of the United States in 1912, when this territory was bought from the Russian government for $ 7.2 million. In 1867, this deal was made by the United States Secretary of State, William Seward. At the same time, the arrangement was mainly discussed by journalists and the public in terms of sarcastic ridicule. For instance, it was often called the “Seward freezer,” “Seward’s insanity,” and “Seward’s failure.” In fact, the country was just beginning to recover from the Civil War, the economic downturn, and the reintegration of the states of the South into the United States.

In 1914, to construct the Alaskan Railway, it was decided to erect a tent town called Ship Creek. It grew very quickly; therefore, on November 20, 1920, it was recalled Anchorage. Its economy has long been based on the functioning of the railway. The next major impetus for the development of the city was World War II. Anchorage, with its well-equipped Merrill Field Airport, has become an important strategic center. In turn, it was used to carry out air transport of equipment and military cargo. At the same time, a large Elmendorf Air Force Base was built here.

In 1964, a powerful 9.2 magnitude earthquake struck Alaska. It almost destroyed Anchorage, depriving it of the majority of the buildings. The city was gradually reconstructed; for example, in 1868, it was discovered the oil field Prudhoe Bay that markedly accelerated the development of the city.

Today, Anchorage is a modern city where a huge amount of attention is paid not only to tourism but also to the protection of the ecosystem from degradation, as well as the conservation of rare species of northern animals.

description.en: Nassau is the capital of the Bahamas on the Atlantic Ocean. Despite the fact that it is not a very large city in comparison with other capitals of the world, it is the largest and most developed city of one of the leading tourist states in the world — its cultural and economic center. Nassau is located on the island of New Providence. Thousands of tourists come here every year to sunbathe in the afternoon under the warm Caribbean sun, and at night to plunge into the world of entertainment. Colorful Victorian-style buildings coexist with new, modern ones. This gives the city a special and unique atmosphere.

long_description.en:
In the middle of the XVII century, the English founded a small town called Charlestown on this land. The city received its present name at the end of the same century, in honor of the ruler of England and Scotland, Willem van Oranje-Nassau.

In the XVIII century, pirates settled in the city so firmly that in 1706, they even founded their own Republic on the islands. The plunders they committed were a real disaster for the ships passing by. Only in 1718, thanks to Captain Woodes Rogers (later the first British governor of the Bahamas), was it possible to control the islands and subdue the pirates.

At the end of that century, the city was under the rule of the Americans (in 1776) and the Spaniards (in 1782). But already in 1783, the state again came under British administration until 1973.

In the early XIX century, when the slave trade was abolished, the black population migrated en masse from America here.

During World War II, the U.S. Coast Guard ships were based in the city, and since 1968, the residence of the Prime Minister of the independent state of the Bahamas was located here.

Today, the Bahamas is a strong and independent country with its own laws, culture, and religion, the capital of which is Nassau.

description.en: Freeport is located on one of the most northern of the Bahamas, Grand Bahama. It is only 105 km from the resort town to the American Palm Beach on the Florida coast. Freeport was founded only in the middle of the XX century, but pirates repeatedly anchored in this area in the XVIII century. The city is surrounded by wildlife, untouched by civilization — mangrove swamps and flat forests. In spring, orchids and other tropical flowers bloom in Freeport and nearby parks. Beautiful lagoons and bays feature pelicans, flamingos, herons, and the coral reefs near the beaches are home to tropical fish, sea turtles, sponges, and clams. The Rand Memorial Nature Center houses the Garden of the Groves Botanical Garden with more than ten thousand specimens of island fauna and flora, Eden Park, and the Museum of Grand Bahama.

Panajachel is located in the southern part of Guatemala on the north-eastern coast of the picturesque alpine Lake Atitlán. The distance from the capital of the country is 150 km. Tourists are attracted by the beauty and magnificent landscapes of the reservoir, as well as the opportunity to ride a boat or speedboat, dive or windsurf. You can also climb the crater of one of the three volcanoes, taste exotic local cuisine, and just have a good rest. The city's main street, Santander, is home to many souvenir shops and stalls. You should definitely go to Santiago Atitlán and see the wooden statue of the Indian deity Maximón, who always smokes a cigarette in his mouth. Also nearby is an ancient temple of St. Santiago and an Indian market. You can also go on a tour of Mayan villages located on the western and southern shores of the lake.

Santo Domingo is the vibrant, bustling, and indescribably colorful capital of the Dominican Republic. This city is literally full of historical sites and monuments. Some landmarks are iconic for the whole of America. After all, the first university and Christian cathedral on the mainland were built here. Santo Domingo has all the conditions for a superb beach holiday amid typical Caribbean scenery: lush palm trees, snow-white sand, and azure waters of the sea.

long_description.en: More than 2.2 million people live in Santo Domingo. The majority of the city's population is mulatto (about 70%). There are few Europeans (up to 20%), and most of them belong to the high social classes. Almost all believers in the city are Catholic — more than 95%.

description.en: On the picturesque coast of the Atlantic Ocean lies the city of Puerto Plata (San Felipe de Puerto Plata) — one of the most popular resorts in the Dominican Republic. “Silver Port”, “Amber Coast” — the city received these names due to turquoise water with silver highlights in the bay and beaches with golden sand. Grains of black amber, which these shores are famous for, give such a rich color to the sand of the beaches. Puerto Plata offers not only ideal beaches and exotic landscapes. Victorian-style mansions, an old fort, cascading waterfalls, a marine park — there is something to see and something to admire.

long_description.en:
The city owes its name to the famous navigator Christopher Columbus, who discovered this land for Europeans. When he first sailed near the bay, its waters sparkled in the sun like silver. That's what gave the place its name Puerto Plata, which translates as "Silver Bay" in Spanish.

Columbus first landed on the shores of Puerto Plata at the very end of the XV century. Then there was another Spanish expedition in 1502, which founded the settlement of San Felipe de Puerto Plata. Gradually it grew, serving as an intermediate port on the way from the Old World to the colonized lands of the Caribbean. At that time, Puerto Plata was often raided by pirates, who had the support of some local residents.

In the middle of the XVIII century, the city began to flourish. Mansions of the planters, who grew rich by growing tobacco and sugar cane, appeared here.

In the second half of the XIX century, the city was severely destroyed during the War for the Restoration of Dominican Independence. After the war, Puerto Plata was quickly rebuilt and gradually became one of the most attractive resorts of the Dominican Republic.

description.en: San Jose is the capital and largest city of Costa Rica, washed by two oceans: the Pacific in the west and the Atlantic in the east. It is a small and cozy town, where untouched nature harmoniously combines with the achievements of modern civilization. Only in San Jose, you can see tobacco and coffee plantations near the city while being on the hundredth floor of one of the skyscrapers. This capital will surprise tourists not only with beautiful beaches and fascinating sights but also with strange rules. For example, it is forbidden for cars that have number five in their registration plates to show up in the city, and not always, but only on Wednesdays. This fantastic city with exciting people definitely deserves your attention.

Ruins of palaces and monasteries that have witnessed pirate raids, fashionable neighborhoods with majestic skyscrapers and picturesque villas, unique bridges connecting not just two coasts, but South America with Central and North — this city has seen a lot of things in its history. Its legends are fascinating, its panoramas captivate, and its street networks attract you to show what you will never see in any other city in the world again. Panama can be very different, as the capital is supposed to be — noisy and business, a little fussy, but at the same time, this city is invariably full of dignity and grandeur; it is open and hospitable. And it is worth seeing it!

long_description.en:
Almost all Panama residents are either mestizos, with Indian blood flowing through their veins, or mulattoes — the descendants of mixed marriages of white and black. Approximately 14% are African Americans, 10% are white, and 6% are Indians. The city residents' main language is Spanish, but a significant part of them, primarily those who are related to the tourism industry, have excellent knowledge of English.

By the way, Panama, with its reasonably high standard of living and low prices, attracts retirees from many countries in America and even Europe, who willingly move here in their old age. There is quite a large Chinese diaspora, and the Arabic one is a bit smaller.

description.en: San Salvador is the capital of El Salvador and the largest city in the country, located in the southwest at the foot of the volcano of the same name. Spanish conquistadors founded San Salvador in 1525. Earthquakes and volcanic eruptions repeatedly destroyed the city. However, tourists can see many interesting sights: the Cathedral, Plaza Barrios with the towering buildings of the former residence of the Palacio Nacional Government, and the Biblioteca Nacional. It is also worth visiting the Libertad Plaza, checking out the churches of El Rosario and Iglesia La Merced, the Monument of Christ standing on the globe, the Art Museum, and the National Theatre. Few people know, but this is where Antoine de Saint-Exupery created his "The Little Prince".

If you want civilized exotics, then Sydney is what you need. Here is comfort at any level in hotels, parks, and reserves with unique flora and fauna, sandy beaches and clear water. Every year, millions of people come to see the Sydney Opera House, the famous Harbor Bridge, and swim on the beaches of Port Jackson Bay. “The city near the bay” (as Sydney is called) is the most expensive city on the entire Australian continent, the most multicultural, most multinational, one of the most beautiful cities in the world.

long_description.en: Sydney is one of the most cosmopolitan cities in the world. About one-third of the population of the city and its suburbs were born outside of Australia. Almost 20% are from Asia. There are quite a few immigrants from Great Britain. Most people who come here permanently live in the capital of Australia. English is the main language spoken, but almost everyone speaks another language, such as Chinese, Arabic, or Vietnamese. The locals are friendly and welcoming to tourists.

description.en: Melbourne, one of Australia's largest metropolises, stretches in a picturesque bay along the Yarra River. The garden-city, the continent's cultural and sports capital, is one of the world's most comfortable cities to live in. Modern quarters with skyscrapers are followed by magnificent Victorian buildings, and numerous museums and galleries offer interesting exhibits. Sunny beaches, lush gardens and parks, historical monuments, and the XIX century buildings, the smell of coffee, and vibrant nightclub music are all in Melbourne.

long_description.en:
In 2015, the city was home to over 4.5 million people. The national composition of Melbourne citizens is very diverse. It is inhabited by immigrants from more than 200 countries in the world. Around 180 languages are spoken in the streets of the city.

The majority of people living here are from England, Ireland, Scotland, Italy, New Zealand, Asia, Greece, Sri Lanka. Of all the inhabitants of the city, only 0.6% are indigenous peoples of the continent.

description.en: Brisbane is Australia's third-largest city, and it attracts more and more Australians than just travelers every day. It is called the "City of the New World" and is often compared to New York City because of its abundance of skyscrapers. There are no ancient architectural buildings, no extraordinary history, or rare attractions. During the walks, there is an impression of a too clean and right place, created as artificial. But this order and the feeling that everything is in its place attract people to Brisbane. There are plenty of bridges, national parks, rare animals. Yet Brisbane has the least dangerous insects and mammals, unlike any other city in Australia. Brisbane is modern, bustling, and incredibly hospitable.

long_description.en: Brisbane is considered to be the fastest-growing city in Australia. Just imagine that the population here increases by 1,000 people every week. The locals, mostly immigrants, and natives of Europe, are very patriotic, love their country, and are grateful to it for all its benefits. They honor the rules of etiquette, always let women first at the entrance, offer help to travelers, and also are very friendly. Don't try to convince a local that there are better cities and countries than Australia and Brisbane. You'll never succeed, and it will cause them great offense.

description.en: Cairns is located in Australia on the Coral Sea coast of the Pacific Ocean. The city is situated in the north-eastern part of Queensland. The resort is famous not only for its wide sandy beaches but also for the Great Barrier Reef, just forty kilometers from the shore. Many scuba diving enthusiasts come to the city to enjoy a range of coral reefs and islands. You can book a sea or air excursion, or buy one of the specially designed tours for diving fans. Ocean waters off the coast are not safe. Therefore you can swim peacefully in the Swimming Lagoon. It's a large artificial pool close to the city's business district. It is worth visiting the surrounding rainforest, the famous Atherton Plateau, or take a tour of the crocodile farm.

Surfers Paradise is a coastal suburb of Australia's city of Gold Coast, located in Queensland on the continent's east coast. The Gold Coast is one of Australia's major tourist destinations, especially when it comes to water sports. At the same time, Surfer's Paradise is the entertainment and tourism hub of the entire city. It has some of the best beaches and hotels, and the area's high-rise buildings form the architecture and skyline of Queensland's second-largest city. The suburbs are often called "Surfers" because of the wide beach zone for this sport. There's also the Q1 Tower skyscraper, once the tallest residential building on the planet. The height of one of the symbols of the city and the whole state is 322.5 m. It is worth taking a stroll along Cavill Avenue, which is considered the busiest shopping street in the state and a nightlife center.

Perth, the capital of Western Australia, is sometimes called the world's most isolated metropolis. Indeed, from the west, the city is washed by the waters of the Indian Ocean, and in the east, it is separated from other large cities with thousands of kilometers of deserts and semi-deserts. But upon closer inspection, the “isolated” Perth looks like a blooming oasis. The city is very comfortable, and for many years occupies high places in the ratings of the most convenient cities for living in the world. This metropolis is amazingly clean, well-maintained, friendly and green. The number of large parks in the city alone exceeds a dozen. Still, as many park zones surround it in a semicircle, and small gardens and squares in Perth cannot be counted. Original modern buildings, interesting examples of colonial architecture, well-maintained beaches, excellent shops, restaurants, cafes and clubs, wonderful nature — all this makes the city surprisingly attractive.

long_description.en:
Australian aborigines, the Noongar, had lived in these lands for thousands of years before the arrival of white people. Europeans saw the west coast of Australia in 1619 but could not land because of bad weather. For the first time, a white man set foot on this land only in 1697. But even then, the Dutch travelers decided that the conditions in these places are not convenient for settlements. In subsequent years, Europeans have repeatedly attempted to develop the territory, but the first permanent settlement appeared only in 1829. Its founder was British captain John Sterling. The colony, which settled on the Swan River, was similarly named Swan River.

Over time, one of the settlements of the colony became the city of Perth. The other, nearby, was named Fremantle and became a port (today, it is a satellite city of Perth). Interestingly, the first capital building erected in Fremantle in 1830 was the prison, the Roundhouse. It is still preserved in its original form.

In 1854, only 4,000 people lived in Perth. And at the end of the XIX century, there was a rapid growth of both Perth and the whole colony. It was connected with the discovery of gold deposits northeast of the city. Then rich deposits of other minerals (diamonds, iron ore, bauxite, oil) were found in Western Australia.

Nowadays, due to their extraction and processing, the state and its capital are prospering. At the same time, Perth is the cultural, educational, financial, and tourist center in Western Australia.

description.en: Busselton is famous for its longest wooden berth in the southern hemisphere — it stretches into the ocean for almost 2000 meters, and its construction began in 1853. A walk along the pier is an excellent opportunity to enjoy the beauty of the ocean. Busselton is located in the south-west of Australia. The distance to the city of Banbury is 52 km, and 229 km to Perth. At the end of the pier is a scientific underwater observatory, from the panoramic windows of which you can see the life of the inhabitants of the ocean. It is also worth seeing the oldest stone temple in the western part of the continent, St. Mary's Church of the middle of the XIX century. You can also visit the Art Complex, which is opened on the premises of a former court, and check out Victoria Park, where the first steam engine of the state, Ballaarat, is installed. Along the coast, there is a 30-km-long beach area.

Adelaide is an extraordinarily sunny and cozy city. The sun, water, and air are the main ingredients of that unforgettable cocktail that this city is ready to offer to any guest. And if you add a little greenery of the parks, the width of the avenues, the glossy skyscrapers, and the hospitality of the locals, you can drink such an extraordinary cocktail in any amount. Honest and straight Adelaide will never confuse a traveler, will not spin in a labyrinth of streets — everything is extremely simple and clear. But, at the same time, it will offer him a hundred fascinating excursions, surprise him with unusual exhibits and expositions, will show strange animals and bizarre plant species. There will be no time to get bored here, as one trip will obviously not be enough to look into all its nooks and crannies and see all the curiosities.

long_description.en:
Adelaide is the fifth most populous city in Australia. The population here is aging a little faster than the national average. Today, 26.7% of the city's residents are over 55 years old. It also has the smallest number of children under 15 years. The number of residents born in other countries is just under 24%. The majority are from England, Scotland, Italy, Vietnam, and Greece. The majority of Adelaide's population is Christian of various denominations, and about a quarter of residents do not consider themselves believers at all.

As in many cities, there are slightly more women than men. Citizens of Adelaide are all very polite, helpful, and sociable, but their English takes some getting used to. There is a peculiar way of speaking where some of the sounds are swallowed, forming many unusual conversational abbreviations, for example, "G*day" instead of "good day".

description.en: Port Lincoln is in the south of Australia. The city is located in the state of South Australia on the coast of Boston Bay. It is a fishermen's town and hosts the famous Tunarama Festival, held annually to celebrate the start of the tuna fishing season. Tourists come here to go fishing and sailing. You can also go on a tour of Dangerous Reef, which is 31 km from the coast. Watching white sharks from a boat or a submerged cage will bring an adrenaline rush to extreme entertainment lovers. Not far from the city is the picturesque island of Boston with a XIX-century cottage. In Port Lincoln, Mikkira Station is the oldest sheep farm, which deserves your visit. Lincoln National Park, 20 kilometers from the city, is a true paradise for birds' lovers, where you can, for example, watch ospreys and eagles.

Canberra is the capital of the Australian Union, surrounded by mountains from different sides. It has a special mild climate and an extremely cozy atmosphere. According to many surveys, this city is populated by the happiest people in the entire world. In fact, the happiness of locals can be explained by several components, such as life expectancy, job availability, and salary rates. As citizens who love their country, Australians are used to taking the first positions in many ways. In turn, the most delicious truffles are grown in Canberra. It is also the birthplace of Wi-Fi. Wireless data transmission technology was created in the capital of the Australian Union more than 20 years ago. In this city, the famous sheepskin boots (uggs) were also born. Furthermore, numerous people aim to come here, as this city offers the opportunity not only to relax but to relax according to exquisite and tasteful standards.

long_description.en:
Canberra was laid out in 1908. It was built to settle a dispute between Melbourne and Sydney. The two cities were competing to be the capital of the Commonwealth of Australia. The winner was Canberra, the Aboriginal name for a 'meeting place'. A piece of land in the interior of the state of New South Wales was allocated for the new capital. Earlier, in the first half of the XIX century, the Australian tribes Ngunnawal and Walgalu lived here.

The plan for the city was developed by the architectural couple from Chicago, Walter Burley and Marion Mahony Griffin. According to their concept, the basic design of the streets and squares was to be a "garden city", where green spaces occupied the majority of the territory. And so it happened. There's so much natural vegetation that the Australians call Canberra their 'Forest Capital'. It's surrounded by nature parks, wildlife refuges, and wilderness areas.

Up until the Great Depression (world economic crisis of 1929-1939) and World War II, which caught up with it, Canberra had been thriving. The forced disruption caused by these events slowed things down, but after the war, the construction of homes and government buildings began apace. The city quickly recovered and became prosperous.

description.en: Auckland is New Zealand's most urbanized city, with 33% of all residents of the country. This is the largest political and economic center of an island nation spread in the southwest of the Pacific Ocean. The city is located on 48 extinct volcanoes that turned into mountains, lakes, and even islands. It is called the most colorful city of Polynesia, because it harmoniously combines Asian, European and Polynesian culture. Tourists will not find historical architectural monuments, ancient castles or fortresses, but this is not what attracts millions of travelers every year. Auckland is beautiful, with a large number of modern museums and galleries. All travelers of all ages will be pleased to spend a couple of days here, and many will think about staying here forever.

long_description.en:
The city is considered the most cosmopolitan in all of New Zealand. More than half of the local population is European.

There are equal parts Asian and Pacific Islanders, with a minority of Maori descendants, Arabs, Hispanics, and others.

Because of the large number of immigrants, all nationalities and religions are tolerated here.

The locals speak excellent English, which makes a stay here comfortable for any tourist.

description.en: Metropolitan Wellington, of course, is inferior to all his brothers in size but beats many in beauty, safety, and comfort. This New Zealand city, which is cozily settled in the harbor surrounded by green hills, has long won fame as an interesting tourist center. They come here to get acquainted with the exotic nature of the islands, learn about the life of modern Maori people, relax on the beaches, and see how the renowned film studios work. And these are not all the tourists' baits of the southernmost and windiest capital on earth.

Papeete is the capital of French Polynesia, its main seaport. The city is located in the northwest of the island of Tahiti. In its time, it has earned a bad reputation for rampant crime and prostitution, as well as lots of traffic on the roads. Everything is in the past today. Papeete is a quiet resort city with developed infrastructure, clean air, and excellent beaches. It is not without reason that the World Beach Football Championship was held here in 2013. It is worth visiting the central square of Toata, where all major cultural events, concerts, and festivals are held. There are also many government buildings here. You can stroll along the city's main shopping street, Vaima Center, and you can reach the beautiful XIX-century Notre Dame Papeete Cathedral. There are several museums in the city, including Paul Gauguin, who lived in Papeete.

Buenos Aires is the largest and busiest city in South America. It is imbued with the spirit of European capitals from its foundation to the spire of the Obelisk. This is not surprising, since, over Buenos' centuries-long history, millions of immigrants from Paris, Rome, Madrid, and other European cities have come here. The ancestors of most of the porteños, which is how the natives call themselves, were from the Old World. The city's population density is a thousand times higher than that of the rest of the country. More than 3 million people in 202 square kilometers live here. If you count the suburbs (the so-called Greater Buenos Aires), the population exceeds 12 million. The mixture of peoples and nationalities has given the city its fascinating identity. Each of its 48 districts has its history, architecture, and an impressive list of attractions. Buenos Aires' metropolis is so multifaceted that it has so much to offer to both the art lover and the nightlife enthusiast.

long_description.en:
Buenos Aires, which has welcomed many immigrants over its history, is a rather multinational city. Most of the population of the metropolis consists of Spaniards and Italians. They are direct descendants of the first settlers and European immigrants, who left their native harbors searching for a better life. More recently, immigrants from other Latin American countries, Korea, China, and Africa, have arrived here. Another 30 percent or so of the population is mestizo. Buenos Aires is also home to people of other nationalities.
        You can hear Portuguese, English, French, and many other languages in the city's streets. Since Buenos Aires' founding, there has been little or no mixing of blood with the aboriginal tribes here, so all the natives are light-skinned. Porteños are cheerful and friendly, and they like to have fun and are ready to support any conversation.

description.en: As one of the most developed cities in the country, Cordoba is located in the heart of Argentina. There are the oldest universities and two Academies of Sciences of global importance. Cordoba honors its history and boasts a significant cultural heritage. In local architecture, you can notice a combination of a variety of styles. In the city, Muslim mosques are situated side by side with synagogues and churches. Many architectural monuments of Cordoba are protected by UNESCO, including the University of San Carlos, the Colegio Nacional de Monserrat, and the Jesuit temple of de la Compaca. To experience the unique atmosphere of Cordoba, visit the Old Market, drop by the Museum of the Inquisition, buy original ethnic souvenirs, and just wander through the atmospheric city streets. Besides, pay attention to the picturesque nature of the surroundings with its lakes, mountains, and waterfalls.

Ushuaia is the Argentine port on the Isla Grande de Tierra del Fuego. The city stands at the foot of the Andes, on the banks of the Beagle Channel. The local climate is rough and changeable, but it doesn’t scare numerous tourists. People come here to see the city at the end of the world, farther only the ice of Antarctica. Ushuaia has a lot to offer to its guests — amazing nature, unusual museums, delicious food, guided tours, and even an incredibly beautiful sunrise, as nowhere else in the world! Extreme sports are well-developed here. You can go diving there. There are not only king crabs and huge laminaria but also the remains of the sunken ships under the waters of the Beagle Channel.

long_description.en:
The Yamana Indians have lived on this land for thousands of years. Surprisingly, they managed to get by in this harsh climate with little or no clothing, thanks to their special metabolism. In 1850, a Spanish expedition led by Pedro de Gamboa arrived here. It was the beginning of a difficult relationship between the indigenous peoples and the Europeans until colonization nearly wiped them out. In 1881, 2,500 Yamana remained.

Further expeditions led to armed conflicts with the natives and the destruction of large numbers of sea lions, seriously disrupting their way of life.

The first European to settle here was the English missionary W. Sterling in 1870. In 1872, the first white child was born, and the city's foundation was announced on October 12 of that year. 

In 1884, an Argentine naval base was founded here. In 1885, Ushuaia became the capital of Tierra del Fuego.

In 1911, they opened the prison, which has become one of the city's main tourist attractions. 

When the Panama Canal was built (in 1914), the route from the Atlantic to the Pacific was shortened several times over. Since then, Ushuaia has ceased to be a transit city and has fallen into decline. The development of tourism in the city brought it an economic success.

Today Ushuaia is a tourist and port city that hosts cruise ships.

description.en: Sao Paulo is one of the most densely populated cities in the world, a major financial centre on the South American continent. It is often compared with Moscow due to the fact that life in both cities is based on frenzied rhythm and a similar atmosphere. Here you can find rich districts that are adjacent to the favelas (slums); therefore, even in the cleanest and most well-groomed corners, you always have the opportunity to meet people who have nowhere to live. Another city that, in the opinion of experienced tourists, is similar to Sao Paulo is American Chicago. In fact, it is as huge, colourful, and beautiful as the richest city in Brazil. Perhaps it can be the reason why there are, on average, 10 tourists per 100 residents of Sao Paulo. The majority of them come from Argentina, USA, Spain, and Russia. Indeed, every traveller dreams of going to the place where the heart of modern Brazil beats.

long_description.en:
More than 12 million people live in Sao Paulo. The main part of the overall population includes Portuguese, Italians, and Spaniards. Simultaneously, mulattos and African Americans are the largest minority groups of the city. Separately, it is essential to highlight the significance of the Japanese Quarter of Liberdade — the largest district in the world of those located outside the original territory.

A significant part of the citizens are Catholics (73%), Protestants (16%), and atheists who account for approximately 9% of the local population. Portuguese and Spanish are the main languages used in the city.

description.en: Rio de Janeiro is one of the brightest cities in the world, a center of tourism in South America. A place where life boils up without stopping day and night. Despite the fact that today Rio is no longer the administrative capital of Brazil, it is considered to be a cultural, football, and dance center of the country. The city sits on the picturesque shores of the Atlantic Ocean Bay, Guanabara. Brazilians are absolutely sure that on the seventh day after the creation of the world, God was busy creating exactly Rio de Janeiro. They have all reasons for this, because Rio is magnificent, beautiful, authentic, filled with energy and rhythms of hot samba. From the top of Corcovado, 700 meters high, the statue of Christ is watching the city, blessing and protecting it from all troubles. Buildings in neoclassical style, mixed with the Mexican architectural school, streets and embankments buried in lush equatorial greenery, giant evergreen palms with emerald crowns, incredible exotic flowers, wonderful beaches — all this awaits you in Rio. The city amazes the imagination. Wherever you go, you hear the music and laughter of people who know how to live in the moment and appreciate what they have.

long_description.en:
Brazil's population is mainly international, with migrants from many countries living in Rio de Janeiro. The multinational composition was formed through a process of mixing different ethnic groups: colonizers from Portugal, African Blacks, native Amerindian tribes, immigrants who arrived in large numbers at the beginning of the XX century from Europe, mainly from Italy, Portugal, Spain, and Germany. Today, the mestizos are the largest ethnic group in Rio.

Residents of the former capital of Brazil are cheerful, friendly and smiling, love music, dancing, and football. They know how to organize holidays, as evidenced by the magnificent Brazilian Carnival.

description.en: Perfect roads, convenient transport interchanges, and fancy architecture — that's Brasilia. The third capital of the sunny country of Brazil pleases with its youth, beauty, and modernity. And the attention of its guests is immediately attracted by the hospitality and friendliness of local residents. These qualities are in such a concentrated version that you are unwittingly looking for some trick. But you shouldn't. National features of the Brazilians, which they can be rightly proud of ( it is not acceptable to refuse to help here), will serve a traveler good service. Rent a bike and hit the road to save time and explore the iconic parks and buildings in the city center. Fascinating discoveries are sure to await you at every step. And in the "city of the future," as Brasilia is often called, there can be no other way.

long_description.en: The city has a population of about three million people, making it the third-largest city in the country (after São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro). More than 20% of all residents are Portuguese; about 15% are Italian; 8% are Spanish; 7% are German; 5% are Arab. A large proportion (about 40%) are Pardo (Brazilians of mixed descent). African Americans make up 6%, and Asians and Indians are about 1%.

description.en: Manaus is the densely populated capital of Amazonas in Brazil. This city is surrounded by impenetrable forests on the banks of the planet’s deepest river — the Amazon. Its origins are a unique phenomenon known to the world as the “Meeting of Waters”, where the dark Rio Negro meets with the sandy-colored upper Amazon River. In addition, Manaus attracts tourists with its pristine and untouched nature. For instance, people can find giant water lilies that grow in protected areas, as well as sloths that hang from vines. Next to the largest archipelago in the world, full of tropical plants, you can feel the unity with nature in the best way possible.

Medellín is a colorful and authentic city in Colombia, second only to the capital. In recent decades, it has become even more attractive to travelers. The picturesque scenery of the Porce River, the green slopes of the mighty Andes, and modern architecture make up the unique appearance of the metropolis.
