And its urban sites are harmoniously placed among the majestic mountains at an altitude of more than 1,500 meters. But Medellín is also a city of contrasts. The wealthy upscale neighborhoods alternate with slums, and the city is equally at home with the popular singer Shakira and drug dealer Pablo Escobar. Grotesque sculptures, art galleries, recreational areas, orchids, museums, art studios, cafes, restaurants — the diversity and mosaic of Medellín's possibilities are astounding. The combination of beautiful scenery and modern infrastructure draws more and more tourists to the city. Medellín is the real breakthrough of Colombia.

long_description.en:
The history of Medellín begins in the XVI century, when the first Europeans, Spanish colonizers led by Jorge Robledo, set foot on this land. Civilized life on the territory of the modern city is inextricably linked to the activities of the conquistadors.

Surprisingly enough, the city grew out of a small ranch in the Aburra Valley. In 1574, the province of Antioquia granted the Spanish settler, Gaspar de Rodas, at his own request, a plot of land to establish and develop a farm. The prosperity of this ranch was the beginning of the economic and demographic development of the future metropolis.

Later, in 1616, the village of San Lorenzo was already formed here. Its founding is considered the starting point of Medellín's life. The subsequent formation of the city is associated with the discovery of gold ore deposits in the region.

The year 1826 was a turning point for Medellín when Colombia gained its independence from Spain. This event provoked a series of dramatic episodes, among which were uprisings and a thousand-day war. But by the early twentieth century, the city began to grow rapidly, mainly due to the export of cocoa beans.

A negative trace in the city's life was left by the criminal activity of drug lord Pablo Escobar in the 80s of the last century. It took many more years to get rid of it. But at the end of the twentieth century, the city seemed to have been reborn. There was a rapid development of industry and urban infrastructure, and the city even had a metro.

The transformation of Medellín was primarily due to the work of the eminent sculptor Fernando Botero. His interesting urban projects brought success.

Today, Medellín is a thriving metropolis that has made a name for itself as a vibrant tourist destination in the Central Andes.

description.en: Cartagena is a charming port town on the Caribbean coast (Colombia). Traditional cobblestone streets, colorful buildings, and the unceasing sounds of reggae are the main symbols of this city. Residents of this city are usually described as open-minded and cheerful individuals. They are always happy to teach tourists how to dance salsa and how to choose the best Colombian coffee. First of all, Cartagena is a place where you want to return due to its unique atmosphere. It can be explained by the abundance of picturesque beaches, stunning architecture, and excellent national cuisine. This city surprisingly manages to find ways how to impress all guests and make them fall in love with this tourist destination forever.

long_description.en:
According to archaeological excavations, the first settlements in the area of Cartagena appeared even before our era. The territory of modern Colombia was inhabited by tribes of Indians, the largest of which was the Sinu. Spanish conquistadors sailed into the bay of Cartagena at the beginning of the XVI century in pursuit of Indian gold and other treasures. The city was founded in 1533 when a squad of 200 Spaniards led by Pedro de Heredia settled in the area.

Thanks to its advantageous location, Cartagena quickly became one of the most important transit points in the trade between the Old and the New Worlds. It was also a major port for exporting gold and silver mined in the Americas to Spain.

Pirates repeatedly attacked the city, and in 1586, it was sacked by English corsairs led by Francis Drake. In 1811, Cartagena was the first city of the Viceroyalty of New Granada to declare its independence from Spain.

Industrial development began in the 1920s, thanks to the discovery of oil fields and the construction of an oil pipeline to Cartagena. Since then, the city has become a major port. In the second half of the XX century, tourism began to play an increasingly important role in its economy.

In 1980, the historical monuments of Cartagena fell under the protection of UNESCO. Today Cartagena is the fifth-largest city in Colombia and the third most important economic center of the country.

description.en: Asunción is not just the capital of Paraguay; it is, in every respect, its core. There are examples of old architecture and historical monuments preserved here, but here you can also feel how the new Paraguay is growing. It is also a city with quarters surrounded by green islands of palm trees and tropical shrubs. Here pineapples are planted like hedges, and no one pays attention to parrots and toucans flying everywhere.

long_description.en:
Most of the city's inhabitants (90%) are mestizo from mixed marriages of Guaraní Indians and Spaniards. The rest of the city's population is Argentinians, Brazilians, Italians, and Germans. But you can also meet Portuguese, Russians, and Ukrainians.

The official languages are considered Spanish and Guarani, but most of the capital residents speak jipara - a kind of dialect based on the language of Guarani, augmented by many Spanish words and phrases.

Almost all believers in Asunción are Catholics, with few Protestants or Orthodox.

description.en: At first glance, the capital of Peru can impress its visitors with its Latin American character, combined with its European appearance. It seems like the Pacific ocean created a sea beauty named Lima with the help of its waves at the foot of the Andes. As a result, the ocean washes this city with its raging waters, giving it a unique look. This city looks so beautiful, as it combines rocky landscapes with palm trees and ocean breezes. Once you arrive here, you can face an inexplicable sense of deja vu. Nevertheless, the effect of the repetition of Spain develops due to the long colonial dependence of Peru. In turn, as soon as the sound of ocean waters is heard, all allusions instantly disappear. In these moments, tourists usually experience a significant desire to explore the city and increase the level of awareness of its attractions. In Lima, centers of exquisite jewelry can be located next to a small vegetable shop, whereas the richest elite areas alternate with poor neighborhoods and slums. Besides, do not be surprised when you see Japanese sushi that is served in the same restaurant as French croissants. Moreover, it is possible to find the streets dedicated to completely opposite figures: one street can be named in honor of the conquistadors, while the other one can be related to the liberators of Lima. In other words, you will not be able to find a similar city of contrasts in the world! Everyone who wants to feel the spirit of South America with a special aftertaste should visit Lima!

long_description.en: One-third of Peru's population — more than nine million citizens — is concentrated in the capital. It is not only the largest metropolis but also the most cosmopolitan. Spaniards, Afro-Latinos, mestizos, indigenous Indians, Italians, Japanese, Germans, Chinese, and Croats live here. It is not just the different ethnic groups but also the races that make the city culturally, religiously, and even culturally diverse.

description.en: Cuzco is a legendary city situated in the south of Peru. It is located in the Urubamba Valley, in the Andes, at an altitude of 3400 meters above sea level. As the historical capital of Peru enveloped in the atmosphere of the Spanish colony, the city is associated with legends of the ancient Incas. The proximity to the incredible wonder of the world, Machu Picchu, has made this city the most popular in the country. Every year, nearly two million tourists interested in the secrets of the Incas tend to come here.

long_description.en:
The first settlements in this area appeared about three thousand years ago. It is believed that the city was founded by the first Inca (ruler of the Inca Empire), Manco Capac. Legend has it that he and his family emerged from the waters of Lake Titicaca in search of a better place. His golden stick "went into the ground" on the site of a settlement of the Savasera Panaca tribe. After Manco Capac destroyed the village, he founded Cusco, the capital of the Inca Empire (translated in Quechua as "the center of the Earth" or "the navel of the Earth").

In the XV century, the ninth Inca ruler, Pachacuti, transformed the Kingdom of Cusco into a prosperous empire. His successor introduced a new tradition. When the Inca died, the title was passed to his son and the property to his other relatives. The new Inca was to build his own house and expand the empire's holdings.

On November 15, 1533, life in Cusco changed dramatically with the arrival of the Spanish conquistadors. Francisco Pizarro "founded" Cusco anew in 1534. The Europeans rebuilt the city in their own way, preserving its original structure and harmoniously combining traditional Spanish architecture with Inca architecture. Often, the new buildings were erected on ancient stone foundations. This style was called "mestizo" and began to manifest itself not only in construction but also in culture.

Churches were erected in place of Indian temples, a cathedral, university, and archbishopric appeared, and conquistadors' residences were built in place of palaces. During that time, Cuzco continued to develop through agriculture, mining, and trade relations with Spain.

In 1950, a major earthquake damaged the Dominican monastery and the Church of St. Dominic, exposing the ancient walls of the Indian Temple of the Sun (Coricancha). It was decided not to rebuild the colonial buildings so that locals and tourists could see the historic ruins of this iconic structure.

In 1983, the city was inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage Sites list. Now Cusco is the main staging post on the way to Machu Picchu, the lost city of the Incas.

description.en: Machu Picchu is a treasure of Latin America, a mysterious city, a subject of controversy of scientists all over the world for many years. It is a masterpiece of architectural and engineering thought, lost among the ranges of the Peruvian Andes at an altitude of 2450 meters. Machu Picchu is the city of the Sons of the Sun, the eighth wonder of the world, a magical place that attracts thrill-seekers from all corners of the globe. A fantastic timeless creation of the Incas, and today you can see the same way the Sons of the Sun created it. The mystical silence that grips the city is shocking and fascinating, with dizzying landscapes that inspire and excite the imagination. Walks through its tangled streets and picturesque terraces, fill the soul with harmony and give the feeling of complete blend with nature. Here you can feel the full scale of freedom of spirit and human genius of distant ancestors.

long_description.en:
Machu Picchu is the city of the Indian tribe of mysterious Incas, which still causes a lot of controversies, stirring the minds of scientists around the world. The number of residents in the city is not exactly known. It could have been 1200 people who lived in the town and its surroundings. Machu Picchu is believed to have been the winter residence of the Supreme Ruler of Pachacutec. During the rainy season, when roads became impassable, there were only 200 residents left in the city. The rest were temporarily relocated to Vilcabamba.

The Incas worshipped the God of Sun and cultivated new lands, preferred to settle high in the mountains. The inhabitants of the ancient city were outstanding builders. Not knowing about the wheels or the existence of mortar for fastening stones, they created unique structures that still amaze and admire their perfection today. The city has more than 700 terraces with an irrigation system — a proof that its inhabitants cultivated the land for a living. It is still a mystery and the subject of scientific research about why they had left their town. There is a wide range of speculation, from plague epidemics to attacks by wild tribes. But the most credible is the version of the Spanish invasion into Latin America.

description.en: Trujillo is located in the northwest of Peru. The city is situated on the Pacific Ocean coast. The country's third-largest city was founded in 1534. Trujillo is rich in attractions and architectural monuments. It offers both sites of the colonial period and unique archaeological excavations and finds that shed light on the history of ancient cultures of Moche and Chimú. Tourists explore the "Spanish" heritage — villas with gorgeous yards, admire the unique wood carvings on their balconies, and the splendor of wrought iron grilles on the windows. Fans of bygone civilizations book excursions to the city of Chan Chan, founded in the IX century, where archaeological excavations are conducted and the pyramids of the Sun and Moon. It is worth seeing the Statue of Liberty in the Plaza de Armas, which was established in 1820 to celebrate the independence of Peru.

Puno is located in the southeast of Peru, on the shores of Lake Titicaca, at an altitude of 3860 meters above sea level. Titicaca, the highest navigable lake in the world, is the main local attraction that raises the interest of tourists. For example, city guests can take into account boat rides on the lake, visits to the floating islands made of reeds, and acquaintance with the life of the “lake people” — natives living near the lake. Nevertheless, the city itself has a variety of interesting sights preserved since colonial times, such as the Cathedral of the 17th century, harmoniously combining the features of Baroque and Peruvian national motifs. Simultaneously, the Uahsapat Hill, the former residence of the Viceroy of Peru, Count de Lemos, as well as the Arch of Deusto, dedicated to the soldiers who fought for the independence of the country from Spanish rule, should be definitely visited in Puno.

Montevideo is the big capital of little Uruguay. It is a green, warm, and delicious city that shocks with the eclecticism of ancient streets. In recent years, Montevideo has been developing rapidly — new neighborhoods appeared, improved urban infrastructure, enterprises, and tourist centers opened. Add to this the rich architectural heritage of the colonial era and the wide white beaches. Only one question arises: why not spend the next vacation in Montevideo?

long_description.en:
The capital of Uruguay is home to almost half the entire country's population.

The indigenous peoples were almost completely exterminated during the exploration of new lands. Today, most of Montevideo's inhabitants are Creoles, descendants of immigrants from Spain, Italy, France, and Portugal, which is why it is considered the whitest city in South America. In addition, the capital of Uruguay has the largest Jewish community in South America.

description.en: Santiago is the capital and largest city of Chile, the longest country in the world. The city is located at the foot of the snowy Alps, 100 kilometers from the Pacific Ocean. For centuries, the city of conquistadors belonged to Spain, but 200 years ago, as a result of the War of Liberation, the Chileans gained independence. Over its history, the city has survived more than 40 destructive earthquakes, and in its vicinity, there are 4 active volcanoes. Therefore, the initial appearance of Santiago was practically not preserved, moreover, today it is a city of skyscrapers, which are built here as a symbol of the triumph of man over nature. Santiago is the economic center of Chile, where banks, the headquarters of world corporations, and the office of the UN economic mission are concentrated. It is also a city of parks and squares; it is easy to travel by public transport, metro and buses. The good news for tourists — Santiago is the safest city in Latin America.

long_description.en: Santiago is home to 5.5 million people, nearly one-third of Chile's total population. In terms of national composition, the majority are Spanish-speaking Chileans, descendants of white immigrants from Europe, America, Asia, and many Native American peoples. There are only 3-4% of native Chilean Indians in the nation's capital.

description.en: Baños is a famous mountain resort in Ecuador. The city is located in the central part of the country, 180 kilometers from the capital of Quito. Baños is cozily nestled in a valley, surrounded by picturesque mountains. Nearby is Volcano Tungurahua, not far from it, there are three other "fire-breathing dragons". In addition to the incredible beauty of these places, this proximity has led to the presence of thermal springs with medicinal properties. These springs, as well as well-appointed outdoor pools with healing water and natural attractions of the Llanganates and Sangay National Parks, attract tourists here. More than five dozen waterfalls can be found here. The Pailon del Diablo or the Devil's Cauldron is the largest and most popular of them. The tunnel will take you to the waterfall. Some travelers come only to feel the indescribable emotions of being behind a wall of crashing water.

Accra is the capital of the Republic of Ghana (West Africa), and its industrial and cultural center. The city is located in the south of the country, on the coast of the Gulf of Guinea. Its architecture blends traditional, colonial, and modern cultures, giving its appearance a special flavor. A variety of historical and cultural attractions, flamboyant African people, rich and extraordinary traditions, as well as comfortable beaches attract tourists from around the world. However, not so long ago, Accra was just a big trading city. The tourism business has only started to develop in recent decades. But that hasn't stopped it from rising to a high level.

long_description.en:
The first settlement on the modern territory of the city was founded in the XV century. It was home to the Ga tribes who migrated here from the north. The name Accra itself translates as "black ant," the totem animal of the Ga tribe. When European traders arrived on the Guinea coast, Accra became an important trading center fought over by Ga, Akuapem, and Ashanti tribes. Until the late XIX century, the city had been a central point in the slave trade. Gold, palm oil, and other goods were also traded here.

In the XVII century, the Portuguese erected their fortresses in the city, followed by the Dutch, Swedes, French, Englishmen, and Danes. The bustling economic activity continued until the abolition of the slave trade in 1807.

In 1850, a new era began in Accra. The city was included in the boundaries of the English colony of the Gold Coast. In 1876, the British took over Accra and moved the seat of residence that had previously been located at Cape Coast to the city. An influx of colonists from Britain began, which led to a significant expansion and economic development of the city. Accra had been the capital of the British colony of the Gold Coast until 1957.

After liberation from colonial dependence, Accra became the capital of the independent state of Ghana. Today it is a large city, one of the ten largest cities in Africa. It has a well-developed economy, culture, education, and tourism business.

description.en: Modern Cairo can be easily called the "city of contrasts." The past, present, and future are closely intertwined here. The city is often compared with an oriental rug, where incompatible things are combined. It is noisy here, as cars are considered an integral part of Cairo. At the same time, this city is considered the "city of 1000 minarets", the oldest of which was built before its formation. For instance, the Ibn Tulun Mosque is one of its main examples. In turn, pyramids are the most famous attractions that are associated with Egypt all over the world. These unique buildings are living proof of the "Seven Wonders of the World," which can still be found in reality. In the vicinity of Cairo, in Giza, there are the pyramids of Cheops, Chephren, Mykerin, and Sphinx. Cairo can be compared with a jewelry box that needs to be opened, as it is going to shine tremendously bright!

long_description.en:
The modern metropolis of Cairo is densely populated. Its population density is 3,150 people/km². Its population is equal to that of the entire country 60 years ago. This growth in the city is due to natural causes — an increase in the birth rate and an influx of rural residents.

Cairo currently has a population of 9.5 million people. The city is populated by Arabs, Copts, Nubians, Bedouins, and other national minorities. The Coptic Egyptians are considered indigenous Egyptians, and the Arabs, who dominate here, are not the indigenous population. According to statistics, about 3 to 10% of Christians live in Cairo, with the rest of the population practicing Islam.

description.en: Hurghada, together with Sharm el-Sheikh, is a popular resort in Egypt. Throughout the year, the temperature is high there. The Red Sea impresses with its color and incredible coral reefs. Historical landmarks remind us that this is the land of pharaohs. In Hurghada, you can spend days on the beach, haggle at the markets, or go to the legendary ancient city of Luxor (300km) and the Pyramids of Giza (500km).

Sharm el-Sheikh is filled with warmth and the sun. This city welcomes a tired traveler in order to make him\her full of strength and energy, filled with emotions and impressions. Soft beaches, perfect for lazy days, will help to renew powers. Wonderful, fascinating undersea, where you can see colorful fish and corals, will fill with emotions. Numerous night clubs will recharge energy. And the starry night sky of the desert will make all your dreams come true. Just make a wish when a sky traveler will be falling down the dark sky.

Dahab is an amazing city. It was able to somehow miraculously unite and make two absolutely opposite categories of holidaymakers fall in love with itself — those who like quiet and even secluded rest, and those who prefer active leisure. Clean water, comfortable beaches, unhurried walks along the promenade, hotels that provide excellent service, attract tourists from the first category. And at the same time, Dahab aspires to numerous fans of windsurfing, diving, and kitesurfing. Nature has created the most suitable conditions for them here. Another undeniable advantage of Dahab, granted by Mother Nature, is the refreshing breeze that makes the heat here not so suffocating. Dahab is considered to be one of the best resorts in Egypt, and it is a must-visit place.

Alexandria is the second-largest Egyptian city on the Mediterranean coast, with an incredibly rich history. It is a rather green metropolis by the standards of the country of pharaohs, with parks, fresh lawns, and palms. It's a mix of cultures of Christians, Muslims, and ancient Greeks. The Nile canal, which runs in the west and north of the city, serves as a kind of a border of Alexandria.

long_description.en:
Alexandria is home to over five million people, and the population increases by about 2% every year.

The majority of the inhabitants are Sunni Muslims, but there are also Palestinians, Lebanese, Syrians, Libyans, Sudanese, Copts, Greeks, Persians, Russians, Armenians, Italians, Englishmen, Frenchmen, and Jews.

description.en: Ancient Luxor located on the banks of the Nile, almost in the center of Egypt. Cairo is 500 km away, and Hurghada - 200 km. This state, with a centuries-old history, has a lot of unique monuments of different epochs, but Luxor and its surroundings can boast of an incredible amount of them. Palaces, temples, tombs of pharaohs, their wives, and noblemen, magnificent murals, and splendid monuments… All these thousands of years old sights can be found here! Luxor is a real treasure for people who are interested in history.

long_description.en:
Luxor has a tropical, dry, desert climate. Besides, the daily range of temperature here is higher than in Cairo. Usually, the difference between day and night temperatures is 17-18 °C, regardless of the season.

Daytime temperature from April till October exceeds +35 °С, and in June-August — often higher than 40 °C. The best time to visit those places is from November to March when the daytime temperature is +23-28 °C. But you should bear in mind that nights are cold in this period — +6-12 °C. During particular years, weather can be even freezing in January and February. As a compromise between hot afternoons and chilly nights, the end of March and April can be a good time to come to Luxor.

On November 4, City Day is celebrated in Luxor. Concerts and other events take place the whole week.

Two-four weeks before Ramadan, Mawlid, a religious holiday celebrating the birth of the protector of the city — Yusuf Abu el Haggag, is held in Luxor. The festivities are rather vivid; they include processions, horse races, stick-fighting events.

description.en: Nairobi is not only the capital of Kenya but also the largest city in Eastern Africa. It doesn’t have access to the ocean, that is why the majority of tourists come here for exciting tours to the main attraction — Nairobi National Park. It is located 7 km from the center. Despite local slums are recognized as the largest and the poorest in the continent, there are a lot of respectable and rich neighborhoods in the city. There are enough places to stay — many comfortable hotels, including 5 star hotels, are ready to accommodate tourists. The majority of them are targeted at safari fans. It can be proved even by the titles — Safari Club, Safari Park & Casino.

long_description.en:
The site of Nairobi was originally part of a swamp. The Maasai tribe lived in the area. They were engaged in cattle breeding and agriculture. Everything changed in the second part of the 19th century when Eastern Africa became a British colony. In 1896, the railway construction began. It was aimed to connect Mombasa with Kisumu, passing the area of Lake Victoria. The railway should have contributed to the development of trade in the region and to protection of the settlements built by the British. As a result, the surrounding lands were taken from Maasai and assigned to European farmers for use.

A small village founded by the railway workers for their needs began to develop. Colonists found this settlement rather comfortable — a lot of small rivers that flew nearby were used as a supply of clean and cool water. Besides, there were no malaria cases in the area. The settlement is located at the height of 1661 m above sea level, and mosquitos that transmitted the virus couldn’t survive in such a chilly climate. The city got the name Nairobi. A watering place for kettle was nearby, and Maasai called it Ewaso Nyirobi (cool water area).

At the beginning of the 20th century, an outbreak of plague happened in Eastern Africa. As a result, Nairobi had to be burned up, but the city was quickly rebuilt, and its area increased by several times. Trade development led to Nairobi replacing Mombasa as the capital. And in 1919, the city was declared to be a municipality.

Thereafter Nairobi has been a popular tourist destination. It grew in size from year to year, gradually shaping a modern look. In 1963, Great Britain granted independence to the country. Nairobi preserved the status of the capital and continued to develop within the new state — the Republic of Kenya.

description.en: Marrakech is one of the four historical capitals of Morocco. The name of the city can be translated from the Berber as "Land of the Gods." Like most cities in Morocco, Marrakech has its own color: both old and new buildings are traditionally painted in a reddish color. People, who take appropriate measures to improve their knowledge about the city and entire country, note that Marrakech is the cleanest and most civilized city in the country. Here you can feel the spirit of the East and take advantage of modern technologies at the same time. The uniqueness of the city was highlighted by the legendary couturier Yves Saint Laurent, who admitted that it was in Marrakech that he was visited by the muse. This is not surprising, as the city captivates with bright colors, cultural heritage, and interesting traditions.

Because of its rich history, Tangier attracts with its architecture, culture, and cuisine. It is washed by the Mediterranean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean. At different times the city belonged to different states. And it made its impact. Arabic mosques stand side by side with churches and synagogues, and original Moroccan cuisine is combined with European and international. Many locals don’t imagine their life without the sea and devote their life to it. And guests of the city after chatting over a cup of peppermint tea can’t help falling in love with them — sincere, kind, and real. Tangier attracted creative people — musicians, writers, artists, as well as risk takers — travelers, contrabandists, and spies. And it remains so till nowadays.

long_description.en:
Tangier began its history in the V B.C. That was when colonists from Carthage settled in the Phoenician settlement. According to the most popular version, its name came from the name of the Berber deity Tinjis (Tinga). Over the centuries, the city was conquered by the Romans, the Vandals, the Greeks, and the Arabs. In 1471, the Portuguese settled here, and in 1580 — the Spaniards. The Portuguese-Spanish rule lasted until 1661 when the city became the dowry of the Portuguese Infanta Catherine of Braganza, who married the English King Charles II. Tangier passed into British hands.

The next milestone in the city's history is the period of 1679, when the Sultan of Morocco, Moulay Ismail Ibn Sharif, tried to seize the territory by storm. Tangier was under siege for a long time. As a result, the British surrendered in 1684, but they had destroyed both the port and the city before that.

The so-called Tangier Crisis began at the beginning of the XX century (1905-1906). Its essence was that France and Germany argued about who would control the Sultanate of Morocco. At the same time, German Kaiser Wilhelm II came to Tangier and offered the Sultan a defensive alliance. The French were not going to back down and even offered the Germans financial compensation for Morocco, but all offers were rejected. The question of establishing a French protectorate in the territory was postponed for five years. Then, in May 1911, the Second Moroccan Crisis began when the French seized the Moroccan capital, Fez. These events resulted in the division of Morocco into French and Spanish protectorates. And in 1923, Tangier was recognized as an international zone (passed to joint ownership) under the rule of representatives of France, Spain, and Great Britain. In 1928, Italy, Portugal, and Belgium joined them. The city had been in this status for 44 years. It did not come under Moroccan rule until 1956, when decolonization took place.

During World War II, Tangier gained fame as a spy city. Many cultural figures of the early and middle of the XX century rested and stayed here — Orwell, Delacroix, Matisse, Burroughs, Ginsberg, Kerouac, and others. The international status of Tangier allowed even political criminals to get temporary asylum here.

Today the city is a popular tourist center with a developed beach infrastructure and beautiful streets. It is convenient to get here from Europe. Despite Islam, it is very common to see women without hats traveling alone. And the locals are so used to the numerous guests that they do not even make remarks to them.

description.en: The mysterious and beautiful city of Casablanca is located off the Atlantic coast, on the northern edge of hot Africa. It is known as the site of the iconic meeting of Roosevelt and Churchill, which played a crucial role in world history. All the tracks and paths seem to be coming together in Casablanca. Morocco's most modern, Europeanized megapolis, delights with its colorful, perfect combination of sightseeing and beach holidays against the background of exotic panoramas. Fresh orange juices are served here at every step and have a special taste. Palm alleys always lead to beaches from anywhere in the city. Only in Casablanca, Moorish buildings, and wide French boulevards live in one limited space. Lovers of unforgettable sensations will definitely appreciate this paradise of our planet! The Oscar-worthy movie of the same name has been attracting tourists from all over the world for over fifty years!

long_description.en:
The city is the largest in Africa after Cairo. It is home to over three million people. Among them, Arabs and Berber nationalities are represented in approximately equal parts. Far fewer people are from other ethnic groups, such as French, Spanish, Portuguese, and Jews. All of them have settled here because of historical events and the proximity of the geographical location to those countries.

The people living in Casablanca are very hospitable, there are no radical Islamists here, and the level of religiosity is moderate enough. The locals treat tourists with great respect and esteem, always glad to help the guests of Casablanca.

description.en: The oldest Imperial city of Morocco, Fez, fascinates from the first minute. Here, unique ancient monuments stand side by side with fashionable hotels and restaurants. People come here to see the oldest in the world Medina, which includes more than 800 mosques. Each of them is a work of art. Also, tourists are interested to meet the masters of their craft — leathercrafters, who still cure animal skin by hand. You should also try traditional Moroccan tagine. Where else would you see such sunny and rocky landscapes? Several episodes of cult Brazilian TV-series The Clone, which was recognized as the best export TV Novel and shown in 90 countries of the world, were filmed here. In other words, if you want to have your vacation in style, you should go to Fez.

This beautiful and welcoming city at the foot of the Atlas Mountains attracts tourists with its ancient Moorish architecture, wide avenues, and fresh green parks. Here, every street is saturated with the spirit of oriental unhurried tales and colorful traditions, and interesting sights are found literally at every step. Rabat is impossible to explore and understand in one trip, but the bewitching atmosphere of the city and its alluring secrets make you come back here again and again.

long_description.en:
The first settlement on the site of Rabat was called Chella and was built in the III century BC on the banks of the river Bou Regreg. Its inhabitants traded with Carthage until its defeat by the troops of the Roman Empire. In 40, the Romans captured Shella and gave it a new name - Sala Colonia. Around 250, it was occupied by Berbers, and the next major change was not until 1146, when Abd al-Mu'min, founder of the Almohad dynasty, conquered the coast. He turned the city into a veritable fortress, from which the troops of this militant caliph made raids on Andalusia.

The first reference to the city's modern name is found in the chronicles of 1170. In Arabic, it sounded like "Ribat Al Fath," which means "victorious."

At the end of the XII century, the capital of the expanding Almohad state was moved from Marrakesh to Rabat. The Caliph's grandson, Yacoub al-Mansour, erected the fortress of Kasbah of the Udayas in the city and began constructing the mosque to become the largest in the world. After the ruler's death, construction work stopped, but the building still rises to this day, albeit in an unfinished form.

During the Marinid dynasty, Rabat fell into decline. Only about 100 houses remained, and the capital was moved to Fez. In the XVII century, many Moorish Christian Moriscos, expelled from Spain, settled in the city, after which the Berber pirates settled there for a long time and created their own Republic of Bou Regreg. In 1818 it was defeated by the Austrian navy.

In 1912, France took Morocco under its protectorate and returned Rabat as the capital, building several military bases on the coast. After World War II, they were occupied by American troops, leaving the country only after the independence of Morocco in 1956.

Modern Rabat forms the metropolitan agglomeration with the city of Salé, which is separated from it by the Bou Régreg River.

description.en: Windhoek is the capital of a young African country, Namibia, located in the heart of the country. Although it is a small city according to world standards, its scale is equal to a metropolis for an African desert country. Mount Eros, rising above the town, the vegetation of the African south, and the proximity of the Namib Desert make the capital particularly exotic. Here you can find corners of wild nature, learn the identity of a low-populated country with a measured way of life, and at the same time, see the essential attributes of a modern city. The German samples of roads, purity, and order since colonization are combined with the most typical flavor of the African continent. Although civilization has come here relatively recently, the tourism industry and all infrastructure are developing rapidly. The opportunity to experience South African exotics in comfort attracts travelers from all over the world to Windhoek.

Zanzibar City is the capital of the island of the same name in Tanzania. The landscapes of the African coast, like from the best advertising postcards, made this place a famous resort. Tourists are welcomed here with a high level of service, security, and historical sights. But the main reason why people come here to have a rest is wide beaches with snow-white sand, blue waters of warm Indian Ocean, and serenity that reigns around. There are magnificent beaches located close to the capital — for example, the quiet and secluded beach of Bububu. There is also the popular beach of the disappearing island of Nakupenda, with crystal water. It appears only at low tide in the morning. Stone Town is a world-famous landmark in Zanzibar. It is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Unique monuments of antiquity have been preserved on its territory, and it is here that the famous musician Freddy Mercury was born. Now, the house where he lived turned into the Mercury House Hotel, and the apartment of the renowned musician is rented out just like the other rooms.

It’s about the molding lace, ligature of the ancient mosaics, colorful ceramics, and unpolished stones. The air gets heated by the sun to such an extent that you can feel it. And the sky is so blue that it seems voluminous. And the smells are mind-blowing — sweet, tempting, awakening the desire to try, compare, and remember. You can hear muezzins' calls and the ringing of bells of an Orthodox church. Tunis is a special city that can be called the crossroads of two cultures, Eastern and Western. They met here but, as an exception, didn’t start to have arguments but became friends, interfused, and got such a successful symbiosis that Tunis cannot be forgotten. It will come into your dreams and return to your holiday plans to welcome and impress again.

long_description.en:
Citizens of Tunis consider themselves Arabs, but they emphasize their identity in every way. They even speak a special dialect of Arabic called Darja. Genetic studies have shown that most of them are descendants of the original inhabitants of Africa, the Berbers. But the subsequent waves of conquests and migrations have mixed the blood of Tunisians so intricately that it contains the heritage of Greeks, Romans, Spaniards, Turks, Slavs, and the French.

As a result, the modern resident of Tunisia is quite cosmopolitan, and the city itself is always welcoming to tourists and open to migrants. The French diaspora is the most numerous here. Many Russians came here in the 1920s, fleeing from the Bolsheviks, and there is a big Jewish community. As for the gender division, the number of women and men in Tunisia is about the same.

description.en: Hammamet is a quiet upmarket resort in Tunisia, washed by the Mediterranean Sea. It attracts tourists from all over the world by its ancient architecture, magnificent nature, and the best centers of thalassotherapy. Hollywood celebrities, millionaires, politicians, singers, and actors come here to improve their health and get harmony back to their lives. Vacation in Hammamet is about the unhurried flow of time, allowing you to learn the culture and traditions of Tunisia, and also European level service.

The pure white mosques domes, harmonious minarets tending to the sky, an ancient ribat fortification, reflecting many enemy attacks in its lifetime and a noisy, many-voiced Medina — all this awaits travelers in Monastir. There are also the gentle sea and yachts, kilometers of sandy beaches, and the laughter of vacationers, wide modern avenues, and an international airport that receives and sends many flights daily. Monastir is both ancient and modern, organically combining the past and the present, able to give an unforgettable vacation and patiently waiting for new meetings.

You may sometimes feel like abandoning everything and going to the ends of the earth. Choose Cape Town, a city at the very edge of the African continent facing two oceans at once - the Atlantic Ocean and the Indian Ocean. Cape Town is one of the most beautiful cities of the world, which is over 500 years old. The magnificent ancient architecture of the times of the Dutch, French, and English conquerors still remains here, and the city is crowned with an awesome Table Mountain of the National Park. The mountain offers a 360-degree panorama. It takes your breath away to see a huge modern city backed by the entire African continent at your feet and the endless ocean and distant Antarctica on the horizon. It is a mirage city, a city of slums and luxury villas. This southernmost city of Africa has joined the culture and traditions of different civilizations, local tribes, and European countries together like a melting pot. Now it is a city of museums and art galleries, restaurants and night clubs, beach vacation and diving facilities. For nature enthusiasts, Cape Town is the Garden of Eden, with thousands of plants from all over South Africa growing in its national parks.

long_description.en:
Cape Town is a multinational city. At the beginning of its history, only white-skinned immigrants lived here, the descendants of these European colonists are referred to as the Afrikaners. They represent only one-fifth of the population. Almost half the city's population are so-called "people of color", a people that was formed as a result of a mixture of Asians, Europeans, and dark-skinned indigenous population. Their native language is Afrikaans, which is, in fact, a Dutch dialect.

One-third of the city's population (the poorest social groups) is represented by African Americans who moved to Cape Town from the north of the country in search of a better life.

Cape Town is also a home for quite a large community of Cape Malay Muslims, the descendants of slaves who were once brought to the city.

description.en: Durban is a coastal city in the province of KwaZulu-Natal in the east of the Republic of South Africa. The modern resort attracts tourists not only by eternal summer and endless golden beaches, but also by its unique culture, a variety of landscapes, and historical places. Local fashionable hotels are accompanied by old buildings; huge shopping centers get along with traditional city markets; exoticism perfectly coexists with well-known modernity. In Durban, you can get acquainted with the amazing underwater world while diving. Besides, you have the opportunity to get a little closer to modern art and plunge into the atmosphere of Indian, African, and European cultures. Filled with the smell of spices and the noise of the Indian Ocean, summer always reigns here.

long_description.en:
About 100,000 years ago, small communities of hunters and gatherers belonging to the Khoisan people lived in the vicinity of present-day Durban. Archaeological finds have made this known. At the beginning of the second millennium AD, Bantu tribes migrating from the north replaced them. Shortly before the Catholic Christmas of 1497, a Portuguese expedition led by Vasco da Gama visited the land. The travelers were looking for a sea route from Europe to India. He named the area Natal, which means "Christmas."

In 1824, several Englishmen under the command of Lieutenant Francis Farewell established a camp in the north of Natal Bay. At first, relations between the settlers and the Zulu tribes were strained, to say the least. But Henry Fynn (Farewell's companion) soon befriended the Zulu chief, curing him of his battle wounds. In gratitude, he gave Fynn a plot of land.

In 1835, the foundation of the city was officially proclaimed, and it was named Durban in honor of Benjamin D'Urban, governor of the British colonies of South Africa.

description.en: Pretoria is the administrative capital of South Africa, located in the north-east of the country, in a valley protected from the winds by the Magaliesberg mountains. Pretoria has always been a metropolitan city that has seen a lot in its lifetime — bloody military conflicts and inspirational speeches. Founded by Europeans, the city has incorporated the traditions of the people of two continents, which can be clearly seen in its architectural appearance and lifestyle of the local population.

long_description.en:
Pretoria is home to about 2.5 million people. Of these, 53% are white, 42% are African, 3% are mestizo, and 2% are Asian. It has the highest number of white residents on the continent.

The main languages spoken in the capital are Afrikaans, Sepedi, Sesotho, Setswana, Xitsonga, and English.

description.en: Joburg, Jozi, Jo'Burg are the names of the largest city in South Africa, known to the world as Johannesburg. It is located at an altitude of 1753 m above sea level in the Witwatersrand mountain range. Its lands were inhabited about 200 years ago by miners who came here in search of real gold. Becoming a metropolis of the New York City type, Johannesburg rapidly became a major South African business center. A fierce fight against racial discrimination led to the imprisonment of national hero Nelson Mandela and Indian ideologist Mahatma Gandhi in a local prison. There were no winners or losers in this racial duel. Now Jozi can be compared to the symbol of Yin and Yang, where blacks and whites simply switched places and comfortably continue to exist within the city.

long_description.en:
In total, 5 635 127 people are living in the city. Only in the last ten years, the number has increased by more than 1 million inhabitants. The most common racial groups are black — 76%, white — only 12%, Asians — 5%. The remaining 8% are of other nationalities. About one-third of the population speaks Nguni, 25% Sotho, and only 18% — English.

The unemployment rate in the city is as high as 37%, and most of the residents are illiterate.
